sn.def: To plunder; to pillage completely.
sn.q: Their vow is made To ransack Troy.

sn.def: To violate; to ravish; to defiour.
sn.q: Rich spoil of ransacked chastity.

entry.def: To make a thorough search.
entry.q: To ransack in the tas [heap] of bodies dead.

entry.def: The act of ransacking, or state of being ransacked; pillage.
entry.q: Even your father's house Shall not be free from ransack.

cs.cd: a war contract, valid by the law of nations, for the ransom of property captured at sea and its safe conduct into port.

entry.ety: OE. raunson raunsoun, OF. rançon raençon raançon, F. rançon, fr. L. redemptio, fr. redimere to redeem. See Redeem, and cf. Redemption

sn.def: The release of a captive, or of captured property, by payment of a consideration; redemption; as, prisoners hopeless of ransom .
The money or price paid for the redemption of a prisoner, or for goods captured by an enemy; payment for freedom from restraint, penalty, or forfeit.
sn.q: Thy ransom paid, which man from death redeems.
His captivity in Austria, and the heavy ransom he paid for his liberty.

sn.def: A sum paid for the pardon of some great offense and the discharge of the offender; also, a fine paid in lieu of corporal punishment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ransomed -sŭmd; p. pr. & vb. n. Ransoming
entry.ety: Cf. F. rançonner. See Ransom n.

sn.def: To redeem from captivity, servitude, punishment, or forfeit, by paying a price; to buy out of servitude or penalty; to rescue; to deliver; as, to ransom prisoners from an enemy.
To exact a ransom for, or a payment on.
sn.q: Such lands as he had rule of he ransomed them so grievously, and would tax the men two or three times in a year.

entry.def: Such as can be ransomed.
One who ransoms or redeems.
Incapable of being ransomed; without ransom.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ranted; p. pr. & vb. n. Ranting
entry.ety: OD. ranten randen, to dote, to be enraged
entry.def: To rave in violent, high-sounding, or extravagant language, without dignity of thought; to be noisy, boisterous, and bombastic in talk or declamation; as, a ranting preacher.
entry.q: Look where my ranting host of the Garter comes!

entry.def: High-sounding language, without importance or dignity of thought; boisterous, empty declamation; bombast; as, the rant of fanatics.
entry.q: This is a stoical rant, without any foundation in the nature of man or reason of things.

sn.def: A noisy talker; a raving declaimer.

sd.def: One of a religious sect which sprung up in 1645; -- called also Seekers. See Seeker.
One of the Primitive Methodists, who seceded from the Wesleyan Methodists on the ground of their deficiency in fervor and zeal; -- so called in contempt.

entry.def: The practice or tenets of the Ranters.
In a ranting manner.

entry.ety: Ranty + pole poll, head
entry.def: A wild, romping young person.
Wild; roving; rakish.
To act like a rantipole.
entry.q: She used to rantipole about the house.

entry.def: Ranterism.
Wild; noisy; boisterous.

entry.ety: L., a little frog, a little swelling on the tongue of cattle, dim. of rana a frog
entry.def: A cyst formed under the tongue by obstruction of the duct of the submaxillary gland.

entry.ety: See Ranunculus
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants (Ranunculaceæ), of which the buttercup is the type, and which includes also the virgin's bower, the monkshood, larkspur, anemone, meadow rue, and peony.

entries.entry: Ra*nun"cu*lus rȧ*nŭṉ"k�*lŭs n.; pl. E. Ranunculuses rȧ*nŭṉ"k�*lŭs*ĕz, L. Ranunculi -lī. L., a little frog, a medicinal plant, perhaps crowfoot, dim. of rana a frog; cf. raccare to roar Bot A genus of herbs, mostly with yellow flowers, including crowfoot, buttercups, and the cultivated ranunculi (Ranunculus Asiaticus Ranunculus aconitifolius, etc.) in which the flowers are double and of various colors.

‖Ranz" des` vaches" räNs" d�` vȧsh". F., the ranks or rows of cows, the name being given from the fact that the cattle, when answering the musical call of their keeper, move towards him in a row, preceded by those wearing bells The name for numerous simple, but very irregular, melodies of the Swiss mountaineers, blown on a long tube called the Alpine horn, and sometimes sung.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: A lay or skein containing 120 yards of yarn.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rapped răpt; p. pr. & vb. n. Rapping
entry.ety: Akin to Sw. rappa to strike, rapp stroke, Dan. rap, perhaps of imitative origin
entry.def: To strike with a quick, sharp blow; to knock; as, to rap on the door.

sn.def: To strike with a quick blow; to knock on.
sn.q: With one great peal they rap the door.

sn.def: To free (a pattern) in a mold by light blows on the pattern, so as to facilitate its removal.

entry.def: A quick, smart blow; a knock.

entry.cs:
To rap and ren To rap and rend . Perhaps fr. Icel. hrapa to hurry and ræna plunder, fr. rān plunder, E. ran
To seize and plunder; to snatch by violence. Dryden. “[Ye] waste all that ye may rape and renne.” Chaucer. All they could rap and rend and pilfer. Hudibras. To rap out to utter with sudden violence, as an oath. A judge who rapped out a great oath. Addison.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rapped răpt, usually written Rapt; p. pr. & vb. n. Rapping
entry.ety: OE. rapen; akin to LG. & D. rapen to snatch, G. raffen, Sw. rappa; cf. Dan. rappe sig to make haste, and Icel. hrapa to fall, to rush, hurry. The word has been confused with L. rapere to seize. Cf. Rape robbery, Rapture Raff v. Ramp v.

sn.def: To snatch away; to seize and hurry off.
sn.q: And through the Greeks and Ilians they rapt The whirring chariot.
From Oxford I was rapt by my nephew, Sir Edmund Bacon, to Redgrove.

sn.def: To hasten.
To seize and bear away, as the mind or thoughts; to transport out of one's self; to affect with ecstasy or rapture; as, rapt into admiration.
sn.q: I'm rapt with joy to see my Marcia's tears.
Rapt into future times, the bard begun.

sn.def: To exchange; to truck.
To engage in a discussion, converse.
to perform a type of rhythmic talking, often with accompanying rhythm instruments. It is considered by some as a type of music; see rap music.

cs.cd: to care nothing.
worth nothing.

entry.ety: Perhaps contr. fr. raparee
entry.def: A popular name for any of the tokens that passed current for a half-penny in Ireland in the early part of the eighteenth century; any coin of trifling value.
entry.q: Many counterfeits passed about under the name of raps.
Tie it [her money] up so tight that you can't touch a rap, save with her consent.

sn.def: conversation; also, rapping.
a type of rhythmic talking, often with accompanying rhythm instruments; rap music.

entry.ety: NL. See Rapacious
entry.def: Same as Accipitres.

entry.ety: L. rapax -acis, from rapere to seize and carry off, to snatch away. See Rapid

sn.def: Given to plunder; disposed or accustomed to seize by violence; seizing by force.
sn.q: The downfall of therapaciousand licentious Knights Templar.

sn.def: Accustomed to seize food; subsisting on prey, or animals seized by violence; as, a tiger is a rapacious animal; a rapacious bird.
Avaricious; grasping; extortionate; also, greedy; ravenous; voracious; as, rapacious usurers; a rapacious appetite.
sn.q: Thy Lord] redeem thee quite from Death's rapacious claim
sn.syn: Greedy; grasping; ravenous; voracious.

entry.ety: L. rapacitas: cf. F. rapacité. See Rapacious

sn.def: The quality of being rapacious; rapaciousness; ravenousness; as, the rapacity of pirates; the rapacity of wolves.
The act or practice of extorting or exacting by oppressive injustice; exorbitant greediness of gain.
sn.q: Therapacityof some ages.

entry.def: See Rapparee.

cs.cd: a poor, thin wine made from the last dregs of pressed grapes.

entry.ety: F. râpe a grape stalk

sn.def: Fruit, as grapes, plucked from the cluster.
The refuse stems and skins of grapes or raisins from which the must has been expressed in wine making.
A filter containing the above refuse, used in clarifying and perfecting malt, vinegar, etc.

entry.ety: Akin to rap to snatch, but confused with L. rapere. See Rap to snatch

sn.def: The act of seizing and carrying away by force; violent seizure; robbery.
sn.q: And ruined orphans of thy rapes complain.

sn.def: Sexual connection with a woman without her consent. See Age of consent, under Consent n.
That which is snatched away.
sn.q: Where now are all my hopes? O, never more Shall they revive! nor death her rapes restore.

sn.def: Movement, as in snatching; haste; hurry.
An action causing results harmful to a person or thing; as, the rape of the land by mining companies.

entry.cs: To rape and ren. See under Rap v. t., to snatch.

sn.def: To commit rape upon; to ravish.
To perform an action causing results harmful or very unpleasant to a person or thing; as, women raped first by their assailants, and then by the Justice system. Corresponds to 2nd rape n. 5.

entry.def: To rob; to pillage.

entry.ety: Icel. hreppr village, district; cf. Icel. hreppa to catch, obtain, AS. hrepian hreppan, to touch
entry.def: One of six divisions of the county of Sussex, England, intermediate between a hundred and a shire.

entry.note: ☞ These plants, with the edible turnip, have been variously named, but are all now believed to be derived from the Brassica campestris of Europe, which by some is not considered distinct from the wild stock (Brassica oleracea) of the cabbage. See Cole.
entry.cs: Broom rape. Bot See Broom rape, in the Vocabulary. Rape cake the refuse remaining after the oil has been expressed from the rape seed. Rape root. Same as Rape. Summer rape. Bot See Colza.
entry.ety: L. rapa rapum, akin to Gr. "ra`pys "ra`fys, G. rübe
entry.def: A name given to a variety or to varieties of a plant of the turnip kind, grown for seeds and herbage. The seeds are used for the production of rape oil, and to a limited extent for the food of cage birds.

sn.def: Violent.
Given to the commission of rape.

entry.def: Violently.
Like Raphael's works; in Raphael's manner of painting.
The principles of painting introduced by Raphael, the Italian painter.
One who advocates or adopts the principles of Raphaelism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. raphanie
entry.def: A convulsive disease, attended with ravenous hunger, not uncommon in Sweden and Germany. It was so called because supposed to be caused by eating corn with which seeds of jointed charlock (Raphanus raphanistrum) had been mixed, but the condition is now known to be a form of ergotism.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "rafh` a seam or suture, fr. "ra`ptein to sew or stitch together

sn.def: A line, ridge, furrow, or band of fibers, especially in the median line; as, the raphe of the tongue.
Same as Rhaphe.

entry.ety: F. raphide
entry.def: See Rhaphides.

entry.ety: L. rapidus, fr. rapere to seize and carry off, to snatch or hurry away; perhaps akin to Gr. 'arpa`zein: cf. F. rapide. Cf. Harpy Ravish

sn.def: Very swift or quick; moving with celerity; fast; as, a rapid stream; a rapid flight; a rapid motion.
sn.q: Ascend my chariot; guide the rapid wheels.

sn.def: Advancing with haste or speed; speedy in progression; in quick sequence; as, rapid growth; rapid improvement; rapid recurrence; rapid succession.
Quick in execution; as, a rapid penman.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rapide. See Rapid a.
entry.def: The part of a river where the current moves with great swiftness, but without actual waterfall or cascade; sometimes called whitewater; -- usually used in the plural; as, the Lachine rapids in the St. Lawrence.
entry.q: Row, brothers, row, the stream runs fast, The rapids are near, and the daylight's past.

entries.entry:
Rap"id-fire` Rap"id-fir`ing
a. Gun Firing shots in rapid succession. Ordnance Capable of being fired rapidly; -- applied to single-barreled guns of greater caliber than small arms, mounted so as to be quickly trained and elevated, with a quick-acting breech mechanism operated by a single motion of a crank or lever (abbr. R. F.); specif.:1In the United States navy, designating such a gun using fixed ammunition or metallic cartridge cases; -- distinguished from breech-loadingabbr. B. L.), applied to all guns loading with the charge in bags, and formerly from quick-fire. Rapid-fire guns in the navy also sometimes include automatic or semiautomatic rapid-fire guns; the former being automatic guns of not less than one inch caliber, firing a shell of not less than one pound weight, the explosion of each cartridge operating the mechanism for ejecting the empty shell, loading, and firing the next shot, the latter being guns that require one operation of the hand at each discharge, to load the gun.2In the United States army, designating such a gun, whether using fixed or separate ammunition, designed chiefly for use in coast batteries against torpedo vessels and the lightly armored batteries or other war vessels and for the protection of defensive mine fields; -- not distinguished from quick-fire.3In Great Britain and Europe used, rarely, as synonymous with quick-fire.
Rapid-fire mount. Ordnance A mount permitting easy and quick elevation or depression and training of the gun, and fitted with a device for taking up the recoil.

entry.ety: L. rapiditas: cf. F. rapidité
entry.def: The quality or state of being rapid; swiftness; celerity; velocity; as, the rapidity of a current; rapidity of speech; rapidity of growth or improvement.
entry.syn: Rapidness; haste; speed; celerity; velocity; swiftness; fleetness; quickness; agility.

entry.def: In a rapid manner.
Quality of being rapid; rapidity.

cs.cd: the swordfish.

entry.ety: F. rapière, perhaps for raspière, and ultimately of German origin, akin to E. rasp, v
entry.def: A straight sword, with a narrow and finely pointed blade, used only for thrusting.
Wearing a rapier.
entry.q: Scarletcoated,rapieredfigures.

entry.ety: It
entry.def: Lapilli.

entry.ety: F. rapine; cf. Pr. & It. rapina; all fr. L. rapina, fr. rapere to seize and carry off by force. See Rapid, and cf. Raven rapine

sn.def: The act of plundering; the seizing and carrying away of things by force; spoliation; pillage; plunder.
sn.q: Men who were impelled to war quite as much by the desire of rapine as by the desire of glory.

sn.def: Ravishment; rape.

entry.def: To plunder.
Given to rapine.
a type of rhythmic talking, often with accompanying rhythm instruments; same as 7th rap n..
The enlargement of a mold caused by rapping the pattern.
A wild Irish plunderer, esp. one of the 17th century; -- so called from his carrying a half-pike, called a rapary.
imp. & p. p. of Rap, to strike.
imp. & p. p. of Rap, to snatch away.

entry.ety: F. râpé, fr. râper to grate, to rasp. See Rasp v.
entry.def: A pungent kind of snuff made from the darker and ranker kinds of tobacco leaves.

entry.ety: F. Cf. Repeal
entry.def: The beat of the drum to call soldiers to arms.

entry.ety: From Rap

sn.def: One who, or that which, raps or knocks; specifically, the knocker of a door.
A forcible oath or lie.
A musician specializing in rap music.

cs.cd: in accord, harmony, or sympathy; having a mutual, especially a private, understanding; in mesmerism, in that relation of sympathy which permits influence or communication.

entry.ety: F., fr. rapporter to bring again or back, to refer; pref. re- re- + apporter to bring, L. apportare. Cf. Report
entry.def: Relation; proportion; conformity; correspondence; accord.
entry.q: 'T is obvious what rapport there is between the conceptions and languages in every country.

entry.ety: F., fr. rapprocher to cause to approach again. See Re-; Approach
entry.def: Act or fact of coming or being drawn near or together; establishment or state of cordial relations.
entry.q: He had witnessed the gradual rapprochement between the papacy and Austria.

entry.ety: See Rascallion
entry.def: A rascal; a good-for-nothing fellow.
imp. & p. p. of Rap, to snatch away.

sn.def: Snatched away; hurried away or along.
sn.q: Waters rapt with whirling away.

sn.def: Transported with love, admiration, delight, etc.; enraptured.
sn.q: Theraptmusician.

sn.def: Wholly absorbed or engrossed, as in work or meditation.
sn.q: Raptin secret studies.

entry.ety: From F. rapt abduction, rape, L. raptus, fr. rapere to seize and carry off, to transport; or fr. E. rapt, a. See Rapt a., and Rapid

sn.def: An ecstasy; a trance.
Rapidity.
To transport or ravish.
To carry away by force.

entry.def: A raptor.

entry.ety: L. raptor, from rapere to ravish. See Rapid
entry.def: A ravisher; a plunderer.

entry.ety: NL. See Raptor
entry.def: An order of birds, same as Accipitres. Called also Raptatores.
Rapacious; living upon prey; -- said especially of certain birds.
Adapted for seizing prey; -- said of the legs, claws, etc., of insects, birds, and other animals.
Of or pertaining to the Raptores. See Illust. of Aves.

entry.ety: L. raptorius
entry.def: Raptorial.

entry.ety: L. rapere raptum, to carry off by force. See Rapid

sn.def: A seizing by violence; a hurrying along; rapidity with violence.
sn.q: That 'gainst a rock, or flat, her keel did dash With headlong rapture.

sn.def: The state or condition of being rapt, or carried away from one's self by agreeable excitement; violence of a pleasing passion; extreme joy or pleasure; ecstasy.
sn.q: Music, when thus applied, raises in the mind of the hearer great conceptions; it strengthens devotion, and advances praise into rapture.
You grow correct that once with rapture writ.

sn.def: A spasm; a fit; a syncope; delirium.
sn.syn: Bliss; ecstasy; transport; delight; exultation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Raptured -t�rd; 135; p. pr. & vb. n. Rapturing
entry.def: To transport with excitement; to enrapture.
An enthusiast.
To put, or be put, in a state of rapture.
Ecstatic; transporting; ravishing; feeling, expressing, or manifesting rapture; as, rapturous joy, pleasure, or delight; rapturous applause.
In a rapturous manner.

entry.ety: Cf. Rather Rath
entry.def: Early.
entry.q: Rude mechanicals that rare and late Work in the market place.

entry.note: ☞ This word is in common use in the United States, but in England its synonym underdone is preferred.
entry.ety: Cf. AS. hrēr, or E. rare early. √18
entry.def: Nearly raw; partially cooked; not thoroughly cooked; underdone; as, rare beef or mutton.
entry.q: New-laid eggs, which Baucis' busy care Turned by a gentle fire, and roasted rare.

entry.usage: Rare Scarce. We call a thing rare when but few examples, specimens, or instances of it are ever to be met with; as, a rare plant. We speak of a thing as scarce, which, though usually abundant, is for the time being to be had only in diminished quantities; as, a bad harvest makes corn scarce .
entry.ety: F., fr. L. rarus thin, rare

sn.def: Not frequent; seldom met with or occurring; unusual; as, a rare event.
Of an uncommon nature; unusually excellent; valuable to a degree seldom found.
sn.q: Rare work, all filled with terror and delight.
Above the rest I judge one beauty rare.

sn.def: Thinly scattered; dispersed.
sn.q: Those rare and solitary, these in flocks.

sn.def: Characterized by wide separation of parts; of loose texture; not thick or dense; thin; as, a rare atmosphere at high elevations.
sn.q: Water is nineteen times lighter, and by consequence nineteen times rarer, than gold.
sn.syn: Scarce; infrequent; unusual; uncommon; singular; extraordinary; incomparable.
sn.q: A perfect union of wit and judgment is one of the rarest things in the world.
When any particular piece of money grew very scarce, it was often recoined by a succeeding emperor.

entry.def: A dainty morsel; a Welsh rabbit. See Welsh rabbit, under Rabbit.

entry.ety: Contr. fr. rarity-show
entry.def: A show carried about in a box; a peep show.

entry.ety: Cf. F. raréfaction. See Rarefy
entry.def: The act or process of rarefying; the state of being rarefied; -- opposed to condensation; as, the rarefaction of air.

entry.ety: Cf. F. raréfiable
entry.def: Capable of being rarefied.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rarefied răr"�*fīd; p. pr. & vb. n. Rarefying răr"�*fī`ĭng
entry.ety: F. raréfier; L. rarus rare + -ficarein comp.) to make; cf. L. rarefacere. See -fy
entry.def: To make rare, thin, porous, or less dense; to expand or enlarge without adding any new portion of matter to; -- opposed to condense.
To become less dense; to become thin and porous.
entry.q: Earthrarefiesto dew.

sn.def: In a rare manner or degree; seldom; not often; as, things rarely seen.
Finely; excellently; with rare skill. See 3d Rare, 2.
sn.q: The person who played so rarely on the flageolet.
The rest of the apartments are rarely gilded.

entry.def: The state or quality of being rare.
entry.q: And let the rareness the small gift commend.

entry.ety: Rare early + ripe. Cf. Rathripe
entry.def: Early ripe; ripe before others, or before the usual season.
An early ripening fruit, especially a kind of freestone peach.
See Rarefaction.

entries.entry:
Rar"i*ty răr"ĭ*t�; 277 n.; pl.Rarities răr"ĭ*tĭz. L. raritas: cf. F. rareté. See Rare
The quality or state of being rare; rareness; thinness; as, the raritycontrasted with the density) of gases.
That which is rare; an uncommon thing; a thing valued for its scarcity. I saw three rarities of different kinds, which pleased me more than any other shows in the place.

entry.def: See 2d Reis.

entry.ety: F., p. pr. of raser to graze
entry.def: Sweeping; grazing; -- applied to a style of fortification in which the command of the works over each other, and over the country, is kept very low, in order that the shot may more effectually sweep or graze the ground before them.

entry.ety: OE. rascaille rabble, probably from an OF. racaille, F. racaille the rabble, rubbish, probably akin to F. racler to scrape, (assumed) LL. rasiculare rasicare, fr. L. radere rasum. See Rase v.

sn.def: One of the rabble; a low, common sort of person or creature; collectively, the rabble; the common herd; also, a lean, ill-conditioned beast, esp. a deer.
sn.q: He smote of the people seventy men, and fifty thousand of the rascal.
Poor men alone? No, no; the noblest deer hath them [horns] as huge as the rascal.

sn.def: A mean, trickish fellow; a base, dishonest person; a rogue; a scoundrel; a trickster.
sn.q: For I have sense to serve my turn in store, And he's a rascal who pretends to more.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the common herd or common people; low; mean; base.
entry.q: Therascalmany.
Therascalpeople.
While she called me rascal fiddler.

entry.def: State of being a rascal; rascality; domain of rascals; rascals, collectively.
A female rascal.

entries.entry:
Ras*cal"i*ty răs*kăl"ĭ*t� n.; pl.Rascalities răs*kăl"ĭ*tĭz
The quality or state of being rascally, or a rascal; mean trickishness or dishonesty; base fraud.
The poorer and lower classes of people. Obs The chief heads of their clans with their several rascalities

entry.ety: From Rascal
entry.def: A low, mean wretch; a rogue; same as rascal n.. 2; now disused, replaced by rapscalion.
Like a rascal; trickish or dishonest; base; worthless; -- often in humorous disparagement, without implication of dishonesty.
entry.q: Our rascally porter is fallen fast asleep.

entry.note: ☞ This word, rase, may be considered as nearly obsolete; graze erase, and raze, having superseded it.

cs.cd: a tool for removing old oakum and pitch from the seams of a vessel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rased rāzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Rasing
entry.ety: F. raser, LL. rasare to scrape often, v. freq. fr. L. radere rasum, to scrape, shave; cf. Skr. rad to scratch, gnaw, L. rodere to gnaw. Cf. Raze Razee Razor Rodent

sn.def: To rub along the surface of; to graze.
sn.q: Was he not in the . . . neighborhood to death? and might not the bullet which rased his cheek have gone into his head?
Sometimes his feet rased the surface of the water, and at others the skylight almost flattened his nose.

sn.def: To rub or scratch out; to erase.
sn.q: Except we rase the faculty of memory, root and branch, out of our mind.

sn.def: To level with the ground; to overthrow; to destroy; to raze.
sn.q: Till Troy were by their brave hands rased, They would not turn home.
sn.syn: To erase; efface; obliterate; expunge; cancel; level; prostrate; overthrow; subvert; destroy; demolish; ruin.

entry.def: To be leveled with the ground; to fall; to suffer overthrow.

sn.def: A scratching out, or erasure.
A slight wound; a scratch.
A way of measuring in which the commodity measured was made even with the top of the measuring vessel by rasing, or striking off, all that was above it.

entry.ety: For arace

sn.def: To pull off or pluck violently.
To slash; to hack; to cut; to slice.
sn.q: Rashing off helms and riving plates asunder.

entry.cs: Canker rash. See in the Vocabulary. Nettle rash. See Urticaria. Rose rash. See Roseola. Tooth rash. See Red-gum.
entry.ety: OF. rasche an eruption, scurf, F. rache; fr. (assumed) LL. rasicare to scratch, fr. L. radere rasum, to scrape, scratch, shave. See Rase, and cf. Rascal
entry.def: A fine eruption or efflorescence on the body, with little or no elevation.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ras short-nap cloth, It. & Sp. raso satin (cf. Rase); or cf. It. rascia serge, G. rasch, probably fr. Arras in France (cf. Arras)
entry.def: An inferior kind of silk, or mixture of silk and worsted.

entry.usage: Rash Adventurous Foolhardy. A man is adventurous who incurs risk or hazard from a love of the arduous and the bold. A man is rash who does it from the mere impulse of his feelings, without counting the cost. A man is foolhardy who throws himself into danger in disregard or defiance of the consequences.
entry.ety: Probably of Scand. origin; cf. Dan. & Sw. rask quick, brisk, rash, Icel. röskr vigorous, brave, akin to D. & G. rasch quick, of uncertain origin

sn.def: Sudden in action; quick; hasty.
sn.q: Strong as aconitum orrashgunpowder.

sn.def: Requiring sudden action; pressing; urgent.
sn.q: I scarce have leisure to salute you, My matter is so rash.

sn.def: Esp., overhasty in counsel or action; precipitate; resolving or entering on a project or measure without due deliberation and caution; opposed to prudent; said of persons; as, a rash statesman or commander.
Uttered or undertaken with too much haste or too little reflection; as, rash words; rash measures.
So dry as to fall out of the ear with handling, as corn.
sn.syn: Precipitate; headlong; headstrong; foolhardy; hasty; indiscreet; heedless; thoughtless; incautious; careless; inconsiderate; unwary.
sn.q: Was never known a more adventurous knight.
Her rash hand in evil hour Forth reaching to the fruit, she plucked, she eat.
If any yet be so foolhardy To expose themselves to vain jeopardy; If they come wounded off, and lame, No honor's got by such a maim.

entry.def: To prepare with haste.

entry.ety: In sense 1, probably fr. rash, a., as being hastily cooked

sn.def: A thin slice of bacon.
A California rockfish (Sebastichthys miniatus).

entry.def: Rash; hasty; precipitate.
A rash person.
In a rash manner; with precipitation.
entry.q: He that doth anything rashly, must do it willingly; for he was free to deliberate or not.

entry.def: The quality or state of being rash.
entry.q: We offend . . . by rashness, which is an affirming or denying, before we have sufficiently informed ourselves.
entry.syn: Temerity; foolhardiness; precipitancy; precipitation; hastiness; indiscretion; heedlessness; inconsideration; carelessness. See Temerity.

entries.entry:
‖Ras*kol"nik răs*kŏl"nĭk n.; pl. Raskolniki răs*kŏl"nĭk*ē or Raskolniks # . Russ. raskol'nik dissenter, fr. raskol dissent The name applied by the Russian government to any subject of the Greek faith who dissents from the established church. The Raskolniki embrace many sects, whose common characteristic is a clinging to antique traditions, habits, and customs. The schism originated in 1667 in an ecclesiastical dispute as to the correctness of the translation of the religious books. The dissenters, who have been continually persecuted, are believed to number about 20,000,000, although the Holy Synod officially puts the number at about 2,000,000. They are officially divided into three groups according to the degree of their variance from orthodox beliefs and observances, as follows: I. “Most obnoxious.” the Judaizers; the Molokane, who refuse to recognize civil authority or to take oaths; the Dukhobortsy, or Dukhobors, who are communistic, marry without ceremony, and believe that Christ was human, but that his soul reappears at intervals in living men; the Khlysty, who countenance anthropolatory, are ascetics, practice continual self-flagellation, and reject marriage; the Skoptsy, who practice castration; and a section of the Bezpopovtsy, or priestless sect, which disbelieve in prayers for the Czar and in marriage. II. “Obnoxious:” the Bezpopovtsy, who pray for the Czar and recognize marriage. III. “Least obnoxious:” the Popovtsy, who dissent from the orthodox church in minor points only.
rascolnik

entry.note: ☞ Formerly, the word Rasores was used in a wider sense, so as to include other birds now widely separated in classification.
entry.ety: NL., fr. L. radere rasum, to scratch. See Rase v. t.
entry.def: An order of birds; the Gallinæ.
Of or pertaining to the Rasores, or gallinaceous birds, as the peacock, domestic fowl, partridge, quail, and the like.
Razor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rasped rȧspt; p. pr. & vb. n. Rasping
entry.ety: OF. rasper, F. râper, to scrape, grate, rasp, fr. OHG. raspōn to scrape together, to collect, probably akin to E. rap. Cf. Rap to snatch

sn.def: To rub or file with a rasp; to rub or grate with a rough file; as, to rasp wood to make it smooth; to rasp bones to powder.
Hence, figuratively: To grate harshly upon; to offend by coarse or rough treatment or language; as, some sounds rasp the ear; his insults rasped my temper.

cs.cd: a Brazilian palm tree (Iriartea exorhiza) which has strong aërial roots like a screw pine. The roots have a hard, rough surface, and are used by the natives for graters and rasps, whence the common name.

entry.ety: OE. raspe, OF. raspe, F. râpe. See Rasp v.

sn.def: A coarse file, on which the cutting prominences are distinct points raised by the oblique stroke of a sharp punch, instead of lines raised by a chisel, as on the true file.
The raspberry.
sn.q: Set sorrel amongstrasps, and the raspswill be the smaller.

entry.ety: LL
entry.def: See Raspatory.

entry.ety: LL. raspatorium: cf. F. raspatoir. See Rasp v.
entry.def: A surgeon's rasp.

entry.note: ☞ Technically, raspberries are those brambles in which the fruit separates readily from the core or receptacle, in this differing from the blackberries, in which the fruit is firmly attached to the receptacle.
entry.ety: From E. rasp, in allusion to the apparent roughness of the fruit
entry.def: The thimble-shaped fruit of the Rubus Idæus and other similar brambles; as, the black, the red, and the white raspberry .
The shrub bearing this fruit.
One who, or that which, rasps; a scraper.
The raspberry.
Like a rasp, or the sound made by a rasp; grating.

entry.ety: Cf. Malay rāsa taste, sensation
entry.def: A carnivore (Viverricula Mallaccensis) allied to the civet but smaller, native of China and the East Indies. It furnishes a perfume resembling that of the civet, which is highly prized by the Javanese. Called also Malacca weasel, and lesser civet.

entry.ety: L. rasura, fr. radere rasum, to scrape, to shave. See Rase v.

sn.def: The act of rasing, scraping, or erasing; erasure; obliteration.
A mark by which a letter, word, or any part of a writing or print, is erased, effaced, or obliterated; an erasure.

entry.note: ☞ “It so chanced that, not long after the accession of the house of Hanover, some of the brown, that is the German or Norway, rats, were first brought over to this country (in some timber as is said); and being much stronger than the black, or, till then, the common, rats, they in many places quite extirpated the latter. The word (both the noun and the verb to rat) was first, as we have seen, leveled at the converts to the government of George the First, but has by degrees obtained a wider meaning, and come to be applied to any sudden and mercenary change in politics.” Lord Mahon.
entry.cs:
Bamboo rat Zoöl any Indian rodent of the genus Rhizomys.
Beaver rat Coast rat . Zoöl See under Beaver and Coast. Blind rat Zoöl the mole rat. Cotton rat Zoöl a long-haired rat (Sigmodon hispidus), native of the Southern United States and Mexico. It makes its nest of cotton and is often injurious to the crop. Ground rat. See Ground Pig, under Ground. Hedgehog rat. See under Hedgehog. Kangaroo rat Zoöl the potoroo. Norway rat Zoöl the common brown rat. See Rat. Pouched rat. Zoöl See Pocket Gopher, under Pocket. Any African rodent of the genus Cricetomys. Rat Indians Ethnol a tribe of Indians dwelling near Fort Ukon, Alaska. They belong to the Athabascan stock. Rat mole. Zoöl See Mole rat, under Mole. Rat pit an inclosed space into which rats are put to be killed by a dog for sport. Rat snake Zoöl a large colubrine snake (Ptyas mucosus) very common in India and Ceylon. It enters dwellings, and destroys rats, chickens, etc. Spiny rat Zoöl any South American rodent of the genus Echinomys. To smell a rat. See under Smell. Wood rat Zoöl any American rat of the genus Neotoma, especially Neotoma Floridana, common in the Southern United States. Its feet and belly are white.
entry.ety: AS. ræt; akin to D. rat, OHG. rato ratta, G. ratte ratze, OLG. ratta, LG. & Dan. rotte, Sw. råtta, F. rat, Ir. & Gael radan, Armor. raz, of unknown origin. Cf. Raccoon

sn.def:
One of several species of small rodents of the genus Rattusformerly included in Mus) and allied genera, of the family Muridae, distinguished from mice primarily by being larger. They infest houses, stores, and ships, especially the Norway rat , also called brown rat, (Rattus norvegicus formerly Mus decumanus), the black rat
Rattus rattus formerly Mus rattus), and the roof rat formerly Mus Alexandrinus, now included in Rattus rattus). These were introduced into America from the Old World. The white rat used most commonly in laboratories is primarily a strain derived from Rattus rattus.
A round and tapering mass of hair, or similar material, used by women to support the puffs and rolls of their natural hair.
One who deserts his party or associates; hence, in the trades, one who works for lower wages than those prescribed by a trades union.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ratted; p. pr. & vb. n. Ratting

sn.def: In English politics, to desert one's party from interested motives; to forsake one's associates for one's own advantage; in the trades, to work for less wages, or on other conditions, than those established by a trades union.
sn.q: Coleridge . . . incurred the reproach of having ratted, solely by his inability to follow the friends of his early days.

sn.def: To catch or kill rats.
To be an informer (against an associate); to inform (on an associate); to squeal; -- used commonly in the phrase to rat on.

entry.ety: Maori
entry.def: A New Zealand forest tree (Metrosideros robusta), also, its hard dark red wood, used by the Maoris for paddles and war clubs.
The quality or state of being ratable.

sn.def: Capable of being rated, or set at a certain value.
sn.q: Twenty oræ were ratable to [at] two marks of silver.

sn.def: Liable to, or subjected by law to, taxation; as, ratable estate.
Made at a proportionate rate; as, ratable payments.

entry.def: a structure which may be rated, or set at a certain value, for the purpose of taxation, usually based on the value; as, with the deterioration of the center cities, the loss of ratables worsened the situation by removing valuable sources of tax revenue.

entry.ety: F., fr. Malay arak arrack + tāfīa a spirit distilled from molasses
entry.def: A spirituous liquor flavored with the kernels of cherries, apricots, peaches, or other fruit, spiced, and sweetened with sugar; -- a term applied to the liqueurs called noyau curaçao, etc.
See Rattan.
Same as Rhatany.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The iterative sound of beating a drum, or of a galloping horse.
Same as Rotche.

entry.ety: See Rack the instrument, Ratchet
entry.def: A ratchet wheel, or notched bar, with which a pawl or click works.
Gravelly stone.

cs.cd: a boring brace, having a ratchet wheel and pawl for rotating the tool by back and forth movements of the brace handle.

a portable machine for working a drill by hand, consisting of a hand lever carrying at one end a drill holder which is revolved by means of a ratchet wheel and pawl, by swinging the lever back and forth.
a circular wheel having teeth, usually angular, with which a reciprocating pawl engages to turn the wheel forward, or a stationary pawl to hold it from turning backward.

entry.note: ☞ In the cut, the moving pawl c slides over the teeth in one direction, but in returning, draws the wheel with it, while the pawl d prevents it from turning in the contrary direction.
entry.ety: Properly a diminutive from the same word as rack: cf. F. rochet. See 2d Ratch Rack the instrument

sn.def: A pawl, click, or detent, for holding or propelling a ratchet wheel, or ratch, etc.
A mechanism composed of a ratchet wheel, or ratch, and pawl. See Ratchet wheel, below, and 2d Ratch.

entry.ety: Perh. fr. E. rate, v. t., to value at a certain rate, to estimate, but more prob. fr. Sw. rata to find fault, to blame, to despise, to hold cheap; cf. Icel. hrat refuse, hrati rubbish
entry.def: To chide with vehemence; to scold; to censure violently; to berate.
entry.q: Go, rate thy minions, proud, insulting boy!
Conscience is a check to beginners in sin, reclaiming them from it, and rating them for it.

entry.ety: OF., fr. L. ratasc. pars), fr. ratus reckoned, fixed by calculation, p. p. of reri to reckon, to calculate. Cf. Reason

sn.def: Established portion or measure; fixed allowance.
sn.q: The one right feeble through the evil rate Of food which in her duress she had found.

sn.def: That which is established as a measure or criterion; degree; standard; rank; proportion; ratio; as, a slow rate of movement; rate of interest is the ratio of the interest to the principal, per annum.
sn.q: Heretofore the rate and standard of wit was different from what it is nowadays.
In this did his holiness and godliness appear above the rate and pitch of other men's, in that he was so . . . merciful.
Many of the horse could not march at that rate, nor come up soon enough.

sn.def: Valuation; price fixed with relation to a standard; cost; charge; as, high or low rates of transportation.
sn.q: They come at dear rates from Japan.

sn.def: A tax or sum assessed by authority on property for public use, according to its income or value; esp., in England, a local tax; as, parish rates; town rates.
Order; arrangement.
sn.q: Thus sat they all around in seemly rate.

sn.def: Ratification; approval.
The gain or loss of a timepiece in a unit of time; as, daily rate; hourly rate; etc.

sd.def: The order or class to which a war vessel belongs, determined according to its size, armament, etc.; as, first rate, second rate, etc.
The class of a merchant vessel for marine insurance, determined by its relative safety as a risk, as A1, A2, etc.

cs.cd: to ascertain the exact rate of its gain or loss as compared with true time, so as to make an allowance or computation dependent thereon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rated; p. pr. & vb. n. Rating

sn.def: To set a certain estimate on; to value at a certain price or degree.
sn.q: To rate a man by the nature of his companions is a rule frequent indeed, but not infallible.
You seem not high enough your joys to rate.

sn.def: To assess for the payment of a rate or tax.
To settle the relative scale, rank, position, amount, value, or quality of; as, to rate a ship; to rate a seaman; to rate a pension.
To ratify.
sn.q: Toratethe truce.
sn.syn: To value; appraise; estimate; reckon.

sn.def: To be set or considered in a class; to have rank; as, the ship rates as a ship of the line.
To make an estimate.

entry.def: See Ratable.

entry.note: ☞ Several species are known in Africa and India. The Cape ratel (Mellivora Capensis) and the Indian ratel (Mellivora Indica) are the best known. The back is gray; the lower parts, face, and tail are black. They are fond of honey, and rob the nests of wild bees.
entry.ety: F
entry.def: Any carnivore of the genus Mellivora, allied to the weasels and the skunks; -- called also honey badger.
One who pays rates or taxes.
One who rates or estimates.
One who rates or scolds.
Same as Rat-tail.

entry.ety: Ir. rath

sn.def: A hill or mound.
A kind of ancient fortification found in Ireland.

entry.ety: AS. hræð hræd, quick, akin to OHG. hrad, Icel. hraðr
entry.def: Coming before others, or before the usual time; early.
entry.q: Bring the rathe primrose that forsaken dies.

entry.def: Early; soon; betimes.
entry.q: Why rise ye up so rathe?
Too rathe cut off by practice criminal.

entry.ety: Compar. of Rath a.
entry.def: Prior; earlier; former.
entry.q: Now no man dwelleth at the rather town.

entry.cs:
The rather the more so; especially; for better reason; for particular cause. You are come to me in happy time,The rather for I have some sport in hand. Shak.
Had ratherorWould rather
prefer to; prefers to; as, he had rather, or would rather go than stay. “I had rather speak five words with my understanding than ten thousand words in an unknown tongue.” 1 Cor. xiv. 19. See Had rather, under Had.
entry.ety: AS. hraðor, compar. of hraðe hræðe, quickly, immediately. See Rath a.

sn.def: Earlier; sooner; before.
sn.q: Thou shalt, quod he, be rather false than I.
A good mean to come the rather to grace.

sn.def: More readily or willingly; preferably.
sn.q: My soul chooseth . . . death rather than my life.

sn.def: On the other hand; to the contrary of what was said or suggested; instead.
sn.q: Was nothing bettered, but rather grew worse.

sn.def: Of two alternatives conceived of, this by preference to, or as more likely than, the other; somewhat.
sn.q: He sought throughout the world, but sought in vain, And nowhere finding, rather feared her slain.

sn.def: More properly; more correctly speaking.
sn.q: This is an art Which does mend nature, change it rather, but The art itself is nature.

sn.def: In some degree; somewhat; as, the day is rather warm; the house is rather damp.

entry.def: Rareripe, or early ripe.
entry.q: Such who delight in rathripe fruits.

entry.ety: G., also ratskeller, prop., town-hall cellar
entry.def: Orig., in Germany, the cellar or basement of the city hall, usually rented for use as a restaurant where beer is sold; hence, a beer saloon of the German type below the street level, where, usually, drinks are served only at tables and simple food may also be had; -- sometimes loosely used, in English, of what are essentially basement restaurants where liquors are served.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ratification
entry.def: The act of ratifying; the state of being ratified; confirmation; sanction; as, the ratification of a treaty.
One who, or that which, ratifies; a confirmer.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ratified răt"ĭ*fīd; p. pr. & vb. n. Ratifying răt"ĭ*fī`ĭng
entry.ety: F. ratifier, fr. L. ratus fixed by calculation, firm, valid + -ficarein comp.) to make. See Rate n., and -fy
entry.def: To approve and sanction; to make valid; to confirm; to establish; to settle; especially, to give sanction to, as something done by an agent or servant; as, to ratify an agreement, treaty, or contract; to ratify a nomination.
entry.q: It is impossible for the divine power to set a seal to a lie by ratifying an imposture with such a miracle.

entry.ety: L. ratihabitio; ratus fixed, valid + habere to hold
entry.def: Confirmation or approbation, as of an act or contract.

entry.note: ☞ Some writers consider ratio as the quotient itself, making ratio equivalent to a number. The term ratio is also sometimes applied to the difference of two quantities as well as to their quotient, in which case the former is called arithmetical ratio, the latter, geometrical ratio. The name ratio is sometimes given to the rule of three in arithmetic. See under Rule.

cs.mcol: Compound ratio Duplicate ratio Inverse ratio, etc.
cs.cd: See under Compound Duplicate, etc.
the constant quantity by which each term is multiplied to produce the succeeding one.

entry.ety: L., fr. reri ratus, to reckon, believe, think, judge. See Reason

sn.def: The relation which one quantity or magnitude has to another of the same kind. It is expressed by the quotient of the division of the first by the second; thus, the ratio of 3 to 6 is expressed by 3/6 or 1/2; of a to b by a/b; or (less commonly) the second term is made the dividend; as, a:b = b/a .
Hence, fixed relation of number, quantity, or degree; rate; proportion; as, the ratio of representation in Congress.

entry.ety: L. ratiocinatus, p. p. of ratiocinari, fr. ratio reason. See Ratio
entry.def: To reason, esp. deductively; to offer reason or argument.

entry.ety: L. ratiocinatio: cf. F. ratiocination
entry.def: The process of reasoning, or deducing conclusions from premises; deductive reasoning.

entry.ety: L. ratiocinativus
entry.def: Characterized by, or addicted to, ratiocination; consisting in the comparison of propositions or facts, and the deduction of inferences from the comparison; argumentative; as, a ratiocinative process.
entry.q: The ratiocinative meditativeness of his character.

entry.def: Ratiocinative.

entry.note: ☞ Officers have several rations, the number varying according to their rank or the number of their attendants.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. ratio a reckoning, calculation, relation, reference, LL. ratio ration. See Ratio

sn.def: A fixed daily allowance of provisions assigned to a soldier in the army, or a sailor in the navy, for his subsistence.
Hence, a certain portion or fixed amount dealt out; an allowance; an allotment.

entry.def: To supply with rations, as a regiment.

entry.cs: Rational horizon. Astron See Horizon, 2 . Rational quantity Alg one that can be expressed without the use of a radical sign, or in exact parts of unity; -- opposed to irrational or radical quantity. Rational symptom Med one elicited by the statements of the patient himself and not as the result of a physical examination.
entry.usage: Rational reasonable. Rational has reference to reason as a faculty of the mind, and is opposed to irrational; as, a rational being, a rational state of mind, rational views, etc. In these cases the speculative reason is more particularly, referred to. Reasonable has reference to the exercise of this faculty for practical purposes, and means, governed or directed by reason; as, reasonable desires or plans; a reasonable charge; a reasonable prospect of success.
entry.ety: L. rationalis: cf. F. rationnel. See Ratio Reason, and cf. Rationale

sn.def: Relating to the reason; not physical; mental.
sn.q: Moral philosophy was his chiefest end; for the rational, the natural, and mathematics . . . were but simple pastimes in comparison of the other.

sn.def: Having reason, or the faculty of reasoning; endowed with reason or understanding; reasoning.
sn.q: It is our glory and happiness to have a rational nature.

sn.def: Agreeable to reason; not absurd, preposterous, extravagant, foolish, fanciful, or the like; wise; judicious; as, rational conduct; a rational man.
Expressing the type, structure, relations, and reactions of a compound; graphic; -- said of formulæ. See under Formula.
sn.syn: Sane; sound; intelligent; reasonable; sensible; wise; discreet; judicious.
sn.q: What higher in her society thou find'st Attractive, human, rational, love still.
A law may be reasonable in itself, although a man does not allow it, or does not know the reason of the lawgivers.

entry.def: A rational being.

entry.ety: L. rationalis, neut. rationale. See Rational a.
entry.def: An explanation or exposition of the principles of some opinion, action, hypothesis, phenomenon, or the like; also, the principles themselves.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rationalisme

sn.def: The doctrine or system of those who deduce their religious opinions from reason or the understanding, as distinct from, or opposed to, revelation.
The system that makes rational power the ultimate test of truth; -- opposed to sensualism, or sensationalism, and empiricism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rationaliste
entry.def: One who accepts rationalism as a theory or system; also, disparagingly, a false reasoner. See Citation under Reasonist.
Belonging to, or in accordance with, the principles of rationalism.

entries.entry:
Ra`tion*al"i*ty răsh"ŭn*ăl"ĭ*t�; 277 n.; pl.-ties -tĭz. F. rationalité, or L. rationalitas
The quality or state of being rational; agreement with reason; possession of reason; due exercise of reason; reasonableness. When God has made rationality the common portion of mankind, how came it to be thy inclosure? Well-directed intentions, whose rationalities will never bear a rigid examination.

entry.def: The act or process of rationalizing.

sn.def: To make rational; also, to convert to rationalism.
To interpret in the manner of a rationalist.
To form a rational conception of.
To render rational; to free from radical signs or quantities.

entry.def: To use, and rely on, reason in forming a theory, belief, etc., especially in matters of religion: to accord with the principles of rationalism.
entry.q: Theodore . . . is justly considered the chief rationalizing doctor of antiquity.

entry.def: In a rational manner.
The quality or state of being rational; rationality.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. ratis a raft; cf. L. ratitus marked with the figure of a raft
entry.def: An order of birds in which the wings are small, rudimentary, or absent, and the breastbone is destitute of a keel. The ostrich, emu, moa, and apteryx are examples.
Of or pertaining to the Ratitæ.
Of or pertaining to the Ratitæ.

entry.ety: Of uncertain origin
entry.def: The small transverse ropes attached to the shrouds and forming the steps of a rope ladder.

entry.ety: Cf. Raccoon
entry.def: A small rat.

sn.def: Same as Rattoon n.
A rattan cane.

entry.def: Same as Rattoon v. i.

entry.ety: Rat + bane
entry.def: Rat poison; white arsenic.
Poisoned by ratsbane.
Like a rat's tail in form; as, a rat-tail file, which is round, slender, and tapering. See Illust. of File.

sn.def: An excrescence growing from the pastern to the middle of the shank of a horse.

sd.def: The California chimæra. See Chimæra.
Any fish of the genus Macrurus. See Grenadier, 2.

cs.cd: the larva of a fly of the genus Eristalis. See Eristalis.
the fer-de-lance.
the musk shrew.

entry.def: Having a long, tapering tail like that of a rat.

entry.ety: Malay rōtan
entry.def: One of the long slender flexible stems of several species of palms of the genus Calamus, mostly East Indian, though some are African and Australian. They are exceedingly tough, and are used for walking sticks, wickerwork, chairs and seats of chairs, cords and cordage, and many other purposes.

entry.ety: F. ratine
entry.def: A thick woolen stuff quilled or twilled.

entry.ety: Prov. E. ratten a rat, hence the verb literally means, to do mischief like a rat
entry.def: To deprive feloniously of the tools used in one's employment (as by breaking or stealing them), for the purpose of annoying; as, to ratten a mechanic who works during a strike.

sn.def: One who, or that which, rats, as one who deserts his party.
Anything which catches rats; esp., a dog trained to catch rats; a rat terrier. See Terrier.

entry.def: A woolen stuff thinner than ratteen.

sn.def: The conduct or practices of one who rats. See Rat v. i., 1.
The low sport of setting a dog upon rats confined in a pit to see how many he will kill in a given time.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rattled -t'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Rattling -tlĭng
entry.ety: Akin to D. ratelen, G. rasseln, AS. hrætele a rattle, in hrætelwyrt rattlewort; cf. Gr. kradai`nein to swing, wave. Cf. Rail a bird

sn.def: To make a quick succession of sharp, inharmonious noises, as by the collision of hard and not very sonorous bodies shaken together; to clatter.
sn.q: And the rude hail in rattling tempest forms.
'T was but the wind, Or the car rattling o'er the stony street.

sn.def: To drive or ride briskly, so as to make a clattering; as, we rattled along for a couple of miles.
To make a clatter with the voice; to talk rapidly and idly; to clatter; -- with on or away; as, she rattled on for an hour.

entry.cs: To rattle off. To tell glibly or noisily; as, to rattle off a story. To rail at; to scold. “She would sometimes rattle off her servants sharply.” Arbuthnot.

sn.def: To cause to make a rattling or clattering sound; as, to rattle a chain.
To assail, annoy, or stun with a rattling noise.
sn.q: Sound but another [drum], and another shall As loud as thine rattle the welkin's ear.

sn.def: Hence, to disconcert; to confuse; as, to rattle one's judgment; to rattle a player in a game.
To scold; to rail at.

entry.note: ☞ The rattle of a rattlesnake is composed of the hardened terminal scales, loosened in succession, but not cast off, and so modified in form as to make a series of loose, hollow joints.

cs.cd: to cause it to sound.
a yellow-flowered herb (Rhinanthus Crista-galli), the ripe seeds of which rattle in the inflated calyx.

sn.def: A rapid succession of sharp, clattering sounds; as, the rattle of a drum.
Noisy, rapid talk.
sn.q: All this ado about the golden age is but an empty rattle and frivolous conceit.

sn.def: An instrument with which a rattling sound is made; especially, a child's toy that rattles when shaken.
sn.q: The rattles of Isis and the cymbals of Brasilea nearly enough resemble each other.
Pleased with a rattle, tickled with a straw.

sn.def: A noisy, senseless talker; a jabberer.
sn.q: It may seem strange that a man who wrote with so much perspicuity, vivacity, and grace, should have been, whenever he took a part in conversation, an empty, noisy, blundering rattle.

sn.def: A scolding; a sharp rebuke.
Any organ of an animal having a structure adapted to produce a rattling sound.
The noise in the throat produced by the air in passing through mucus which the lungs are unable to expel; -- chiefly observable at the approach of death, when it is called the death rattle. See Râle.
A toy that makes a rattling sound; a rattle.

sd.def: An American herb (Crotalaria sagittalis), the seeds of which, when ripe, rattle in the inflated pod.
Any species of Crotalaria, a genus of yellow-flowered herbs, with inflated, many-seeded pods.

entry.def: Giddy; rattle-headed.
An empty, noisy talker.
Noisy; giddy; unsteady.
A bat.
A rattlehead.
Rattle-headed.
entry.q: A noisy,rattle-patedfellow.

entry.def: One who, or that which, rattles.

entry.cs: Ground rattlesnake Zoöl a small rattlesnake (Caudisona miliaria or Sistrurus miliaria) of the Southern United States, having a small rattle. It has nine large scales on its head. Rattlesnake fern Bot a common American fern (Botrychium Virginianum) having a triangular decompound frond and a long-stalked panicle of spore cases rising from the middle of the frond. Rattlesnake grass Bot a handsome American grass (Glyceria Canadensis) with an ample panicle of rather large ovate spikelets, each one composed of imbricated parts and slightly resembling the rattle of the rattlesnake. Sometimes called quaking grass. Rattlesnake plantain Bot See under Plantain. Rattlesnake root Bot a name given to certain American species of the composite genus Prenanthes Prenanthes alba and Prenanthes serpentaria), formerly asserted to cure the bite of the rattlesnake. Called also lion's foot gall of the earth, and white lettuce. Rattlesnake's master Bot A species of Agave (Agave Virginica) growing in the Southern United States. An umbelliferous plant (Eryngium yuccæfolium) with large bristly-fringed linear leaves. A composite plant, the blazing star (Liatris squarrosa). Rattlesnake weed Bot a plant of the composite genus Hieracium Hieracium venosum); -- probably so named from its spotted leaves. See also Snakeroot.
entry.def: Any one of several species of venomous American snakes belonging to the genera Crotalus and Caudisona, or Sistrurus; sometimes also called rattler. They have a series of horny interlocking joints at the end of the tail which make a sharp rattling sound when shaken. The common rattlesnake of the Northern United States (Crotalus horridus), and the diamondback rattlesnakealso called diamondback rattler, and diamondback) of the South and East (Crotalus adamanteus) and West (Crotalus atrox), are the best known. See Illust. of Fang.
Any machine or vehicle that does not run smoothly.
Any plant of the genus Astragalus. See Milk vetch.
The golden-eye.

entry.ety: AS. hrætelwyrt
entry.def: Same as Rattlebox.
Ratlines.

entry.ety: Sp. retoño
entry.def: One of the stems or shoots of sugar cane of the second year's growth from the root, or later. See Plant-cane.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rattooned -t�nd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Rattooning
entry.ety: Cf. Sp. retoñar
entry.def: To sprout or spring up from the root, as sugar cane from the root of the previous year's planting.

entry.ety: L. raucus hoarse; cf. LL. raucidus
entry.def: Hoarse; raucous.

entry.ety: L. raucitas, from raucus hoarse: cf. F. raucité
entry.def: Harshness of sound; rough utterance; hoarseness; as, the raucity of a trumpet, or of the human voice.

entry.ety: L. raucus
entry.def: Hoarse; harsh; rough; as, a raucous, thick tone.
entry.q: His voice slightlyraucous.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Reach.
imp. & p. p. of Reck.
See Ranch.
Ransom.

entry.ety: F., fr. (assumed) L. rapagium rapaticum, fr. rapere to carry off by force, to ravish. See Rapacious Ravish
entry.def: Desolation by violence; violent ruin or destruction; devastation; havoc; waste; as, the ravage of a lion; the ravages of fire or tempest; the ravages of an army, or of time.
entry.q: Would one think 't were possible for love To make such ravage in a noble soul?
entry.syn: Despoilment; devastation; desolation; pillage; plunder; spoil; waste; ruin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ravaged răv"�jd; p. pr. & vb. n. Ravaging răv"�*jĭng
entry.ety: F. ravager. See Ravage n.
entry.def: To lay waste by force; to desolate by violence; to commit havoc or devastation upon; to spoil; to plunder; to consume.
entry.q: Already Cæsar Has ravaged more than half the globe.
His lands were daily ravaged, his cattle driven away.
entry.syn: To despoil; pillage; plunder; sack; spoil; devastate; desolate; destroy; waste; ruin.

entry.def: One who, or that which, ravages or lays waste; spoiler.
imp. of Rive.

entry.ety: Prov. E. raves, or rathes, a frame laid on a wagon, for carrying hay, etc
entry.def: One of the upper side pieces of the frame of a wagon body or a sleigh.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Raved rāvd; p. pr. & vb. n. Raving
entry.ety: F. rêver to rave, to be delirious, to dream; perhaps fr. L. rabere to rave, rage, be mad or furious. Cf. Rage Reverie

sn.def: To wander in mind or intellect; to be delirious; to talk or act irrationally; to be wild, furious, or raging, as a madman.
sn.q: In our madness evermore we rave.
Have I not cause to rave and beat my breast?
The mingled torrent of redcoats and tartans went raving down the valley to the gorge of Killiecrankie.

sn.def: To rush wildly or furiously.
To talk with unreasonable enthusiasm or excessive passion or excitement; -- followed by about of, or on; as, he raved about her beauty.
sn.q: The hallowed scene Which others rave of, though they know it not.

entry.def: To utter in madness or frenzy; to say wildly; as, to rave nonsense.

sn.def: An instance of raving.
A highly flattering or enthusiastic review of a play, book, etc.

A clamorous dance party, especially one featuring a band or disc jockey playing loud modern rock music oriented toward young people, held in a large room such as a warehouse, often organized by an informal or ad hoc sponsor.

entry.def: A tool, hooked at the end, for enlarging or clearing seams for the reception of oakum.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Raveled -'ld or Ravelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Raveling or Ravelling
entry.ety: OD. ravelen, D. rafelen, akin to LG. rebeln rebbeln reffeln

sn.def: To separate or undo the texture of; to unravel; to take apart; to untwist; to unweave or unknit; -- often followed by out; as, to ravel a twist; to ravel out a stocking.
sn.q: Sleep, that knits up the raveled sleave of care.

sn.def: To undo the intricacies of; to disentangle.
To pull apart, as the threads of a texture, and let them fall into a tangled mass; hence, to entangle; to make intricate; to involve.
sn.q: What glory's due to him that could divide Such raveled interests? has the knot untied?
The faith of very many men seems a duty so weak and indifferent, is so often untwisted by violence, or raveled and entangled in weak discourses!

sn.def: To become untwisted or unwoven; to be disentangled; to be relieved of intricacy.
To fall into perplexity and confusion.
sn.q: Till, by their own perplexities involved, They ravel more, still less resolved.

sn.def: To make investigation or search, as by picking out the threads of a woven pattern.
sn.q: The humor of raveling into all these mystical or entangled matters.

entry.ety: Also raveller
entry.def: One who ravels.

entry.ety: F.; cf. Sp. rebellin, It. revellino rivellino; perhaps fr. L. re- again + vallum wall
entry.def: A detached work with two embankments which make a salient angle. It is raised before the curtain on the counterscarp of the place. Formerly called demilune and half-moon.

entry.ety: Also ravelling

sn.def: The act of untwisting or of disentangling.
That which is raveled out; esp., a thread detached from a texture.

cs.cd: the cormorant.

entry.ety: AS. hræfn; akin to D. raaf, G. rabe, OHG. hraban, Icel. hrafn, Dan. ravn, and perhaps to L. corvus, Gr. ko`rax. √19
entry.def: A large black passerine bird (Corvus corax), similar to the crow, but larger, and has a harsh, loud call. It is native of the northern parts of Europe, Asia and America, and is noted for its sagacity.
Of the color of the raven; jet black; as, raven curls; raven darkness.

entry.ety: OF. ravine impetuosity, violence, F. ravine ravine. See Ravine Rapine

sn.def: Rapine; rapacity.
Prey; plunder; food obtained by violence.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ravened răv"'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Ravening
entry.ety: Written also ravin, and ravine

sn.def: To obtain or seize by violence.
To devour with great eagerness.
sn.q: Like rats that ravin down their proper bane.

entry.def: To prey with rapacity; to be greedy; to show rapacity.
entry.q: Benjamin shall raven as a wolf.

entry.note: ☞ Ravenala Madagascariensis, the principal species, is an unbranched tree with immense oarlike leaves growing alternately from two sides of the stem. The sheathing bases of the leafstalks collect and retain rain water, which flows freely when they are pierced with a knife, whence the plant is called traveler's tree.
entry.ety: Malagasy
entry.def: A genus of plants related to the banana.

sn.def: One who, or that which, ravens or plunders.
A bird of prey, as the owl or vulture.

entry.def: Eagerness for plunder; rapacity; extortion.
Greedily devouring; rapacious; as, ravening wolves.

entry.ety: From 2d Raven

sn.def: Devouring with rapacious eagerness; furiously voracious; hungry even to rage; as, a ravenous wolf or vulture.
Eager for prey or gratification; as, a ravenous appetite or desire.

entry.ety: Cf. G. ravenstuch
entry.def: A fine quality of sailcloth.
One who raves.
Ravenous.

entry.ety: See 2d Raven
entry.def: Food obtained by violence; plunder; prey; raven.
entry.q: Fowls ofravyne.
Though Nature, red in tooth and claw With ravine, shrieked against his creed.

entry.def: See Raven v. t. & i.

entry.ety: F., a place excavated by a torrent, a ravine, fr. ravir to snatch or tear away, L. rapere; cf. L. rapina rapine. See Ravish, and cf. Rapine Raven prey

sn.def: A torrent of water.
A deep and narrow hollow, usually worn by a stream or torrent of water; a gorge; a mountain cleft.

entry.def: Talking irrationally and wildly; as, a raving lunatic.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ravished -ĭsht; p. pr. & vb. n. Ravishing
entry.ety: OE. ravissen, F. ravir, fr. L. rapere to snatch or tear away, to ravish. See Rapacious Rapid, and -ish

sn.def: To seize and carry away by violence; to snatch by force.
sn.q: These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin Will quicken, and accuse thee.
This hand shall ravish thy pretended right.

sn.def: To transport with joy or delight; to delight to ecstasy.
sn.q: Ravished. . . for the joy.
Thou hast ravished my heart.

sn.def: To have carnal knowledge of (a woman) by force, and against her consent; to rape.
sn.syn: To transport; entrance; enrapture; delight; violate; deflower; force.

entry.def: One who ravishes (in any sense).
Rapturous; transporting.
In a ravishing manner.

entry.ety: F. ravissement. See Ravish

sn.def: The act of carrying away by force or against consent; abduction; as, the ravishment of children from their parents, of a ward from his guardian, or of a wife from her husband.
The state of being ravished; rapture; transport of delight; ecstasy.
sn.q: In whose sight all things joy, with ravishment Attracted by thy beauty still to gaze.

sn.def: The act of ravishing a woman; rape.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: In a half-raised position, as if about to spring on prey.

cs.cd: material that has not been subjected to a (specified) process of manufacture; as, ore is the raw material used in smelting; leather is the raw material of the shoe industry.
cast iron as it comes from the smelting furnace.

entry.ety: AS. hreáw; akin to D. raauw, LG. rau, G. roh, OHG. rō, Icel. hrār, Dan. raa, Sw. rå, L. crudus, Gr. kre`as flesh, Skr. kravis raw flesh. √18. Cf. Crude Cruel

sn.def: Not altered from its natural state; not prepared by the action of heat; as, raw sienna;
not cooked; not changed by heat to a state suitable for eating; not done; as, raw meat.
Hence: Unprepared for use or enjoyment; immature; unripe; unseasoned; inexperienced; unpracticed; untried; as, raw soldiers; a raw recruit.
sn.q: Approved himself to the raw judgment of the multitude.

entry.sn:
Not worked in due form; in the natural state; untouched by art; unwrought. Specifically: Not distilled; as, raw water. Obs Bacon.
Not spun or twisted; as, raw silk or cotton.
Not mixed or diluted; as, raw spirits.
Not tried; not melted and strained; as, raw tallow.
Not tanned; as, raw hides.
Not trimmed, covered, or folded under; as, the raw edge of a piece of metal or of cloth.

Not covered; bare. Specifically: Bald. Obs With skull allraw. Spenser
Deprived of skin; galled; as, a raw sore.
Sore, as if by being galled. And all his sinews waxen weak and raw Through long imprisonment.

sn.def: Disagreeably damp or cold; chilly; bleak; as, a raw wind.
sn.q: Arawand gusty day.

entry.def: A raw, sore, or galled place; a sensitive spot; as, to touch one on the raw .
entry.q: Like savage hackney coachmen, they know where there is a raw.

entry.def: Rawboned.
Having little flesh on the bones; gaunt.
A specter mentioned to frighten children; as, rawhead and bloodybones.
A cowhide, or coarse riding whip, made of untanned (or raw) hide twisted.
Somewhat raw.

sn.def: In a raw manner; unskillfully; without experience.
Without proper preparation or provision.

entry.def: The quality or state of being raw.

entry.ety: An aphetic form of array; cf. Beray

sn.def: To array.
To mark, stain, or soil; to streak; to defile.
sn.q: The filth that did itray.

entry.def: Array; order; arrangement; dress.
entry.q: And spoiling all her gears and goodly ray.

entry.cs:
Bundle of rays. Geom See Pencil of rays, below. Extraordinary ray Opt that one of two parts of a ray divided by double refraction which does not follow the ordinary law of refraction. Ordinary ray Opt that one of the two parts of a ray divided by double refraction which follows the usual or ordinary law of refraction. Pencil of rays Geom a definite system of rays.
Ray flowerorRay floret
Bot one of the marginal flowers of the capitulum in such composite plants as the aster, goldenrod, daisy, and sunflower. They have an elongated, strap-shaped corolla, while the corollas of the disk flowers are tubular and five-lobed. Ray point Geom the common point of a pencil of rays. Röntgen ray rẽnt"gĕn rā` Phys a kind of ray generated in a very highly exhausted vacuum tube by the electrical discharge; now more commonly called X-ray. It is composed of electromagnetic radiation of wavelength shorter than that of ultraviolet light, and is capable of passing through many bodies opaque to light, and producing photographic and fluorescent effects by which means pictures showing the internal structure of opaque objects are made, called radiographs sciagraphs X-ray photographs radiograms, or X-rays. So called from the discoverer, W. C. Röntgen. X ray the Röntgen ray; -- so called by its discoverer because of its enigmatical character, x being an algebraic symbol for an unknown quantity.
entry.ety: OF. rai, F. rais, fr. L. radius a beam or ray, staff, rod, spoke of a wheel. Cf. Radius

sn.def: One of a number of lines or parts diverging from a common point or center, like the radii of a circle; as, a star of six rays .
A radiating part of a flower or plant; the marginal florets of a compound flower, as an aster or a sunflower; one of the pedicels of an umbel or other circular flower cluster; radius. See Radius.

sd.def: One of the radiating spines, or cartilages, supporting the fins of fishes.
One of the spheromeres of a radiate, especially one of the arms of a starfish or an ophiuran.
A line of light or heat proceeding from a radiant or reflecting point; a single element of light or heat propagated continuously; as, a solar ray; a polarized ray.
One of the component elements of the total radiation from a body; any definite or limited portion of the spectrum; as, the red ray; the violet ray. See Illust. under Light.

sn.def: Sight; perception; vision; -- from an old theory of vision, that sight was something which proceeded from the eye to the object seen.
sn.q: All eyes direct their rays On him, and crowds turn coxcombs as they gaze.

sn.def: One of a system of diverging lines passing through a point, and regarded as extending indefinitely in both directions. See Half-ray.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rayed rād; p. pr. & vb. n. Raying
entry.ety: Cf. OF. raier raiier rayer, L. radiare to irradiate. See Ray n., and cf. Radiate

sn.def: To mark with long lines; to streak.
To send forth or shoot out; to cause to shine out; as, to ray smiles.

entry.def: To shine, as with rays.

entry.cs:
Bishop ray a yellow-spotted, long-tailed eagle ray (Stoasodon nàrinari) of the Southern United States and the West Indies. Butterfly ray a short-tailed American sting ray (Pteroplatea Maclura), having very broad pectoral fins. Devil ray. See Sea Devil. Eagle ray any large ray of the family Myliobatidæ, or Ætobatidæ. The common European species (Myliobatis aquila) is called also whip ray, and miller.
Electric ray, or Cramp ray
a torpedo. Starry ray a common European skate (Raia radiata). Sting ray any one of numerous species of rays of the family Trygonidæ having one or more large, sharp, barbed dorsal spines on the whiplike tail. Called also stingaree.
entry.ety: F. raie, L. raia. Cf. Roach
entry.def: Any one of numerous elasmobranch fishes of the order Raiæ, including the skates, torpedoes, sawfishes, etc.
In a restricted sense, any of the broad, flat, narrow-tailed species, as the skates and sting rays. See Skate.

entry.ety: Ar. ra'iyah a herd, a subject, fr. ra'a to pasture, guard
entry.def: A person not a Mohammedan, who pays the capitation tax.

entries.entry:
Ray" grass`
Italian ray grass or Italian rye grass . See Darnel, and Grass.
rā" grȧs`. Etymol. of ray is uncertain Bot A perennial European grass (Lolium perenne); -- called also rye grass, and red darnel. See Darnel, and Grass.

entry.def: Destitute of rays; hence, dark; not illuminated; blind; as, a rayless sky; rayless eyes.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Ray; beam.

sn.def: A synthetic fiber, made of thin filaments of regenerated cellulose, extruded from a solution of viscose. Called also viscose fiber and viscose rayon fiber.
a textile fabric made from rayon{1}.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Darting forth rays, as the sun when it shines out.

entry.ety: See Race
entry.def: A Shakespearean word (used once) supposed to mean the same as race, a root.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Razed rāzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Razing
entry.ety: F. raser. See Rase v. t.

sn.def: To erase; to efface; to obliterate.
sn.q: Razing the characters of your renown.

sn.def: To subvert from the foundation; to lay level with the ground; to overthrow; to destroy; to demolish.
sn.q: The royal hand that razed unhappy Troy.
sn.syn: To demolish; level; prostrate; overthrow; subvert; destroy; ruin. See Demolish.

entry.def: Slashed or striped in patterns.
entry.q: Two Provincial roses on myrazedshoes.

entry.ety: F. vaisseau rasé, fr. raser to raze, to cut down ships. See Raze v. t. Rase v. t.
entry.def: An armed ship having her upper deck cut away, and thus reduced to the next inferior rate, as a seventy-four cut down to a frigate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Razeed rȧ*zēd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Razeeing
entry.def: To cut down to a less number of decks, and thus to an inferior rate or class, as a ship; hence, to prune or abridge by cutting off or retrenching parts; as, to razee a book, or an article.

entry.cs:
Razor fish. Zoöl A small Mediterranean fish (Coryphæna novacula), prized for the table. The razor shell. Razor grass Bot a West Indian plant (Scleria scindens), the triangular stem and the leaves of which are edged with minute sharp teeth. Razor grinder Zoöl the European goat-sucker. Razor shell Zoöl any marine bivalve shell belonging to Solen and allied genera, especially Solen ensisor Ensatella ensis), and Solen Americana, which have a long, narrow, somewhat curved shell, resembling a razor handle in shape. Called also razor clam razor fish knife handle. Razor stone. Same as Novaculite.
Razor strap, or razor strop
a strap or strop used in sharpening razors.
entry.ety: OE. rasour, OF. rasur, LL. rasor: cf. F. rasoir, LL. rasorium. See Raze v. t. Rase v. t.

sn.def: A keen-edged knife of peculiar shape, used in shaving the hair from the face or the head; also called a straight razor.
sn.q: Take thee a barber'srazor.

sn.def: a device used for shaving, having a replaceable blade with a very sharp edge; also called safety razor. Also a similar device, made of plastic, in which the blade is neither replaceable nor can be sharpened, intended to be discarded after the blade dulls -- called a disposable razor.
A tusk of a wild boar.

entry.def: Ready for the razor; fit to be shaved.
The rorqual.
Having a sharp, lean, or thin back; as, a razor-backed hog, perch, etc.
A species of auk (Alca torda) common in the Arctic seas. See Auk, and Illust. in Appendix.
See Cutwater, 3.
having an edge as sharp as that of a razor; very sharp.
as thin as a razor blade; very thin.

entry.ety: See Rasure

sn.def: The act of erasing or effacing, or the state of being effaced; obliteration. See Rasure.
An erasure; a change made by erasing.

entry.ety: F., fr. Ar. ghāzīapron. razia in Algeria)
entry.def: A plundering and destructive incursion; a foray; a raid.

entries.entry:
Re- rē-. L. re-, older form (retained before vowelsred-: cf. F. re- ré-
A prefix signifying back against again anew; as, recline, to lean back; recall, to call back; recede; remove; reclaim, to call out against; repugn, to fight against; recognition, a knowing again; rejoin, to join again; reiterate; reassure. Combinations containing the prefix re- are readily formed, and are for the most part of obvious signification.
Re rā. It Mus A syllable applied in solmization to the second tone of the diatonic scale of C; in the American system, to the second tone of any diatonic scale.

entry.def: To absorb again; to draw in, or imbibe, again what has been effused, extravasated, or thrown off; to swallow up again; as, to reabsorb chyle, lymph, etc.; -- used esp. of fluids.
The act or process of reabsorbing.
A second access or approach; a return.
To accuse again.
To retch.
An effort to vomit.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reached rēcht Raught, the old preterit, is obsolete); p. pr. & vb. n. Reaching
entry.ety: OE. rechen, AS. rǣcan rǣcean, to extend, stretch out; akin to D. reiken, G. reichen, and possibly to AS. rīce powerful, rich, E. rich. √115

sn.def: To extend; to stretch; to thrust out; to put forth, as a limb, a member, something held, or the like.
sn.q: Her tresses yellow, and long straughten, Unto her heeles down they raughten.
Reach hither thy hand and thrust it into my side.
Fruit trees, over woody, reached too far Their pampered boughs.

sn.def: Hence, to deliver by stretching out a member, especially the hand; to give with the hand; to pass to another; to hand over; as, to reach one a book.
sn.q: He reached me a full cup.

sn.def: To attain or obtain by stretching forth the hand; to extend some part of the body, or something held by one, so as to touch, strike, grasp, or the like; as, to reach an object with the hand, or with a spear.
sn.q: O patron power, . . . thy present aid afford, Than I may reach the beast.

sn.def: To strike, hit, or touch with a missile; as, to reach an object with an arrow, a bullet, or a shell.
Hence, to extend an action, effort, or influence to; to penetrate to; to pierce, or cut, as far as.
sn.q: If these examples of grown men reach not the case of children, let them examine.

sn.def: To extend to; to stretch out as far as; to touch by virtue of extent; as, his land reaches the river.
sn.q: Thy desire . . . leads to no excess That reaches blame.

sn.def: To arrive at; to come to; to get as far as.
sn.q: Before this letter reaches your hands.

sn.def: To arrive at by effort of any kind; to attain to; to gain; to be advanced to.
sn.q: The best account of the appearances of nature which human penetration can reach, comes short of its reality.

sn.def: To understand; to comprehend.
sn.q: Do what, sir? I reach you not.

sn.def: To overreach; to deceive.

cs.mcol: To reach afterorTo reach fororTo reach at
cs.cd: to make efforts to attain to or obtain.
cs.q: He would be in the posture of the mind reaching after a positive idea of infinity.

sn.def: To stretch out the hand.
sn.q: Goddess humane, reach, then, and freely taste!

sn.def: To strain after something; to make efforts.
sn.q: Reaching above our nature does no good.

sn.def: To extend in dimension, time, amount, action, influence, etc., so as to touch, attain to, or be equal to, something.
sn.q: And behold, a ladder set upon the earth, and the top of it reached to heaven.
The new world reaches quite across the torrid zone.

sn.def: To sail on the wind, as from one point of tacking to another, or with the wind nearly abeam.

The act of stretching or extending; extension; power of reaching or touching with the person, or a limb, or something held or thrown; as, the fruit is beyond my reach; to be within reach of cannon shot.
The power of stretching out or extending action, influence, or the like; power of attainment or management; extent of force or capacity.
sn.q: Drawn by others who had deeper reaches than themselves to matters which they least intended.
Be sure yourself and your own reach to know.

sn.def: Extent; stretch; expanse; hence, application; influence; result; scope.
sn.q: And on the left hand, hell, With long reach, interposed.
I am to pray you not to strain my speech To grosser issues, nor to larger reach Than to suspicion.

sn.def: An extended portion of land or water; a stretch; a straight portion of a stream or river, as from one turn to another; a level stretch, as between locks in a canal; an arm of the sea extending up into the land.
