entry.def: Recitative.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recited; p. pr. & vb. n. Reciting
entry.ety: F. réciter, fr. L. recitare recitatum; pref. re- re- + citare to call or name, to cite. See Cite

sn.def: To repeat, as something already prepared, written down, committed to memory, or the like; to deliver from a written or printed document, or from recollection; to rehearse; as, to recite the words of an author, or of a deed or covenant.
To tell over; to go over in particulars; to relate; to narrate; as, to recite past events; to recite the particulars of a voyage.
To rehearse, as a lesson to an instructor.
To state in or as a recital. See Recital, 5.
sn.syn: To rehearse; narrate; relate; recount; describe; recapitulate; detail; number; count.

entry.def: To repeat, pronounce, or rehearse, as before an audience, something prepared or committed to memory; to rehearse a lesson learned.
A recital.
One who recites; also, a book of extracts for recitation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recked rĕkt obs. imp. Roughte); p. pr. & vb. n. Recking
entry.ety: AS. reccan rēcan, to care for; akin to OS. rōkian, OHG. ruochan, G. geruhen, Icel. rækja, also to E. reckon rake an implement. See Rake, and cf. Reckon

sn.def: To make account of; to care for; to heed; to regard.
sn.q: This son of mine not recking danger.
And may you better reck the rede Than ever did the adviser.

sn.def: To concern; -- used impersonally.
sn.q: What recks it them?

entry.def: To make account; to take heed; to care; to mind; -- often followed by of.
entry.q: Then reck I not, when I have lost my life.
I reck not though I end my life to-day.
Of me she recks not, nor my vain desire.

entry.ety: AS. recceleás rēceleás

sn.def: Inattentive to duty; careless; neglectful; indifferent.
Rashly negligent; utterly careless or heedless.
sn.q: It made the king as reckless as them diligent.
sn.syn: Heedless; careless; mindless; thoughtless; negligent; indifferent; regardless; unconcerned; inattentive; remiss; rash.

entry.def: Needing care; weak; feeble; as, a reckling child.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reckoned rĕk"'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Reckoning
entry.ety: OE. rekenen, AS. gerecenian to explain; akin to D. rekenen to reckon, G. rechnen, OHG. rehhanōncf. Goth. rahnjan), and to E. reck rake an implement; the original sense probably being, to bring together, count together. See Reck v. t.

sn.def: To count; to enumerate; to number; also, to compute; to calculate.
sn.q: The priest shall reckon to him the money according to the years that remain.
I reckoned above two hundred and fifty on the outside of the church.

sn.def: To count as in a number, rank, or series; to estimate by rank or quality; to place by estimation; to account; to esteem; to repute.
sn.q: He was reckoned among the transgressors.
For him I reckon not in high estate.

sn.def: To charge, attribute, or adjudge to one, as having a certain quality or value.
sn.q: Faith was reckoned to Abraham for righteousness.
Without her eccentricities being reckoned to her for a crime.

sn.def: To conclude, as by an enumeration and balancing of chances; hence, to think; to suppose; -- followed by an objective clause; as, I reckon he won't try that again.
sn.syn: To number; enumerate; compute; calculate; estimate; value; esteem; account; repute. See Calculate Guess.

entry.cs:
To reckon for to answer for; to pay the account for. “If they fail in their bounden duty, they shall reckon for it one day.” Bp. Sanderson.
To reckon on To reckon upon
to count or depend on; to include as a factor within one's considerations. To reckon with to settle accounts or claims with; -- used literally or figuratively. to include as a factor in one's plans or calculations; to anticipate. to deal with; to handle; as, I have to reckon with raising three children as well as doing my job. After a long time the lord of those servants cometh, and reckoneth with them. Matt. xxv. 19. To reckon without one's host to ignore in a calculation or arrangement the person whose assent is essential; hence, to reckon erroneously.

sn.def: To make an enumeration or computation; to engage in numbering or computing.
To come to an accounting; to make up accounts; to settle; to examine and strike the balance of debt and credit; to adjust relations of desert or penalty.
sn.q: “Parfay,” sayst thou, “sometime he reckon shall.”

entry.def: One who reckons or computes; also, a book of calculations, tables, etc., to assist in reckoning.
entry.q: Reckoners without their host must reckon twice.

cs.col: To be out of her reckoning
cs.cd: to be at a distance from the place indicated by the reckoning; -- said of a ship.
the day or time when one must pay one's debts, fulfill one's obligations, or be punished for one's transgressions.

entry.sn:
The act of one who reckons, counts, or computes; the result of reckoning or counting; calculation. Specifically: An account of time. Sandys.
Adjustment of claims and accounts; settlement of obligations, liabilities, etc. Even reckoning makes lasting friends, and the way to make reckonings even is to make them often. He quitted London, never to return till the day of a terrible and memorable reckoning had arrived.

sn.def: The charge or account made by a host at an inn.
sn.q: A coin would have a nobler use than to pay a reckoning.

sn.def: Esteem; account; estimation.
sn.q: You make no further reckoning of it [beauty] than of an outward fading benefit nature bestowed.

sd.def: The calculation of a ship's position, either from astronomical observations, or from the record of the courses steered and distances sailed as shown by compass and log, -- in the latter case called dead reckoningsee under Dead); -- also used for dead reckoning in contradistinction to observation.
The position of a ship as determined by calculation.

entry.def: To claim back; to demand the return of as a right; to attempt to recover possession of.
entry.q: A tract of land [Holland] snatched from an element perpetually reclaiming its prior occupancy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reclaimed r�*klāmd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Reclaiming
entry.ety: F. réclamer, L. reclamare reclamatum, to cry out against; pref. re- re- + clamare to call or cry aloud. See Claim

sn.def: To call back, as a hawk to the wrist in falconry, by a certain customary call.
To call back from flight or disorderly action; to call to, for the purpose of subduing or quieting.
sn.q: The headstrong horses hurried Octavius . . . along, and were deaf to his reclaiming them.

sn.def: To reduce from a wild to a tamed state; to bring under discipline; -- said especially of birds trained for the chase, but also of other animals.
sn.q: An eagle wellreclaimed.

sn.def: Hence: To reduce to a desired state by discipline, labor, cultivation, or the like; to rescue from being wild, desert, waste, submerged, or the like; as, to reclaim wild land, overflowed land, etc.
To call back to rectitude from moral wandering or transgression; to draw back to correct deportment or course of life; to reform.
sn.q: It is the intention of Providence, in all the various expressions of his goodness, to reclaim mankind.

sn.def: To correct; to reform; -- said of things.
sn.q: Your error, in time reclaimed, will be venial.

sn.def: To exclaim against; to gainsay.
sn.syn: To reform; recover; restore; amend; correct.

sn.def: To cry out in opposition or contradiction; to exclaim against anything; to contradict; to take exceptions.
sn.q: Scripture reclaims, and the whole Catholic church reclaims, and Christian ears would not hear it.
At a later period Grote reclaimed strongly against Mill's setting Whately above Hamilton.

sn.def: To bring anyone back from evil courses; to reform.
sn.q: They, hardened more by what might most reclaim, Grieving to see his glory, . . . took envy.

sn.def: To draw back; to give way.

entry.def: The act of reclaiming, or the state of being reclaimed; reclamation; recovery.
That may be reclaimed.

entry.ety: Cf. F. réclamant, p. pr
entry.def: One who reclaims; one who cries out against or contradicts.
One who reclaims.
That can not be reclaimed.

entry.ety: F. réclamation, L. reclamatio. See Reclaim

sn.def: The act or process of reclaiming.
Representation made in opposition; remonstrance.
sn.q: I would now, on the reclamation both of generosity and of justice, try clemency.

entry.def: To clasp or unite again.

entry.ety: L. reclinans, p. pr. See Recline
entry.def: Bending or leaning backward.

entry.ety: L. reclinatus, p. p
entry.def: Reclined, as a leaf; bent downward, so that the point, as of a stem or leaf, is lower than the base.

entry.ety: Cf. F. réclinaison

sn.def: The act of leaning or reclining, or the state of being reclined.
The angle which the plane of the dial makes with a vertical plane which it intersects in a horizontal line.

The act or process of removing a cataract, by applying the needle to its anterior surface, and depressing it into the vitreous humor in such a way that the front surface of the cataract becomes the upper one and its back surface the lower one.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reclined r�*klīnd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Reclining
entry.ety: L. reclinare; pref. re- re- + clinare to lean, incline. See Incline Lean to incline
entry.def: To cause or permit to lean, incline, rest, etc.; to place in a recumbent position; as, to recline the head on the hand.
entry.q: The motherReclined her dying head upon his breast.

sn.def: To lean or incline; as, to recline against a wall.
To assume, or to be in, a recumbent position; as, to recline on a couch.

entry.ety: L. reclinis. See Recline v. t.
entry.def: Having a reclining posture; leaning; reclining.
entry.q: They sat, recline On the soft downy bank, damasked with flowers.

entry.def: Falling or turned downward; reclinate.

sn.def: One who, or that which, reclines.

An armchair with a back that can be adjusted to lean backward, and a footrest that can be moved up to support the legs, or folded under the chair when the person is sitting up; the back and footrest are often geared so that they move together, allowing the chair to be conveniently adjusted either for sitting up or for lying back; also called a reclining chair.

cs.cd: a dial whose plane is inclined to the vertical line through its center. Davies & Peck Math. Dict.

entry.def: Bending or curving gradually back from the perpendicular.
Recumbent.
To close again.
To clothe again.

entry.ety: L. recludere to unclose, open; pref. re- again, back, un- + claudere to shut
entry.def: To open; to unclose.

entry.ety: F. reclus, L. reclusus, from recludere reclusum, to unclose, open, in LL., to shut up. See Close
entry.def: Shut up, sequestered; retired from the world or from public notice; solitary; living apart; as, a recluse monk or hermit; a recluse life
entry.q: In meditation deep, recluse From human converse.

entry.ety: F. reclus, LL. reclusus. See Recluse a.

sn.def: A person who lives in seclusion from intercourse with the world, as a hermit or monk; specifically, one of a class of secluded devotees who live in single cells, usually attached to monasteries.
The place where a recluse dwells.

entry.def: To shut up; to seclude.
In a recluse or solitary manner.
Quality or state of being recluse.

entry.ety: LL. reclusio: cf. F. reclusion
entry.def: A state of retirement from the world; seclusion.

sn.def: Affording retirement from society.
sn.q: Somereclusiveand religious life.

sn.def: Disposed to avoid the company of other people; living like a recluse{1}; not sociable; -- of people.

entry.ety: LL. reclusorium
entry.def: The habitation of a recluse; a hermitage.

entry.ety: L. recoctus, p. p. of recoquere to cook or boil over again. See Re-, and 4th Cook
entry.def: To boil or cook again; hence, to make over; to vamp up; to reconstruct.
A second coction or preparation; a vamping up.

entry.ety: L. recognitio: cf. F. recognition. See Recognizance
entry.def: The act of recognizing, or the state of being recognized; acknowledgment; formal avowal; knowledge confessed or avowed; notice.
entry.q: The lives of such saints had, at the time of their yearly memorials, solemn recognition in the church of God.

entry.ety: LL
entry.def: One of a jury impaneled on an assize.
Pertaining to, or connected with, recognition.
The quality or condition of being recognizable.
Capable of being recognized.

entry.note: ☞ Among lawyers the g in this and the related words (except recognize) is usually silent.
entry.ety: F. reconnaissance, OF. recognoissance, fr. recognoissant, p. pr. of recognoistre to recognize, F. reconnaître, fr. L. recognoscere; pref. re- re- + cognoscere to know. See Cognizance Know, and cf. Recognize Reconnoissance

sd.def: An obligation of record entered into before some court of record or magistrate duly authorized, with condition to do some particular act, as to appear at the same or some other court, to keep the peace, or pay a debt. A recognizance differs from a bond, being witnessed by the record only, and not by the party's seal.
The verdict of a jury impaneled upon assize.

sn.def: A token; a symbol; a pledge; a badge.
sn.q: That recognizance and pledge of love Which I first gave her.

sn.def: Acknowledgment of a person or thing; avowal; profession; recognition.

entry.def: Recognition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recognized rĕk"ŏg*nīzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Recognizing rĕk"ŏg*nī`zĭng
entry.ety: From Recognizance; see Cognition, and cf. Reconnoiter

sn.def: To know again; to perceive the identity of, with a person or thing previously known; to recover or recall knowledge of.
sn.q: Speak, vassal; recognize thy sovereign queen.

sn.def: To avow knowledge of; to allow that one knows; to consent to admit, hold, or the like; to admit with a formal acknowledgment; as, to recognize an obligation; to recognize a consul.
To acknowledge acquaintance with, as by salutation, bowing, or the like.
To show appreciation of; as, to recognize services by a testimonial.
To review; to reëxamine.
To reconnoiter.
sn.syn: To acknowledge; avow; confess; own; allow; concede. See Acknowledge.

entry.note: ☞ In legal usage in the United States the second syllable is often accented.
entry.def: To enter an obligation of record before a proper tribunal; as, A B recognized in the sum of twenty dollars.
The person in whose favor a recognizance is made.
One who recognizes; a recognizor.
One who enters into a recognizance.

entry.ety: L. recognoscere. See Recognizance
entry.def: To recognize.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recoiled r�*koild"; p. pr. & vb. n. Recoiling
entry.ety: OE. recoilen, F. reculer, fr. L. pref. re- re- + culus the fundament. The English word was perhaps influenced in form by accoil

sn.def: To start, roll, bound, spring, or fall back; to take a reverse motion; to be driven or forced backward; to return.
sn.q: Evil on itself shall back recoil.
The solemnity of her demeanor made it impossible . . . that we should recoil into our ordinary spirits.

sn.def: To draw back, as from anything repugnant, distressing, alarming, or the like; to shrink.
To turn or go back; to withdraw one's self; to retire.
sn.q: To your bowersrecoil.

entry.def: To draw or go back.

entry.cs: Recoil dynamometer Gunnery an instrument for measuring the force of the recoil of a firearm. Recoil escapement. See the Note under Escapement.

sn.def: A starting or falling back; a rebound; a shrinking; as, the recoil of nature, or of the blood.
The state or condition of having recoiled.
sn.q: The recoil from formalism is skepticism.

sn.def: Specifically, the reaction or rebounding of a firearm when discharged.

entry.def: One who, or that which, recoils.
In the manner of a recoil.

entry.ety: Cf. F. reculement
entry.def: Recoil.
To coin anew or again.

sn.def: The act of coining anew.
That which is coined anew.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + collect
entry.def: To collect again; to gather what has been scattered; as, to re-collect routed troops.
entry.q: God will one day raise the dead, re-collecting our scattered dust.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recollected; p. pr. & vb. n. Recollecting
entry.ety: Pref. re- + collect: cf. L. recolligere recollectum, to collect. Cf. Recollet

sn.def: To recover or recall the knowledge of; to bring back to the mind or memory; to remember.
Reflexively, to compose one's self; to recover self-command; as, to recollect one's self after a burst of anger; -- sometimes, formerly, in the perfect participle.

entry.ety: See Recollet
entry.def: A friar of the Strict Observance, -- an order of Franciscans.

entry.ety: Cf. F. récollection

sn.def: The act of recollecting, or recalling to the memory; the operation by which objects are recalled to the memory, or ideas revived in the mind; reminiscence; remembrance.
The power of recalling ideas to the mind, or the period within which things can be recollected; remembrance; memory; as, an event within my recollection .
That which is recollected; something called to mind; reminiscence.
sn.q: One of his earliestrecollections.

sn.def: The act or practice of collecting or concentrating the mind; concentration; self-control.
sn.q: From such an education Charles contracted habits of gravity and recollection.
sn.syn: Reminiscence; remembrance. See Memory.

entry.def: Having the power of recollecting.

entry.ety: F. récollet, fr. L. recollectus, p. p. of recolligere to gather again, to gather up; NL., to collect one's self, esp. for religious contemplation
entry.def: Same as Recollect n.
A second or renewed colonization.
To colonize again.
Combination a second or additional time.
To combine again.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + comfort: cf. F. réconforter
entry.def: To comfort again; to console anew; to give new strength to.
entry.q: Gan her recomfort from so sad affright.

entry.def: Without comfort.
The act of recomforting; restoration of comfort.

sn.def: To commence or begin again.
To begin anew to be; to act again as.
sn.q: He seems desirous enough of recommencing courtier.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + commence: cf. F. recommencer
entry.def: To commence again or anew.
A commencement made anew.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recommended; p. pr. & vb. n. Recommending
entry.ety: Pref. re- + commend: cf. F. recommander

sn.def: To commend to the favorable notice of another; to commit to another's care, confidence, or acceptance, with favoring representations; to put in a favorable light before any one; to bestow commendation on; as, he recommended resting the mind and exercising the body.
sn.q: Mæcenas recommended Virgil and Horace to Augustus, whose praises . . . have made him precious to posterity.

sn.def: To make acceptable; to attract favor to.
sn.q: A decent boldness ever meets with friends, Succeeds, and e'en a stranger recommends.

sn.def: To commit; to give in charge; to commend.
sn.q: Paul chose Silas and departed, being recommended by the brethren unto the grace of God.

entry.ety: Cf. F. recommandable
entry.def: Suitable to be recommended; worthy of praise; commendable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. recommandation

sn.def: The act of recommending.
That which recommends, or commends to favor; anything procuring, or tending to procure, a favorable reception, or to secure acceptance and adoption; as, he brought excellent recommendations .
The state of being recommended; esteem.
sn.q: The burying of the dead . . . hath always been had in an extraordinary recommendation amongst the ancient.

entry.def: That which recommends; a recommendation.
Serving to recommend; recommending; commendatory.
One who recommends.
To commission again; to give a new commission to.
entry.q: Officers whose time of service had expired were to be recommissioned.

entry.def: To commit again; to give back into keeping; specifically, to refer again to a committee; as, to recommit a bill to the same committee.
A second or renewed commitment; a renewed reference to a committee.
To compact or join anew.
entry.q: Recompactmy scattered body.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. recompensatio

sn.def: Recompense.
Used to denote a case where a set-off pleaded by the defendant is met by a set-off pleaded by the plaintiff.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recompensed -p?nst; p. pr. & vb. n. Recompensing -p?n`s?ng
entry.ety: F. récompenser, LL. recompensare, fr.L. pref. re- re- + compensare to compensate. See Compensate

sn.def: To render an equivalent to, for service, loss, etc.; to requite; to remunerate; to compensate.
sn.q: He can not recompense me better.

sn.def: To return an equivalent for; to give compensation for; to atone for; to pay for.
sn.q: God recompenseth the gift.
To recompense My rash, but more unfortunate, misdeed.

sn.def: To give in return; to pay back; to pay, as something earned or deserved.
sn.q: Recompense to no man evil for evil.
sn.syn: To repay; requite; compensate; reward; remunerate.

entry.def: To give recompense; to make amends or requital.

entry.ety: Cf. F. récompense
entry.def: An equivalent returned for anything done, suffered, or given; compensation; requital; suitable return.
entry.q: To me belongeth vengeance, and recompense.
And every transgression and disobedience received a just recompense of reward.
entry.syn: Repayment; compensation; remuneration; amends; satisfaction; reward; requital.

entry.def: Recompense; requital.
One who recompenses.
entry.q: A thankful recompenser of the benefits received.

entry.def: Of the nature of recompense; serving to recompense.
A new compilation.
To compile anew.
The act of recompiling; new compilation or digest; as, a recompilement of the laws.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recomposed -p?zd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Recomposing
entry.ety: Pref. re- + compose: cf. F. recomposer

sn.def: To compose again; to form anew; to put together again or repeatedly.
sn.q: The far greater number of the objects presented to our observation can only be decomposed, but not actually recomposed.

sn.def: To restore to composure; to quiet anew; to tranquilize; as, to recompose the mind.

entry.def: One who recomposes.

entry.ety: Cf. F. recomposition
entry.def: The act of recomposing.

entry.ety: Sp., p.p. of reconcentrar to inclose, to reconcentrate
entry.def: Lit., one who has been reconcentrated; specif., in Cuba, the Philippines, etc., during the revolution of 1895-98, one of the rural noncombatants who were concentrated by the military authorities in areas surrounding the fortified towns, and later were reconcentrated in the smaller limits of the towns themselves.
To concentrate again; to concentrate thoroughly.

The act of reconcentrating or the state of being reconcentrated; esp., the act or policy of concentrating the rural population in or about towns and villages for convenience in political or military administration, as in Cuba during the revolution of 1895-98.

entry.ety: Cf. F. réconciliable
entry.def: Capable of being reconciled; as, reconcilable adversaries; an act reconciable with previous acts.
entry.q: The different accounts of the numbers of ships are reconcilable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reconciled -s?ld`; p. pr. & vb. n. Reconciling
entry.ety: F. réconcilier, L. reconciliare; pref. re- re- + conciliare to bring together, to unite. See Conciliate

sn.def: To cause to be friendly again; to conciliate anew; to restore to friendship; to bring back to harmony; to cause to be no longer at variance; as, to reconcile persons who have quarreled.
sn.q: Propitious now and reconciled by prayer.
The church [if defiled] is interdicted till it be reconciledi.e., restored to sanctity] by the bishop.
We pray you . . . be ye reconciled to God.

sn.def: To bring to acquiescence, content, or quiet submission; as, to reconcile one's self to affictions.
To make consistent or congruous; to bring to agreement or suitableness; -- followed by with or to.
sn.q: The great men among the ancients understood how to reconcile manual labor with affairs of state.
Some figures monstrous and misshaped appear, Considered singly, or beheld too near; Which, but proportioned to their light or place, Due distance reconciles to form and grace.

sn.def: To adjust; to settle; as, to reconcile differences.
sn.syn: To reunite; conciliate; placate; propitiate; pacify; appease.

entry.def: To become reconciled.
Reconciliation.
One who reconciles.

entry.ety: F. réconciliation, L. reconciliatio

sn.def: The act of reconciling, or the state of being reconciled; reconcilenment; restoration to harmony; renewal of friendship.
sn.q: Reconciliation and friendship with God really form the basis of all rational and true enjoyment.

sn.def: Reduction to congruence or consistency; removal of inconsistency; harmony.
sn.q: A clear and easy reconciliation of those seeming inconsistencies of Scripture.
sn.syn: Reconcilement; reunion; pacification; appeasement; propitiation; atonement; expiation.

entry.def: Serving or tending to reconcile.
The act or process of recondensing.
To condense again.

entry.ety: L. reconditus, p. p. of recondere to put up again, to lay up, to conceal; pref. re- re- + condere to bring or lay together. See Abscond

sn.def: Hidden from the mental or intellectual view; secret; abstruse; as, recondite causes of things.
Dealing in things abstruse; profound; searching; as, recondite studies.
sn.q: Reconditelearning.

entry.ety: LL. reconditorium
entry.def: A repository; a storehouse.
To conduct back or again.
entry.q: A guide toreconductthy steps.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + confirm: cf. F. reconfirmer
entry.def: To confirm anew.

entry.ety: F. réconforter
entry.def: To recomfort; to comfort.
To join or conjoin anew.

entries.entry:
Re*con"nais*sance Re*con"nois*sance
Reconnoissance in force Mil a demonstration or attack by a large force of troops for the purpose of discovering the position and strength of an enemy.
r?-k?n"n?s-s?ns n. F. See Recognizance
The act of reconnoitering; preliminary examination or survey. Specifically: Geol An examination or survey of a region in reference to its general geological character. Engin An examination of a region as to its general natural features, preparatory to a more particular survey for the purposes of triangulation, or of determining the location of a public work. Mil An examination of a territory, or of an enemy's position, for the purpose of obtaining information necessary for directing military operations; a preparatory expedition.

entry.ety: F. reconnoitre, a former spelling of reconnaître. See Recognize

sn.def: To examine with the eye to make a preliminary examination or survey of; esp., to survey with a view to military or engineering operations.
To recognize.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + conquer: cf. F. reconquérir
entry.def: To conquer again; to recover by conquest; as, to reconquer a revolted province.
A second conquest.
To consecrate anew or again.
Renewed consecration.

sn.def: To consider again; as, to reconsider a subject.
To take up for renewed consideration, as a motion or a vote which has been previously acted upon.

entry.def: The act of reconsidering, or the state of being reconsidered; as, the reconsideration of a vote in a legislative body.
To console or comfort again.
To consolidate anew or again.
The act or process of reconsolidating; the state of being reconsolidated.
To construct again; to rebuild; to remodel; to form again or anew.
entry.q: Regiments had been dissolved and reconstructed.

sn.def: The act of constructing again; the state of being reconstructed.

The act or process of reorganizing the governments of the States which had passed ordinances of secession, and of reëstablishing their constitutional relations to the national government, after the close of the Civil War.

entry.def: Reconstructing; tending to reconstruct; as, a reconstructive policy.
The act or state of recontinuing.
To continue anew.
To convene or assemble again; to call or come together again.
A cross demand; an action brought by the defendant against the plaintiff before the same judge.
A second conversion.
To convert again.
A person who has been reconverted.
Capable of being reconverted; convertible again to the original form or condition.

sn.def: To convey back or to the former place; as, to reconvey goods.
To transfer back to a former owner; as, to reconvey an estate.

entry.def: Act of reconveying.
To copy again.

cs.cd: etc., to have a copy of the same entered in the records of the office designated by law, for the information of the public.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recorded; p. pr. & vb. n. Recording
entry.ety: OE. recorden to repeat, remind, F. recorder, fr. L. recordari to remember; pref. re- re- + cor cordis, the heart or mind. See Cordial Heart

sn.def: To recall to mind; to recollect; to remember; to meditate.
sn.q: I it yourecord.

sn.def: To repeat; to recite; to sing or play.
sn.q: They longed to see the day, to hear the larkRecord her hymns, and chant her carols blest.

sn.def: To preserve the memory of, by committing to writing, to printing, to inscription, or the like; to make note of; to write or enter in a book or on parchment, for the purpose of preserving authentic evidence of; to register; to enroll; as, to record the proceedings of a court; to record historical events.
sn.q: Those things that are recorded of him . . . are written in the chronicles of the kings.

sn.def: To reflect; to ponder.
sn.q: Praying all the way, and recording upon the words which he before had read.

sn.def: To sing or repeat a tune.
sn.q: Whether the birds or she recorded best.

entry.cs:
Court of record pron. r�*k�rd" in Eng. a court whose acts and judicial proceedings are written on parchment or in books for a perpetual memorial. Debt of record a debt which appears to be due by the evidence of a court of record, as upon a judgment or a cognizance. Trial by record a trial which is had when a matter of record is pleaded, and the opposite party pleads that there is no such record. In this case the trial is by inspection of the record itself, no other evidence being admissible. Blackstone.
To beat the recordorTo break the record
Sporting to surpass any performance of like kind as authoritatively recorded; as, to break the record in a walking match. Records in many fields of endeavor are listed in the Guiness Book of World Records .
entry.ety: OF. recort record, remembrance, attestation, record. See Record v. t.

sn.def: A writing by which some act or event, or a number of acts or events, is recorded; a register; as, a record of the acts of the Hebrew kings; a record of the variations of temperature during a certain time; a family record .

entry.sn:
Especially: An official contemporaneous writing by which the acts of some public body, or public officer, are recorded; as, a record of city ordinances; the records of the receiver of taxes.
An authentic official copy of a document which has been entered in a book, or deposited in the keeping of some officer designated by law.
An official contemporaneous memorandum stating the proceedings of a court of justice; a judicial record.
The various legal papers used in a case, together with memoranda of the proceedings of the court; as, it is not permissible to allege facts not in the record .

sn.def: Testimony; witness; attestation.
sn.q: John bare record, saying.

sn.def: That which serves to perpetuate a knowledge of acts or events; a monument; a memorial.
That which has been, or might be, recorded; the known facts in the course, progress, or duration of anything, as in the life of a public man; as, a politician with a good or a bad record .
That which has been publicly achieved in any kind of competitive sport as recorded in some authoritative manner, as the time made by a winning horse in a race.

entry.def: Remembrance.

entry.ety: L. recordatio: cf. F. recordation. See Record v. t.
entry.def: Remembrance; recollection; also, a record.

sn.def: One who records; specifically, a person whose official duty it is to make a record of writings or transactions.

The title of the chief judical officer of some cities and boroughs; also, of the chief justice of an East Indian settlement. The Recorder of London is judge of the Lord Mayor's Court, and one of the commissioners of the Central Criminal Court.
A kind of wind instrument resembling the flageolet.
sn.q: Flutes and softrecorders.

entry.def: The office of a recorder.
Keeping a record or a register; as, a recording secretary; -- applied to numerous instruments with an automatic appliance which makes a record of their action; as, a recording gauge or telegraph.
The act of investing again with a body; the state of being furnished anew with a body.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + couch: cf. F. recoucher
entry.def: To retire again to a couch; to lie down again.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + count
entry.def: To count or reckon again.
A counting again, as of votes.

entry.ety: F. raconter to relate, to recount; pref. re- again + � (L. ad.) + conter to relate. See Count v.
entry.def: To tell over; to relate in detail; to recite; to tell or narrate the particulars of; to rehearse; to enumerate; as, to recount one's blessings.
entry.q: To all his angels, who, with true applause,Recount his praises.

entry.def: Recital.

entry.ety: F. recouper; pref. re- re- + couper to cut

sn.def: To keep back rightfully (a part), as if by cutting off, so as to diminish a sum due; to take off (a part) from damages; to deduct; as, where a landlord recouped the rent of premises from damages awarded to the plaintiff for eviction.
To get an equivalent or compensation for; as, to recoup money lost at the gaming table; to recoup one's losses in the share market.
To reimburse; to indemnify; -- often used reflexively and in the passive.
sn.q: Elizabeth had lost her venture; but if she was bold, she might recoup herself at Philip's cost.
Industry is sometimes recouped for a small price by extensive custom.

entry.def: One who recoups.

entry.note: ☞ Recoupment applies to equities growing out of the very affair from which thw principal demand arises, set-off to cross-demands which may be independent in origin.
entry.def: The act of recouping.

cs.cd: words sometimes added to the indorsement of a negotiable instrument to protect the indorser from liability to the indorsee and subsequent holders. It is a restricted indorsement.

entry.ety: F. recours, L. recursus a running back, return, fr. recurrere recursum, to run back. See Recur

sn.def: A coursing back, or coursing again, along the line of a previous coursing; renewed course; return; retreat; recurence.
sn.q: Swiftrecourseof flushing blood.
Unto my first I will have my recourse.
Preventive physic . . . preventeth sickness in the healthy, or the recourse thereof in the valetudinary.

sn.def: Recurrence in difficulty, perplexity, need, or the like; access or application for aid; resort.
sn.q: Thus died this great peer, in a time of great recourse unto him and dependence upon him.
Our last recourse is therefore to our art.

sn.def: Access; admittance.
sn.q: Give me recourse to him.

sn.def: To return; to recur.
sn.q: The flame departing and recoursing.

sn.def: To have recourse; to resort.

entry.def: Having recurring flow and ebb; moving alternately.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + cover: cf. F. recouvrir
entry.def: To cover again.

cs.cd: a command whereby the piece is brought from the position of “aim” to that of “ready.”

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recovered -?rd; p. pr. & vb. n. Recovering.
entry.ety: OE. recoveren, OF. recovrer, F. recouvrer, from L. recuperare; pref. re- re + a word of unknown origin. Cf.Recuperate

sn.def: To get or obtain again; to get renewed possession of; to win back; to regain.
sn.q: David recovered all that the Amalekites had carried away.

sn.def: To make good by reparation; to make up for; to retrieve; to repair the loss or injury of; as, to recover lost time.
sn.q: Loss of catel mayrecoveredbe.
Even good men have many failings and lapses to lament and recover.

sn.def: To restore from sickness, faintness, or the like; to bring back to life or health; to cure; to heal.
sn.q: The wine in my bottle will recover him.

sn.def: To overcome; to get the better of, -- as a state of mind or body.
sn.q: I do hope to recover my late hurt.
When I had recovered a little my first surprise.

sn.def: To rescue; to deliver.
sn.q: That they may recover themselves out of the snare of the devil, who are taken captive by him.

sn.def: To gain by motion or effort; to obtain; to reach; to come to.
sn.q: The forest is not three leagues off; If we recover that, we're sure enough.
Except he could recover one of the Cities of Refuge he was to die.

sn.def: To gain as a compensation; to obtain in return for injury or debt; as, to recover damages in trespass; to recover debt and costs in a suit at law; to obtain title to by judgement in a court of law; as, to recover lands in ejectment or common recovery; to gain by legal process; as, to recover judgement against a defendant.
sn.syn: To regain; repossess; resume; retrieve; recruit; heal; cure.

sn.def: To regain health after sickness; to grow well; to be restored or cured; hence, to regain a former state or condition after misfortune, alarm, etc.; -- often followed by of or from; as, to recover from a state of poverty; to recover from fright.
sn.q: Go, inquire of Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron, whether I shall recover of this disease.

sn.def: To make one's way; to come; to arrive.
sn.q: With much ado the Christians recovered to Antioch.

sn.def: To obtain a judgement; to succeed in a lawsuit; as, the plaintiff has recovered in his suit.

entry.def: Recovery.

entry.ety: Cf. F. recouvrable
entry.def: Capable of being recovered or regained; capable of being brought back to a former condition, as from sickness, misfortune, etc.; obtainable from a debtor or possessor; as, the debt is recoverable; goods lost or sunk in the ocean are not recoverable.
entry.q: A prodigal course Is like the sun's; but not, like his, recoverable.
If I am recoverable, why am I thus?

entry.def: Recovery.
The person against whom a judgment is obtained in common recovery.
One who recovers.
The demandant in a common recovery after judgment.

cs.cd: a species of common assurance or mode of conveying lands by matter of record, through the forms of an action at law, formerly in frequent use, but now abolished or obsolete, both in England and America.

sn.def: The act of recovering, regaining, or retaking possession.
Restoration from sickness, weakness, faintness, or the like; restoration from a condition of mistortune, of fright, etc.
The obtaining in a suit at law of a right to something by a verdict and judgment of court.
The getting, or gaining, of something not previously had.
sn.q: Help be pastrecovery.

sn.def: In rowing, the act of regaining the proper position for making a new stroke.
Act of regaining the natural position after curtseying.
Act of regaining the position of guard after making an attack.

entry.def: Recreancy.
The quality or state of being recreant.

entry.ety: OF., cowardly, fr. recroire recreire, to forsake, leave, tire, discourage, regard as conquered, LL. recredere se to declare one's self conquered in combat; hence, those are called recrediti or recreanti who are considered infamous; L. pref. re- again, back + credere to believe, to be of opinion; hence, originally, to disavow one's opinion. See Creed

sn.def: Crying for mercy, as a combatant in the trial by battle; yielding; cowardly; mean-spirited; craven.
sn.q: Thisrecreantknight.

sn.def: Apostate; false; unfaithful.
sn.q: Who, for so many benefits received, Turned recreant to God, ingrate and false.

entry.def: One who yields in combat, and begs for mercy; a mean-spirited, cowardly wretch.
entry.q: You are all recreants and dastards!

entry.ety: Pref. re- + create
entry.def: To create or form anew.
entry.q: On opening the campaign of 1776, instead of reënforcing, it was necessary to re-create, the army.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recreated -`td; p. pr. & vb. n. Recreating
entry.ety: L. recreatus, p. p. of recreate to create anew, to refresh; pref. re- re- + creare to create. See Create
entry.def: To give fresh life to; to reanimate; to revive; especially, to refresh after wearying toil or anxiety; to relieve; to cheer; to divert; to amuse; to gratify.
entry.q: Painters, when they work on white grounds, place before them colors mixed with blue and green, to recreate their eyes, white wearying . . . the sight more than any.
St. John, who recreated himself with sporting with a tame partridge.
These ripe fruits recreate the nostrils with their aromatic scent.

entry.def: To take recreation.

entry.ety: F. récréation, L. recreatio
entry.def: The act of recreating, or the state of being recreated; refreshment of the strength and spirits after toil; amusement; diversion; sport; pastime.

entry.ety: See Re-create
entry.def: A forming anew; a new creation or formation.
Creating anew; as, re-creative power.

entry.ety: Cf. F. récréatif. See Recreate
entry.def: Tending to recreate or refresh; recreating; giving new vigor or animation; reinvigorating; giving relief after labor or pain; amusing; diverting.
entry.q: Let the music of them be recreative.

entry.ety: L. recrementum; pref. re- re- + cernere cretum, to separate, sift: cf. F. récrément

sn.def: Superfluous matter separated from that which is useful; dross; scoria; as, the recrement of ore.

sd.def: Excrement.
A substance secreted from the blood and again absorbed by it.

entry.def: Recrementitious.

entry.ety: Cf. F. récrémentitiel
entry.def: Of the nature of a recrement. See Recrement, 2 .
entry.q: Recrementitialfluids.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to recrement; consisting of recrement or dross.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + criminate: cf. F. récriminer, LL. recriminare
entry.def: To return one charge or accusation with another; to charge back fault or crime upon an accuser.
entry.q: It is not my business to recriminate, hoping sufficiently to clear myself in this matter.

entry.def: To accuse in return.

entry.ety: F. récrimination, LL. recriminatio
entry.def: The act of recriminating; an accusation brought by the accused against the accuser; a counter accusation.
entry.q: Accusations and recriminations passed backward and forward between the contending parties.

entry.def: Recriminatory.
One who recriminates.

entry.ety: Cf. F. récriminatoire
entry.def: Having the quality of recrimination; retorting accusation; recriminating.
To cross a second time.
Recrudescence.

entry.ety: See Recrudescent
entry.def: To be in a state of recrudescence; esp., to come into renewed freshness, vigor, or activity; to revive.
entry.q: The general influence . . . which is liable every now and then to recrudesce in his absence.

entry.ety: Cf. F. recrudescence

sn.def: The state or condition of being recrudescent.
sn.q: A recrudescence of barbarism may condemn it [land] to chronic poverty and waste.

sn.def: Increased severity of a disease after temporary remission.

entry.ety: L. recrudescens -entis, p. pr. of recrudescere to become raw again; pref. re- re- + crudescere to become hard or raw: cf. F. recrudescent

sn.def: Growing raw, sore, or painful again.
Breaking out again after temporary abatement or supression; as, a recrudescent epidemic.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recruited; p. pr. & vb. n. Recruiting
entry.ety: F. recruter, corrupted (under influence of recrue recruiting, recruit, from recroî/tre, p. p. recrû, to grow again) from an older recluter, properly, to patch, to mend (a garment); pref. re- + OF. clut piece, piece of cloth; cf. Icel. klūtr kerchief, E. clout

sn.def: To repair by fresh supplies, as anything wasted; to remedy lack or deficiency in; as, food recruits the flesh; fresh air and exercise recruit the spirits.
sn.q: Her cheeks glow the brighter, recruiting their color.

sn.def: Hence, to restore the wasted vigor of; to renew in strength or health; to reinvigorate.
To supply with new men, as an army; to fill up or make up by enlistment; as, he recruited two regiments; the army was recruited for a campaign; also, to muster; to enlist; as, he recruited fifty men.
To gain new supplies of anything wasted; to gain health, flesh, spirits, or the like; to recuperate; as, lean cattle recruit in fresh pastures.
To gain new supplies of men for military or other service; to raise or enlist new soldiers; to enlist troops.
A supply of anything wasted or exhausted; a reënforcement.
sn.q: The state is to have recruits to its strength, and remedies to its distempers.

sn.def: Specifically, a man enlisted for service in the army; a newly enlisted soldier.

entry.def: One who, or that which, recruits.
The act or process of recruiting; especially, the enlistment of men for an army.
The process or recrystallizing.
To crystallize again.
Of or pertaining to the rectum; in the region of the rectum.

entry.note: ☞ As the area of a rectangle is expressed by the product of its two dimensions, the term rectangle is sometimes used for product; as, the rectangle of a and b, that is, ab.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. rectus right + angulus angle. See Right, and Angle
entry.def: A four-sided figure having only right angles; a right-angled parallelogram.
Rectangular.
Rectangular.

entry.ety: CF. F. rectangulaire
entry.def: Right-angled; having one or more angles of ninety degrees.
The quality or condition of being rectangular, or right-angled.

entries.entry: Rec"ti- r?k"t?*. L. rectus straight A combining form signifying straight; as, rectilineal, having straight lines; rectinerved.

sn.def: Capable of being rectified; as, a rectifiable mistake.
Admitting, as a curve, of the construction of a straight line equal in length to any definite portion of the curve.

cs.cd: its adjustment preparatory to the solution of a proposed problem.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rectification

sn.def: The act or operation of rectifying; as, the rectification of an error; the rectification of spirits.
sn.q: After the rectification of his views, he was incapable of compromise with profounder shapes of error.

sn.def: The determination of a straight line whose length is equal a portion of a curve.

entry.def: That which rectifies or refines; esp., a part of a distilling apparatus in which the more volatile portions are separated from the less volatile by the process of evaporation and condensation; a rectifier.

sn.def: One who, or that which, rectifies.
Specifically: Naut An instrument used for determining and rectifying the variations of the compass on board ship. Chem A rectificator.

cs.cd: to adjust it in order to prepare for the solution of a proposed problem.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rectified -f?d; p. pr. & vb. n. Rectifying -f?`?ng
entry.ety: F. rectifier, LL. rectificare; L. rectus right + -ficarein comp.) to make. See Right, and -fy

sn.def: To make or set right; to correct from a wrong, erroneous, or false state; to amend; as, to rectify errors, mistakes, or abuses; to rectify the will, the judgment, opinions; to rectify disorders.
sn.q: I meant to rectify my conscience.
This was an error of opinion which a conflicting opinion would have rectified.

sn.def: To refine or purify by repeated distillation or sublimation, by which the fine parts of a substance are separated from the grosser; as, to rectify spirit of wine.
To produce ( as factitious gin or brandy) by redistilling low wines or ardent spirits (whisky, rum, etc.), flavoring substances, etc., being added.
sn.syn: To amend; emend; correct; better; mend; reform; redress; adjust; regulate; improve. See Amend.

entry.ety: Recti- + lineal linear
entry.def: Straight; consisting of a straight line or lines; bounded by straight lines; as, a rectineal angle; a rectilinear figure or course.
The quality or state of being rectilinear.
Rectilinear.

entry.ety: Recti- + nerve
entry.def: Having the veins or nerves straight; -- said of leaves.

entry.ety: L. rectio, fr. regere to rule or govern
entry.def: See Government n., 7.

entry.ety: Recti- + rostral
entry.def: Having a straight beak.

entry.ety: Recti- + serial
entry.def: Arranged in exactly vertical ranks, as the leaves on stems of many kinds; -- opposed to curviserial.

entry.ety: NL. See Rectum, and -itis
entry.def: Proctitis.

entry.ety: L. rectitudo, fr. rectus right, straight: cf. F. rectitude. See Right

sn.def: Straightness.

Rightness of principle or practice; exact conformity to truth, or to the rules prescribed for moral conduct, either by divine or human laws; uprightness of mind; uprightness; integrity; honesty; justice.
Right judgment.
sn.syn: See Justice.

entries.entry: Rec"to- r?k"t?*. A combining form indicating connection with, or relation to the rectum; as, recto-vesical.

entry.ety: Abbrev. fr. LL. breve de recto. See Right
entry.def: A writ of right.

entry.ety: Cf. F. recto
entry.def: The right-hand page; -- opposed to verso.

entry.ety: L., fr. regere rectum, to lead straight, to rule: cf. F. recteur. See Regiment Right

sn.def: A ruler or governor.
sn.q: God is the supreme rector of the world.

sd.def: A clergyman who has the charge and cure of a parish, and has the tithes, etc.; the clergyman of a parish where the tithes are not impropriate. See the Note under Vicar.
A clergyman in charge of a parish.

sn.def: The head master of a public school.
The chief elective officer of some universities, as in France and Scotland; sometimes, the head of a college; as, the Rector of Exeter College, or of Lincoln College, at Oxford.
The superior officer or chief of a convent or religious house; and among the Jesuits the superior of a house that is a seminary or college.

entry.ety: CF. F. rectoral
entry.def: Pertaining to a rector or governor.

entry.ety: LL. rectoratus: cf. F. rectorat
entry.def: The office, rank, or station of a rector; rectorship.

sn.def: A governess; a rectrix.
The wife of a rector.

entry.def: Pertaining to a rector or a rectory; rectoral.

sn.def: Government; guidance.
sn.q: Therectorshipof judgment.

sn.def: The office or rank of a rector; rectorate.

entries.entry:
Rec"to*ry -t?*r? n.; pl.Rectories -r�z. Cf. OF. rectorie or rectorerie, LL. rectoria
The province of a rector; a parish church, parsonage, or spiritual living, with all its rights, tithes, and glebes.
A rector's mansion; a parsonage house.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to both the rectum and the uterus.
Of or pertaining to both the rectum and the vagina.
Of or pertaining to both the rectum and the bladder.
A rectoress.

entries.entry:
‖Rec"trix -tr?ks n.; pl.Rectrices -tr�"s�z. L., fem. of rector
A governess; a rectoress.
Zoöl One of the quill feathers of the tail of a bird.

entry.ety: NL. (sc. intestinum), fr. L. rectus straight. See Right
entry.def: The terminal part of the large intestine; -- so named because supposed by the old anatomists to be straight. See Illust. under Digestive.

entries.entry: ‖Rec"tus -t?s n.; pl.Recti -t�. NL., fr. L. regere to keep straight Anat A straight muscle; as, the recti of the eye.

entry.ety: L. recubare to lie upon the back
entry.def: Recumbence.
To recoil.

entry.ety: F. reculement
entry.def: Recoil.

entry.ety: L. recumbere; pref. re- back + cumberein comp.), akin to cubare to lie down
entry.def: To lean; to recline; to repose.
The act of leaning, resting, or reclining; the state of being recumbent.
Recumbence.

entry.ety: L. recumbens -entis, p. pr. of recumbere. See Recumb Incumbent
entry.def: Leaning; reclining; lying; as, the recumbent posture of the Romans at their meals. Hence, figuratively; Resting; inactive; idle.

entry.ety: Cf.F. récupérable. See Recover
entry.def: Recoverable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recuperated -?`t?d; p. pr. & vb. n. Recuperating
entry.ety: L. recuperatus, p. p. of recuperare. See Recover to get again
entry.def: To recover health; to regain strength; to convalesce.
To recover; to regain; as, to recuperate the health or strength.

entry.ety: L. recuperatio: cf. F. récupération
entry.def: Recovery, as of anything lost, especially of the health or strength.

entry.ety: L. recuperativus recuperatorius
entry.def: Of or pertaining to recuperation; tending to recovery.

entry.ety: Cf. L. recuperator a recoverer
entry.def: Same as Regenerator.

cs.cd: a circulating decimal. See under Decimal.
an algebraic series in which the coefficients of the several terms can be expressed by means of certain preceding coefficients and constants in one uniform manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Recurred -k?rd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Recurring
entry.ety: L. recurrere; pref. re- re- + currere to run. See Current

sn.def: To come back; to return again or repeatedly; to come again to mind.
sn.q: When any word has been used to signify an idea, the old idea will recur in the mind when the word is heard.

sn.def: To occur at a stated interval, or according to some regular rule; as, the fever will recur to-night.
To resort; to have recourse; to go for help.
sn.q: If, to avoid succession in eternal existence, they recur to the “punctum stans” of the schools, they will thereby very little help us to a more positive idea of infinite duration.

entry.ety: Cf. Recover

sn.def: To arrive at; to reach; to attain.
To recover; to regain; to repossess.
sn.q: When their powers, impaired through labor long, With due repast, they had recured well.

sn.def: To restore, as from weariness, sickness; or the like; to repair.
sn.q: In western waves his weary wagon did recure.

sn.def: To be a cure for; to remedy.
sn.q: No medicine Might avail his sickness to recure.

entry.def: Cure; remedy; recovery.
entry.q: But whom he hite, without recure he dies.

entry.def: Incapable of cure.

entry.ety: Cf. F. récurrence
entry.def: The act of recurring, or state of being recurrent; return; resort; recourse.
entry.q: I shall insensibly go on from a rare to a frequent recurrence to the dangerous preparations.

entry.cs: Recurrent fever. Med See Relapsing fever, under Relapsing. Recurrent pulse Physiol the pulse beat which appears (when the radial artery is compressed at the wrist) on the distal side of the point of pressure through the arteries of the palm of the hand. Recurrent sensibility Physiol the sensibility manifested by the anterior, or motor, roots of the spinal cord (their stimulation causing pain) owing to the presence of sensory fibers from the corresponding sensory or posterior roots.
entry.ety: L. recurrens -entis, p. pr. of recurrere: cf.F. récurrent. See Recur

sn.def: Returning from time to time; recurring; as, recurrent pains.
Running back toward its origin; as, a recurrent nerve or artery.

entry.ety: L. recursans -antis, p. pr. of recursare to run back, v. freq. of recurrere. See Recure
entry.def: Displayed with the back toward the spectator; -- said especially of an eagle.

entry.ety: L. recursio. See Recur
entry.def: The act of recurring; return.

entry.ety: L. recurvatus, p. p. of recurvare. See Re-, and Curvate
entry.def: Recurved.
To bend or curve back; to recurve.
The act of recurving, or the state of being recurved; a bending or flexure backward.
To curve in an opposite or unusual direction; to bend back or down.
Curved in an opposite or uncommon direction; bent back; as, a bird with a recurved bill; flowers with recurved petals.

entry.ety: L. recurvus bent back + rostrum beack; cf. F. récurvirostre
entry.def: A bird whose beak bends upward, as the avocet.

entry.ety: See Recurviroster
entry.def: Having the beak bent upwards.
Recurvation.

entry.ety: L. recurvus; pref. re- re + curvus curved
entry.def: Recurved.
The state of being recusant; nonconformity.

entry.ety: L. recusans -antis, p. pr. of recure to refuse, to oject to; pref. re- re + causa a cause, pretext: cf. F. récusant. See Cause, and cf. Ruse
entry.def: Obstinate in refusal; specifically, in English history, refusing to acknowledge the supremacy of the king in the churc, or to conform to the established rites of the church; as, a recusant lord.
entry.q: It stated him to have placed his son in the household of the Countess of Derby, a recusant papist.

sn.def: One who is obstinate in refusal; one standing out stubbornly against general practice or opinion.
sn.q: The last rebellious recusants among the European family of nations.

sn.def: A person who refuses to acknowledge the supremacy of the king in matters of religion; as, a Roman Catholic recusant, who acknowledges the supremacy of the pope.
One who refuses communion with the Church of England; a nonconformist.
sn.q: All that are recusants of holy rites.

entry.ety: L. recusatio: cf. F. récusation

sn.def: Refusal.
The act of refusing a judge or challenging that he shall not try the cause, on account of his supposed partiality.

entry.def: Refusing; denying; negative.

entry.ety: F. récuser, or L. recusare. See Recusant
entry.def: To refuse or reject, as a judge; to challenge that the judge shall not try the cause.

To withdraw oneself from serving as a judge or other decision-maker in order to avoid a real or apparent conflict of interest; -- often used with the reflexive; as, the judge recused himself due to a financial interest in the matter.

entry.ety: L. recutire recussum, to beat back; pref. re- re- + quatere to shake
entry.def: The act of beating or striking back.
imp. & p. p. of Read.
To put on order; to make tidy; also, to free from entanglement or embarrassement; -- generally with up; as, to red up a house.

entry.note: ☞ Red is a general term, including many different shades or hues, as scarlet, crimson, vermilion, orange red, and the like.
☞ Red is often used in the formation of self-explaining compounds; as, red-breasted, red-cheeked, red-faced, red-haired, red-headed, red-skinned, red-tailed, red-topped, red-whiskered, red-coasted.
entry.cs:
Red admiral Zoöl a beautiful butterfly (Vanessa Atalanta) common in both Europe and America. The front wings are crossed by a broad orange red band. The larva feeds on nettles. Called also Atalanta butterfly, and nettle butterfly. Red ant. Zoöl A very small ant (Myrmica molesta) which often infests houses. A larger reddish ant (Formica sanguinea), native of Europe and America. It is one of the slave-making species. Red antimony Min kermesite. See Kermes mineral, under Kermes. Red ash Bot an American tree (Fraxinus pubescens), smaller than the white ash, and less valuable for timber. Cray. Red bass. Zoöl See Redfish. Red bay Bot a tree (Persea Caroliniensis) having the heartwood red, found in swamps in the Southern United States. Red beard Zoöl a bright red sponge (Microciona prolifera), common on oyster shells and stones. Local, U.S Red birch Bot a species of birch (Betula nigra) having reddish brown bark, and compact, light-colored wood. Gray. Red blindness. Med See Daltonism. Red book a book containing the names of all the persons in the service of the state. Eng Red book of the Exchequer an ancient record in which are registered the names of all that held lands per baroniam in the time of Henry II. Brande & C. Red brass an alloy containing eight parts of copper and three of zinc. Red bug. Zoöl A very small mite which in Florida attacks man, and produces great irritation by its bites. A red hemipterous insect of the genus Pyrrhocoris, especially the European species (Pyrrhocoris apterus), which is bright scarlet and lives in clusters on tree trunks. See Cotton stainder, under Cotton. Red cedar. Bot An evergreen North American tree (Juniperus Virginiana) having a fragrant red-colored heartwood. A tree of India and Australia (Cedrela Toona) having fragrant reddish wood; -- called also toon tree in India.
Red chalk. See under Chalk. Red copper Min red oxide of copper; cuprite. Red coral Zoöl the precious coral (Corallium rubrum). See Illusts. of Coral and Gorgonlacea. Red cross. The cross of St. George, the national emblem of the English. The Geneva cross. See Geneva convention, and Geneva cross, under Geneva. Red currant. Bot See Currant. Red deer. Zoöl The common stag (Cervus elaphus), native of the forests of the temperate parts of Europe and Asia. It is very similar to the American elk, or wapiti. The Virginia deer. See Deer. Red duck Zoöl a European reddish brown duck (Fuligula nyroca); -- called also ferruginous duck. Red ebony. Bot See Grenadillo. Red empress Zoöl a butterfly. See Tortoise shell. Red fir Bot a coniferous tree (Pseudotsuga Douglasii) found from British Columbia to Texas, and highly valued for its durable timber. The name is sometimes given to other coniferous trees, as the Norway spruce and the American Abies magnifica and Abies nobilis. Red fire. Pyrotech See Blue fire, under Fire. Red flag. See under Flag. Red fox Zoöl the common American fox (Vulpes fulvus), which is usually reddish in color. Red grouse Zoöl the Scotch grouse, or ptarmigan. See under Ptarmigan.
Red gumorRed gum-tree
Bot a name given to eight Australian species of Eucalyptus Eucalyptus amygdalina resinifera, etc.) which yield a reddish gum resin. See Eucalyptus. Red hand Her a left hand appaumé, fingers erect, borne on an escutcheon, being the mark of a baronet of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland; -- called also Badge of Ulster. Red herring the common herring dried and smoked.
Red horse. Zoöl Any large American red fresh-water sucker, especially Moxostoma macrolepidotum and allied species. See the Note under Drumfish.Red lead. See under Lead, and Minium. Red-lead ore. Min Same as Crocoite. Red liquor Dyeing a solution consisting essentially of aluminium acetate, used as a mordant in the fixation of dyestuffs on vegetable fiber; -- so called because used originally for red dyestuffs. Called also red mordant. Red maggot Zoöl the larva of the wheat midge. Red manganese. Min Same as Rhodochrosite. Red man one of the American Indians; -- so called from his color. Red maple Bot a species of maple (Acer rubrum). See Maple. Red mite. Zoöl See Red spider, below. Red mulberry Bot an American mulberry of a dark purple color (Morus rubra). Red mullet Zoöl the surmullet. See Mullet. Red ocher Min a soft earthy variety of hematite, of a reddish color. Red perch Zoöl the rosefish. Red phosphorus. Chem See under Phosphorus. Red pine Bot an American species of pine (Pinus resinosa); -- so named from its reddish bark. Red precipitate. See under Precipitate. Red Republican European Politics originally, one who maintained extreme republican doctrines in France, -- because a red liberty cap was the badge of the party; an extreme radical in social reform. Cant Red ribbon the ribbon of the Order of the Bath in England. Red sanders. Bot See Sanders. Red sandstone. Geol See under Sandstone. Red scale Zoöl a scale insect (Aspidiotus aurantii) very injurious to the orange tree in California and Australia. Red silver Min an ore of silver, of a ruby-red or reddish black color. It includes proustite, or light red silver, and pyrargyrite, or dark red silver. Red snapper Zoöl a large fish (Lutjanus aya syn. Lutjanus Blackfordii) abundant in the Gulf of Mexico and about the Florida reefs. Red snow snow colored by a mocroscopic unicellular alga (Protococcus nivalis) which produces large patches of scarlet on the snows of arctic or mountainous regions. Red softening Med a form of cerebral softening in which the affected parts are red, -- a condition due either to infarction or inflammation. Red spider Zoöl a very small web-spinning mite (Tetranychus telarius) which infests, and often destroys, plants of various kinds, especially those cultivated in houses and conservatories. It feeds mostly on the under side of the leaves, and causes them to turn yellow and die. The adult insects are usually pale red. Called also red mite. Red squirrel Zoöl the chickaree. Red tape the tape used in public offices for tying up documents, etc. Hence, official formality and delay; excessive bureaucratic paperwork. Red underwing Zoöl any species of noctuid moths belonging to Catacola and allied genera. The numerous species are mostly large and handsomely colored. The under wings are commonly banded with bright red or orange. Red water a disease in cattle, so called from an appearance like blood in the urine.
entry.ety: OE. red reed, AS. reád reód; akin to OS. rōd, OFries. rād, D. rood, G. roht rot, OHG. rōt, Dan. & Sw. röd, Icel. rauðr rjōðr, Goth. ráuds, W. rhudd, Armor. ruz, Ir. & Gael. ruadh, L. ruber rufus, Gr. 'eryqro`s, Skr. rudhira rohita; cf. L. rutilus. √113. Cf. Erysipelas Rouge Rubric Ruby Ruddy Russet Rust
entry.def: Of the color of blood, or of a tint resembling that color; of the hue of that part of the rainbow, or of the solar spectrum, which is furthest from the violet part.
entry.q: Fresh flowers, white andreede.
Your color, I warrant you, is as red as any rose.

entry.cs: English red a pigment prepared by the Dutch, similar to Indian red. Hypericum red a red resinous dyestuff extracted from Hypericum. Indian red. See under Indian, and Almagra.

sn.def: The color of blood, or of that part of the spectrum farthest from violet, or a tint resembling these.
sn.q: Celestial rosyred, love's proper hue.

sn.def: A red pigment.
An abbreviation for Red Republican. See under Red, a.
The menses.

entry.ety: L. redactus, p. p. of redigere; pref. red- re-, again, back + agere to put in motion, to drive
entry.def: To reduce to form, as literary matter; to digest and put in shape (matter for publication); to edit.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: See Redactor.

entry.ety: F. rédaction
entry.def: The act of redacting; work produced by redacting; a digest.
One who redacts; one who prepares matter for publication; an editor.

entry.ety: F., for OF. redent a double notching or jagging, as in the teeth of a saw, fr. L. pref. re- re- + dens dentis, a tooth. Cf. Redented

sn.def: A work having two parapets whose faces unite so as to form a salient angle toward the enemy.
A step or vertical offset in a wall on uneven ground, to keep the parts level.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Redargued -g?d; p. pr. & vb. n. Redarguing
entry.ety: L. redarguere; pref. red- re- re- + arguere to accuse, charge with: cf. F. rédarguer
entry.def: To disprove; to refute; toconfute; to reprove; to convict.
entry.q: How shall I . . . suffer that God should redargue me at doomsday, and the angels reproach my lukewarmness?
Now this objection to the immediate cognition of external objects has, as far as I know, been redargued in three different ways.

entry.ety: L. redargutio
entry.def: The act of redarguing; refutation.
Pertaining to, or containing, redargution; refutatory.
The dunlin.
The char.
The cardinal bird.
The summer redbird (Piranga rubra).
The scarlet tanager. See Tanager.

sd.def: The European robin.
The American robin. See Robin.
The knot, or red-breasted snipe; -- called also robin breast, and robin snipe. See Knot.

sn.def: The long-eared pondfish. See Pondfish.

entry.def: A small ornamental leguminous tree of the American species of the genus Cercis. See Judas tree, under Judas.

sn.def: The European goldfinch.
A specter having long teeth, popularly supposed to haunt old castles in Scotland.

entry.def: One who wears a red coat; specifically, a red-coated British soldier.

entries.entry:
Red Cross In islamic countries, a similarly motivated affiliated organization is called the Red Crescent. The American Red Cross was founded in 1881, largely due to the initiative of Clara Barton. The American Red Cross maintains a web page on the internet, where additional information can be found.. The crusaders or the cause they represented.
A hospital or ambulance service established as a result of, though not provided for by, the Geneva convention of 1864; any of the national societies for alleviating the sufferings of the sick and wounded war, also giving aid and relief during great calamities; also, a member or worker of such a society; -- so called from the badge of neutrality; the Geneva cross.

entry.def: obs. imp. of Read, or Rede.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reddened -d'nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Reddening
entry.ety: From Red a.
entry.def: To make red or somewhat red; to give a red color to.
To grow or become red; to blush.
entry.q: Appius reddens at each word you speak.
He no sooner saw that her eye glistened and her cheek reddened than his obstinacy was at once subbued.

entry.ety: Neut. of L. reddendus that must be given back or yielded, gerundive of reddere. See Reddition
entry.def: A clause in a deed by which some new thing is reserved out of what had been granted before; the clause by which rent is reserved in a lease.
Somewhat red; moderately red.

entry.ety: L. redditio, fr. reddere to give back, to return: cf. F. reddition. See Render

sn.def: Restoration: restitution: surrender.
Explanation; representation.
sn.q: The reddition or application of the comparison.

entry.ety: L. redditivus
entry.def: Answering to an interrogative or inquiry; conveying a reply; as, redditive words.

entry.ety: From Red; cf. G. röthel. Cf. Ruddle
entry.def: Red chalk. See under Chalk.

entries.entry: Red dogorRed`-dog" flour . The lowest grade of flour in milling. It is dark and of little expansive power, is secured largely from the germ or embryo and adjacent parts, and contains a relatively high percentage of protein. It is chiefly useful as feed for farm animals.

entry.ety: F. raideur, fr. raide stiff
entry.def: Rigor; violence.

entry.ety: See Read v. t.

sn.def: To advise or counsel.
sn.q: I rede that our host here shall begin.

sn.def: To interpret; to explain.
sn.q: My sweven [dreamrede aright.

entry.ety: See Read n.

sn.def: Advice; counsel; suggestion.
sn.q: There was none other remedy ne reed.

sn.def: A word or phrase; a motto; a proverb; a wise saw.
sn.q: Thisredeis rife.

cs.cd: to make the best use of it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Redeemed. (-d�md"); p. pr. & vb. n. Redeeming
entry.ety: F. rédimer, L. redimere; pref. red- re- re- + emere emptum, to buy, originally, to take, cf. OIr. emin comp.), Lith. imti. Cf. Assume Consume Exempt Premium Prompt Ransom

sn.def: To purchase back; to regain possession of by payment of a stipulated price; to repurchase.
sn.q: If a man sell a dwelling house in a walled city, then he may redeem it within a whole year after it is sold.

entry.sn:
Hence, specifically: Law To recall, as an estate, or to regain, as mortgaged property, by paying what may be due by force of the mortgage.
Com To regain by performing the obligation or condition stated; to discharge the obligation mentioned in, as a promissory note, bond, or other evidence of debt; as, to redeem bank notes with coin.

sn.def: To ransom, liberate, or rescue from captivity or bondage, or from any obligation or liability to suffer or to be forfeited, by paying a price or ransom; to ransom; to rescue; to recover; as, to redeem a captive, a pledge, and the like.
sn.q: Redeem Israel, O God, out of all his troubles.
The Almighty from the grave Hath me redeemed.

sn.def: Hence, to rescue and deliver from the bondage of sin and the penalties of God's violated law.
sn.q: Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us.

sn.def: To make good by performing fully; to fulfill; as, to redeem one's promises.
sn.q: I will redeem all this on Percy's head.

sn.def: To pay the penalty of; to make amends for; to serve as an equivalent or offset for; to atone for; to compensate; as, to redeem an error.
sn.q: Which of ye will be mortal, to redeem Man's mortal crime?
It is a chance which does redeem all sorrows.

entry.def: Redeemableness.

sn.def: Capable of being redeemed; subject to repurchase; held under conditions permitting redemption; as, a pledge securing the payment of money is redeemable .
Subject to an obligation of redemtion; conditioned upon a promise of redemtion; payable; due; as, bonds, promissory notes, etc. , redeemabble in gold, or in current money, or four months after date.

entry.def: The quality or state of being redeemable; redeemability.

sn.def: One who redeems.
Specifically, the Savior of the world, Jesus Christ.

entry.def: Without rede or counsel.
To deliberate again; to reconsider.

sn.def: To deliver or give back; to return.
To deliver or liberate a second time or again.
To report; to deliver the answer of.
sn.q: Shall Iredeliveryou e'en so?

entry.def: A second deliverance.

sn.def: Act of delivering back.
A second or new delivery or liberation.

entry.ety: Pref. re- back, again + demand: cf. F. redemander
entry.def: To demand back; to demand again.
A demanding back; a second or renewed demand.
To demise back; to convey or transfer back, as an estate.
The transfer of an estate back to the person who demised it; reconveyance; as, the demise and redemise of an estate. See under Demise.
To demonstrate again, or anew.
entry.q: Every truth of morals must be redemonstrated in the experience of the individual man before he is capable of utilizing it as a constituent of character or a guide in action.

entry.def: Redeemable.

entries.entry:
Re-demp"tion -sh?n n. F. rédemption, L. redemptio. See Redeem, and cf. Ransom
The act of redeeming, or the state of being redeemed; repurchase; ransom; release; rescue; deliverance; as, the redemption of prisoners taken in war; the redemption of a ship and cargo. Specifically: Law The liberation of an estate from a mortgage, or the taking back of property mortgaged, upon performance of the terms or conditions on which it was conveyed; also, the right of redeeming and reëntering upon an estate mortgaged. See Equity of redemption, under Equity. Com Performance of the obligation stated in a note, bill, bond, or other evidence of debt, by making payment to the holder. Theol The procuring of God's favor by the sufferings and death of Christ; the ransom or deliverance of sinners from the bondage of sin and the penalties of God's violated law. In whom we have redemption through his blood.

entry.def: One who is, or may be, redeemed.

sn.def: One who redeems himself, as from debt or servitude.
Formerly, one who, wishing to emigrate from Europe to America, sold his services for a stipulated time to pay the expenses of his passage.

entry.def: A monk of an order founded in 1197; -- so called because the order was especially devoted to the redemption of Christians held in captivity by the Mohammedans. Called also Trinitarian.
Serving or tending to redeem; redeeming; as, the redemptive work of Christ.

entry.ety: F. rédemptoriste, fr. L. redemptor redeemer, from redinere. See Redeem
entry.def: One of the Congregation of the Most Holy Redeemer, founded in Naples in 1732 by St. Alphonsus Maria de Liquori. It was introduced onto the United States in 1832 at Detroit. The Fathers of the Congregation devote themselves to preaching to the neglected, esp. in missions and retreats, and are forbidden by their rule to engage in the instruction of youth.
Paid for ransom; serving to redeem.
entry.q: Hector'sredemptoryprice.

entry.def: Redemption.

entry.ety: From OF. redent. See Redan
entry.def: Formed like the teeth of a saw; indented.
To deposit again.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + descend: cf. F. redescendre
entry.def: To descend again.

sn.def: To develop again;
to intensify (a developed image), as by bleaching with mercuric chloride and subsequently subjecting anew to a developing agent.
to rebuild an urban area, usually commercial but sometimes residential; -- typically involving some portion of government involvement and expenditure.

entry.def: the rebuilding of an urban area, usually a commercial district but sometimes residential or industrial, and typically involving some portion of government involvement and expenditure; to organize a municipal redevelopment agency.

sd.def: The rudd.
Same as Redfish.
The goggle-eye, or fresh-water rock bass.

sn.def: A scheduled public conveyance, such as a train or airplane, which travels late at night or overnight.

entry.def: A small North American dace (Minnilus cornutus, or Notropis megalops). The male, in the breeding season, has bright red fins. Called also red dace, and shiner. Applied also to Notropis ardens, of the Mississippi valley.
The European linnet.
The blueback salmon of the North Pacific; -- called also nerka. See Blueback.
The rosefish.
A large California labroid food fish (Trochocopus pulcher); -- called also fathead.
The red bass, red drum, or drumfish. See the Note under Drumfish.

entry.ety: OE. reed gounde; AS. reád red + gund matter, pus

sn.def: An eruption of red pimples upon the face, neck, and arms, in early infancy; tooth rash; strophulus.
A name of rust on grain. See Rust.

entry.def: Having hands red with blood; in the very act, as if with red or bloody hands; -- said of a person taken in the act of homicide; hence, fresh from the commission of crime; as, he was taken red-hand or red-handed .

sn.def: A person having red hair.

sd.def: An American duck (Aythya Americana) highly esteemed as a game bird. It is closely allied to the canvasback, but is smaller and its head brighter red. Called also red-headed duck. American poachard grayback, and fall duck. See Illust. under Poachard.
The red-headed woodpecker. See Woodpecker.

sn.def: A kind of milkweed (Asclepias Curassavica) with red flowers. It is used in medicine.

entry.ety: L. redhibitio a taking back
entry.def: The annulling of a sale, and the return by the buyer of the article sold, on account of some defect.

entry.ety: L. redhibitorius
entry.def: Of or pertaining to redhibition; as, a redhibitory action or fault.
The male of the European bullfinch.
Any species of a tribe of butterflies (Fugacia) including the common yellow species and the cabbage butterflies. The antennæ are usually red.
Red with heat; heated to redness; as, red-hot iron; red-hot balls. Hence, figuratively, excited; violent; as, a red-hot radical.

entries.entry: ‖Re"di*a r?"d?*? n.; pl. L. Rediæ-ē), E. Redias -�z. NL.; of uncertain origin Zoöl A kind of larva, or nurse, which is prroduced within the sporocyst of certain trematodes by asexual generation. It in turn produces, in the same way, either another generation of rediæ, or else cercariæ within its own body. Called also proscolex, and nurse. See Illustration in Appendix.

entry.ety: L. rediens, p. pr. of redire to return; pref. red- + ire to go
entry.def: Returning.

entry.ety: Turk. redīf, fr. radīf, orig., he who rides behind another on the same beast, fr. radaf to follow
entry.def: A reserve force in the Turkish army, or a soldier of the reserve. See Army organization, above.
To digest, or reduce to form, a second time.
To diminish again.

entry.ety: F., corrupted from E. riding coat
entry.def: A long plain double-breasted outside coat for women.

entry.ety: L. redintegratus, p. p. of redintegrare to restore; pref. red- re-, re- + integrare to make whole, to renew, fr. integer whole. See Integer
entry.def: Restored to wholeness or a perfect state; renewed.
To make whole again; a renew; to restore to integrity or soundness.
entry.q: The English nation seems obliterated. What could redintegrate us again?

entry.ety: L. redintegratio

sn.def: Restoration to a whole or sound state; renewal; renovation.
Restoration of a mixed body or matter to its former nature and state.

The law that objects which have been previously combined as part of a single mental state tend to recall or suggest one another; -- adopted by many philosophers to explain the phenomena of the association of ideas.

entry.def: Applied to the examination of a witness, by the party calling him, after the cross-examination.
To disburse anew; to give, or pay, back.
To discover again.
To dispose anew or again; to readjust; to rearrange.
To disseize anew, or a second time.
A disseizin by one who once before was adjudged to have dassezed the same person of the same lands, etc.; also, a writ which lay in such a case.
One who redisseizes.
To dissolve again.
To distill again.
One who distrains again.
To distribute again.
To divide into new districts.

entry.ety: L. reditio, fr. redire. See Redient
entry.def: Act of returning; return.
To divide anew.

entry.ety: L., fr. pref. red- re-, re- + vivus alive
entry.def: Living again; revived; restored.
The redshank.
The turnstone.
