entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Relumed -l?md"; p. pr. & vb. n. Reluming
entry.ety: OF. relumercf. F. rallumer), L. reluminare; pref. re- re- + luminare to light. Cf. Reillume
entry.def: To rekindle; to light again.
entry.q: Relumed her ancient light, not kindled new.
I know not where is that Promethean heat That can thy light relume.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Relumined -m?nd; p. pr. & vb. n. Relumining
entry.ety: See Relume

sn.def: To light anew; to rekindle.
To illuminate again.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Relied -l?d"; p. pr. & vb. n. Relying
entry.ety: Pref. re- + lie to rest
entry.def: To rest with confidence, as when fully satisfied of the veracity, integrity, or ability of persons, or of the certainty of facts or of evidence; to have confidence; to trust; to depend; -- with on, formerly also with in.
entry.q: Go in thy native innocence; rely On what thou hast of virtue.
On some fond breast the parting soul relies.
entry.syn: To trust; depend; confide; repose.

entry.def: imp. & p. p. of Remake.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Remained -m?nd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Remaining
entry.ety: OF. remaindre remanoir, L. remanere; pref. re- re- + manere to stay, remain. See Mansion, and cf. Remainder Remnant

sn.def: To stay behind while others withdraw; to be left after others have been removed or destroyed; to be left after a number or quantity has been subtracted or cut off; to be left as not included or comprised.
sn.q: Gather up the fragments that remain.
Of whom the greater part remain unto this present, but some are fallen asleep.
That . . . remains to be proved.

sn.def: To continue unchanged in place, form, or condition, or undiminished in quantity; to abide; to stay; to endure; to last.
sn.q: Remain a widow at thy father's house.
Childless thou art; childless remain.
sn.syn: To continue; stay; wait; tarry; rest; sojourn; dwell; abide; last; endure.

entry.def: To await; to be left to.
entry.q: The easier conquest now remains thee.

sn.def: State of remaining; stay.
sn.q: Which often, since my here remain in England, I 've seen him do.

sn.def: That which is left; relic; remainder; -- chiefly in the plural.
sn.q: Theremainsof old Rome.
When this remain of horror has entirely subsided.

sd.def: That which is left of a human being after the life is gone; relics; a dead body.
sd.q: Old warriors whose adored remains In weeping vaults her hallowed earth contains!

sn.sd: The posthumous works or productions, esp. literary works, of one who is dead; as, Cecil's Remains.

entry.ety: OF. remaindre, inf. See Remain

sn.def: Anything that remains, or is left, after the separation and removal of a part; residue; remnant.
sn.q: The lastremaindersof unhappy Troy.
If these decoctions be repeated till the water comes off clear, the remainder yields no salt.

sn.def: The quantity or sum that is left after subtraction, or after any deduction.

An estate in expectancy, generally in land, which becomes an estate in possession upon the determination of a particular prior estate, created at the same time, and by the same instrument; for example, if land be conveyed to A for life, and on his death to B, A's life interest is a particuar estate, and B's interest is a remainder, or estate in remainder.
sn.syn: Balance; rest; residue; remnant; leavings.

entry.def: Remaining; left; left over; refuse.
entry.q: Which is as dry as the remainder biscuit After a voyage.

entries.entry: Re*main"der-man - măn n.; pl.Remainder-men -mĕn. Law One who has an estate after a particular estate is determined. See Remainder n., 3.

entry.def: To make anew.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Remanded; p. pr. & vb. n. Remanding
entry.ety: F. remander to send word again, L. remandare; pref. re- re- + mandare to commit, order, send word. See Mandate
entry.def: To recommit; to send back.
entry.q: Remand it to its former place.
Then were they remanded to the cage again.

entry.def: The act of remanding; the order for recommitment.
A remand.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. remanence, LL. remanentia, fr. L. remanens. See Remanent a.
entry.def: The state of being remanent; continuance; permanence.
entry.q: The remanence of the will in the fallen spirit.

entry.ety: See Remanent a.
entry.def: That which remains; a remnant; a residue.

cs.cd: magnetism which remains in a body that has little coercive force after the magnetizing force is withdrawn, as soft iron; -- called also residual magnetism.

entry.ety: L. remanens, p. pr. of remanere. See Remain, and cf. Remnant
entry.def: Remaining; residual.
entry.q: That little hope that is remanent hath its degree according to the infancy or growth of the habit.

entry.ety: L., it remains
entry.def: A case for trial which can not be tried during the term; a postponed case.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + mark
entry.def: To mark again, or a second time; to mark anew.

entry.usage: Remark Observe Notice. To observe is to keep or hold a thing distinctly before the mind. To remark is simply to mark or take note of whatever may come up. To notice implies still less continuity of attention. When we turn from these mental states to the expression of them in language, we find the same distinction. An observation is properly the result of somewhat prolonged thought; a remark is usually suggested by some passing occurence; a notice is in most cases something cursory and short. This distinction is not always maintained as to remark and observe, which are often used interchangeably. “Observing men may form many judgments by the rules of similitude and proportion.” I. Watts. ”He can not distinguish difficult and noble speculations from trifling and vulgar remarks.” Collier. ”The thing to be regarded, in taking notice of a child's miscarriage, is what root it springs from.” Locke.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Remarked -m?rkt"; p. pr. & vb. n. Remarking
entry.ety: F. remarquer; pref. re- re- + marquer to mark, marque a mark, of German origin, akin to E. mark. See Mark v. & n.

sn.def: To mark in a notable manner; to distinquish clearly; to make noticeable or conspicuous; to piont out.
sn.q: Thou art a man remarked to taste a mischief.
His manacles remark him; there he sits.

sn.def: To take notice of, or to observe, mentally; as, to remark the manner of a speaker.
To express in words or writing, as observed or noticed; to state; to say; -- often with a substantive clause; as, he remarked that it was time to go.
sn.syn: To observe; notice; heed; regard; note; say.

entry.def: To make a remark or remarks; to comment.

entry.ety: Cf. F. remarque

sn.def: Act of remarking or attentively noticing; notice or observation.
sn.q: The cause, though worth the search, may yet elude Conjecture and remark, however shrewd.

sn.def: The expression, in speech or writing, of something remarked or noticed; the mention of that which is worthy of attention or notice; hence, also, a casual observation, comment, or statement; as, a pertinent remark .
sn.syn: Observation; note; comment; annotation.

entry.ety: F. remarquable
entry.def: Worthy of being remarked or noticed; noticeable; conspicuous; hence, uncommon; extraordinary.
entry.q: 'T is remarkable, that they Talk most who have the least to say.
There is nothing left remarlable Beneath the visiting moon.
entry.syn: Observable; noticeable; extraordinary; unusual; rare; strange; wonderful; notable; eminent.

entry.def: One who remarks.

entries.entry: Re*marque" n. Also Remark . Engraving A small design etched on the margin of a plate and supposed to be removed after the earliest proofs have been taken; also, any feature distinguishing a particular stage of the plate. A print or proof so distinguished; -- commonly called a Remarque proof .

entry.def: A second or repeated marriage.
To marry again.
To furnish with a new mast or set of masts.
To chew or masticate again; to chew over and over, as the cud.
The act of masticating or chewing again or repeatedly.
See Ramberge.

entry.ety: F., fr. remblayer to fill up an excavation, to embank
entry.def: Earth or materials made into a bank after having been excavated.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. embler to steal, fr. L. involare to fly into or at, to carry off
entry.def: To remove.
Realm.
To give meaning to; to explain the meaning of; to interpret.

entry.ety: L. remeans -antis, p. pr. of remeare to go or come back
entry.def: Coming back; returning.
entry.q: Like theremeantsun.

entry.def: To measure again; to retrace.
entry.q: They followed him . . . The way they came, their steps remeasured right.

entry.def: Remedy.

entry.ety: L. remediabilis: cf. F. remédiable
entry.def: Capable of being remedied or cured.

entry.ety: L. remedialis
entry.def: Affording a remedy; intended for a remedy, or for the removal or abatement of an evil; as, remedial treatment.
entry.q: Statutes are declaratory or remedial.
It is an evil not compensated by any beneficial result; it is not remedial, not conservative.

entry.def: In a remedial manner.
Remedial.

sn.def: Not admitting of a remedy; incapable of being restored or corrected; incurable; irreparable; as, a remediless mistake or loss.
sn.q: Chainsremedilesse.
Hopeless are all my evils, all remediless.

sn.def: Not answering as a remedy; ineffectual.
sn.q: Forced to forego the attempt remediless.
sn.syn: Incurable; cureless; irremediable; irrecoverable; irretrievable; irreparable; desperate.

entries.entry:
Rem"e*dy
Civil remedy. See under Civil. Remedy of the mint Coinage a small allowed deviation from the legal standard of weight and fineness; -- called also tolerance.
r?m"?-d? n.; pl.Remedies -d�z. L. remedium; pref. re- re- + mederi to heal, to cure: cf. F. remède remedy, remédier to remedy. See Medical
That which relieves or cures a disease; any medicine or application which puts an end to disease and restores health; -- with for; as, a remedy for the gout.
That which corrects or counteracts an evil of any kind; a corrective; a counteractive; reparation; cure; -- followed by for or against, formerly by to. What may else be remedy or cure To evils which our own misdeeds have wrought, He will instruct us.
Law The legal means to recover a right, or to obtain redress for a wrong. Cure; restorative; counteraction; reparation; redress; relief; aid; help; assistance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Remedied -d?d; p. pr. & vb. n. Remedying
entry.ety: L. remediare remediari: cf. F. remédier. See Remedy n.
entry.def: To apply a remedy to; to relieve; to cure; to heal; to repair; to redress; to correct; to counteract.
entry.q: I will remedy this gear ere long.

entry.def: To melt again.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Remembered -b?rd; p. pr. & vb. n. Remembering
entry.ety: OF. remebrer, L. rememorari; pref. re- re- + memorare to bring to remembrance, from memor mindful. See Memory, and cf. Rememorate

sn.def: To have (a notion or idea) come into the mind again, as previously perceived, known, or felt; to have a renewed apprehension of; to bring to mind again; to think of again; to recollect; as, I remember the fact; he remembers the events of his childhood; I cannot remember dates.
sn.q: We are said to remember anything, when the idea of it arises in the mind with the consciousness that we have had this idea before.

sn.def: To be capable of recalling when required; to keep in mind; to be continually aware or thoughtful of; to preserve fresh in the memory; to attend to; to think of with gratitude, affection, respect, or any other emotion.
sn.q: Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy.
That they may have their wages duly paid 'em, And something over to remember me by.
Remember what I warn thee; shun to taste.

sn.def: To put in mind; to remind; -- also used reflexively and impersonally.
sn.q: Rememberingthem the trith of what they themselves known.
My friends remembered me of home.
Remember you of passed heaviness.
And well thou wost [knowest] if it remember thee.

sn.def: To mention.
sn.q: As in many cases hereafter to beremembered.

sn.def: To recall to the mind of another, as in the friendly messages, remember me to him, he wishes to be remembered to you, etc.

entry.def: To execise or have the power of memory; as, some remember better than others.
Capable or worthy of being remembered.
entry.q: The whole vale of Keswick is so rememberable.

entry.def: One who remembers.

entry.ety: OF. remembrance

sn.def: The act of remembering; a holding in mind, or bringing to mind; recollection.
sn.q: Lest fierce remembrance wake my sudden rage.
Lest the remembrance of his grief should fail.

sn.def: The state of being remembered, or held in mind; memory; recollection.
sn.q: This, ever grateful, in remembrance bear.

sn.def: Something remembered; a person or thing kept in memory.
That which serves to keep in or bring to mind; a memorial; a token; a memento; a souvenir; a memorandum or note of something to be remembered.
sn.q: And on his breast a bloody cross he bore, The dear remembrance of his dying Lord.
Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.

sn.def: Something to be remembered; counsel; admoni��on; instruction.
Power of remembering; reach of personal knowledge; period over which one's memory extends.
sn.q: Thee I have heard relating what was done Ere my remembrance.
sn.syn: Recollection; reminiscence. See Memory.

sn.def: One who, or that which, serves to bring to, or keep in, mind; a memento; a memorial; a reminder.
sn.q: Premature consiolation is but the remembrancer of sorrow.
Ye that are the lord's remembrancers.

sn.def: A term applied in England to several officers, having various functions, their duty originally being to bring certain matters to the attention of the proper persons at the proper time.
sn.q: Theremembrancerof the lord treasurer in the exchequer.

entry.ety: L. rememoratus, p. p. of rememorari. See Remember
entry.def: To recall something by means of memory; to remember.

entry.ety: F. remémoration, or L. rememoratio
entry.def: A recalling by the faculty of memory; remembrance.
Tending or serving to remind.
A remnant.

entry.ety: F. remercier; pref. re- re- + OF. mercier to thank, from OF. & F. merci. See Mercy
entry.def: To thank.
entry.q: She him remercied as the patron of her life.

entry.def: To merge again.
entry.q: Remergingin the general Soul.

entry.def: To remove.

entry.ety: L. remus oar + -form
entry.def: Shaped like an oar.

entries.entry: ‖Rem"i*ges r?m"?*j?z n. pl.; sing. Remex. (r�"m�ks. L. remex -igis, an oarsman Zoöl The quill feathers of the wings of a bird.

entry.ety: L. remigrare. See Re-, and Migrate
entry.def: To migrate again; to go back; to return.
Migration back to the place from which one came.
To put (one) in mind of something; to bring to the remembrance of; to bring to the notice or consideration of (a person).
entry.q: When age itself, which will not be defied, shall begin to arrest, seize, and remind us of our mortality.

entry.def: One who, or that which, reminds; that which serves to awaken remembrance.
Tending or adapted to remind; careful to remind.

entry.ety: F. réminiscence, L. reminiscentia

sn.def: The act or power of recalling past experience; the state of being reminiscent; remembrance; memory.
sn.q: The other part of memory, called reminiscence, which is the retrieving of a thing at present forgot, or but confusedly remembered.
I forgive your want of reminiscence, since it is long since I saw you.

sn.def: That which is remembered, or recalled to mind; a statement or narration of remembered experience; a recollection; as, pleasing or painful reminiscences .
sn.syn: Remembrance; recollection. See Memory.

entry.def: Reminiscence.

entry.ety: L. reminiscens -entis, p. pr. of reminisci to recall to mind, to recollect; pref. re- re + a word akin to mens mind, memini I remember. See Mind
entry.def: Recalling to mind, or capable of recalling to mind; having remembrance; reminding one of something.
entry.q: Some other of existence of which we have been previously conscious, and are now reminiscent.

entry.def: One who is addicted to indulging, narrating, or recording reminiscences.
Of or pertaining to reminiscence, or remembrance.

entry.ety: L. remus oar + pes pedis, foot: cf. F. rémipède
entry.def: Having feet or legs that are used as oars; -- said of certain crustaceans and insects.
An animal having limbs like oars, especially one of certain crustaceans.
One of a group of aquatic beetles having tarsi adapted for swimming. See Water beetle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Remised -m?zd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Remising
entry.ety: F. remise delivery, surrender, fr. remettre to put back, deliver, L. remittere. See Remit
entry.def: To send, give, or grant back; to release a claim to; to resign or surrender by deed; to return.
A giving or granting back; surrender; return; release, as of a claim.

sn.def: A house for covered carriages; a chaise house.
A livery carriage of a kind superior to an ordinary fiacre; -- so called because kept in a remise.

entry.ety: L. remissus, p. p. of remittere to send back, relax. See Remit
entry.def: Not energetic or exact in duty or business; not careful or prompt in fulfilling engagements; negligent; careless; tardy; behindhand; lagging; slack; hence, lacking earnestness or activity; languid; slow.
entry.q: Thou never wast remiss, I bear thee witness.
These nervous, bold; those languid and remiss.
Its motion becomes more languid and remiss.
entry.syn: Slack; dilatory; slothful; negligent; careless; neglectful; inattentive; heedles; thoughtless.

entry.def: The act of being remiss; inefficiency; failure.
entry.q: Remissesof laws.

entry.def: Inclined to remit punishment; lenient; clement.
The state or quality of being remissible.

entry.ety: L. remissibilis: cf. F. rémissible. See Remit
entry.def: Capable of being remitted or forgiven.

entry.ety: F. rémission, L. remissio. See Remit

sn.def: The act of remitting, surrendering, resigning, or giving up.
Discharge from that which is due; relinquishment of a claim, right, or obligation; pardon of transgression; release from forfeiture, penalty, debt, etc.
sn.q: This is my blood of the new testament, which is shed for many for the remission of sins.
That ples, therefore, . . . Will gain thee no remission.

sn.def: Diminution of intensity; abatement; relaxation.
A temporary and incomplete subsidence of the force or violence of a disease or of pain, as destinguished from intermission, in which the disease completely leaves the patient for a time; abatement.
The act of sending back.
Act of sending in payment, as money; remittance.

entry.ety: L. remissivus. See Remit
entry.def: Remitting; forgiving; abating.
In a remiss or negligent manner; carelessly.
Quality or state of being remiss.
Serving or tending to remit, or to secure remission; remissive.
entry.q: A sacrifice expiatory orremissory.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Remitted; p. pr. & vb. n. Remitting
entry.ety: L. remittere remissum, to send back, to slacken, relax; pref. re- re- + mittere to send. See Mission, and cf. Remise Remiss

sn.def: To send back; to give up; to surrender; to resign.
sn.q: In the case the law remits him to his ancient and more certain right.
In grevious and inhuman crimes, offenders should be remitted to their prince.
The prisoner was remitted to the guard.

sn.def: To restore.
sn.q: The archbishop was . . . remitted to his liberty.

sn.def: To transmit or send, esp. to a distance, as money in payment of a demand, account, draft, etc.; as, he remitted the amount by mail.

To send off or away; hence: To refer or direct (one) for information, guidance, help, etc. “Remitting them . . . to the works of Galen.” Sir T. Elyot. To submit, refer, or leave (something) for judgment or decision.
sn.q: Whether the counsel be good Iremitit to the wise readers.

sn.def: To relax in intensity; to make less violent; to abate.
sn.q: So willingly doth God remit his ire.

sn.def: To forgive; to pardon; to remove.
sn.q: Whose soever sins ye remit, they are remitted unto them.

sn.def: To refrain from exacting or enforcing; as, to remit the performance of an obligation.
sn.q: The sovereign was undoubtedly competent toremitpenalties.
sn.syn: To relax; release; abate; relinguish; forgive; pardon; absolve.

sn.def: To abate in force or in violence; to grow less intense; to become moderated; to abate; to relax; as, a fever remits; the severity of the weather remits.
To send money, as in payment.

entry.def: The act of remitting, or the state of being remitted; remission.
entry.q: Disavowing the remitment of Claudius.

entry.def: A remitting; a giving up; surrender; as, the remittal of the first fruits.

sn.def: The act of transmitting money, bills, or the like, esp. to a distant place, as in satisfaction of a demand, or in discharge of an obligation.
The sum or thing remitted.

entry.def: One to whom a remittance is sent.

cs.cd: a fever in which the symptoms temporarily abate at regular intervals, but do not wholly cease. See Malarial fever, under Malarial.

entry.ety: L. remittens, p. pr. : cf. F. rémittent
entry.def: Remitting; characterized by remission; having remissions.

sn.def: One who remits.

sd.def: One who pardons.
One who makes remittance.

sn.def: The sending or placing back of a person to a title or right he had before; the restitution of one who obtains possession of property under a defective title, to his rights under some valid title by virtue of which he might legally have entered into possession only by suit.

entry.ety: L., (it) is remitted
entry.def: A remission or surrender,remittitur damnut being a remission of excess of damages.
A sending back, as when a record is remitted by a superior to an inferior court.
One who makes a remittance; a remitter.
To mix again or repeatedly.

entry.ety: OF. remanant, p. pr. of remanoir remaindre. See Remanent Remain
entry.def: Remaining; yet left.
entry.q: Because of theremnantdregs of his disease.
And quiet dedicate her remnant life To the just duties of an humble wife.

entry.ety: OF. remanant. See Remnant a.

sn.def: That which remains after a part is removed, destroyed, used up, performed, etc.; residue.
sn.q: The remnant that are left of the captivity.
The remnant of my tale is of a length To tire your patience.

sn.def: A small portion; a slight trace; a fragment; a little bit; a scrap.
sn.q: Some odd quirks and remnants of wit.

sn.def: An unsold end of piece goods, as cloth, ribbons, carpets, etc.
sn.syn: Residue; rest; remains; remainder.

entry.def: To model or fashion anew; to change the form of.
entry.q: The corporation had been remodeled.

entry.def: The act of remodifying; the state of being remodified.
To modify again or anew; to reshape.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: A kind of piquant sauce or salad dressing resembling mayonnaise.
An ointment used in farriery.

entry.def: To mold or shape anew or again; to reshape.

entry.ety: L. remolliens, p. pr. of remollire to mollify: cf. F. rémollient. See Mollient
entry.def: Mollifying; softening.
The act of remonetizing.
To restore to use as money; as, to remonetize silver.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. remonstrance, F. remonstrance. See Remonstrate
entry.sn:
The act of remonstrating; as: A pointing out; manifestation; proof; demonstration. Obs You may marvel why I . . . would not rather Make rash remonstrance of my hidden power Than let him be so lost.
Earnest presentation of reason in opposition to something; protest; expostulation.

sn.def: Same as Monstrance.

entry.ety: LL. remonstranc -antis, p. pr. of remonstrare: cf. OF. remonstrant, F. remontrant
entry.def: Inclined or tending to remonstrate; expostulatory; urging reasons in opposition to something.

entries.entry: Re*mon"strant n. One who remonstrates; specifically Eccl. Hist one of the Arminians who remonstrated against the attacks of the Calvinists in 1610, but were subsequently condemned by the decisions of the Synod of Dort in 1618. See Arminian.

entry.def: In a remonstrant manner.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Remonstrated -str�*t�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Remonstrating
entry.ety: LL. remonstratus, p. p. of remonstrare to remonstrate; L. pref. re- + monstrare to show. See Monster
entry.def: To point out; to show clearly; to make plain or manifest; hence, to prove; to demonstrate.
entry.q: I will remonstrate to you the third door.

entry.usage: These words are commonly interchangeable, the principal difference being that expostulate is now used especially to signify remonstrance by a superior or by one in authority. A son remonstrates against the harshness of a father; a father expostulates with his son on his waywardness. Subjects remonstrate with their rulers; sovereigns expostulate with the parliament or the people.
entry.def: To present and urge reasons in opposition to an act, measure, or any course of proceedings; to expostulate; as, to remonstrate with a person regarding his habits; to remonstrate against proposed taxation.
entry.q: It is proper business of a divine to state cases of conscience, and to remonstrate against any growing corruptions in practice, and especially in principles.
entry.syn: Expostulate Remonstrate.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. remonstration, LL. remonstratio
entry.def: The act of remonstrating; remonstrance.
Having the character of a remonstrance; expressing remonstrance.
One who remonstrates; a remonsrant.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Rising again; -- applied to a class of roses which bloom more than once in a season; the hybrid perpetual roses, of which the Jacqueminot is a well-known example.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: See under Escapement.

entry.note: ☞ The anterior dorsal fin is converted into a large sucking disk, having two transverse rows of lamellæ, situated on the top of the head. They adhere firmly to sharks and other large fishes and to vessels by this curious sucker, letting go at will. The pegador, or remora of sharks (Echeneis naucrates), and the swordfish remora (Remora brachyptera), are common American species.
entry.ety: L.: cf. F. rémora

sn.def: Delay; obstacle; hindrance.
Any one of several species of fishes belonging to Echeneis Remora, and allied genera. Called also sucking fish.
An instrument formerly in use, intended to retain parts in their places.

entry.ety: L. remoratus, p. p. of remorari; pref. re- re- + morari to delay
entry.def: To hinder; to delay.

entry.ety: L. remordere to bite again, to torment: cf. F. remordre. See Remorse
entry.def: To excite to remorse; to rebuke.
To feel remorse.
Remorse; compunction; compassion.

entry.ety: OE. remors, OF. remors,F. remords, LL. remorsus, fr. L. remordere remorsum, to bite again or back, to torment; pref. re- re- + mordere to bite. See Morsel

sn.def: The anguish, like gnawing pain, excited by a sense of guilt; compunction of conscience for a crime committed, or for the sins of one's past life.
sn.q: Nero will be tainted withremorse.

sn.def: Sympathetic sorrow; pity; compassion.
sn.q: Curse on the unpardoning prince, whom tears can draw To no remorse.
But evermore it seem'd an easier thing At once without remorse to strike her dead.
sn.syn: Compunction; regret; anguish; grief; compassion. See Compunction.

entry.def: Feeling remorse.

sn.def: Full of remorse.
sn.q: The full tide of remorseful passion had abated.

sn.def: Compassionate; feeling tenderly.
Exciting pity; pitiable.

entry.def: Being without remorse; having no pity; hence, destitute of sensibility; cruel; insensible to distress; merciless.
entry.q: Remorselessadversaries.
Withremorselesscruelty.
entry.syn: Unpitying; pitiless; relentless; unrelenting; implacable; merciless; unmerciful; savage; cruel.

entry.ety: L. remotus, p. p. of removere to remove. See Remove

sn.def: Removed to a distance; not near; far away; distant; -- said in respect to time or to place; as, remote ages; remote lands.
sn.q: Places remote enough are in Bohemia.
Remote from men, with God he passed his days.

entry.sn:
Hence, removed; not agreeing, according, or being related; -- in various figurative uses. Specifically: Not agreeing; alien; foreign. All these propositions, howremotesoever from reason. Locke.
Not nearly related; not close; as, a remote connection or consanguinity.
Separate; abstracted. Wherever the mind places itself by any thought, either amongst, orremotefrom, all bodies. Locke.
Not proximate or acting directly; primary; distant. From the effect to theremotestcause. Granville.
Not obvious or sriking; as, a remote resemblance.

sn.def: Separated by intervals greater than usual.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Removed -m??vd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Removing
entry.ety: OF. removoir remouvoir, L. removere remotum; pref. re- re- + movere to move. See Move

sn.def: To move away from the position occupied; to cause to change place; to displace; as, to remove a building.
sn.q: Thou shalt not remove thy neighbor's landmark.
When we had dined, to prevent the ladies' leaving us, I generally ordered the table to be removed.

sn.def: To cause to leave a person or thing; to cause to cease to be; to take away; hence, to banish; to destroy; to put an end to; to kill; as, to remove a disease.
sn.q: King Richard thusremoved.

sn.def: To dismiss or discharge from office; as, the President removed many postmasters.

entry.note: ☞ The verb remove, in some of its application, is synonymous with move, but not in all. Thus we do not apply remove to a mere change of posture, without a change of place or the seat of a thing. A man moves his head when he turns it, or his finger when he bends it, but he does not remove it. Remove usually or always denotes a change of place in a body, but we never apply it to a regular, continued course or motion. We never say the wind or water, or a ship, removes at a certain rate by the hour; but we say a ship was removed from one place in a harbor to another. Move is a generic term, including the sense of remove, which is more generally applied to a change from one station or permanent position, stand, or seat, to another station.
entry.def: To change place in any manner, or to make a change in place; to move or go from one residence, position, or place to another.
entry.q: Till Birnam wood remove to Dunsinane, I can not taint with fear.

sn.def: The act of removing; a removal.
sn.q: This place should be at once both school and university, not needing a remove to any other house of scholarship.
And drags at each remove a lengthening chain.

sn.def: The transfer of one's business, or of one's domestic belongings, from one location or dwelling house to another; -- in the United States usually called a move.
sn.q: It is an English proverb that three removes are as bad as a fire.

sn.def: The state of being removed.
That which is removed, as a dish removed from table to make room for something else.

The distance or space through which anything is removed; interval; distance; stage; hence, a step or degree in any scale of gradation; specifically, a division in an English public school; as, the boy went up two removes last year.
sn.q: A freeholder is but one remove from a legislator.

sn.def: The act of resetting a horse's shoe.
Changed in place.
Dismissed from office.

entries.entry:
‖Re*nais`sance" F. r�-n�`säNs"; E. r�-nās"s�ns n. F., fr. renaître to be born again. Cf. Renascence
A new birth, or revival. Specifically: The transitional movement in Europe, marked by the revival of classical learning and art in Italy in the 15th century, and the similar revival following in other countries. The style of art which prevailed at this epoch. The Renaissance was rather the last stage of the Middle Ages, emerging from ecclesiastical and feudal despotism, developing what was original in mediæval ideas by the light of classic arts and letters.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Renaissance.

entries.entry: Ren"der*ing n. The act of one who renders, or that which is rendered. Specifically: A version; translation; as, the rendering of the Hebrew text. Lowth. In art, the presentation, expression, or interpretation of an idea, theme, or part. The act of laying the first coat of plaster on brickwork or stonework. The coat of plaster thus laid on. Gwilt. The process of trying out or extracting lard, tallow, etc., from animal fat.

Ren"dez*vous Rare in the plural r?n"d?*v� orr?n"-; 277 n.; pl.Rendezvouses r�n"d�-v�`z�z. F. rendez-vous, properly, render yourselves, repair to a place. See Render
A place appointed for a meeting, or at which persons customarily meet. An inn, the free rendezvous of all travelers.
Especially, the appointed place for troops, or for the ships of a fleet, to assemble; also, a place for enlistment. The king appointed his whole army to be drawn together to a rendezvous at Marlborough.

One faithless to principle or party. Specifically: An apostate from Christianity or from any form of religious faith. James justly regarded these renegades as the most serviceable tools that he could employ. One who deserts from a military or naval post; a deserter. Arbuthnot. A common vagabond; a worthless or wicked fellow.

entry.cs: Cheese rennet. Bot See under Cheese. Rennet ferment Physiol. Chem the enzyme rennin, present in rennet and in variable quantity in the gastric juice of most animals, which has the power of curdling milk. The enzyme presumably acts by changing the casein of milk from a soluble to an insoluble form. Rennet stomach Anat the fourth stomach, or abomasum, of ruminants.

an infusion or preparation of the calf stomach lining, used for coagulating milk. The active principle in this coagulating action is the enzyme rennin.

entry.q: Pressed milkrenneted.

entry.def: Same as 1st Rennet.
A milk-clotting enzyme obtained from the true stomach (abomasum) of a suckling calf. Mol. wt. about 31,000. Also called chymosin rennase, and abomasal enzyme.
See 2d Rennet.
entry.q: Asses' milk is holden for to be thickest, and therefore they use it instead of renning, to turn milk.

cs.cd: to decline to act as the executor of a will.

entry.usage: Renounce Abjure Recant. -- To renounce is to make an affirmative declaration of abandonment. To abjure is to renounce with, or as with, the solemnity of an oath. To recant is to renounce or abjure some proposition previously affirmed and maintained.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Renounced -nounst"; p. pr. & vb. n. Renouncing -noun"s?ng

sn.def: To declare against; to reject or decline formally; to refuse to own or acknowledge as belonging to one; to disclaim; as, to renounce a title to land or to a throne.
To cast off or reject deliberately; to disown; to dismiss; to forswear.
sn.q: This world I do renounce, and in your sights Shake patiently my great affliction off.

Either to die the death, or to abjure Forever the society of man.
Ease would recant Vows made in pain, as violent and void.

sn.q: He of my sons who fails to make it good, By one rebellious act renounces to my blood.

sn.q: Dryden died without a will, and his widow having renounced, his son Charles administered on June 10.

entry.ety: Cf. F. renoncement
entry.def: The act of disclaiming or rejecting; renunciation.
One who renounces.

entry.ety: L. renovatus, p. p. of renovare;pref. re- re- + novare to make new, fr. novus new. See New, and �� Renew

sn.q: Nor envy we Thy great renown, nor grudge thy victory.

sn.q: This famous duke of Milan, Of whom so often I have heard renown.

entry.q: For joi to hear me so renown his son.
The bard whom pilfered pastorals renown.

entry.def: Famous; celebrated for great achievements, for distinguished qualities, or for grandeur; eminent; as, a renowned king.

entry.syn: Famous; famed; distinguished; noted; eminent; celebrated; remarkable; wonderful. See Famous.

Having great renown; famous.

A soft, compact variety of talc,, being an altered pyroxene. It is often worked in a lathe into inkstands and other articles.
To rant.
imp. & p. p. of Rend.

entry.ety: From Rend

sn.def: An opening made by rending; a break or breach made by force; a tear.
sn.q: See what a rent the envious Casca made.

sn.def: Figuratively, a schism; a rupture of harmony; a separation; as, a rent in the church.
sn.syn: Fissure; breach; disrupture; rupture; tear; dilaceration; break; fracture.

entry.def: To tear. See Rend.

entry.note: ☞ The term rent is also popularly applied to compensation for the use of certain personal chattels, as a piano, a sewing machine, etc.
entry.cs: Black rent. See Blackmail, 3. Forehand rent rent which is paid in advance; foregift. Rent arrear, rent in arrears; unpaid rent. Blackstone. Rent charge Law a rent reserved on a conveyance of land in fee simple, or granted out of lands by deed; -- so called because, by a covenant or clause in the deed of conveyance, the land is charged with a distress for the payment of it. Bouvier. Rent roll a list or account of rents or income; a rental. Rent seck Law a rent reserved by deed, but without any clause of distress; barren rent. A power of distress was made incident to rent seck by Statute 4 George II. c. 28. Rent service Eng. Law rent reserved out of land held by fealty or other corporeal service; -- so called from such service being incident to it. White rent a quitrent when paid in silver; -- opposed to black rent.
entry.ety: F. rente, LL. renta, fr. L. reddita, fem. sing. or neut. pl. of redditus, p. p. of reddere to give back, pay. See Render

sn.def: Income; revenue. See Catel.
sn.q: Catel had they enough andrent.
Bacchus] a waster was and all his rent In wine and bordel he dispent.
So bought an annual rent or two, And liv'd, just as you see I do.

sn.def: Pay; reward; share; toll.
sn.q: Death, that taketh of high and low his rent.

sn.def: A certain periodical profit, whether in money, provisions, chattels, or labor, issuing out of lands and tenements in payment for the use; commonly, a certain pecuniary sum agreed upon between a tenant and his landlord, paid at fixed intervals by the lessee to the lessor, for the use of land or its appendages; as, rent for a farm, a house, a park, etc.

sd.def: That portion of the produce of the earth paid to the landlord for the use of the “original and indestructible powers of the soil;” the excess of the return from a given piece of cultivated land over that from land of equal area at the “margin of cultivation.” Called also economic rentorRicardian rent. Economic rent is due partly to differences of productivity, but chiefly to advantages of location; it is equivalent to ordinary or commercial rent less interest on improvements, and nearly equivalent to ground rent.
Loosely, a return or profit from a differential advantage for production, as in case of income or earnings due to rare natural gifts creating a natural monopoly.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rented; p. pr. & vb. n. Renting
entry.ety: F. renter. See Rent n.

sn.def: To grant the possession and enjoyment of, for a rent; to lease; as, the owwner of an estate or house rents it.
To take and hold under an agreement to pay rent; as, the tennant rents an estate of the owner.

entry.def: To be leased, or let for rent; as, an estate rents for five hundred dollars a year.
Capable of being rented, or suitable for renting.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. rentage
entry.def: Rent.

entry.ety: LL. rentale, fr. renta. See Rent income

sn.def: A schedule, account, or list of rents, with the names of the tenants, etc.; a rent roll.
A sum total of rents; as, an estate that yields a rental of ten thousand dollars a year.

entry.ety: F. See Rent income
entry.def: In France, interest payable by government on indebtedness; the bonds, shares, stocks, etc., which represent government indebtedness.
One who rents or leases an estate; -- usually said of a lessee or tenant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rentered -t?rd; p. pr. & vb. n. Rentering
entry.ety: F. rentraire; L. pref. re- re- + in into, in + trahere to draw

sn.def: To sew together so that the seam is scarcely visible; to sew up with skill and nicety; to finedraw.
To restore the original design of, by working in new warp; -- said with reference to tapestry.

entry.def: One who renters.

entry.ety: F. See 5th Rent
entry.def: One who has a fixed income, as from lands, stocks, or the like.

entry.ety: L. renumeratus, p. p. of renumerare to count over, count up; pref. re- re- + numerare to count. See Numerate
entry.def: To recount.

entry.ety: Cf. F. renonciation, L. renuntiatio ann announcement. See Renounce

sn.def: The act of renouncing.
Formal declination to take out letters of administration, or to assume an office, privilege, or right.
sn.syn: Renouncement; disownment; disavowal; disavowment; disclaimer; rejection; abjuration; recantation; denial; abandonment; relinquishment.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. renuntiatorius
entry.def: Pertaining to renunciation; containing or declaring a renunciation; as, renunciatory vows.

entry.ety: F. renverser; L. pref. re- re- + in in, into + versare, v. intens. fr. vertere to turn
entry.def: To reverse.
entry.q: Whose shield he bears renverst.

entry.ety: F. renversé p. p.
entry.def: Reversed; set with the head downward; turned contrary to the natural position.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A reversing.

entry.ety: F. renvoyer
entry.def: To send back.
entry.q: Not dismissing orrenvoyingher.

entry.ety: F. renvoi
entry.def: A sending back.
To obtain again.
That may be reobtained.
To occupy again.
Same as Rheometer.
To open again.
To oppose again.

entry.ety: Pref. re- re- + ordain: cf. F. réordonner
entry.def: To ordain again, as when the first ordination is considered defective.
To order a second time.
A second ordination.
The act of reorganizing; a reorganized existence; as, reorganization of the troops.
To organize again or anew; as, to reorganize a society or an army.
Rising again.
entry.q: The life reorient out of dust.

entry.def: See Rheostat.
See Rheotrope.

entry.ety: Prob. a corruption of rib: cf. F. reps
entry.def: A fabric made of silk or wool, or of silk and wool, and having a transversely corded or ribbed surface.
Formed with a surface closely corded, or ribbed transversely; -- applied to textile fabrics of silk or wool; as, rep silk.
To pace again; to walk over again in a contrary direction.
To pacify again.
To pack a second time or anew; as, to repack beef; to repack a trunk.
One who repacks.
To paganize anew; to bring back to paganism.
imp. & p. p. of Repay.
To paint anew or again; as, to repaint a house; to repaint the ground of a picture.

entry.ety: OE. repairen, OF. repairier to return, fr. L. repatriare to return to one's contry, to go home again; pref. re- re- + patria native country, fr. pater father. See Father, and cf. Repatriate

sn.def: To return.
sn.q: I thought . . . that he repaire should again.

sn.def: To go; to betake one's self; to resort; ass, to repair to sanctuary for safety.
sn.q: Go, mount the winds, and to the shades repair.

entry.ety: OF. repaire retreat, asylum, abode. See Repair to go

sn.def: The act of repairing or resorting to a place.
sn.q: The king sent a proclamation for their repair to their houses.

sn.def: Place to which one repairs; a haunt; a resort.
sn.q: There the fierce winds his tender force assail And beat him downward to his first repair.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Repaired -p?rd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Repairing
entry.ety: F. réparer, L. reparare; pref. re- re- + parare to prepare. See Pare, and cf. Reparation

sn.def: To restore to a sound or good state after decay, injury, dilapidation, or partial destruction; to renew; to restore; to mend; as, to repair a house, a road, a shoe, or a ship; to repair a shattered fortune.
sn.q: Secret refreshings that repair his strength.
Do thou, as thou art wont, repair My heart with gladness.

sn.def: To make amends for, as for an injury, by an equivalent; to indemnify for; as, to repair a loss or damage.
sn.q: I 'll repair the misery thou dost bear.
sn.syn: To restore, recover; renew; amend; mend; retrieve; recruit.

sn.def: Restoration to a sound or good state after decay, waste, injury, or partial restruction; supply of loss; reparation; as, materials are collected for the repair of a church or of a city.
sn.q: Sunk down and sought repair Of sleep, which instantly fell on me.

sn.def: Condition with respect to soundness, perfectness, etc.; as, a house in good, or bad, repair; the book is out of repair.

entry.def: Reparable.
One who, or that which, repairs, restores, or makes amends.
Act of repairing.

entry.ety: L. repandus bent backward, turned up; pref. re- re- + pandus bent, crooked
entry.def: Having a slightly undulating margin; -- said of leaves.
The quality or state of being reparable.

entry.ety: L. reparabilis: cf. F. réparable
entry.def: Capable of being repaired, restored to a sound or good state, or made good; restorable; as, a reparable injury.
In a reparable manner.

entry.ety: F. réparation, L. reparatio. See Repair to mend

sn.def: The act of renewing, restoring, etc., or the state of being renewed or repaired; as, the reparation of a bridge or of a highway; -- in this sense, repair is oftener used.

The act of making amends or giving satisfaction or compensation for a wrong, injury, etc.; also, the thing done or given; amends; satisfaction; indemnity; --used, e.g. in the phrase make reparation pay reparationsormake reparations.
sn.q: I am sensible of the scandal I have given by my loose writings, and make what reparation I am able.
sn.syn: Restoration; repair; restitution; compensation; amends; satisfaction.

entry.def: Repairing, or tending to repair.
That which repairs.

entry.ety: Cf. Reapparel
entry.def: A change of apparel; a second or different suit.

entry.ety: F. repartie, fr. repartir to reply, depart again; pref. re- re- partir to part, depart. See Part
entry.def: A smart, ready, and witty reply.
entry.q: Cupid was as bad as he; Hear but the youngster's repartee.
entry.syn: Retort; reply. See Retort.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reparteed -t?d"; p. pr. & vb. n. Reparteeing
entry.def: To make smart and witty replies.

entry.ety: Sp., fr. repartir to divide
entry.def: A partition or distribution, especially of slaves; also, an assessment of taxes.
Another, or an additional, separation into parts.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + pass: cf. F. repasser. Cf. Repace
entry.def: To pass again; to pass or travel over in the opposite direction; to pass a second time; as, to repass a bridge or a river; to repass the sea.
To pass or go back; to move back; as, troops passing and repassing before our eyes.
The act of repassing; passage back.

entry.ety: Cf. F. repassant, p. pr
entry.def: Counterpassant.

entry.ety: OF. repast, F. repas, LL. repastus, fr. L. repascere to feed again; pref. re- re- + pascere pastum, to pasture, feed. See Pasture

sn.def: The act of taking food.
sn.q: From dance to sweet repast they turn.

sn.def: That which is taken as food; a meal; figuratively, any refreshment.
sn.q: Sleep . . . thy bestrepast.
Go and get me some repast.

entry.def: To supply food to; to feast; to take food.
entry.q: Repastthem with my blood.
He then, also, as before, left arbitrary the dieting and repasting of our minds.

entry.def: One who takes a repast.

entry.ety: See Repast
entry.def: Food; entertainment.
entry.q: Food for his rage, repasture for his den.

entry.ety: L. repatriare. See 1st Repair
entry.def: To restore to one's own country.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. repatriatio return to one's country
entry.def: Restoration to one's country.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Repaid -p?d"; p. pr. & vb. n. Repaying
entry.ety: Pref. re- + pay: cf. F. repayer

sn.def: To pay back; to refund; as, to repay money borrowed or advanced.
sn.q: If you repay me not on such a day, In such a place, such sum or sums.

sn.def: To make return or requital for; to recompense; -- in a good or bad sense; as, to repay kindness; to repay an injury.
sn.q: Benefits which can not be repaid . . . are not commonly found to increase affection.

sn.def: To pay anew, or a second time, as a debt.
sn.syn: To refund; restore; return; recompense; compensate; remunerate; satisfy; reimburse; requite.

entry.def: Capable of being, or proper to be, repaid; due; as, a loan repayable in ten days; services repayable in kind.

sn.def: The act of repaying; reimbursement.
The money or other thing repaid.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Repealed -p?ld"; p. pr. & vb. n. Repealing
entry.ety: OF. repeler to call back, F. rappeler; pref. re- re- + OF. apeler, F. appeler, to call, L. appellare. See Appeal, and. cf. Repel

sn.def: To recall; to summon again, as persons.
sn.q: The banished Bolingbroke repeals himself, And with uplifted arms is safe arrived.

sn.def: To recall, as a deed, will, law, or statute; to revoke; to rescind or abrogate by authority, as by act of the legislature; as, to repeal a law.
To suppress; to repel.
sn.q: Whence Adam soon repealed The doubts that in his heart arose.
sn.syn: To abolish; revoke; rescind; recall; annul; abrogate; cancel; reverse. See Abolish.

sn.def: Recall, as from exile.
sn.q: The tribunes are no soldiers; and their people Will be as rash in the repeal, as hasty To expel him thence.

sn.def: Revocation; abrogation; as, the repeal of a statute; the repeal of a law or a usage.

entry.def: The quality or state of being repealable.
Capable of being repealed.
entry.syn: Revocable; abrogable; voidable; reversible.

entry.def: One who repeals; one who seeks a repeal; specifically, an advocate for the repeal of the Articles of Union between Great Britain and Ireland.
Recall, as from banishment.

cs.cd: to do or say what one has already done or said.
to make the same signals again; specifically, to communicate, by repeating them, the signals shown at headquarters.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Repeated; p. pr. & vb. n. Repeating
entry.ety: F. répéter, L. repetere; pref. re- re- + petere to fall upon, attack. See Petition

sn.def: To go over again; to attempt, do, make, or utter again; to iterate; to recite; as, to repeat an effort, an order, or a poem.
sn.q: I willrepeatour former communication.
Not well conceived of God; who, though his power Creation could repeat, yet would be loth Us to abolish.

sn.def: To make trial of again; to undergo or encounter again.
To repay or refund (an excess received).
sn.syn: To reiterate; iterate; renew; recite; relate; rehearse; recapitulate. See Reiterate.

sn.def: The act of repeating; repetition.
That which is repeated; as, the repeat of a pattern; that is, the repetition of the engraved figure on a roller by which an impression is produced (as in calico printing, etc.).
A mark, or series of dots, placed before and after, or often only at the end of, a passage to be repeated in performance.

entry.def: More than once; again and again; indefinitely.

entries.entry:
Re*peat"er -?r n. One who, or that which, repeats. Specifically: A watch with a striking apparatus which, upon pressure of a spring, will indicate the time, usually in hours and quarters. A repeating firearm. Teleg An instrument for resending a telegraphic message automatically at an intermediate point.
A person who votes more than once at an election. U.S See Circulating decimal, under Decimal. Naut A pennant used to indicate that a certain flag in a hoist of signal is duplicated.

entry.cs:
Repeating circle. See the Note under Circle n., 3. Repeating decimal Arith a circulating decimal. See under Decimal. Repeating firearm a firearm that may be discharged many times in quick succession; especially: A form of firearm so constructed that by the action of the mechanism the charges are successively introduced from a chamber containing them into the breech of the barrel, and fired. A form in which the charges are held in, and discharged from, a revolving chamber at the breech of the barrel. See Revolver, and Magazine gun, under Magazine.
Repeating instruments Astron. & Surv instruments for observing angles, as a circle, theodolite, etc., so constructed that the angle may be measured several times in succession, and different, but successive and contiguous, portions of the graduated limb, before reading off the aggregate result, which aggregate, divided by the number of measurements, gives the angle, freed in a measure from errors of eccentricity and graduation. Repeating watch. See Repeater
entry.def: Doing the same thing over again; accomplishing a given result many times in succession; as, a repeating firearm; a repeating watch.

entry.ety: L. repedare to step back; pref. re- re- + pes pedis, foot
entry.def: A stepping or going back.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Repelled -p?ld"; p. pr. & vb. n. Repelling
entry.ety: L. repellere repulsum; pref. re- re- + pellere to drive. See Pulse a beating, and cf. Repulse Repeal

sn.def: To drive back; to force to return; to check the advance of; to repulse as, to repel an enemy or an assailant.
sn.q: Hippomedon repelled the hostile tide.
They repelled each other strongly, and yet attracted each other strongly.

sn.def: To resist or oppose effectually; as, to repel an assault, an encroachment, or an argument.
sn.q: He] gently repelled their entreaties.
sn.syn: Tu repulse; resist; oppose; reject; refuse.

entry.def: To act with force in opposition to force impressed; to exercise repulsion.
The principle of repulsion; the quality or capacity of repelling; repulsion.

entry.ety: L. repellens -entis, p. pr.
entry.def: Driving back; able or tending to repel.

sn.def: That which repels.
A remedy to repel from a tumefied part the fluids which render it tumid.
A kind of waterproof cloth.

entry.def: One who, or that which, repels.

entry.ety: L. repens -entis, creeping, p. pr. of repere to creep

sn.def: Prostrate and rooting; -- said of stems.
Same as Reptant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Repented; p. pr. & vb. n. Repenting
entry.ety: F. se repentir; L. pref. re- re- + poenitere to make repent, poenitet me it repents me, I repent. See Penitent

sn.def: To feel pain, sorrow, or regret, for what one has done or omitted to do.
sn.q: First she relents With pity; of that pity then repents.

sn.def: To change the mind, or the course of conduct, on account of regret or dissatisfaction.
sn.q: Lest, peradventure, the people repent when they see war, and they return to Egypt.

sn.def: To be sorry for sin as morally evil, and to seek forgiveness; to cease to love and practice sin.
sn.q: Except ye repent, ye shall likewise perish.

sn.def: To feel pain on account of; to remember with sorrow.
sn.q: I do repent it from my very soul.

sn.def: To feel regret or sorrow; -- used reflexively.
sn.q: My father has repented him ere now.

sn.def: To cause to have sorrow or regret; -- used impersonally.
sn.q: And itrepentedthe Lord that he had made man on the earth.

entry.ety: F. repentance
entry.def: The act of repenting, or the state of being penitent; sorrow for what one has done or omitted to do; especially, contrition for sin.
entry.q: Godly sorrow worketh repentance to salvation.
Repentance is a change of mind, or a conversion from sin to God.

Repentance is the relinquishment of any practice from the conviction that it has offended God. Sorrow, fear, and anxiety are properly not parts, but adjuncts, of repentance; yet they are too closely connected with it to be easily separated.
entry.syn: Contrition; regret; penitence; contriteness; compunction. See Contrition.

entry.ety: F. repentant

sn.def: Penitent; sorry for sin.
sn.q: Thus they, in lowliest plight, repentant stood.

sn.def: Expressing or showing sorrow for sin; as, repentant tears; repentant ashes.
sn.q: Repentantsighs and voluntary pains.

entry.def: One who repents, especially one who repents of sin; a penitent.
In a repentant manner.
One who repents.
With repentance; penitently.
Unrepentant.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + people: cf. F. repeupler
entry.def: To people anew.
The act of perceiving again; a repeated perception of the same object.
entry.q: No external praise can give me such a glow as my own solitary reperception and ratification of what is fine.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Repercussed -k?st";p. pr. & vb. n. Repercussing
entry.ety: L. repercusus, p. p. of repercutere to drive back; pref. re- re- + percutere. See Percussion
entry.def: To drive or beat back; hence, to reflect; to reverberate.
entry.q: Perceiving all the subjacent country, . . . to repercuss such a light as I could hardly look against.

entry.ety: L. repercussio: cf. F. répercussion

sn.def: The act of driving back, or the state of being driven back; reflection; reverberation; as, the repercussion of sound.
sn.q: Ever echoing back in endless repercussion.

sn.def: Rapid reiteration of the same sound.
The subsidence of a tumor or eruption by the action of a repellent.
In a vaginal examination, the act of imparting through the uterine wall with the finger a shock to the fetus, so that it bounds upward, and falls back again against the examining finger.

entry.ety: Cf. F. répercussif

sn.def: Tending or able to repercuss; having the power of sending back; causing to reverberate.
sn.q: Ye repercussive rocks! repeat the sound.

sn.def: Repellent.
sn.q: Blood is stanched by astringent andrepercussivemedicines.

sn.def: Driven back; rebounding; reverberated.
sn.q: Rages loud therepercussiveroar.

entry.def: A repellent.

entry.ety: L. reperticius. See Repertory
entry.def: Found; gained by finding.

entry.ety: F. See Repertory
entry.def: A list of dramas, operas, pieces, parts, etc., which a company or a person has rehearsed and is prepared to perform.

entry.ety: L. repertorium, fr. reperire to find again; pref. re- re + parire parere, to bring forth, procure: cf. F. répertoire. Cf. Parent

sn.def: A place in which things are disposed in an orderly manner, so that they can be easily found, as the index of a book, a commonplace book, or the like.
A treasury; a magazine; a storehouse.
Same as Répertoire.

entry.def: A second or repeated perusal.
To peruse again.

entry.ety: L. repetendus to be repeated, fr. repetere to repeat
entry.def: That part of a circulating decimal which recurs continually, ad infinitum: -- sometimes indicated by a dot over the first and last figures; thus, in the circulating decimal .728328328 + (otherwise .7�8�), the repetend is 283.

entry.ety: L. repetitio: cf. F. répétition. See Repeat

sn.def: The act of repeating; a doing or saying again; iteration.
sn.q: I need not be barren of accusations; he hath faults, with surplus to tire in repetition.

sn.def: Recital from memory; rehearsal.
The act of repeating, singing, or playing, the same piece or part a second time; reiteration of a note.
Reiteration, or repeating the same word, or the same sense in different words, for the purpose of making a deeper impression on the audience.
The measurement of an angle by successive observations with a repeating instrument.
sn.syn: Iteration; rehearsal. See Tautology.

entry.def: Of the nature of, or containing, repetition.
One who repeats.
Repeating; containing repetition.
Containing repetition; repeating.

entry.ety: Cf. L. repetitor a reclaimer
entry.def: A private instructor.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + pine to languish

sn.def: To fail; to wane.
sn.q: Reppeningcourage yields no foot to foe.

sn.def: To continue pining; to feel inward discontent which preys on the spirits; to indulge in envy or complaint; to murmur.
sn.q: But Lachesis thereat gan to repine.
What if the head, the eye, or ear repined To serve mere engines to the ruling mind?

entry.def: Vexation; mortification.
One who repines.
With repening or murmuring.

entry.ety: From the native name
entry.def: Any edible sea urchin.

entry.note: ☞ The propriety of the use of replace instead of displace supersede take the place of, as in the third and fourth definitions, is often disputed on account of etymological discrepancy; but the use has been sanctioned by the practice of careful writers.

cs.cd: a crystal having one or more planes in the place of its edges or angles.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + place: cf. F. replacer

sn.def: To place again; to restore to a former place, position, condition, or the like.
sn.q: The earl . . . was replaced in his government.

sn.def: To refund; to repay; to restore; as, to replace a sum of money borrowed.
To supply or substitute an equivalent for; as, to replace a lost document.
sn.q: With Israel, religion replaced morality.

sn.def: To take the place of; to supply the want of; to fulfull the end or office of.
sn.q: This duty of right intention does not replace or supersede the duty of consideration.

sn.def: To put in a new or different place.

entry.def: The quality, state, or degree of being replaceable.

sn.def: Capable or admitting of being put back into a place.
Admitting of having its place supplied by a like thing or an equivalent; as, the lost book is replaceable .
Capable of being replaced (by), or of being exchanged (for); as, the hydrogen of acids is replaceable by metals or by basic radicals.
The act of replacing.
The removal of an edge or an angle by one or more planes.

entry.def: To plait or fold again; to fold, as one part over another, again and again.
To plant again.
That may be planted again.
The act of planting again; a replanting.
To plead again.
A second pleading, or course of pleadings; also, the right of pleading again.
entry.q: Whenever a repleader is granted, the pleadings must begin de novo.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Replenished -?sht; p. pr. & vb. n. Replenishing
entry.ety: OE. replenissen, OF. replenir; L. pref. re- re- + plenus full. See Full -ish, and cf. Replete

sn.def: To fill again after having been diminished or emptied; to stock anew; hence, to fill completely; to cause to abound.
sn.q: Multiply and replenish the earth.
The waters thus With fish replenished, and the air with fowl.

sn.def: To finish; to complete; to perfect.
sn.q: We smothered The most replenished sweet work of nature.

entry.def: To recover former fullness.
entry.q: The humors will not replenish so soon.

entry.def: One who replenishes.

sn.def: The act of replenishing, or the state of being replenished.
That which replenishes; supply.

entry.ety: L. repletus, p. p. of replere to fill again, fill up; pref. re- re- + plere to fill, akin to plenus full: cf. F. replet corpulent. See Plenty Replenish
entry.def: Filled again; completely filled; full; charged; abounding.
entry.q: His wordsrepletewith guile.
When he of wine was replet at his feast.
In heads replete with thoughts of other men.

entry.def: To fill completely, or to satiety.
The state of being replete.

entry.ety: L. repletio a filling up: cf. F. réplétion. See Replete

sn.def: The state of being replete; superabundant fullness.
sn.q: The tree had too much repletion, and was oppressed with its own sap.
Repleccioun [overeating] ne made her never sick.

sn.def: Fullness of blood; plethora.

entry.ety: Cf. F. réplétif
entry.def: Tending to make replete; filling.
Repletive.

entry.ety: See Replevy
entry.def: Capable of being replevied.

entry.ety: LL. replevina. See Replevy, and cf. Plevin

sn.def: A personal action which lies to recover possession of goods and chattle wrongfully taken or detained. Originally, it was a remedy peculiar to cases for wrongful distress, but it may generally now be brought in all cases of wrongful taking or detention.
The writ by which goods and chattels are replevied.

entry.def: To replevy.

entry.ety: OF. replevisable
entry.def: Repleviable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Replevied -?d; p. pr. & vb. n. Replevying
entry.ety: OF. replevir, LL. replevire. See Pledge Replevin

sn.def: To take or get back, by a writ for that purpose (goods and chattels wrongfully taken or detained), upon giving security to try the right to them in a suit at law, and, if that should be determined against the plaintiff, to return the property replevied.
To bail.

entry.def: Replevin.

entry.ety: It. See Reply v. & n.

sn.def: A copy of a work of art, as of a picture or statue, made by the maker of the original.
Repetition.

entry.def: One who replies.
To reply.

entry.ety: L. replicatus, p. p. of replicare. See Reply
entry.def: Folded over or backward; folded back upon itself; as, a replicate leaf or petal; a replicate margin of a shell.

entry.ety: L. replicatio. See Reply

sn.def: An answer; a reply.
sn.q: Withouten any repplicacioun.

sn.def: The reply of the plaintiff, in matters of fact, to the defendant's plea.
Return or repercussion, as of sound; echo.
sn.q: To hear the replication of your sounds.

sn.def: A repetition; a copy.

The copying, by enzymes, of a cell's genome, i.e. the DNA or RNA comprising its genetic material, so as to form an identical genome. This is an essential step in the division of one cell into two. This differs from transcription, which is the copying of only part of the genetic information of a cell's genome into RNA, as in the processes of biosynthesis of messenger RNA or ribosomal RNA.
sn.syn: Answer; response; reply; rejoinder.

entry.def: One who replies.

entry.ety: L., doorcase
entry.def: The framework of some pods, as the cress, which remains after the valves drop off.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Replied -pl?d"; p. pr. & vb. n. Replying
entry.ety: OE. replien, OF. replier, F. répliquer, fr. L. replicare to fold back, make a reply; pref. re- re- + plicare to fold. See Ply, and cf. Replica

sn.def: To make a return in words or writing; to respond; to answer.
sn.q: O man, who art thou that repliest against God?

sn.def: To answer a defendant's plea.
Figuratively, to do something in return for something done; as, to reply to a signal; to reply to the fire of a battery.
sn.syn: To answer; respond; rejoin.

entry.def: To return for an answer.
entry.q: Lords, vouchsafe To give me hearing what I shall reply.

entries.entry:
Re*ply"
Reply Rejoinder Answer. A reply is a distinct response to a formal question or attack in speech or writing. A rejoinder is a second reply (a reply to a reply) in a protracted discussion or controversy. The word answer is used in two senses, namely (1), in the most general sense of a mere response; as, the answer to a question; or (2), in the sense of a decisive and satisfactory confutation of an adversary's argument, as when we speak of a triumphant answer to the speech or accusations of an opponent. Here the noun corresponds to a frequent use of the verb, as when we say. “This will answeri.e., fully meet) the end in view;” “It answers the purpose.” n.; pl.Replies -pl�z". See Reply v. i., and cf. Replica
That which is said, written, or done in answer to what is said, written, or done by another; an answer; a response. Answer; rejoinder; response.

entry.def: See Replier.
To polish again.

entry.ety: L. reponere; pref. re- re- + ponere to place
entry.def: To replace.
The act of repeopling; act of furnishing with a population anew.

cs.mcol: To be reportedorTo be reported of
cs.cd: to be spoken of; to be mentioned, whether favorably or unfavorably.
to betake one's self, as to a superior or one to whom service is due, and be in readiness to receive orders or do service.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reported; p. pr. & vb. n. Reporting
entry.ety: F. reporter to carry back, carry (cf. rapporter; see Rapport), L. reportare to bear or bring back; pref. re- re- + portare to bear or bring. See Port bearing, demeanor

sn.def: To refer.
sn.q: Baldwin, his son, . . . succeeded his father; so like unto him that we report the reader to the character of King Almeric, and will spare the repeating his description.

sn.def: To bring back, as an answer; to announce in return; to relate, as what has been discovered by a person sent to examine, explore, or investigate; as, a messenger reports to his employer what he has seen or ascertained; the committee reported progress.
sn.q: There is no man that may reporten all.

sn.def: To give an account of; to relate; to tell; to circulate publicly, as a story; as, in the common phrase, it is reported .
sn.q: It is reported among the heathen, and Gashmu saith it, that thou and the Jews think to rebel.

sn.def: To give an official account or statement of; as, a treasurer reports the receipts and expenditures.
To return or repeat, as sound; to echo.
sn.q: A church with windows only from above, thatreporteththe voice thirteen times.

sn.def: To return or present as the result of an examination or consideration of any matter officially referred; as, the committee reported the bill witth amendments, or reported a new bill, or reported the results of an inquiry.
To make minutes of, as a speech, or the doings of a public body; to write down from the lips of a speaker.
To write an account of for publication, as in a newspaper; as, to report a public celebration or a horse race.
To make a statement of the conduct of, especially in an unfavorable sense; as, to report a servant to his employer.
sn.syn: To relate; narrate; tell; recite; describe.

sn.def: To make a report, or response, in respect of a matter inquired of, a duty enjoined, or information expected; as, the committee will report at twelve o'clock.
To furnish in writing an account of a speech, the proceedings at a meeting, the particulars of an occurrence, etc., for publication.

To present one's self, as to a superior officer, or to one to whom service is due, and to be in readiness for orders or to do service; also, to give information, as of one's address, condition, etc.; as, the officer reported to the general for duty; to report weekly by letter.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rapport. See Report.v. t.
entry.sn:
That which is reported. Specifically: An account or statement of the results of examination or inquiry made by request or direction; relation. From Thetis sent as spies to makereport. Waller.
A story or statement circulating by common talk; a rumor; hence, fame; repute; reputation. It was a true report that I heard in mine own land of thy acts and of thy wisdom. Cornelius the centurion, a just man, and . . . of good report among all the nation of the Jews.
Sound; noise; as, the report of a pistol or cannon.
An official statement of facts, verbal or written; especially, a statement in writing of proceedings and facts exhibited by an officer to his superiors; as, the reports of the heads af departments to Congress, of a master in chancery to the court, of committees to a legislative body, and the like.
An account or statement of a judicial opinion or decision, or of case argued and determined in a court of law, chancery, etc.; also, in the plural, the volumes containing such reports; as, Coke's Reports .
A sketch, or a fully written account, of a speech, debate, or the proceedings of a public meeting, legislative body, etc.

sn.def: Rapport; relation; connection; reference.
sn.q: The corridors worse, having no report to the wings they join to.
sn.syn: Account; relation; narration; detail; description; recital; narrative; story; rumor; hearsay.

entry.def: Capable or admitting of being reported.
SAme as Report.
One who reports.
An officer or person who makes authorized statements of law proceedings and decisions, or of legislative debates.
One who reports speeches, the proceedings of public meetings, news, etc., for the newspapers.
entry.q: Of our tales judge and reportour.

entry.def: By report or common fame.
Of or pertaining to a reporter or reporters; as, the reportorial staff of a newspaper.

entry.ety: From Repose

sn.def: The act or state of reposing; as, the reposal of a trust.
That on which one reposes.

entry.def: Reliance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reposed -p?zd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Reposing
entry.ety: F. reposer; L. pref. re- re- + pausare to pause. See Pause Pose v.

sn.def: To cause to stop or to rest after motion; hence, to deposit; to lay down; to lodge; to reposit.
sn.q: But these thy fortunes let us straight repose In this divine cave's bosom.
Pebbles reposed in those cliffs amongst the earth . . . are left behind.

sn.def: To lay at rest; to cause to be calm or quiet; to compose; to rest, -- often reflexive; as, to repose one's self on a couch.
sn.q: All being settled and reposed, the lord archbishop did present his majesty to the lords and commons.
After the toil of battle to repose Your wearied virtue.

sn.def: To place, have, or rest; to set; to intrust.
sn.q: The king reposeth all his confidence in thee.

sn.def: To lie at rest; to rest.
sn.q: Within a thicket I reposed.

sn.def: Figuratively, to remain or abide restfully without anxiety or alarms.
sn.q: It is upon these that the soul may repose.

sn.def: To lie; to be supported; as, trap reposing on sand.
sn.syn: To lie; recline; couch; rest; sleep; settle; lodge; abide.

cs.cd: the inclination of a plane at which a body placed on the plane would remain at rest, or if in motion would roll or slide down with uniform velocity; the angle at which the various kinds of earth will stand when abandoned to themselves.

entry.ety: F. repos. See Repose v.

sn.def: A lying at rest; sleep; rest; quiet.
sn.q: Shake off the golden slumber of repose.

sn.def: Rest of mind; tranquillity; freedom from uneasiness; also, a composed manner or deportment.
A rest; a pause.

That harmony or moderation which affords rest for the eye; -- opposed to the scattering and division of a subject into too many unconnected parts, and also to anything which is overstrained; as, a painting may want repose .
sn.syn: Rest; recumbency; reclination; ease; quiet; quietness; tranquillity; peace.

entry.def: Composed; calm; tranquil; at rest.
Full of repose; quiet.
One who reposes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reposited; p. pr. & vb. n. Repositing
entry.ety: L. repositus, p. p. of reponere to put back; pref. re- re- + ponere to put. See Position
entry.def: To cause to rest or stay; to lay away; to lodge, as for safety or preservation; to place; to store.
entry.q: Others reposit their young in holes.

entry.ety: L. repositio
entry.def: The act of repositing; a laying up.
An instrument employed for replacing a displaced organ or part.

entry.ety: L. repositorium repostorium: cf. OF. repositoire
entry.def: A place where things are or may be reposited, or laid up, for safety or preservation; a depository.

entry.cs: To repossess one's self ofsomething), to acquire again (something lost).

sn.def: To possess again; as, to repossess the land.

entry.sn: Specifically: To take possession of, for failure of the possessor to make payments owed for purchase of; -- used of real estate subject to mortgage payments and of other objects purchased on a time-payment plan, which may be taken back (repossessed) by the original vendor if the payments are not made on time.

entry.def: The act or the state of possessing again.
Rest; quiet.
entry.q: In the reposure of most soft content.

entry.def: To pour again.

entry.ety: F. See Repoussé
entry.def: Art or process of hammering out or pressing thin metal from the reverse side: (1) in producing repoussé work; (2) in leveling up any part of an etched plate that has been worked so as to cause a depression.

cs.cd: ornamentation of metal in relief by pressing or hammering on the reverse side.

entry.ety: F., p. p. of repousser to thrust back; pref re- + pousser to push. See Push
entry.def: Formed in relief, as a pattern on metal.
Ornamented with patterns in relief made by pressing or hammering on the reverse side; -- said of thin metal, or of a vessel made of thin metal.
Reproof.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reprehended; p. pr. & vb. n. Reprehending
entry.ety: L. reprehendere reprehensum, to hold back, seize, check, blame; pref. re- re- + prehendere to lay hold of. See Prehensile, and cf. Reprisal.
entry.def: To reprove or reprimand with a view of restraining, checking, or preventing; to make charge of fault against; to disapprove of; to chide; to blame; to censure.
entry.q: Aristippus being reprehended of luxury by one that was not rich, for that he gave six crowns for a small fish.
Pardon me for reprehending thee.
In which satire human vices, ignorance, and errors . . . are severely reprehended.
I nor advise nor reprehend the choice.

entry.def: One who reprehends.

entry.ety: L. reprehensibilis: cf. F. répréhensible
entry.def: Worthy of reprehension; culpable; censurable; blamable.

entry.ety: L. reprehensio: cf. F. répréhension
entry.def: Reproof; censure; blame; disapproval.
entry.q: This Basilius took as though his mistress had given him a secret reprehension that he had not showed more gratefulness to Dorus.
entry.syn: Censure; reproof; reprimand. See Admonition.

entry.ety: Cf. F. répréhensif
entry.def: Containing reprehension; conveying reproof.
Containing reproof; reprehensive; as, reprehensory complaint.
To present again; as, to re-present the points of an argument.

entry.ety: F. représenter, L. repraesentare repraesentatum; pref. re- re- + preesentare to place before, present. See Present v. t.

sn.def: To present again or anew; to present by means of something standing in the place of; to exhibit the counterpart or image of; to typify.
sn.q: Before him burn Seven lamps, as in a zodiac representing The heavenly fires.

sn.def: To portray by pictoral or plastic art; to delineate; as, to represent a landscape in a picture, a horse in bronze, and the like.
To portray by mimicry or action of any kind; to act the part or character of; to personate; as, to represent Hamlet.

To stand in the place of; to supply the place, perform the duties, exercise the rights, or receive the share, of; to speak and act with authority in behalf of; to act the part of (another); as, an heir represents his ancestor; an attorney represents his client in court; a member of Congress represents his district in Congress.
To exhibit to another mind in language; to show; to give one's own impressions and judgement of; to bring before the mind; to set forth; sometimes, to give an account of; to describe.
sn.q: He represented Rizzio's credit with the queen to be the chief and only obstacle to his success in that demand.
This bank is thought the greatest load on the Genoese, and the managers of it have been represented as a second kind of senate.

sn.def: To serve as a sign or symbol of; as, mathematical symbols represent quantities or relations; words represent ideas or things.
To bring a sensation of into the mind or sensorium; to cause to be known, felt, or apprehended; to present.
sn.q: Among these. Fancy next Her office holds; of all external things Which he five watchful senses represent, She forms imaginations, aery shapes.

sn.def: To form or image again in consciousness, as an object of cognition or apprehension (something which was originally apprehended by direct presentation). See Presentative, 3.
sn.q: The general capability of knowledge necessarily requires that, besides the power of evoking out of unconsciousness one portion of our retained knowledge in preference to another, we posses the faculty of representing in consciousness what is thus evoked . . . This representative Faculty is Imagination or Phantasy.

entry.def: Capable of being represented.
Representation; likeness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. repr�sentant
entry.def: Appearing or acting for another; representing.

entry.ety: F. representant
entry.def: A representative.

entry.ety: F. repr�sentation, L. representatio

sn.def: The act of representing, in any sense of the verb.

entry.sn:
That which represents. Specifically: A likeness, a picture, or a model; as, a representation of the human face, or figure, and the like.
A dramatic performance; as, a theatrical representation; a representation of Hamlet.
A description or statement; as, the representation of an historian, of a witness, or an advocate.
The body of those who act as representatives of a community or society; as, the representation of a State in Congress.
Insurance Law Any collateral statement of fact, made orally or in writing, by which an estimate of the risk is affected, or either party is influenced.

sn.def: The state of being represented.
sn.syn: Description; show; delineaton; portraiture; likeness; resemblance; exhibition; sight.

entry.ety: See Re-present
entry.def: The act of re-presenting, or the state of being presented again; a new presentation; as, re-presentation of facts previously stated.
Implying representation; representative.

entry.ety: Cf. F. repr�sentatif

sn.def: Fitted to represent; exhibiting a similitude.
