Bearing the character or power of another; acting for another or others; as, a council representative of the people.
Conducted by persons chosen to represent, or act as deputies for, the people; as, a representative government.

sd.def: Serving or fitted to present the full characters of the type of a group; typical; as, a representative genus in a family.
Similar in general appearance, structure, and habits, but living in different regions; -- said of certain species and varieties.

sn.def: Giving, or existing as, a transcript of what was originally presentative knowledge; as, representative faculties; representative knowledge. See Presentative, 3 and Represent, 8.

entry.note: ☞ The executor or administrator is ordinarily held to be the representative of a deceased person, and is sometimes called the legal representative, or the personal representative. The heir is sometimes called the real representative of his deceased ancestor. The heirs and executors or administrators of a deceased person are sometimes compendiously described as his real and personal representatives.
entry.ety: Cf. LL. repraesentativus

sn.def: One who, or that which, represents (anything); that which exhibits a likeness or similitude.
sn.q: A statute of Rumor, whispering an idiot in the ear, who was the representative of Credulity.
Difficulty must cumber this doctrine which supposes that the perfections of God are the representatives to us of whatever we perceive in the creatures.

sn.def: An agent, deputy, or substitute, who supplies the place of another, or others, being invested with his or their authority.
One who represents, or stands in the place of, another.
A member of the lower or popular house in a State legislature, or in the national Congress.

sd.def: That which presents the full character of the type of a group.
A species or variety which, in any region, takes the place of a similar one in another region.

entry.def: In a representative manner; vicariously.
The quality or state of being representative.
entry.q: Dr. Burnet observes, that every thought is attended with consciousness and representativeness.

sn.def: One who shows, exhibits, or describes.
A representative.

entry.def: Representation.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + press
entry.def: To press again.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + press: cf. L. reprimere repressum. Cf. Reprimand

sn.def: To press back or down effectually; to crush down or out; to quell; to subdue; to supress; as, to repress sedition or rebellion; to repress the first risings of discontent.
Hence, to check; to restrain; to keep back.
sn.q: Desire of wine and all delicious drinks, . . . Thou couldst repress.
sn.syn: To crush; overpower; subdue; suppress; restrain; quell; curb; check.

entry.def: The act of repressing.
One who, or that which, represses.
Capable of being repressed.

entry.ety: Cf. F. répression

sn.def: The act of repressing, or state of being repressed; as, the repression of evil and evil doers.
That which represses; check; restraint.

entry.ety: Cf. F. répressif. LL. repressivus
entry.def: Having power, or tending, to repress; as, repressive acts or measures.
Reprovable.

entry.ety: See Reprieve v. t.
entry.def: To reprove.
entry.q: Reprevehim of his vice.

entry.def: Reproof.
Repreve.
Reprieve.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reprieved -pr?vd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Reprieving
entry.ety: OE. repreven to reject, disallow, OF. reprover to blame, reproach, condemn (pres. il reprueve), F. réprouver to disapprove, fr. L. reprobare to reject, condemn; pref. re- re- + probare to try, prove. See Prove and cf. Reprove Reprobate

sn.def: To delay the punishment of; to suspend the execution of sentence on; to give a respite to; to respite; as, to reprieve a criminal for thirty days.
sn.q: He reprieves the sinnner from time to time.

sn.def: To relieve for a time, or temporarily.
sn.q: Company, thought it may reprieve a man from his melaneholy yet can not secure him from his conscience.

sn.def: A temporary suspension of the execution of a sentence, especially of a sentence of death.
sn.q: The morning Sir John Hotham was to die, a reprieve was sent to suspend the execution for three days.

sn.def: Interval of ease or relief; respite.
sn.q: All that I ask is but a short reprieve, ll I forget to love, and learn to grieve.

entry.ety: F. réprimande fr. L. reprimendus reprimenda, that is to be checked or suppressed, fr. reprimere to check, repress; pref. re- re + premere to press. See Press, and cf. Repress
entry.def: Severe or formal reproof; reprehension, private or public.
entry.q: Goldsmith gave his landlady a sharp reprimand for her treatment of him.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reprimanded; p. pr. & vb. n. Reprimanding
entry.ety: Cf. F. réprimander. See Reprimand n.

sn.def: To reprove severely; to reprehend; to chide for a fault; to consure formally.
sn.q: Germanicus was severely reprimanded by Tiberius for traveling into Egypt without his permission.

sn.def: To reprove publicly and officially, in execution of a sentence; as, the court ordered him to be reprimanded .
sn.syn: To reprove; reprehend; chide; rebuke; censure; blame. See Reprove.

entry.def: One who reprimands.
A machine or implement for applying fresh primers to spent cartridge shells, so that the shells be used again.

sn.def: To print again; to print a second or a new edition of.
To renew the impression of.
sn.q: The whole business of our redemption is . . . to reprint God's image upon the soul.

entry.def: A second or a new impression or edition of any printed work; specifically, the publication in one country of a work previously published in another.
One who reprints.

entry.cs: Letters of marque and reprisal. See under Marque.
entry.ety: F. repr�saille, It. ripresaglia rappresaglia, LL. reprensaliae, fr. L. reprehendere reprehensum. See Reprehend Reprise

sn.def: The act of taking from an enemy by way of reteliation or indemnity.
sn.q: Debatable ground, on which incursions and reprisals continued to take place.

sn.def: Anything taken from an enemy in retaliation.
The act of retorting on an enemy by inflicting suffering or death on a prisoner taken from him, in retaliation for an act of inhumanity.
Any act of retaliation.

entry.ety: F. reprise, fr. reprendre repris, to take back, L. reprehendere. See Reprehend

sn.def: A taking by way of retaliation.
Deductions and duties paid yearly out of a manor and lands, as rent charge, rent seck, pensions, annuities, and the like.
A ship recaptured from an enemy or from a pirate.

entry.ety: Written also reprize

sn.def: To take again; to retake.
To recompense; to pay.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + pristine
entry.def: To restore to an original state.
Restoration to an original state; renewal of purity.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + L. privare to deprive
entry.def: To take back or away.
To reprieve.
See Reprise.
See Reprise n., 2.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reproached -pr?cht"; p. pr. & vb. n. Reproaching
entry.ety: F. reprocher, OF. reprochier, (assumed) LL. reproriare; L. pref. re- again, against, back + prope near; hence, originally, to bring near to, throw in one's teeth. Cf. Approach

sn.def: To come back to, or come home to, as a matter of blame; to bring shame or disgrace upon; to disgrace.
sn.q: I thought your marriage fit; else imputation, For that he knew you, might reproach your life.

sn.def: To attribute blame to; to allege something disgraceful against; to charge with a fault; to censure severely or contemptuously; to upbraid.
sn.q: If ye be reproached for the name of Christ.
That this newcomer, Shame, There sit not, and reproach us as unclean.
Mezentius . . . with his ardor warmed His fainting friends, reproached their shameful flight. Repelled the victors.
sn.syn: To upbraid; censure; blame; chide; rebuke; condemn; revile; vilify.

entry.ety: F. reproche. See Reproach v.

sn.def: The act of reproaching; censure mingled with contempt; contumelious or opprobrious language toward any person; abusive reflections; as, severe reproach .
sn.q: No reproaches even, even when pointed and barbed with the sharpest wit, appeared to give him pain.
Give not thine heritage to reproach.

sn.def: A cause of blame or censure; shame; disgrace.
An object of blame, censure, scorn, or derision.
sn.q: Come, and let us build up the wall of Jerusalem, that we be no more a reproach.
sn.syn: Disrepute; discredit; dishonor; opprobrium; invective; contumely; reviling; abuse; vilification; scurrility; insolence; insult; scorn; contempt; ignominy; shame; scandal;; disgrace; infamy.

entry.ety: Cf. F. reprochable

sn.def: Deserving reproach; censurable.
Opprobrius; scurrilous.

entry.def: One who reproaches.

sn.def: Expressing or containing reproach; upbraiding; opprobrious; abusive.
sn.q: The reproachful speeches . . . That he hath breathed in my dishonor here.

sn.def: Occasioning or deserving reproach; shameful; base; as, a reproachful life.
sn.syn: Opprobrious; contumelious; abusive; offensive; insulting; contemptuous; scornful; insolent; scurrilous; disreputable; discreditable; dishonorable; shameful; disgraceful; scandalous; base; vile; infamous.

entry.def: Being without reproach.
Reprobation.
Reprobation.

entry.ety: L. reprobatus, p. p. of reprobare to disapprove, condemn. See Reprieve Reprove

sn.def: Not enduring proof or trial; not of standard purity or fineness; disallowed; rejected.
sn.q: Reprobate silver shall men call them, because the Lord hath rejected them.

sn.def: Abandoned to punishment; hence, morally abandoned and lost; given up to vice; depraved.
sn.q: And strength, and art, are easily outdone By spirits reprobate.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to one who is given up to wickedness; as, reprobate conduct.
sn.q: Reprobatedesire.
sn.syn: Abandoned; vitiated; depraved; corrupt; wicked; profligate; base; vile. See Abandoned.

entry.def: One morally abandoned and lost.
entry.q: I acknowledge myself for a reprobate, a villain, a traitor to the king.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reprobated -b?`t?d; p. pr. & vb. n. Reprobating

sn.def: To disapprove with detestation or marks of extreme dislike; to condemn as unworthy; to disallow; to reject.
sn.q: Such an answer as this is reprobated and disallowed of in law; I do not believe it, unless the deed appears.
Every scheme, every person, recommended by one of them, was reprobated by the other.

sn.def: To abandon to punishment without hope of pardon.
sn.syn: To condemn; reprehend; censure; disown; abandon; reject.

entry.def: The state of being reprobate.
One who reprobates.

entry.ety: F. réprobation, or L. reprobatio

sn.def: The act of reprobating; the state of being reprobated; strong disapproval or censure.
sn.q: The profligate pretenses upon which he was perpetually soliciting an increase of his disgraceful stipend are mentioned with becoming reprobation.
Set a brand of reprobation on clipped poetry and false coin.

sn.def: The predestination of a certain number of the human race as reprobates, or objects of condemnation and punishment.

entry.def: One who believes in reprobation. See Reprobation, 2.
Of or pertaining to reprobation; expressing reprobation.
Reprobative.

entries.entry: Re`pro*duce" r?`pr?-d?s" v. t. To produce again. Especially: To bring forward again; as, to reproduce a witness; to reproduce charges; to reproduce a play. To cause to exist again. Those colors are unchangeable, and whenever all those rays with those their colors are mixed again they reproduce the same white light as before. To produce again, by generation or the like; to cause the existence of (something of the same class, kind, or nature as another thing); to generate or beget, as offspring; as, to reproduce a rose; some animals are reproduced by gemmation. To make an image or other representation of; to portray; to cause to exist in the memory or imagination; to make a copy of; as, to reproduce a person's features in marble, or on canvas; to reproduce a design.

sn.def: One who, or that which, reproduces.
In a phonograph, a device containing a sounding diaphragm and the needle or stylus that traverses the moving record, for reproducing the sound.
In a manograph, a device for reproducing the engine stroke on a reduced scale.

entry.note: ☞ There are two distinct methods of reproduction; viz.: asexual reproductionagamogenesis) and sexual reproductiongamogenesis). In both cases the new individual is developed from detached portions of the parent organism. In asexual reproduction (gemmation, fission, etc.), the detached portions of the organism develop into new individuals without the intervention of other living matter. In sexual reproduction, the detached portion, which is always a single cell, called the female germ cell, is acted upon by another portion of living matter, the male germ cell, usually from another organism, and in the fusion of the two (impregnation) a new cell is formed, from the development of which arises a new individual.
entry.ety: Cf. F. reproduction
entry.sn: The act or process of reproducing; the state of being reproduced; specifically Biol the process by which plants and animals give rise to offspring.

sn.def: That which is reproduced.

entry.ety: Cf. F. reproductif
entry.def: Tending, or pertaining, to reproduction; employed in reproduction.
Reproductive.

entry.ety: OE. reproef. See Proof Reprove

sn.def: Refutation; confutation; contradiction.
An expression of blame or censure; especially, blame expressed to the face; censure for a fault; chiding; reproach.
sn.q: Those best can bear reproof who merit praise.
sn.syn: Admonition; reprehension; chiding; reprimand; rebuke; censure; blame. See Admonition.

entry.ety: Cf. F. réprouvable
entry.def: Worthy of reproof or censure.
entry.syn: Blamable; blameworthy; censurable; reprehensible; culpable; rebukable.

entry.def: Reproof.

entry.usage: Reprove Rebuke Reprimand. These words all signufy the expression of disapprobation. To reprove implies greater calmness and self-possession. To rebuke implies a more excited and personal feeling. A reproof may be administered long after the offience is committed, and is usually intended for the reformation of the offender; a rebuke is commonly given at the moment of the wrong, and is administered by way of punishment and condemnation. A reprimand proceeds from a person invested with authority, and is a formal and offiscial act. A child is reproved for his faults, and rebuked for his impudence. A military officer is reprimanded for neglect or violation of duty.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reproved -pr??vd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Reproving
entry.ety: F. réprouver, OF. reprover, fr. L. reprobare. See Reprieve Reprobate, and cf. Reproof

sn.def: To convince.
sn.q: When he is come, he will reprove the world of sin, and of righteousness, and of judgment.

sn.def: To disprove; to refute.
sn.q: Reprove my allegation, if you can.

sn.def: To chide to the face as blameworthy; to accuse as guilty; to censure.
sn.q: What if thy son
Prove disobedient, and, reproved, retort, “Wherefore didst thou beget me?”

sn.def: To express disapprobation of; as, to reprove faults.
sn.q: He neither reproved the ordinance of John, neither plainly condemned the fastings of the other men.
sn.syn: To reprehend; chide; rebuke; scold; blame censure.

entry.def: One who, or that which, reproves.
In a reproving manner.
To prune again or anew.
entry.q: Yet soon reprunes her wing to soar anew.

entry.ety: See Reap
entry.def: Money anciently paid by servile tenants to their lord, in lieu of the customary service of reaping his corn or grain.

entry.ety: L. reptans -antis, p. pr. of reptare, v. intens. from repere to creep. See Reptile

sn.def: Same as Repent.
Creeping; crawling; -- said of reptiles, worms, etc.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A division of gastropods; the Pectinibranchiata.

entry.ety: L. reptatio, from reptare: cf. F. reptation
entry.def: The act of creeping.
Creeping.

entry.ety: F. reptile, L. reptilis, fr. repere reptum, to creep; cf. Lith. reploti; perh. akin to L. serpere. Cf. Serpent

sn.def: Creeping; moving on the belly, or by means of small and short legs.
Hence: Groveling; low; vulgar; as, a reptile race or crew; reptile vices.
sn.q: There is also a false, reptile prudence, the result not of caution, but of fear.
And dislodge their reptile souls From the bodies and forms of men.

entry.note: ☞ The amphibians were formerly classed with Reptilia, and are still popularly called reptiles, though much more closely allied to the fishes.

sn.def: An animal that crawls, or moves on its belly, as snakes,, or by means of small, short legs, as lizards, and the like.
sn.q: An inadvertent step may crush the snail That crawls at evening in the public path; But he that has humanity, forewarned, Will tread aside, and let the reptile live.

sn.def: One of the Reptilia, or one of the Amphibia.
A groveling or very mean person.

entry.note: ☞ It is nearly related in many respects to Aves, or birds. The principal existing orders are Testidunata or Cheloniaturtles), Crocodilia Lacertillalizards), Ophidiaserpents), and Rhynchocephala; the chief extinct orders are Dinosauria Theremorpha Mosasauria Pterosauria Plesiosauria Ichtyosauria.
entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A class of air-breathing oviparous vertebrates, usually covered with scales or bony plates. The heart generally has two auricles and one ventricle. The development of the young is the same as that of birds.

cs.cd: that part of geological time comprising the Triassic, Jurassic, and Cretaceous periods, and distinguished as that era in which the class of reptiles attained its highest expansion; -- called also the Secondary or Mezozoic age.

entry.def: Belonging to the reptiles.
One of the Reptilia; a reptile.

entry.note: ☞ In some ancient states called republics the sovereign power was exercised by an hereditary aristocracy or a privileged few, constituting a government now distinctively called an aristocracy. In some there was a division of authority between an aristocracy and the whole body of the people except slaves. No existing republic recognizes an exclusive privilege of any class to govern, or tolerates the institution of slavery.

cs.cd: The collective body of literary or learned men.

entry.ety: F. république, L. respublica commonwealth; res a thing, an affair + publicus publica, public. See Real a., and Public

sn.def: Common weal.
A state in which the sovereign power resides in the whole body of the people, and is exercised by representatives elected by them; a commonwealth. Cf. Democracy, 2.

entry.cs: Republican party. U.S. Politics An earlier name of the Democratic party when it was opposed to the Federal party. Thomas Jefferson was its great leader. One of the existing great parties. It was organized in 1856 by a combination of voters from other parties for the purpose of opposing the extension of slavery, and in 1860 it elected Abraham Lincoln president.
entry.ety: F. républicain

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a republic.
sn.q: The Roman emperors were republican magistrates named by the senate.

sn.def: Consonant with the principles of a republic; as, republican sentiments or opinions; republican manners.

entry.cs: Red republican. See under Red.

sn.def: One who favors or prefers a republican form of government.
A member of the Republican party.

sd.def: The American cliff swallow. The cliff swallows build their nests side by side, many together.
A South African weaver bird (Philetærus socius). These weaver birds build many nests together, under a large rooflike shelter, which they make of straw.

entry.ety: Cf. F. républicanisme

sn.def: A republican form or system of government; the principles or theory of republican government.
Attachment to, or political sympathy for, a republican form of government.
The principles and policy of the Republican party, so called

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Republicanized -?zd; p. pr. & vb. n. Republicanizing -?`z?ng
entry.ety: Cf. F. républicaniser
entry.def: To change, as a state, into a republic; to republican principles; as, France was republicanized; to republicanize the rising generation.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. republicare
entry.def: To make public again; to republish.

A second publication, or a new publication of something before published, as of a former will, of a volume already published, or the like; specifically, the publication in one country of a work first issued in another; a reprint.
entry.q: If there be many testaments, the last overthrows all the former; but the republication of a former will revokes one of a later date, and establishes the first.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Republished -l?sht; p. pr. & vb. n. Republishing
entry.def: To publish anew; specifically, to publish in one country (a work first published in another); also, to revive (a will) by re�xecution or codicil.
entry.q: Subsecquent to the purchase or contract, the devisor republished his will.

entry.def: One who republishes.

entry.ety: See Repudilate
entry.def: Admitting of repudiation; fit or proper to be put away.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Repudiated -?`t?d; p. pr. & vb. n. Repudiating
entry.ety: L. repudiatus, p. p. of repudiare to repudiate, reject, fr. repudium separation, divorce; pref. re- re- + pudere to be ashamed

sn.def: To cast off; to disavow; to have nothing to do with; to renounce; to reject.
sn.q: Servitude is to be repudiated with greater care.

sn.def: To divorce, put away, or discard, as a wife, or a woman one has promised to marry.
sn.q: His separation from Terentis, whom he repudiated not long afterward.

sn.def: To refuse to acknowledge or to pay; to disclaim; as, the State has repudiated its debts.

entry.ety: Cf.F. répudiation, L. repudiatio
entry.def: The act of repudiating, or the state of being repuddiated; as, the repudiation of a doctrine, a wife, a debt, etc.
One who favors repudiation, especially of a public debt.

entry.ety: L., a rejecter, contemner
entry.def: One who repudiates.

entry.ety: F. répugner, L. repugnare repugnatum; pref. re- + pugnare to fight. See Pugnacious
entry.def: To fight against; to oppose; to resist.
entry.q: Stubbornly he did repugn the truth.

entry.def: Capable of being repugned or resisted.

entry.ety: F. répugnance, L. repugnantia
entry.def: The state or condition of being repugnant; opposition; contrariety; especially, a strong instinctive antagonism; aversion; reluctance; unwillingness, as of mind, passions, principles, qualities, and the like.
entry.q: That which causes us to lose most of our time is the repugnance which we naturally have to labor.
Let the foes quietly cut their throats, Without repugnancy.
entry.syn: Aversion; reluctance; unwillingness; dislike; antipathy; hatred; hostility; irreconcilableness; contrariety; inconsistency. See Dislike.

entry.ety: F. répugnant, or L. repugnans -antis, p. pr. of repugnare. See Repugn
entry.def: Disposed to fight against; hostile; at war with; being at variance; contrary; inconsistent; refractory; disobedient; also, distasteful in a high degree; offensive; -- usually followed by to, rarely and less properly by with; as, all rudeness was repugnant to her nature.
entry.q: His swordrepugnant to command.
There is no breach of a divine law but is more or less repugnant unto the will of the Lawgiver, God himself.
entry.syn: Opposite; opposed; adverse; contrary; inconsistent; irreconcilable; hostile; inimical.

entry.def: In a repugnant manner.

entry.ety: From L. repugnare. See Repugn
entry.def: To oppose; to fight against.
One who repugns.

entry.ety: L. repullulare repullulatum. See Pullulate
entry.def: To bud again.
entry.q: Though tares repullulate, there is wheat still left in the field.

entry.def: The act of budding again; the state of having budded again.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Repulsed -p?lst"; p. pr. & vb. n. Repulsing
entry.ety: L. repulsus, p. p. of repellere. See Repel

sn.def: To repel; to beat or drive back; as, to repulse an assault; to repulse the enemy.
sn.q: Complete to have discovered and repulsed Whatever wiles of foe or seeming friend.

sn.def: To repel by discourtesy, coldness, or denial; to reject; to send away; as, to repulse a suitor or a proffer.

entry.ety: L. repulsa, fr. repellere repulsum

sn.def: The act of repelling or driving back; also, the state of being repelled or driven back.
sn.q: By fate repelled, and with repulses tired.
He received in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts in the body.

sn.def: Figuratively: Refusal; denial; rejection; failure.

entry.def: Not capable of being repulsed.
One who repulses, or drives back.

entry.ety: L. repulsio: cf. F. répulsion

sn.def: The act of repulsing or repelling, or the state of being repulsed or repelled.
A feeling of violent offence or disgust; repugnance.

The power, either inherent or due to some physical action, by which bodies, or the particles of bodies, are made to recede from each other, or to resist each other's nearer approach; as, molecular repulsion; electrical repulsion.

entry.ety: Cf. F. répulsif

sn.def: Serving, or able, to repulse; repellent; as, a repulsive force.
sn.q: Repulsive of his might the weapon stood.

sn.def: Cold; forbidding; offensive; as, repulsive manners.

entry.ety: L. repulsorius
entry.def: Repulsive; driving back.
To buy back or again; to regain by purchase.
The act of repurchasing.
To purify again.

entry.ety: From Repute
entry.def: Having, or worthy of, good repute; held in esteem; honorable; praiseworthy; as, a reputable man or character; reputable conduct.
entry.q: In the article of danger, it is as reputable to elude an enemy as defeat one.
entry.syn: Respectable; creditable; estimable.

entry.ety: F. réputation, L. reputatio a reckoning, consideration. See Repute v. t.

sn.def: The estimation in which one is held; character in public opinion; the character attributed to a person, thing, or action; repute.
sn.q: The best evidence of reputation is a man's whole life.

sn.def: The character imputed to a person in the community in which he lives. It is admissible in evidence when he puts his character in issue, or when such reputation is otherwise part of the issue of a case.
Specifically: Good reputation; favorable regard; public esteem; general credit; good name.
sn.q: I see my reputation is at stake.
The security of his reputation or good name.

sn.def: Account; value.
sn.q: /Christ] made himself of no reputation.
sn.syn: Credit; repute; regard; estimation; esteem; honor; fame. See the Note under Character.

entry.def: By repute.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reputed; p. pr. & vb. n. Reputing
entry.ety: F. réputer, L. reputare to count over, think over; pref. re- re- + putare to count, think. See Putative
entry.def: To hold in thought; to account; to estimate; to hold; to think; to reckon.
entry.q: Wherefore are we counted as beasts, and reputed vile in your sight?
The king your father was reputed for A prince most prudent.

sn.def: Character reputed or attributed; reputation, whether good or bad; established opinion; public estimate.
sn.q: He who regns Monarch in heaven, till then as one secure Sat on his throne, upheld by old repute.

sn.def: Specifically: Good character or reputation; credit or honor derived from common or public opinion; -- opposed to disrepute.
sn.q: Dead stocks, which have been ofrepute.

entry.def: In common opinion or estimation; by repute.
Not having good repute; disreputable; disgraceful; inglorius.
To require.

entry.cs: Court of Requests. A local tribunal, sometimes called Court of Consience, founded by act of Parliament to facilitate the recovery of small debts from any inhabitant or trader in the district defined by the act; -- now mostly abolished. A court of equity for the relief of such persons as addressed the sovereign by supplication; -- now abolished. It was inferior to the Court of Chancery. Eng Brande & C.
entry.ety: OE. requeste, OF. requeste, F. requête, LL. requesta, for requisita, fr. L. requirere requisitum, to seek again, ask for. See Require, and cf. Quest

sn.def: The act of asking for anything desired; expression of desire or demand; solicitation; prayer; petition; entreaty.
sn.q: I will marry her, sir, at your request.

sn.def: That which is asked for or requested.
sn.q: He gave them theirrequest.
I will both hear and grant you your requests.

sn.def: A state of being desired or held in such estimation as to be sought after or asked for; demand.
sn.q: Knowledge and fame were in as great request as wealth among us now.
sn.syn: Asking; solicitation; petition; prayer; supplication; entreaty; suit.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Requested; p. pr. & vb. n. Requesting
entry.ety: Cf. OF. requester, F. requêter

sn.def: To ask for (something); to express desire ffor; to solicit; as, to request his presence, or a favor.
To address with a request; to ask.
sn.q: I request you To give my poor host freedom.
sn.syn: To ask; solicit; entreat; beseech. See Beg.

entry.def: One who requests; a petitioner.
To quicken anew; to reanimate; to give new life to.

entry.ety: Acc. of L. requies rest, the first words of the Mass being “Requiem aeternam dona eis, Domine,” give eternal rest to them, O lord; pref. re- re + quies quiet. See Quiet n., and cf. Requin

sn.def: A mass said or sung for the repose of a departed soul.
sn.q: We should profane the service of the dead To sing a requiem and such rest to her As to peace-parted souls.

sn.def: Any grand musical composition, performed in honor of a deceased person.
Rest; quiet; peace.
sn.q: Else had I an eternal requiem kept, And in the arms of peace forever slept.

entry.ety: L. requietorium, fr. requiescere requietum, to rest. See Re-, and Quiesce
entry.def: A sepulcher.

entry.ety: F., fr. reqiem a Mass sung for the dead. See Requiem
entry.def: The man-eater, or white shark (Carcharodon carcharias); -- so called on account of its causing requiems to be sung.
Capable of being required; proper to be required.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Required -kw?rd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Requiring
entry.ety: OE. requeren requiren, OF. requerre, F. requ�rir; L. pref. re- re- + quaerere to ask; cf. L. requirere. See Query, and cf. Request Requisite

sn.def: To demand; to insist upon having; to claim as by right and authority; to exact; as, to require the surrender of property.
sn.q: Shall I say to Cæsar What you require of him?
By nature did what was by law required.

sn.def: To demand or exact as indispensable; to need.
sn.q: Just gave what life required, and gave no more.
The two last [biographiesrequire to be particularly noticed.

sn.def: To ask as a favor; to request.
sn.q: I was ashamed to require of the king a band of soldiers and horsemen to help us against the enemy in the way.
sn.syn: To claim; exact; enjoin; prescribe; direct; order; demand; need.

sn.def: The act of requiring; demand; requisition.
That which is required; an imperative or authoritative command; an essential condition; something needed or necessary; a need.
sn.q: One of those who believe that they can fill up every requirement contained in the rule of righteousness.
God gave her the child, and gave her too an instinctive knowledge of its nature and requirements.

entry.def: One who requires.
That which is required, or is necessary; something indispensable.
entry.q: God, on his part, has declared the requisites on ours; what we must do to obtain blessings, is the great business of us all to know.

entry.ety: L. requisitus, p. p. requirere; pref. re- re- + quaerere to ask. See Require
entry.def: Required by the nature of things, or by circumstances; so needful that it can not be dispensed with; necessary; indispensable.
entry.q: All truth requisite for men to know.
entry.syn: Necessary; needful; indispensable; essential.

entry.ety: Cf. F. réquisition, L. requisitio a searching
entry.sn:
The act of requiring, as of right; a demand or application made as by authority. Specifically: International Law A formal demand made by one state or government upon another for the surrender or extradition of a fugitive from justice. Kent.
Law A notarial demand of a debt. Wharton.
Mil A demand by the invader upon the people of an invaded country for supplies, as of provision, forage, transportation, etc. Farrow.
A formal application by one officer to another for things needed in the public service; as, a requisition for clothing, troops, or money.

sn.def: That which is required by authority; especially, a quota of supplies or necessaries.
A written or normal call; an invitation; a summons; as, a reqisition for a public meeting.
To make a reqisition on or for; as, to requisition a district for forage; to requisition troops.
To present a requisition to; to summon request; as, to requisition a person to be a candidate.

entry.def: One who makes or signs a requisition.
Expressing or implying demand.
One who, or that which, makes requisition; a requisitionist.
One who makes reqisition; esp., one authorized by a requisition to investigate facts.
Sought for; demanded.
That may be requited.

entry.ety: From Requite
entry.def: The act of requiting; also, that which requites; return, good or bad, for anything done; in a good sense, compensation; recompense; as, the requital of services; in a bad sense, retaliation, or punishment; as, the requital of evil deeds.
entry.q: No merit their aversion can remove, Nor ill requital can efface their love.
entry.syn: Compensation; recompense; remuneration; reward; satisfaction; payment; retribution; retaliation; reprisal; punishment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Requited; p. pr. & vb. n. Requiting
entry.ety: Pref. re- + quit
entry.def: To repay; in a good sense, to recompense; to return (an equivalent) in good; to reward; in a bad sense, to retaliate; to return (evil) for evil; to punish.
entry.q: He can requite thee; for he knows the charma That call fame on such gentle acts as these.
Thou hast seen it; for thou beholdest mischief and spite, to requite it with thy hand.
entry.syn: To repay; reward; pay; compensate; remunerate; satisfy; recompense; punish; revenge.

entry.def: Requital
One who requites.

entry.ety: F. arri�re-bras
entry.def: Armor for the upper part of the arm.

entry.ety: F. arri�re back + de of + main hand
entry.def: A backward stroke.

entry.ety: From rear + F. dos back, L. dorsum. Cf. Dorsal
entry.def: A screen or partition wall behind an altar.
The back of a fireplace.
The open hearth, upon which fires were lighted, immediately under the louver, in the center of ancient halls.

entry.ety: F. arrière-fief. See Rear hinder, and Fief
entry.def: A fief held of a superior feudatory; a fief held by an under tenant.
To reign again.
To reiterate many times.
entry.q: Myre-reiteratedwish.

entry.def: A rearmouse.
To resolve again.
entry.q: Resolves, and re-resolves, then dies the same.

entry.ety: See Rearward
entry.def: The rear guard of an army.

entries.entry:
‖Res
‖Res gestæ L., things done Law the facts which form the environment of a litigated issue. Wharton. ‖Res judicata L Law a thing adjudicated; a matter no longer open to controversy.
r?z n.; pl.Res. L A thing; the particular thing; a matter; a point.

entry.def: To sail again; also, to sail back, as to a former port.
A sale at second hand, or at retail; also, a second sale.
Realgar.
To salute again.
To saw again; specifically, to saw a balk, or a timber, which has already been squared, into dimension lumber, as joists, boards, etc.

entry.ety: Sp. rescattar
entry.def: To ransom; to release; to rescue.

entry.ety: Sp. rescate
entry.def: Ransom; release.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rescinded; p. pr. & vb. n. Rescinding
entry.ety: L. rescindere rescissum; pref re- re- + scindere to cut, split: cf. F. rescinder. See Shism

sn.def: To cut off; to abrogate; to annul.
sn.q: The blessed Jesus . . . did sacramentally rescind the impure relics of Adam and the contraction of evil customs.

sn.def: Specifically, to vacate or make void, as an act, by the enacting authority or by superior authority; to repeal; as, to rescind a law, a resolution, or a vote; to rescind a decree or a judgment.
sn.syn: To revoke; repeal; abrogate; annul; recall; reverse; vacate; void.

entry.def: Capable of being rescinded.
The act of rescinding; rescission.

entry.ety: L. rescissio: cf. F. rescission. See Rescind
entry.def: The act of rescinding, abrogating, annulling, or vacating; as, the rescission of a law, decree, or judgment.

entry.ety: L. rescissorius: cf. F. rescisoire
entry.def: Tending to rescind; rescinding.
entry.q: To pass a general act rescissoryas it was called), annulling all the Parliaments that had been held since the year 1633.

entry.ety: OE., fr. OF. rescousse, fr. rescourre, p. p. rescous, to rescue. See Rescue

sn.def: Rescue; deliverance.
See Rescue, 2.

entry.def: To rescue.

entry.ety: L. rescribere; pref. re- re- + scribere to write. See Scribe

sn.def: To write back; to write in reply.
To write over again.

entry.ety: L. rescriptum: cf. F. rescrit, formerly also spelt rescript. See Rescribe,v. t.

sn.def: The answer of an emperor when formallyconsulted by particular persons on some difficult question; hence, an edict or decree.
sn.q: In their rescripts and other ordinances, the Roman emperors spoke in the plural number.

sn.def: The official written answer of the pope upon a question of canon law, or morals.
A counterpart.

entry.ety: L. rescriptio: cf. F. rescription. See Rescribe
entry.def: A writing back; the answering of a letter.
Pertaining to, or answering the purpose of, a rescript; hence, deciding; settling; determining.
By rescript.
That may be rescued.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rescued -k?d;p. pr. & vb. n. Rescuing
entry.ety: OE. rescopuen, OF. rescourre rescurre rescorre; L. pref. re- re- + excutere to shake or drive out; ex out + quatere to shake. See Qtash to crush, Rercussion
entry.def: To free or deliver from any confinement, violence, danger, or evil; to liberate from actual restraint; to remove or withdraw from a state of exposure to evil; as, to rescue a prisoner from the enemy; to rescue seamen from destruction.
entry.q: Had I been seized by a hungry lion, I would have been a breakfast to the best, Rather than have false Proteus rescue me.
entry.syn: To retake; recapture; free; deliver; liberate; release; save.

entry.cs: Rescue grass. Etymol. uncertain Bot A tall grass (Ceratochloa unioloides) somewhat resembling chess, cultivated for hay and forage in the Southern States.
entry.ety: From Rescue v.; cf. Rescous

sn.def: The act of rescuing; deliverance from restraint, violence, or danger; liberation.
sn.q: Spur to the rescue of the noble Talbot.

sd.def: The forcible retaking, or taking away, against law, of things lawfully distrained.
The forcible liberation of a person from an arrest or imprisonment.
The retaking by a party captured of a prize made by the enemy.
sd.q: The rescue of a prisoner from the court is punished with perpetual imprisonment and forfeiture of goods.

entry.def: Without rescue or release.
One who rescues.
The party in whose favor a rescue is made.

entry.ety: LL
entry.def: One who makes an unlawful rescue; a rescuer.
To shake; to quake; to tremble.
entry.q: It made all the gates for torese.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + search
entry.def: To search again; to examine anew.

entry.note: The distinctive characteristic of scientific research is the maintenance of records and careful control or observation of conditions under which the phenomena are studied so that others will be able to reproduce the observations. When the person conducting the research varies the conditions beforehand in order to test directly the effects of changing conditions on the results of the observation, such investigation is called experimental research or experimentation or experimental science ; it is often conducted in a laboratory. If the investigation is conducted with a view to obtaining information directly useful in producing objects with commercial or practical utility, the research is called applied research . Investigation conducted for the primary purpose of discovering new facts about natural phenomena, or to elaborate or test theories about natural phenomena, is called basic research or fundamental research . Research in fields such as astronomy, in which the phenomena to be observed cannot be controlled by the experimenter, is called observational research . Epidemiological research is a type of observational research in which the researcher applies statistical methods to analyse patterns of occurrence of disease and its association with other phenomena within a population, with a view to understanding the origins or mode of transmission of the disease.
entry.ety: Pref. re- + search: cf OF. recerche, F. recherche

sn.def: Diligent inquiry or examination in seeking facts or principles; laborious or continued search after truth; as, researches of human wisdom; to research a topic in the library; medical research .
sn.q: The dearest interests of parties have frequently been staked on the results of the researches of antiquaries.

sn.def: Systematic observation of phenomena for the purpose of learning new facts or testing the application of theories to known facts; -- also called scientific research. This is the research part of the phrase “research and development” (R&D).
sn.syn: Investigation; examination; inquiry; scrutiny.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + search: cf. OF. recerchier, F. rechercher
entry.def: To search or examine with continued care; to seek diligently.
One who conducts research. In the field of scientific research, also called an investigator or scientist.
Making researches; inquisitive.

sn.def: To seat or set again, as on a chair, throne, etc.
To put a new seat, or new seats, in; as, to reseat a theater; to reseat a chair or trousers.

entries.entry: ‖Ré`seau" rā`zō" n. F A network; specif.: Astron A system of lines forming small squares of standard size, which is photographed, by a separate exposure, on the same plate with star images to facilitate measurements, detect changes of the film, etc. In lace, a ground or foundation of regular meshes, like network.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resected;p. pr. & vb. n. Resecting

entry.ety: L. , a kind of plant

sn.def: A genus of plants, the type of which is mignonette.
A grayish green color, like that of the flowers of mignonette.

entry.def: To seek again.

sn.def: To seize again, or a second time.

entry.def: A second seizure; the act of seizing again.
To sell again; to sell what has been bought or sold; to retail.

entry.ety: See Resemble
entry.def: Admitting of being compared; like.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ressemblance. See Resemble

sn.def: The quality or state of resembling; likeness; similitude; similarity.

Probability; verisimilitude.
sn.syn: Likeness; similarity; similitude; semblance; representation; image.

entry.ety: F., a . and p. pr. fr. ressembler to resemble. See Resemble
entry.def: Having or exhibiting resemblance; resembling.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resembled -b'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Resembling -bl?ng
entry.ety: F. ressembler; pref. re- re- + sembler to seem, resemble, fr. L. similare simulare, to imitate, fr. similis like, similar. See Similar

sn.def: To be like or similar to; to bear the similitude of, either in appearance or qualities; as, these brothers resemble each other.
sn.q: We will resemble you in that.

sn.def: To liken; to compare; to represent as like.
sn.q: The other . . . He did resemble to his lady bright.

sn.def: To counterfeit; to imitate.

So as to resemble; with resemblance or likeness.

entry.ety: L. pref. re- again + seminatus, p. p. of seminare to sow
entry.def: To produce again by means of seed.

sn.def: To send again; as, to resend a message.
To send back; as, to resend a gift.
To send on from an intermediate station by means of a repeater.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resented; p. pr. & vb. n. Resenting
entry.ety: F. ressentir; L. pref. re- re- + sentire to feel. See Sense
entry.sn:
To be sensible of; to feel; as: In a good sense, to take well; to receive with satisfaction. Obs Which makes the tragical ends of noble persons more favorably resented by compassionate readers.
In a bad sense, to take ill; to consider as an injury or affront; to be indignant at.

sn.def: To express or exhibit displeasure or indignation at, as by words or acts.
sn.q: The good prince King James . . . bore dishonorably what he might have resented safely.

sn.def: To recognize; to perceive, especially as if by smelling; -- associated in meaning with sent, the older spelling of scent to smell. See Resent v. i.
sn.q: This bird of prey resented a worse than earthly savor in the soul of Saul.
Our King Henry the Seventh quickly resented his drift.

sn.def: To feel resentment.
To give forth an odor; to smell; to savor.
sn.q: The judicious prelate will prefer a drop of the sincere milk of the word before vessels full of traditionary pottage resenting of the wild gourd of human invention.

entry.def: One who resents.
Inclined to resent; easily provoked to anger; irritable.
Resentment.

sn.def: With deep sense or strong perception.
With a sense of wrong or affront; with resentment.

entry.def: Resentful.

entry.usage: Resentment Anger. Anger is the broader term, denoting a keen sense of disapprobation (usually with a desire to punish) for whatever we feel to be wrong, whether directed toward ourselves or others. Resentment is anger exicted by a sense of personal injury. It is, etymologically, that reaction of the mind which we instinctively feel when we think ourselves wronged. Pride and selfishness are apt to aggravate this feeling until it changes into a criminal animosity; and this is now the more common signification of the term. Being founded in a sense of injury, this feeling is hard to be removed; and hence the expressions bitter or implacable resentment. See Anger.
entry.ety: F. ressentiment

sn.def: The act of resenting.
The state of holding something in the mind as a subject of contemplation, or of being inclined to reflect upon something; a state of consciousness; conviction; feeling; impression.
sn.q: He retains vivid resentments of the more solid morality.
It is a greater wonder that so many of them die, with so little resentment of their danger.

sn.def: In a good sense, satisfaction; gratitude.
sn.q: The Council taking notice of the many good services performed by Mr. John Milton, . . . have thought fit to declare their resentment and good acceptance of the same.

sn.def: In a bad sense, strong displeasure; anger; hostility provoked by a wrong or injury experienced.
sn.q: Resentment . . . is a deep, reflective displeasure against the conduct of the offender.
sn.syn: Anger; irritation; vexation; displeasure; grudge; indignation; choler; gall; ire; wrath; rage; fury.
sn.q: Anger is like A full-hot horse, who being allowed his way, Self-mettle tires him.
Can heavently minds such high resentment show, Or exercise their spite in human woe?

entry.ety: L. reseratus, p. p. of reserare to unlock
entry.def: To unlock; to open.
Reservation.

entry.note: ☞ This term is often used in the same sense with exception, the technical distinction being disregarded.

cs.cd: the withholding, or failing to disclose, something that affects a statement, promise, etc., and which, if disclosed, would materially change its import.

entry.ety: Cf. F. réservation, LL. reservatio. See Reserve

sn.def: The act of reserving, or keeping back; concealment, or withholding from disclosure; reserve.
sn.q: With reservation of an hundred knights.
Make some reservation of your wrongs.

sn.def: Something withheld, either not expressed or disclosed, or not given up or brought forward.
A tract of the public land reserved for some special use, as for schools, for the use of Indians, etc.
The state of being reserved, or kept in store.

sd.def: A clause in an instrument by which some new thing is reserved out of the thing granted, and not in esse before.
A proviso.
The portion of the sacramental elements reserved for purposes of devotion and for the communion of the absent and sick.
A term of canon law, which signifies that the pope reserves to himself appointment to certain benefices.

sn.def: an agreement to have some space, service or other acommodation, as at a hotel, a restaurant, or on a public transport system, held for one's future use; also, the record or receipt for such an agreement, or the contractual obligation to retain that accommodation; as, a hotel reservation; a reservation on a flight to Dallas; to book a reservation at the Ritz.

entry.def: Tending to reserve or keep; keeping; reserving.

entry.ety: LL. reservatorium,fr. L. resservare. See Reserve v. t., and cf. Reservior
entry.def: A place in which things are reserved or kept.

entry.note: In cases where one person or party makes a request to an agent that some accommodation (such as a hotel room or place at a restaurant) be kept (reserved) for their use at a particular time, the word reserve applies both to the action of the person making the request, and to the action of the agent who takes the approproriate action (such as a notation in a book of reservations) to be certain that the accommodation is available at that time.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reserved. (z�rvd");p. pr. & vb. n. Reserving
entry.ety: F. réserver, L. reservare reservatum; pref. re- re- + servare to keep. See Serve

sn.def: To keep back; to retain; not to deliver, make over, or disclose.
sn.q: I havereservedto myself nothing.

sn.def: Hence, to keep in store for future or special use; to withhold from present use for another purpose or time; to keep; to retain; to make a reservation{7}.
sn.q: Hast thou seen the treasures of the hail, which I have reserved against the time of trouble?
Reserve your kind looks and language for private hours.

sn.def: To make an exception of; to except.

entry.ety: F. réserve

sn.def: The act of reserving, or keeping back; reservation.
sn.q: However any one may concur in the general scheme, it is still with certain reserves and deviations.

sn.def: That which is reserved, or kept back, as for future use.
sn.q: The virgins, besides the oil in their lamps, carried likewise a reserve in some other vessel for a continual supply.

sn.def: That which is excepted; exception.
sn.q: Each has some darling lust, which pleads for a reserve.

sn.def: Restraint of freedom in words or actions; backwardness; caution in personal behavior.
sn.q: My soul, surprised, and from her sex disjoined, Left all reserve, and all the sex, behind.
The clergyman's shy and sensitive reserve had balked this scheme.

sn.def: A tract of land reserved, or set apart, for a particular purpose; as, the Connecticut Reserve in Ohio, originally set apart for the school fund of Connecticut; the Clergy Reserves in Canada, for the support of the clergy.

sd.def: A body of troops in the rear of an army drawn up for battle, reserved to support the other lines as occasion may require; a force or body of troops kept for an exigency.
troops trained but released from active service, retained as a formal part of the military force, and liable to be recalled to active service in cases of national need (see Army organization, above).

sn.def: Funds kept on hand to meet liabilities.

sn.sd: That part of the assets of a bank or other financial institution specially kept in cash in a more or less liquid form as a reasonable provision for meeting all demands which may be made upon it; specif.:

sd.def: Usually, the uninvested cash kept on hand for this purpose, called the real reserve. In Great Britain the ultimate real reserve is the gold kept on hand in the Bank of England, largely represented by the notes in hand in its own banking department; and any balance which a bank has with the Bank of England is a part of its reserve. In the United States the reserve of a national bank consists of the amount of lawful money it holds on hand against deposits, which is required by law (in 1913) to be not less than 15 per cent (U. S. Rev. Stat. secs. 5191, 5192), three fifths of which the banks not in a reserve city (which see) may keep deposited as balances in national banks that are in reserve cities (U. S. Rev. Stat. sec. 5192).

The amount of funds or assets necessary for a company to have at any given time to enable it, with interest and premiums paid as they shall accure, to meet all claims on the insurance then in force as they would mature according to the particular mortality table accepted. The reserve is always reckoned as a liability, and is calculated on net premiums. It is theoretically the difference between the present value of the total insurance and the present value of the future premiums on the insurance. The reserve, being an amount for which another company could, theoretically, afford to take over the insurance, is sometimes called the reinsurance fund or the self-insurance fund. For the first year upon any policy the net premium is called the initial reserve, and the balance left at the end of the year including interest is the terminal reserve. For subsequent years the initial reserve is the net premium, if any, plus the terminal reserve of the previous year. The portion of the reserve to be absorbed from the initial reserve in any year in payment of losses is sometimes called the insurance reserve, and the terminal reserve is then called the investment reserve.

sn.def: In exhibitions, a distinction which indicates that the recipient will get a prize if another should be disqualified.
A resist.
A preparation used on an object being electroplated to fix the limits of the deposit.

entries.entry:
Reserve city
In reserve in keeping for other or future use; in store; as, he has large quantities of wheat in reserve; he has evidence or arguments in reserve . Reserve air. Physiol Same as Supplemental air, under Supplemental. . Banking In the national banking system of the United States, any of certain cities in which the national banks are required (U. S. Rev. Stat. sec. 5191) to keep a larger reserve (25 per cent) than the minimum (15 per cent) required of all other banks. The banks in certain of the reserve cities (specifically called central reserve cities) are required to keep their reserve on hand in cash; banks in other reserve cities may keep half of their reserve as deposits in these banks (U. S. Rev. Stat. sec. 5195). Reservation; retention; limitation; backwardness; reservedness; coldness; restraint; shyness; coyness; modesty.

sn.def: Kept for future or special use, or for an exigency; as, reserved troops; a reserved seat in a theater.
Restrained from freedom in words or actions; backward, or cautious, in communicating one's thoughts and feelings; not free or frank.
sn.q: To all obliging, yet reserved to all.
Nothing reserved or sullen was to see.

entry.def: One to, or for, whom anything is reserved; -- contrasted with reservor.
One who reserves.
A member of a reserve force of soldiers or militia.

cs.cd: a principal reservoir into which an aqueduct or rising main delivers water, and from which a distributing reservoir draws its supply.

A small intercellular space, often containing resin, essential oil, or some other secreted matter.
a large quantity of infectious microorganisms resident in animals other than man, potentially capable of being transmitted to humans.

a large quantity of infectious microorganisms or parasites resident in animals other than man, potentially capable of being transmitted to humans; especially, such organisms in animals where they do little or no harm to the host.
a large supply or stock of anything which may be rapidly put to use; a reserve.

entry.def: One who reserves; a reserver.
To set again; as, to reset type; to reset copy; to reset a diamond.

That which is reset; matter set up again.

entry.def: One who receives or conceals, as stolen goods or criminal.
One who resets, or sets again.
To settle again.
To settle again, or a second time.
Act of settling again, or state of being settled again; as, the resettlement of lees.
entry.q: The resettlement of my discomposed soul.

entry.def: To shape again.
To ship again; to put on board of a vessel a second time; to send on a second voyage; as, to reship bonded merchandise.
To engage one's self again for service on board of a vessel after having been discharged.
The act of reshipping; also, that which is reshipped.
One who reships.

entry.ety: LL. reseantia, �� OF. reseance
entry.def: Residence; abode.

entry.def: Resident; present in a place.
entry.q: In which her kingdom's throne is chiefly resiant.

entry.def: A resident.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resided; p. pr. & vb. n. Residing

sn.q: At the moated grange, resides this dejected Mariana.
In no fixed place the happy souls reside.

sn.def: To have a seat or fixed position; to inhere; to lie or be as in attribute or element.
sn.q: In such like acts, the duty and virtue of contentedness doth especially reside.

sn.def: To sink; to settle, as sediment.
sn.syn: To dwell; inhabit; sojourn; abide; remain; live; domiciliate; domicile.

sn.def: The act or fact of residing, abiding, or dwelling in a place for some continuance of time; as, the residence of an American in France or Italy for a year.
sn.q: The confessor had often made considerable residences in Normandy.

sn.def: The place where one resides; an abode; a dwelling or habitation; esp., a settled or permanent home or domicile.
sn.q: Near theresidenceof Posthumus.
Johnson took up his residence in London.

sn.def: The residing of an incumbent on his benefice; -- opposed to nonresidence.
The place where anything rests permanently.
sn.q: But when a king sets himself to bandy against the highest court and residence of all his regal power, he then, . . . fights against his own majesty and kingship.

sn.def: Subsidence, as of a sediment.
That which falls to the bottom of liquors; sediment; also, refuse; residuum.
sn.syn: Domiciliation; sojourn; stay; abode; home; dwelling; habitation; domicile; mansion.

entry.ety: Sp
entry.def: In Spanish countries, a court or trial held, sometimes as long as six months, by a newly elected official, as the governor of a province, to examine into the conduct of a predecessor.

sn.def: Residence.
A political agency at a native court in British India, held by an officer styled the Resident; also, a Dutch commercial colony or province in the East Indies.

entry.ety: F. résident, L. residens -entis, p. pr. of residere. See Reside

sn.def: Dwelling, or having an abode, in a place for a continued length of time; residing on one's own estate; -- opposed to nonresident; as, resident in the city or in the country.
Fixed; stable; certain.
sn.q: Stable andresidentlike a rock.
One there still resident as day and night.

sn.def: One who resides or dwells in a place for some time.
A diplomatic representative who resides at a foreign court; -- a term usualy applied to ministers of a rank inferior to that of ambassadors. See the Note under Minister, 4.

entry.def: A resident.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a residence or residents; as, residential trade; a residential part of town.
Residing; residentiary.

entry.ety: LL. residentiaris
entry.def: Having residence; as, a canon residentary; a residentiary guardian.

sn.def: One who is resident.
sn.q: The residentiary, or the frequent visitor of the favored spot, . . . will discover that both have been there.

sn.def: An ecclesiastic who keeps a certain residence.
sn.syn: Inhabitant; inhabiter; dweller; sojourner.

entry.def: The office or condition of a residentiary.
The office or condition of a resident.
One who resides in a place.

entry.cs: Residual air Physiol that portion of air contained in the lungs which can not be expelled even by the most violent expiratory effort. It amounts to from 75 to 100 cubic inches. Cf. Supplemental air, under Supplemental. Residual error. Mensuration See Error, 6 . Residual figure Geom the figure which remains after a less figure has been taken from a greater one. Residual magnetism Physics remanent magnetism. See under Remanent. Residual product a by product, as cotton waste from a cotton mill, coke and coal tar from gas works, etc. Residual quantity Alg a binomial quantity the two parts of which are connected by the negative sign, as a-b. Residual root Alg the root of a residual quantity, as √(a-b.
entry.ety: See Residue
entry.def: Pertaining to a residue; remaining after a part is taken.
The difference of the results obtained by observation, and by computation from a formula.
The difference between the mean of several observations and any one of them.

cs.cd: that part of the testator's will in which the residue of his estate is disposed of.
the person to whom the residue of real estate is devised by a will.
the person to whom the residue of personal estate is bequeathed.

entry.ety: See Residue
entry.def: Consisting of residue; as, residuary matter; pertaining to the residue, or part remaining; as, the residuary advantage of an estate.

entry.note: ☞ The term radical is sometimes restricted to groups containing carbon, the term residue and moiety being applied to the others.
entry.ety: F. résidu, L. residuum, fr. residuus that is left behind, remaining, fr. residere to remain behind. See Reside, and cf. Residuum

sn.def: That which remains after a part is taken, separated, removed, or designated; remnant; remainder.
sn.q: The residue of them will I deliver to the sword.
If church power had then prevailed over its victims, not a residue of English liberty would have been saved.

sn.def: That part of a testeator's estate wwhich is not disposed of in his will by particular and special legacies and devises, and which remains after payment of debts and legacies.

That which remains of a molecule after the removal of a portion of its constituents; hence, an atom or group regarded as a portion of a molecule; a moiety or group; -- used as nearly equivalent to radical, but in a more general sense.
Any positive or negative number that differs from a given number by a multiple of a given modulus; thus, if 7 is the modulus, and 9 the given number, the numbers -5, 2, 16, 23, etc., are residues .
sn.syn: Rest; remainder; remnant; balance; residuum; remains; leavings; relics.

entry.ety: L. residuus
entry.def: Remaining; residual.

entry.ety: L. See Residue
entry.def: That which is left after any process of separation or purification; that which remains after certain specified deductions are made; residue.
entry.q: “I think so,” is the whole residuum . . . after evaporating the prodigious pretensions of the zealot demagogue.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + siege a seat
entry.def: To seat again; to reinstate.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + sign
entry.def: To affix one's signature to, a second time; to sign again.

entry.usage: Resign Relinquish. To resign is to give up, as if breaking a seal and yielding all it had secured; hence, it marks a formal and deliberate surrender. To relinquish is less formal, but always implies abandonment and that the thing given up has been long an object of pursuit, and, usually, that it has been prized and desired. We resign what we once held or considered as our own, as an office, employment, etc. We speak of relinquishing a claim, of relinquishing some advantage we had sought or enjoyed, of relinquishing seme right, privilege, etc. “Men are weary with the toil which they bear, but can not find it in their hearts to relinquish it.” Steele. See Abdicate.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resigned -z?nd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Resigning
entry.ety: F. résigner, L. resignare to unseal, annul, assign, resign; pref. re- re- + signare to seal, stamp. See Sign and cf. Resignation

sn.def: To sign back; to return by a formal act; to yield to another; to surrender; -- said especially of office or emolument. Hence, to give up; to yield; to submit; -- said of the wishes or will, or of something valued; -- also often used reflexively.
sn.q: I here resign my government to thee.
Lament not, Eve, but patiently resign What justly thou hast lost.
What more reasonable, than that we should in all things resign up ourselves to the will of God?

sn.def: To relinquish; to abandon.
sn.q: He soon resigned his former suit.

sn.def: To commit to the care of; to consign.
sn.q: Gentlement of quality have been sent beyong the seas, resigned and concredited to the conduct of such as they call governors.
sn.syn: To abdicate; surrender; submit; leave; relinquish; forego; quit; forsake; abandon; renounce.

entry.def: Resignation.

entry.ety: F. résignation. See Resign

sn.def: The act of resigning or giving up, as a claim, possession, office, or the like; surrender; as, the resignation of a crown or commission.
The state of being resigned or submissive; quiet or patient submission; unresisting acquiescence; as, resignation to the will and providence of God.
sn.syn: Patience; surrender; relinquishment; forsaking; abandonment; abdication; renunciation; submission; acquiescence; endurance. See Patience.

entry.def: Submissive; yielding; not disposed to resist or murmur.
entry.q: A firm, yet cautious mind; Sincere, though prudent; constant, yet resigned.

entry.def: With submission.
One to whom anything is resigned, or in whose favor a resignation is made.
One who resigns.
The act of resigning.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. resiled -zīld"; p. pr. & vb. n. resiling
entry.ety: L. resilire to leap or spring back; pref. re- re- + salire to leap, spring. See Salient
entry.def: To start back; to recoil; to recede from a purpose.

sn.def: The act of springing back, rebounding, or resiling; as, the resilience of a ball or of sound.
The power or inherent property of returning to the form from which a substance is bent, stretched, compressed, or twisted; elasticity[1]; springiness; -- of objects and substances.
The power or ability to recover quickly from a setback, depression, illness, overwork or other adversity; buoyancy; elasticity[2]; -- of people.
The mechanical work required to strain an elastic body, as a deflected beam, stretched spring, etc., to the elastic limit; also, the work performed by the body in recovering from such strain.

entry.ety: L. resiliens, p. pr
entry.def: Leaping back; rebounding; recoiling.
Resilience.

entry.note: ☞ Resins exude from trees in combination with essential oils, gums, etc., and in a liquid or semiliquid state. They are composed of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen, and they consist primarily of polymerized small molecules having carboxylic groups. Copal, mastic, guaiacum, and colophony or pine resin, are some of them. When mixed with gum, they form the gum resins, like asafetida and gamboge; mixed with essential oils, they form balsams, or oleoresins. They are also used in making varnishes.

cs.cd: a fossil resin resembling copal, occuring in blue clay at Highgate, near London.
a low composite shrub (Euryops speciosissimus) of South Africa, having smooth pinnately parted leaves and abounding in resin.

entry.ety: F. résine, L. resina; cf. Gr. "rhti`nh Cf. Rosin
entry.def: Any one of a class of yellowish brown solid inflammable substances, of vegetable origin, which are nonconductors of electricity, have a vitreous fracture, and are soluble in ether, alcohol, and essential oils, but not in water; specif., pine resin (see Rosin).

sn.def: Any of various polymeric substance resembling the natural resins[1], prepared synthetically; -- they are used, especially in particulate form, in research and industry for their property of specifically absorbing or adsorbing substances of particular types; they are especially useful in separation processes such as chromatography; as, an ion-exchange resin .

entry.def: Having the quality of resin; resinous.
Any one of the salts the resinic acids.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, resin; as, the resinic acids.

entry.ety: Resin + -ferous: cf. F. résinifère
entry.def: Yielding resin; as, a resiniferous tree or vessel.

entry.ety: Resin + -form: cf. F. résiniforme
entry.def: Having the form of resin.
Containing or exhibiting resinous electricity.
Somewhat like resin.

cs.cd: electricity which is exited by rubbing bodies of the resinous kind. See Negative electricity, under Negative.

entry.ety: L. resinous: cf. F. résineux. See Resin
entry.def: Of or pertaining to resin; of the nature of resin; resembling or obtained from resin.
By means, or in the manner, of resin.
The quality of being resinous.
Like resin; resinous.

entry.ety: L. resipiscentia, from resipiscere to recover one's senses: cf. F. résipiscence
entry.def: Wisdom derived from severe experience; hence, repentance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resisted; p. pr. & vb. n. Resisting
entry.ety: F. résister, L. resistere, pref. re- re- + sistere to stand, cause to stand, v. causative of stare to stand. See Stand

sn.def: To stand against; to withstand; to obstruct.
sn.q: That mortal dint, Save He who reigns above, none can resist.

sn.def: To strive against; to endeavor to counteract, defeat, or frustrate; to act in opposition to; to oppose.
sn.q: God resisteth the proud.
Contrary to his high will Whom we resist.

sn.def: To counteract, as a force, by inertia or reaction.
To be distasteful to.
sn.syn: To withstand; oppose; hinder; obstruct; counteract; check; thwart; baffle; disappoint.

entry.def: To make opposition.

sn.def: A substance used to prevent a color or mordant from fixing on those parts to which it has been applied, either by acting machanically in preventing the color, etc., from reaching the cloth, or chemically in changing the color so as to render it incapable of fixing itself in the fibers; -- also called reserve. The pastes prepared for this purpose are called resist pastes.

cs.cd: a rheostat consisting of a box or case containing a number of resistance coils of standard values so arranged that they can be combined in various ways to afford more or less resistance.
a coil of wire introduced into an electric circuit to increase the resistance.
a solid of such a form as to experience, in moving in a fluid, less resistance than any other solid having the same base, height, and volume.

entry.ety: F. résistance, LL. resistentia, fr. resistens -entis, p. pr. See Resist

sn.def: The act of resisting; opposition, passive or active.
sn.q: When King Demetrius saw that . . . no resistance was made against him, he sent away all his forces.

sn.def: The quality of not yielding to force or external pressure; that power of a body which acts in opposition to the impulse or pressure of another, or which prevents the effect of another power; as, the resistance of the air to a body passing through it; the resistance of a target to projectiles.
A means or method of resisting; that which resists.
sn.q: Unfold to us some warlike resistance.

sn.def: A certain hindrance or opposition to the passage of an electrical current or discharge offered by conducting bodies. It bears an inverse relation to the conductivity, -- good conductors having a small resistance, while poor conductors or insulators have a very high resistance. The unit of resistance is the ohm.

entries.entry: Re*sist"ance frame`. Elec A rheostat consisting of an open frame on which are stretched spirals of wire. Being freely exposed to the air, they radiate heat rapidly.

entry.ety: F. résistant: cf. L. resistens. See Resist
entry.def: Making resistance; resisting.

def2.def: One who, or that which, resists.

entry.def: One who resists.
Making much resistance.

sn.def: The quality of being resistible; resistibleness.
The quality of being resistant; resitstance.
sn.q: The name “body” being the complex idea of extension and resistibility together in the same subject.

entry.ety: Cf. F. résistible
entry.def: Capable of being resisted; as, a resistible force.
Making resistance; opposing; as, a resisting medium.
Serving to resist.

sn.def: Having no power to resist; making no opposition.
Incapable of being resisted; irresistible.
sn.q: Masters' commands come with a power resistless To such as owe them absolute subjection.

entry.ety: L. resolubolis: cf. F. résoluble. See Resolve, and cf. Resolvable
entry.def: Admitting of being resolved; resolvable; as, bodies resoluble by fire.

entry.ety: Cf. F. résolu. The L. resolutusp. p. of resolvere) means, relaxed, enervated, effeminate. See Resolve v. t. & i.

sn.def: Having a decided purpose; determined; resolved; fixed in a determination; hence, bold; firm; steady.
sn.q: Edward is at hand, Ready to fight; therefore be resolute.

sn.def: Convinced; satisfied; sure.
Resolving, or explaining; as, the Resolute Doctor Durand.
sn.syn: Determined; decided; fixed; steadfast; steady; constant; persevering; firm; bold; unshaken.

sn.def: One who is resolute; hence, a desperado.
Redelivery; repayment.
sn.q: Yearlyresolutes, deductions, and payments.

entry.def: In a resolute manner; with fixed purpose; boldly; firmly; steadily; with perseverance.
entry.q: Some . . . facts he examines, some he resolutely denies.

entry.def: The quality of being resolute.

entry.cs:
Joint resolution. See under Joint a.
Resolution of a forceorResolution of a motion
Mech the separation of a single force or motion into two or more which have different directions, and, taken together, are an equivalent for the single one; -- the opposite of composition of a force. Resolution of a nebula Astron the exhibition of it to the eye by a telescope of such power as to show it to be composed of small stars.
entry.ety: F. résolution. L. resolutio a loosening, solution. See Resolve

sn.def: The act, operation, or process of resolving.

sd.def: The act of separating a compound into its elements or component parts.
The act of analyzing a complex notion, or solving a vexed question or difficult problem.
sd.q: The unraveling and resolution of the difficulties that are met with in the execution of the design are the end of an action.

sn.def: The state of being relaxed; relaxation.
The state of being resolved, settled, or determined; firmness; steadiness; constancy; determination.
sn.q: Be it with resolution then to fight.

sn.def: That which is resolved or determined; a settled purpose; determination. Specifically: A formal expression of the opinion or will of an official body or a public assembly, adopted by vote; as, a legislative resolution; the resolutions of a public meeting.
The state of being resolved or firm in opinion or thought; conviction; assurance.
sn.q: Little resolution and certainty there is as touching the islands of Mauritania.

sn.def: The act or process of solving; solution; as, the resolution of an equation or problem.
A breaking up, disappearance; or termination, as of a fever, a tumor, or the like.
The passing of a dissonant into a consonant chord by the rising or falling of the note which makes the discord.
The act of distinguishing between two close but not identical objects, or, when taking a measurement, bbetween two close values of the property measured.

a measure of the ability to distinguish between two close but not identical values of the property being measured; it is expressed as the difference in values of a property necessary to make such a distinction; as, a microscope with a resolution of one micron; a thermometer with a resolution of one-tenth of a degree. Also called resolving power.
sn.syn: Decision; analysis; separation; disentanglement; dissolution; resolvedness; resoluteness; firmness; constancy; perseverance; steadfastness; fortitude; boldness; purpose; resolve. See Decision.

entry.def: One who makes a resolution; one who joins with others in a declaration or resolution; specifically, one of a party in the Scottish Church in the 17th century.
entry.q: He was sequestrated afterwards as a Resolutioner.

entry.def: One who makes a resolution.

entry.ety: Cf.F. résolutif
entry.def: Serving to dissolve or relax.
Resolutive.
The quality or condition of being resolvable; resolvableness.

entry.ety: See Resolve, and cf. Resoluble
entry.def: Admitting of being resolved; admitting separation into constituent parts, or reduction to first principles; admitting solution or explanation; as, resolvable compounds; resolvable ideas or difficulties.
The quality of being resolvable; resolvability.

entry.cs: To resolve a nebula.Astron See Resolution of a nebula, under Resolution.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resolved -z?lvd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Resolving
entry.ety: L. resolvere resolutum, to untie, loosen, relax, enfeeble; pref. re- re- + solvere to loosen, dissolve: cf. F. résoudare to resolve. See Solve, and cf. Resolve v. i. Resolute Resolution

sn.def: To separate the component parts of; to reduce to the constituent elements; -- said of compound substances; hence, sometimes, to melt, or dissolve.
sn.q: O, that this too too solid flesh would melt, Thaw, and resolve itself into a dew!
Ye immortal souls, who once were men, And now resolved to elements again.

sn.def: To reduce to simple or intelligible notions; -- said of complex ideas or obscure questions; to make clear or certain; to free from doubt; to disentangle; to unravel; to explain; hence, to clear up, or dispel, as doubt; as, to resolve a riddle.
sn.q: Resolvemy doubt.
To the resolving whereof we must first know that the Jews were commanded to divorce an unbelieving Gentile.

sn.def: To cause to perceive or understand; to acquaint; to inform; to convince; to assure; to make certain.
sn.q: Sir, be resolved. I must and will come.
Resolve me, Reason, which of these is worse, Want with a full, or with an empty purse?
In health, good air, pleasure, riches, I am resolved it can not be equaled by any region.
We must be resolved how the law can be pure and perspicuous, and yet throw a polluted skirt over these Eleusinian mysteries.

sn.def: To determine or decide in purpose; to make ready in mind; to fix; to settle; as, he was resolved by an unexpected event.

To express, as an opinion or determination, by resolution and vote; to declare or decide by a formal vote; -- followed by a clause; as, the house resolved (or, it was resolved by the house) that no money should be apropriated (or, to appropriate no money.
To change or convert by resolution or formal vote; -- used only reflexively; as, the house resolved itself into a committee of the whole.
To solve, as a problem, by enumerating the several things to be done, in order to obtain what is required; to find the answer to, or the result of.
To dispere or scatter; to discuss, as an inflammation or a tumor.
To let the tones (as of a discord) follow their several tendencies, resulting in a concord.
To relax; to lay at ease.
sn.syn: To solve; analyze; unravel; disentangle.

entry.ety: The sense “to be convinced, to determine” comes from the idea of loosening, breaking up into parts, analyzing, hence, determining

sn.def: To be separated into its component parts or distinct principles; to undergo resolution.
To melt; to dissolve; to become fluid.
sn.q: When the blood stagnates in any part, it first coagulates, then resolves, and turns alkaline.

sn.def: To be settled in opinion; to be convinced.
sn.q: Let men resolve of that as they plaease.

sn.def: To form a purpose; to make a decision; especially, to determine after reflection; as, to resolve on a better course of life.
sn.syn: To determine; decide; conclude; purpose.

sn.def: The act of resolving or making clear; resolution; solution.
sn.q: To give a fullresolveof that which is so much controverted.

sn.def: That which has been resolved on or determined; decisive conclusion; fixed purpose; determination; also, legal or official determination; a legislative declaration; a resolution.
sn.q: Nor is your firm resolve unknown.
Cæsar's approach has summoned us together, And Rome attends her fate from our resolves.

entry.def: Having a fixed purpose; determined; resolute; -- usually placed after its noun; as, a man resolved to be rich.
entry.q: That makes him a resolved enemy.
I am resolved she shall not settle here.

sn.def: So as to resolve or clear up difficulties; clearly.
sn.q: Of that, and all the progress, more or less,Resolvedly more leisure shall express.
