sn.def: Resolutely; decidedly; firmly.

entry.def: Fixedness of purpose; firmness; resolution.
Having power to resolve; causing solution; solvent.

entry.ety: L. resolvens, p. pr. of resolvere: cf. F. résolvant. See Resolve

sn.def: That which has the power of resolving, or causing solution; a solvent.
That which has power to disperse inflammatory or other tumors; a discutient; anything which aids the absorption of effused products.
An equation upon whose solution the solution of a given pproblem depends.
That which decomposes, or dissolves.
That which clears up and removes difficulties, and makes the mind certain or determined.
One who resolves, or formal a firm purpose.

entry.note: The shattering of a glass object when impinged upon by sound of a certain frequency is one example of this phenomenon; another is the very large tides in certain basins such as that of the Bay of Fundy, which has a natural cycling frequency close to that of the tidal cycle.

cs.cd: the sound heard on percussing over the lungs.
the sound transmitted to the ear when auscultation is made while the patient is speaking.

entry.ety: Cf. F. résonance, L. resonantia an echo

sn.def: The act of resounding; the quality or state of being resonant.

A prolongation or increase of any sound, either by reflection, as in a cavern or apartment the walls of which are not distant enough to return a distinct echo, or by the production of vibrations in other bodies, as a sounding-board, or the bodies of musical instruments.

A phenomenon in which a vibration or other cyclic process (such as tide cycles) of large amplitude is produced by smaller impulses, when the frequency of the external impulses is close to that of the natural cycling frequency of the process in that system.

An electric phenomenon corresponding to that of acoustic resonance, due to the existance of certain relations of the capacity, inductance, resistance, and frequency of an alternating circuit; the tuning of a radio transmitter or receiver to send or detect waves of specific frequencies depends on this phenomenon.

entry.def: Resonance.

entry.ety: L. resonans, p. pr. of resonare to resound: cf. F. résonnant. See Resound

sn.def: Returning, or capable of returning, sound; fitted to resound; resounding; echoing back.
sn.q: Through every hour of the golden morning, the streets were resonant with female parties of young and old.

sn.def: Adjusted as to dimensions (as an electric circuit) so that currents or electric surgings are produced by the passage of electric waves of a given frequency.

entry.def: In a resonant manner.

entry.ety: NL. & G

sn.def: Anything which resounds; specifically, a vessel in the form of a cylinder open at one end, or a hollow ball of brass with two apertures, so contrived as to greatly intensify a musical tone by its resonance. It is used for the study and analysis of complex sounds.

entry.sn:
Anything that resounds or resonates; specif.: Teleg An open box for containing a sounder and designed to concentrate and amplify the sound.
Elec Any of various apparatus for exhibiting or utilizing the effects of resonance in connection with open circuits, as a device having an oscillating circuit which includes a helix of bare copper wire, a variable number of coils of which can be connected in circuit with a condenser and spark gap excited with an induction coil. It is used to create high-frequency electric brush discharges.
Wireless Teleg The antenna system and other high-frequency circuits of a receiving apparatus.

entry.ety: L. reorbere; pref. re- re- + sorbere to suck or drink in

sn.def: To swallow up.
sn.q: Now lifted by the tide, and now resorbed.

sn.def: to absorb (something which has been secreted or exuded by the same organism).

entry.ety: L. resorbens, p. pr. of resorbere
entry.def: Swallowing up.

entry.ety: Resin + orcin. So called because in its higher homologue it resembles orcin
entry.def: A colorless crystalline substance of the phenol series, obtained by melting certain resins, as galbanum, asafetida, etc., with caustic potash. It is also produced artificially and used in making certain dyestuffs, as phthaleïn, fluoresceïn, and eosin.
Of, or pertaining to, or producing, resorcin; as, resorcylic acid.

sn.def: The act of resorbing; also, the act of absorbing again; reabsorption.

The redissolving wholly or in part, in the molten magma of an igneous rock, of crystals previously formed. The dissolved material may again solidify, giving rise to a mass of small crystals, usually of a different kind.

entry.ety: F. ressort
entry.def: Active power or movement; spring.
entry.q: Some . . . know the resorts and falls of business that can not sink into the main of it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resorted; p. pr. & vb. n. Resorting
entry.ety: OF. resortir to withdraw, take refuge, F. ressortir to be in the jurisdiction, LL. resortire; pref. re- re- + L. sortiri to draw lots, obtain by lot, from sors lot. See Sort. The meaning is first to reobtain (by lot), then to gain by appeal to a higher court (as a law term), to appeal, go for protection or refuge

sn.def: To go; to repair; to betake one's self.
sn.q: What men name resort to him?

sn.def: To fall back; to revert.
sn.q: The inheritance of the son never resorted to the mother, or to any of her ancestors.

sn.def: To have recourse; to apply; to one's self for help, relief, or advantage.
sn.q: The king thought it time to resort to other counsels.

cs.cd: ultimate means of relief; also, final tribunal; that from which there is no appeal.

entry.ety: Cf. F. ressort jurisdiction. See Resort v.

sn.def: The act of going to, or making application; a betaking one's self; the act of visiting or seeking; recourse; as, a place of popular resort ; -- often figuratively; as, to have resort to force.
sn.q: Join with me to forbid him her resort.

sn.def: A place to which one betakes himself habitually; a place of frequent assembly; a haunt.
sn.q: Far from all resort of mirth.

sn.def: That to which one resorts or looks for help; resource; refuge.

entry.def: One who resorts; a frequenter.
Reason.
To resound.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + sound
entry.def: To sound again or anew.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resounded; p. pr. & vb. n. Resounding
entry.ety: OE. resounen, OF. resoner, F. résonner, from L. resonare; pref. re- re- + sonare to sound, sonus sound. See Sound to make a noise

sn.def: To sound loudly; as, his voice resounded far.
To be filled with sound; to ring; as, the woods resound with song.
To be echoed; to be sent back, as sound.
sn.q: Common fame . . .resoundsback to them again.

sn.def: To be mentioned much and loudly.
To echo or reverberate; to be resonant; as, the earth resounded with his praise.
To throw back, or return, the sound of; to echo; to reverberate.
sn.q: Albion's cliffs resound the rur��ay.

sn.def: To praise or celebrate with the voice, or the sound of instruments; to extol with sounds; to spread the fame of.
sn.q: The man for wisdom's various arts renowned, Long exercised in woes, O muse, resound.
sn.syn: To echo; reëcho; reverberate; sound.

entry.def: Return of sound; echo.

entry.ety: F. ressource, fr. OF. ressourdre resourdre, to spring forth or up again; pref. re- re- + sourdre to spring forth. See Source

sn.def: That to which one resorts orr on which one depends for supply or support; means of overcoming a difficulty; resort; expedient.
sn.q: Threat'nings mixed with prayers, his last resource.

sn.def: Pecuniary means; funds; money, or any property that can be converted into supplies; available means or capabilities of any kind.
sn.q: Scotland by no means escaped the fate ordained for every country which is connected, but not incorporated, with another country of greater resources.
sn.syn: Expedient; resort; means; contrivance.

entry.def: Full of resources.
Destitute of resources.
To sow again.
To resound.

sn.def: To speak or utter again.
To answer; to echo.

entry.cs:
As respects as regards; with regard to; as to. Macaulay.
To respect the personorTo respect the persons
to favor a person, or persons on corrupt grounds; to show partiality. “Ye shall not respect persons in judgment.” Deut. i. 17.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Respected; p. pr. & vb. n. Respecting
entry.ety: L. respectare, v. intens. from respicere respectum, to look back, respect; pref. re- re- + specere spicere, to look, to view: cf. F. respecter. See Spy, and cf. Respite

sn.def: To take notice of; to regard with special attention; to regard as worthy of special consideration; hence, to care for; to heed.
sn.q: Thou respectest not spilling Edward's blood.
In orchards and gardens, we do not so much respect beauty as variety of ground for fruits, trees, and herbs.

sn.def: To consider worthy of esteem; to regard with honor.
sn.q: I dorespectthee as my soul.

sn.def: To look toward; to front upon or toward.
sn.q: Palladius adviseth the front of his house should so respect the ��uth.

sn.def: To regard; to consider; to deem.
sn.q: To whom my father gave this name of Gaspar, And as his own respected him to death.

sn.def: To have regard to; to have reference to; to relate to; as, the treaty particularly respects our commerce.
sn.syn: To regard; esteem; honor; revere; venerate.

entry.cs:
In respect in comparison. Obs Shak. In respect of. In comparison with. Obs Shak. As to; in regard to. Archaic “Monsters in respect of their bodies.” Bp. Wilkins. “In respect of these matters.” Jowett. (Thucyd
In respect toorWith respect to
in relation to; with regard to; as respects. Tillotson. To have respect of persons to regard persons with partiality or undue bias, especially on account of friendship, power, wealth, etc. “It is not good to have respect of persons in judgment.” Prov. xxiv. 23.
entry.ety: L. respectus: cf. F. respect. See Respect v., and cf. Respite

sn.def: The act of noticing with attention; the giving particular consideration to; hence, care; caution.
sn.q: But he it well did ward with wise respect.

sn.def: Esteem; regard; consideration; honor.
sn.q: Seen without awe, and served without respect.
The same men treat the Lord's Day with as little respect.

sn.def: An expression of respect of deference; regards; as, to send one's respects to another.
Reputation; repute.
sn.q: Many of the best respect in Rome.

sn.def: Relation; reference; regard.
sn.q: They believed but one Supreme Deity, which, with respect to the various benefits men received from him, had several titles.

sn.def: Particular; point regarded; point of view; as, in this respect; in any respect; in all respects.
sn.q: Everything which is imperfect, as the world must be acknowledged in many respects.
In one respect I'll be thy assistant.

sn.def: Consideration; motive; interest.
sn.q: Whatever secretrespectswere likely to move them.
To the publik good Private respects must yield.
sn.syn: Deference; attention; regard; consideration; estimation. See Deference.

entry.def: The state or quality of being respectable; the state or quality which deserves or commands respect.

entry.ety: F. respectable, LL. respectabilis

sn.def: Worthy of respect; fitted to awaken esteem; deserving regard; hence, of good repute; not mean; as, a respectable citizen.
sn.q: Therespectablequarter of Sicca.
No government, any more than an individual, will long be respected, without being truly respectable.

sn.def: Moderate in degree of excellence or in number; as, a respectable performance; a respectable audience.

entry.ety: F., p. pr. of respecter. See Respect
entry.def: Placed so as to face one another; -- said of animals.

cs.cd: one who regards or judges with partiality.

entry.def: One who respects.
entry.q: Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons.

entry.def: Marked or characterized by respect; as, respectful deportment.
entry.q: With humble joi and with respectful fear.

entry.def: With regard or relation to; regarding; concerning; as, respecting his conduct there is but one opinion.

entry.ety: Cf.LL. respectio
entry.def: The act of respecting; respect; regard.
entry.q: Without difference or respection of persons.

entry.ety: Cf. F. respectif, LL. respectivus. See Respect

sn.def: Noticing with attention; hence, careful; wary; considerate.
sn.q: If you look upon the church of England with a respective eye, you can not . . . refuse this charge.

sn.def: Looking towardl having reference to; relative, not absolute; as, the respective connections of society.
Relating to particular persons or things, each to each; particular; own; as, they returned to their respective places of abode.
Fitted to awaken respect.
Rendering respect; respectful; regardful.
sn.q: With respective shame, rose, took us by the hands.
With thy equals familiar, yet respective.

sn.def: As relating to each; particularly; as each belongs to each; as each refers to each in order; as, let each man respectively perform his duty.
sn.q: The impressions from the objects or the senses do mingle respectively every one with its kind.

sn.def: Relatively; not absolutely.
Partially; with respect to private views.
With respect; regardfully.

entry.def: Having no respect; without regard; regardless.
entry.q: Rather than again Endure, respectless, their so moving c�ies.

sn.def: Respectful; as, a respectuous silence.
Respectable.

entry.def: To spell again.

entry.ety: L. respersus, p. p. of respergere; pref. re- re- + spargere to srew, sprinkle
entry.def: To sprinkle; to scatter.

entry.ety: L. respersio
entry.def: The act of sprinkling or scattering.

entry.ety: Cf. F. respirabilit�
entry.def: The quality or state of being respirable; respirableness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. respirable
entry.def: Suitable for being breathed; adapted for respiration.

entry.note: ☞ Respiration in the higher animals is divided into: (a Internal respiration, or the interchange of oxygen and carbonic acid between the cells of the body and the bathing them, which in one sense is a process of nutrition. (b External respiration, or the gaseous interchange taking place in the special respiratory organs, the lungs. This constitutes respiration proper. Gamgee. In the respiration of plants oxygen is likewise absorbed and carbonic acid exhaled, but in the light this process is obscured by another process which goes on with more vigor, in which the plant inhales and absorbs carbonic acid and exhales free oxygen.
entry.ety: L. respiratio: cf. F. respiration. See Respire

sn.def: The act of respiring or breathing again, or catching one's breath.
Relief from toil or suffering: rest.
sn.q: Till the day Appear of respiration to the just And vengeance to the wicked.

sn.def: Interval; intermission.

The act of resping or breathing; the act of taking in and giving out air; the aggregate of those processes bu which oxygen is introduced into the system, and carbon dioxide, or carbonic acid, removed.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to respiration; as, respirational difficulties.
Of or pertaining to respiration; as, respirative organs.

entry.ety: Cf. F. respirateur
entry.def: A divice of gauze or wire, covering the mouth or nose, to prevent the inhalation of noxious substances, as dust or smoke. Being warmed by the breath, it tempers cold air passing through it, and may also be used for the inhalation of medicated vapors.

entry.cs: Respiratory foods. Physiol See 2d Note under Food n., 1. Respiratory tree Zoöl the branched internal gill of certain holothurians.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to respiration; serving for respiration; as, the respiratory organs; respiratory nerves; the respiratory function; respiratory changes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Respired -sp?rd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Respiring
entry.ety: L. respirare respiratum; pref. re- re- + spirare to breathe: cf. F. respirer. See Spirit

sn.def: To take breath again; hence, to take rest or refreshment.
sn.q: Here leave me to respire.
From the mountains where I now respire.

sn.def: To breathe; to inhale air into the lungs, and exhale it from them, successively, for the purpose of maintaining the vitality of the blood.
To breathe in and out; to inspire and expire,, as air; to breathe.
sn.q: A native of the land where I respire The clear air for a while.

sn.def: To breathe out; to exhale.

entry.ety: OF. respit, F. répit, from L. respectus respect, regard, delay, in LL., the deferring of a day. See Respect

sn.def: A putting off of that which was appointed; a postponement or delay.
sn.q: I crave but four day's respite.

sn.def: Temporary intermission of labor, or of any process or operation; interval of rest; pause; delay.
sn.q: Without morerespite.
Some pause and respite only I require.

sd.def: Temporary suspension of the execution of a capital offender; reprieve.
The delay of appearance at court granted to a jury beyond the proper term.
sd.syn: Pause; interval; stop; cessation; delay; postponement; stay; reprieve.

entries.entry:
Res"pite v. t.
imp. & p. p. Respited; p. pr. & vb. n. Respiting
OF. respiter, LL. respectare. See Respite n.
To give or grant a respite to. Specifically: To delay or postpone; to put off. To keep back from execution; to reprieve. Forty days longer we do respite you. To relieve by a pause or interval of rest. Torespitehis day labor with repast.

entry.def: Without respite.

entry.ety: L. resplendentia
entry.def: The quality or state of being resplendent; brilliant luster; vivid brightness; splendor.
entry.q: Son! thou in whom my glory I behold In full resplendence, heir of all my might.
The resplendency of his own almighty goodness.

entry.ety: L. resplendens -entis, p. pr. of resplendere to shine brightly; pref. re- re- + splendere to shine. See Splendid
entry.def: Shining with brilliant luster; very bright.
entry.q: With royal arras and resplendent gold.

entry.def: Resplendent; brilliant.
Resplendent.
To split again.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Responded; p. pr. & vb. n. Responding
entry.ety: OF. respondre, F. répondre, fr. L. respondere responsum; pref. re- re- + spondere to promise. See Sponsor

sn.def: To say somethin in return; to answer; to reply; as, to respond to a question or an argument.
To show some effect in return to a force; to act in response; to accord; to correspond; to suit.
sn.q: A new affliction strings a new cord in the heart, which responds to some new note of complaint within the wide scale of human woe.
To every theme responds thy various lay.

sn.def: To render satisfaction; to be answerable; as, the defendant is held to respond in damages.
sn.syn: To answer; reply; rejoin. See Reply.

sn.def: To answer; to reply.
To suit or accord with; to correspond to.
sn.q: For his great deeds respond his speeches great.

sn.def: An answer; a response.
A short anthem sung at intervals during the reading of a chapter.
A half pier or pillar attached to a wall to support an arch.

entry.def: The act of responding; the state of being respondent; an answering.
entry.q: The angelical soft trembling voice made To the instruments divine respondence meet.

entry.ety: L. respondens, p. pr. of respondere
entry.def: Disposed or expected to respond; answering; according; corresponding.
entry.q: Wealth respondent to payment and contributions.

entries.entry:
Re*spond"ent n. Cf. F. répondant
One who responds. It corresponds in general to defendant. Specifically: Law One who answers in certain suits or proceedings, generally those which are not according to the course of the common law, as in equity and admiralty causes, in petitions for partition, and the like; -- distinquished from appellant. One who maintains a thesis in reply, and whose province it is to refute objections, or overthrow arguments; -- distinguished from opponent.

entry.ety: NL. See Respondence
entry.def: A loan upon goods laden on board a ship. It differs from bottomry, which is a loan on the ship itself.
Answerable.

entry.ety: Cf.LL. resposalis

sn.def: One who is answerable or responsible.
Response.

entry.ety: OF. response respons, F. réponse, from L. responsum, from respondere. See Respond

sn.def: The act of responding.

entry.sn:
An answer or reply. Specifically: Reply to an objection in formal disputation. I. Watts.
Eccl The answer of the people or congregation to the priest or clergyman, in the litany and other parts of divine service.
R.C.Ch A kind of anthem sung after the lessons of matins and some other parts of the office.
Mus A repetition of the given subject in a fugue by another part on the fifth above or fourth below. Busby.

entry.def: Giving no response.

entries.entry:
Re*spon`si*bil"i*ty r?*sp?n`s?*b?l"?*t? n.; pl.-ties -t�z. Cf. F. responsabilité
The state of being responsible, accountable, or answerable, as for a trust, debt, or obligation.
That for which anyone is responsible or accountable; as, the resonsibilities of power.
Ability to answer in payment; means of paying.

entry.ety: Cf. F. responsable. See Respond

sn.def: Liable to respond; likely to be called upon to answer; accountable; answerable; amenable; as, a guardian is responsible to the court for his conduct in the office.
Able to respond or answer for one's conduct and obligations; trustworthy, financially or otherwise; as, to have a responsible man for surety.
Involving responsibility; involving a degree of accountability on the part of the person concerned; as, a responsible office.
sn.syn: Accountable; answerable; amenable.

entry.ety: L. responsio. See Respond

sn.def: The act of answering.
The first university examination; -- called also little go. See under Little a.

entry.ety: Cf. F. resposif

sn.def: That responds; ready or inclined to respond.
Suited to something else; correspondent.
sn.q: The vocal lay responsive to the strings.

sn.def: Responsible.

entry.def: Responsory; antiphonal.
Containing or making answer; answering.

entries.entry:
Re*spon"so*ry n.; pl.-ries -r�z. LL. responsorium
Eccl
The answer of the people to the priest in alternate speaking, in church service.
A versicle sung in answer to the priest, or as a refrain. Which, if should repeat again, would turn my answers into responsories, and beget another liturgy.
Eccl An antiphonary; a response book.

entry.ety: Hind. risāldār, fr. risāltātroop of horse + Per. dār holding
entry.def: In the Anglo-Indian army, a native commander of a ressala.

entry.ety: For arrest
entry.def: To arrest.

cs.cd: an empty house for the accomodation of travelers; a caravansary.
cs.mcol: To set one's restorTo set up one's rest
cs.cd: to have a settled determination; -- from an old game of cards, when one so expressed his intention to stand or rest upon his hand.

entry.usage: Rest Repose. Rest is a ceasing from labor or exertion; repose is a mode of resting which gives relief and refreshment after toil and labor. The words are commonly interchangeable.
entry.ety: AS. rest ræst, rest; akin to D. rust, G. rast. OHG. rasta, Dan. & Sw. rast rest, repose, Icel. röst the distance between two resting places, a mole, Goth. rasta a mile, also to Goth. razn house, Icel. rann, and perhaps to G. ruhe rest, repose, AS. rōw, Gr. 'erwh`. Cf. Ransack

sn.def: A state of quiet or repose; a cessation from motion or labor; tranquillity; as, rest from mental exertion; rest of body or mind.
sn.q: Sleep give thee all his rest!

sn.def: Hence, freedom from everything which wearies or disturbs; peace; security.
sn.q: And the land had rest fourscore years.

sn.def: Sleep; slumber; hence, poetically, death.
sn.q: How sleep the brave who sink to rest, By all their country's wishes blest.

sn.def: That on which anything rests or leans for support; as, a rest in a lathe, for supporting the cutting tool or steadying the work.
sn.q: He made narrowed rests round about, that the beams should not be fastened in the walls of the house.

sn.def: A projection from the right side of the cuirass, serving to support the lance.
sn.q: Their visors closed, their lances in the rest.

sn.def: A place where one may rest, either temporarily, as in an inn, or permanently, as, in an abode.
sn.q: Halfway houses and travelers'rests.
In dust our final rest, and native home.
Ye are not as yet come to the rest and to the inheritance which the Lord your God giveth you.

sn.def: A short pause in reading verse; a cæsura.
The striking of a balance at regular intervals in a running account.
sn.q: An account is said to be taken with annual or semiannualrests.

sn.def: A set or game at tennis.
Silence in music or in one of its parts; the name of the character that stands for such silence. They are named as notes are, whole half quarter,etc.
sn.syn: Cessation; pause; intermission; stop; stay; repose; slumber; quiet; ease; quietness; stillness; tranquillity; peacefulness; peace.

cs.cd: to be in the power of; to depend upon; as, it rests with him to decide.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rested; p. pr. & vb. n. Resting
entry.ety: AS. restan. See Rest n.

sn.def: To cease from action or motion, especially from action which has caused weariness; to desist from labor or exertion.
sn.q: God . . . rested on the seventh day from all his work which he had made.
Six days thou shalt do thy work, and on the seventh day thou shalt rest.

sn.def: To be free from whanever wearies or disturbs; to be quiet or still.
sn.q: There rest, if any rest can harbor there.

sn.def: To lie; to repose; to recline; to lan; as, to rest on a couch.
To stand firm; to be fixed; to be supported; as, a column rests on its pedestal.
To sleep; to slumber; hence, poetically, to be dead.
sn.q: Fancy . . . then retries Into her private cell when Nature rests.

sn.def: To lean in confidence; to trust; to rely; to repose without anxiety; as, to rest on a man's promise.
sn.q: On him I rested, after long debate, And not without considering, fixed �� fate.

sn.def: To be satisfied; to acquiesce.
sn.q: To rest in Heaven's determination.

sn.def: To lay or place at rest; to quiet.
sn.q: Your piety has paid All needful rites, to rest my wandering shade.

sn.def: To place, as on a support; to cause to lean.
sn.q: Her weary head upon your bosom rest.

entries.entry:
Rest n. F. reste, fr. rester to remain, L. restare to stay back, remain; pref. re- re- + stare to stand, stay. See Stand, and cf. Arrest Restive With the definite article That which is left, or which remains after the separation of a part, either in fact or in contemplation; remainder; residue. Religion gives part of its reward in hand, the present comfort of having done our duty, and, for the rest, it offers us the best security that Heaven can give.
Those not included in a proposition or description; the remainder; others. Plato and therestof the philosophers. Armed like the rest, the Trojan prince appears.
Com A surplus held as a reserved fund by a bank to equalize its dividends, etc.; in the Bank of England, the balance of assets above liabilities. Eng Remainder; overplus; surplus; remnant; residue; reserve; others.

entry.ety: F. rester. See Rest remainder
entry.def: To be left; to remain; to continue to be.
entry.q: The affairs of men rest still uncertain.

entry.ety: L. restagnans, p. pr.
entry.def: Stagnant; motionless.

entry.ety: L. restagnare to overflow
entry.def: To stagnate; to cease to flow.

entry.ety: L. restagnatio aninundation
entry.def: Stagnation.

entry.ety: L. restans, p. pr. of restare: cf. F. restant. See Rest remainder
entry.def: Persistent.
To state anew.

entry.ety: F., fr. restaurer. See Restore
entry.def: An eating house.

entry.ety: L. restauratus, p. p. of restaurare. See Restore
entry.def: To restore.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: The keeper of an eathing house or a restaurant.

entry.ety: LL. restauratio: cf. F. restauration
entry.def: Restoration.

entries.entry: Rest cure. Med Treatment of severe nervous disorder, as neurasthenia, by rest and isolation with systematic feeding and the use of massage and electricity.

sn.def: To force back against the current; as, to restem their backward course.
To stem, or move against; as, to restem a current.
Being at rest; quiet.
Giving rest; freeing from toil, trouble, etc.
sn.q: Tired with all these, for restful death I cry.

entry.def: A European leguminous plant (Ononis arvensis) with long, tough roots.
Restive.
A restive or stubborn horse.
Restiveness.

entry.ety: L. restis rope + -form
entry.def: Formed like a rope; -- applied especially to several ropelike bundles or masses of fibers on the dorsal side of the medulla oblongata.
In a resty manner.

entry.ety: L. restinctio. See Restinguish
entry.def: Act of quenching or extingishing.
The quality or state of being resty; sluggishness.
entry.q: The snake by restiness and lying still all winter.

cs.cd: a spore in certain orders of algæ, which remains quiescent, retaining its vitality, for long periods of time.

entry.def: a. & n. from Rest v. t. & i.

entry.ety: L. restinquere restinctum; pref. re- re- + stinquere to quench
entry.def: To quench or extinguish.

entry.ety: L. restitutus, p. p. of restituere; pref. re- re- + statuere to put, place. See Statute
entry.def: To restore to a former state.
That which is restored or offered in place of something; a substitute.

entry.ety: F. restitution, L. restitutio. See Restitute v.

sn.def: The act of restoring anything to its rightful owner, or of making good, or of giving an equivalent for any loss, damage, or injury; indemnification.
sn.q: A restitution of ancient rights unto the crown.
He restitution to the value makes.

sn.def: That which is offered or given in return for what has been lost, injured, or destroved; compensation.
The act of returning to, or recovering, a former state; as, the restitution of an elastic body.

The movement of rotetion which usually occurs in childbirth after the head has been delivered, and which causes the latter to point towards the side to which it was directed at the beginning of labor.
sn.syn: Restoration; return; indemnification; reparation; compensation; amends; remuneration.

entries.entry:
Res"ti*tu`tor r?s"t?*t?`t?r n. L.: cf. F. restituteur
One who makes restitution. R.

Rest"ive
Rest"ive adv. Rest"ive*ness n.
Rest"ive adv. Rest"ive*ness n.
r?st"?v a. OF. restif, F. rétif, fr. L. restare to stay back, withstand, resist. See Rest remainder, and cf. Restiff . Unwilling to go on; obstinate in refusing to move forward; stubborn; drawing back.
Restive or resty, drawing back, instead of going forward, as some horses do. The people remarked with awe and wonder that the beasts which were to drag him [Abraham Holmes] to the gallows became restive, and went back.
Inactive; sluggish. Obs
Impatient under coercion, chastisement, or opposition; refractory.
Uneasy; restless; averse to standing still; fidgeting about; -- applied especially to horses.

entry.cs: Restless thrush. Zoöl See Grinder, 3.
entry.ety: AS. restleás

sn.def: Never resting; unquiet; uneasy; continually moving; as, a restless child.
sn.q: Restlessrevolution day by day.

sn.def: Not satisfied to be at rest or in peace; averse to repose or quiet; eager for change; discontented; as, restless schemers; restless ambition; restless subjects.
sn.q: Restlessat home , and ever prone to range.

sn.def: Deprived of rest or sleep.
sn.q: Restless he passed the remnants of the night.

sn.def: Passed in unquietness; as, the patient has had a restless night.
Not affording rest; as, a restless chair.
sn.syn: Unquiet; uneasy; disturbed; disquieted; sleepless; agitated; unsettled; roving; wandering.

entry.def: Admitting of being restored; capable of being reclaimed; as, restorable land.
Restoration.

cs.cd: the return of King Charles II. in 1660, and the reëstablishment of monarchy.
the final recovery of all men from sin and alienation from God to a state of happiness; universal salvation.

entry.ety: OE. restauracion, F. restauration, fr. L. restauratio. See Restore

sn.def: The act of restoring or bringing back to a former place, station, or condition; the fact of being restored; renewal; reëstablishment; as, the restoration of friendship between enemies; the restoration of peace after war.
sn.q: Behold the different climes agree, Rejoicing in thy restoration.

sn.def: The state of being restored; recovery of health, strength, etc.; as, restoration from sickness.
That which is restored or renewed.
sn.syn: Recovery; replacement; renewal; renovation; redintegration; reinstatement; reëstablishment; return; revival; restitution; reparation.

entry.def: A Restorationist.
The belief or doctrines of the Restorationists.
One who believes in a temporary future punishment and a final restoration of all to the favor and presence of God; a Universalist.

entry.ety: Cf. F. restoratif
entry.def: Of or pertaining to restoration; having power to restore.
entry.q: Destroys life's enemy, Hunger, with sweet restorative delight.

entry.def: Something which serves to restore; especially, a restorative medicine.
In a restorative manner.
A restaurateur.
Restorative.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + store
entry.def: To store again; as, the goods taken out were re-stored .

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Restored r?-st?rd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Restoring
entry.ety: OE. restoren, OF. restorer, F. restaurer, fr. L. restaurare; pref. re- re- + an unused word; cf. Gr. ���� an upright pale or stake, Skr. sth�vara fixed, firm. Cf. Restaurant Store
entry.def: To bring back to its former state; to bring back from a state of ruin, decay, disease, or the like; to repair; to renew; to recover.
entry.q: Torestoreand to build Jerusalem.
Our fortune restored after the severest afflictions.
And his hand was restored whole as the other.

sn.def: To give or bring back, as that which has been lost., or taken away; to bring back to the owner; to replace.
sn.q: Now therefore restore the man his wife.
Loss of Eden, till one greater manRestore us, and regain the blissful seat.
The father banished virtue shall restore.

sn.def: To renew; to reëstablish; as, to restore harmony among those who are variance.
To give in place of, or as satisfaction for.
sn.q: He shall restore five oxen for an ox, and four sheep for a sheep.

sn.def: To make good; to make amends for.
sn.q: But if the while I think on thee, dear friend, All losses are restored, and sorrows end.

sd.def: To bring back from a state of injury or decay, or from a changed condition; as, to restore a painting, statue, etc.
To form a picture or model of, as of something lost or mutilated; as, to restore a ruined building, city, or the like.
sd.syn: To return; replace; refund; repay; reinstate; rebuild; reëstablish; renew; repair; revive; recover; heal; cure.

entry.def: Restoration.
Restoration.
One who, or that which, restores.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Restrained; p. pr. & vb. n. Restraining
entry.ety: OE. restreinen, F. restreindre, fr. L. restringere restrictum; pref. re- re- + stringere to draw, bind, or press together. See Strain v. t., and cf. Restrict

sn.def: To draw back again; to hold back from acting, proceeding, or advancing, either by physical or moral force, or by any interposing obstacle; to repress or suppress; to keep down; to curb.
sn.q: Restrain in me the cursed thoughts that nature Gives way to in repose!

sn.def: To draw back toghtly, as a rein.
To hinder from unlimited enjoiment; to abridge.
sn.q: Though they two were committed, at least restrained of their liberty.

sn.def: To limit; to confine; to restrict.
sn.q: Not only a metaphysical or natural, but a moral, universality also is to be restrained by a part of the predicate.

sn.def: To withhold; to forbear.
sn.q: Thou restrained prayer before God.
sn.syn: To check; hinder; stop; withhold; repress; curb; suppress; coerce; restrict; limit; confine.

entry.def: Capable of being restrained; controllable.
With restraint.
One who, or that which, restrains.
The act of restraining.

entry.ety: OF. restraincte, fr. restrainct, F. restreint, p. p. of restraindre restrendre. See Restrain

sn.def: The act or process of restraining, or of holding back or hindering from motion or action, in any manner; hindrance of the will, or of any action, physical or mental.
sn.q: No man was altogether above the restrains of law, and no man altogether below its protection.

sn.def: The state of being restrained.
That which restrains, as a law, a prohibition, or the like; limitation; restriction.
sn.q: For one restraint, lords of the world besides.
sn.syn: Repression; hindrance; check; stop; curb;�oercion; confinement; limitation; restriction.

entry.def: To strengthen again; to fortify anew.

entry.ety: L. restrictus, p. p. of restringere. See Restrain
entry.def: Restricted.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Restricted; p. pr. & vb. n. Restricting
entry.def: To restrain within bounds; to limit; to confine; as, to restrict worlds to a particular meaning; to restrict a patient to a certain diet.
entry.syn: To limit; bound; circumscribe; restrain; repress; curb; coerce.

entry.ety: F. restriction, L. restrictio

sn.def: The act of restricting, or state of being restricted; confinement within limits or bounds.
sn.q: This is to have the same restriction with all other recreations,that it be made a divertisement.

sn.def: That which restricts; limitation; restraint; as, restrictions on trade.

entry.def: Restrictive.

entry.ety: Cf. F. restrictif

sn.def: Serving or tending to restrict; limiting; as, a restrictive particle; restrictive laws of trade.
Astringent or styptic in effect.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Restringed; p. pr. & vb. n. Restringing
entry.ety: L. restringere. See Restrain
entry.def: To confine; to contract; to stringe.
Quality or state of being restringent; astringency.

entry.ety: L. restringens, p. pr.: cf. F. restringent
entry.def: Restringing; astringent; styptic.
To strive anew.
Disposed to rest; indisposed toexercton; sluggish; also, restive.
entry.q: Where the master is too resty or too rich to say his own prayers.

entry.def: A second subjection.
To sublime again.

entry.ety: L. resudare to sweat again. See Sudation
entry.def: Act of sweating again.

cs.cd: a trust raised by implication for the benefit of a party granting an estate. The phrase is also applied to a trust raised by implication for the benefit of a party who advances the purchase money of an estate, etc.
a use which, being limited by the deed, expires or can not vest, and thence returns to him who raised it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resulted; p. pr. & vb. n. Resulting
entry.ety: F. résulter, fr. L. resultare resultarum, to spring or leap back, v. intens. fr. resilire. See Resile

sn.def: To leap back; to rebound.
sn.q: The huge round stone, resulting with a bound.

sn.def: To come out, or have an issue; to terminate; to have consequences; -- followed by in; as, this measure will result in good or in evil.
To proceed, spring, or rise, as a consequence, from facts, arguments, premises, combination of circumstances, consultation, thought, or endeavor.
sn.q: Pleasure and peace do naturally result from a holy and good life.
sn.syn: To proceed; spring; rise; arise; ensue; terminate.

sn.def: A flying back; resilience.
sn.q: Sound is produced between the string and the air by the return or the result of the string.

sn.def: That which results; the conclusion or end to which any course or condition of things leads, or which is obtained by any process or operation; consequence or effect; as, the result of a course of action; the result of a mathematical operation.
sn.q: If our proposals once again were heard, We should compel them to a quick result.

sn.def: The decision or determination of a council or deliberative assembly; a resolve; a decree.
sn.q: Then of their session ended they bid cry With trumpet's regal sound the great result.
sn.syn: Effect; consequence; conclusion; inference; issue; event. See Effect.

entry.def: The act of resulting; that which results; a result.

cs.cd: a force which is the result of two or more forces acting conjointly, or a motion which is the result of two or more motions combined. See Composition of forces, under Composition.

entry.ety: L. resultans, p. pr. : cf. F. résultant
entry.def: Resulting or issuing from a combination; existing or following as a result or consequence.

entries.entry: Re*sult"ant n. That which results. Specifically: Mech A reultant force or motion. Math An eliminant. The resultant of homogeneous general functions of n variables is that function of their coefficients which, equaled to zero, expresses in the simplest terms the condition of the possibility of their existence.

entry.ety: L. resultatus, p. p.
entry.def: A result.
entry.q: Theresultateof their counsil.

entry.def: HAving results or effects.
Resultant.
Being without result; as, resultless investigations.
Capable of, or admitting of, being resumed.

entry.ety: F. See Resume
entry.def: A summing up; a condensed statement; an abridgment or brief recapitulation.
entry.q: The exellent little résumé thereof in Dr. Landsborough's book.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resumed;p. pr. & vb. n. Resuming
entry.ety: L. resumere resumptum; pref. re- re- + sumere to take: cf. F. résumer. See Assume Redeem

sn.def: To take back.
sn.q: The sun, like this, from which our sight we have, Gazed on too long, resumes the light he gave.
Perhaps God will resume the blessing he has bestowed ere he attains the age of manhood.

sn.def: To enter upon, or take up again.
sn.q: Reason resumed her place, and Passion fled.

sn.def: To begin again; to recommence, as something which has been interrupted; as, to resume an argument or discourse.

entry.def: To summon again.
A second summons.

entry.ety: cf. F. résumption, L. resumptio restoration, recovery, fr. resumere. See Resume

sn.def: The act of resuming; as, the resumption of a grant, of delegated powers, of an argument, of specie payments, etc.
The taking again into the king's hands of such lands or tenements as he had granted to any man on false suggestions or other error.

entry.ety: cf. L. resumptivus restorative
entry.def: Taking back; resuming, or tending toward resumption; as, resumptive measures.

entry.ety: L. resupinatus, p. p. of resupinare to bend back. See Resupine
entry.def: Inverted in position; appearing to be upside down or reversed, as the flowers of the orchis and the leaves of some plants.
Resupinate.
The state of luing on the back; the state of being resupinate, or reversed.
entry.q: Our Vitruvius calleth this affection in the eye a resupination of the figure.

entry.ety: L. resupinus; pref. re- re- + supinus bent backward, supine
entry.def: Lying on the back; supine; hence, careless.
entry.q: He spake, and, downward swayed, fell resupine, With his huge neck aslant.

entry.def: To supply again.
The act of rising again; resurrection.

entry.ety: L. resurgens -entis, p. pr. of resurgere. See Resurrection
entry.def: Rising again, as from the dead.
One who rises again, as from the dead.

entry.ety: See Resurrection

sn.def: To take from the grave; to disinter.
To reanimate; to restore to life; to bring to view (that which was forgotten or lost).

cs.cd: a slender cross with a pennant floating from the junction of the bars.

a name given to several species of Selaginellaas Selaginella convoluta and Selaginella lepidophylla), flowerless plants which, when dry, close up so as to resemble a bird's nest, but revive and expand again when moistened. The name is sometimes also given to the rose of Jericho. See under Rose.

entry.ety: F. résurrection, L. resurrectio, fr. resurgere resurrectum, to rise again; pref. re- re- + surgere to rise. See Source

sn.def: A rising again; the resumption of vigor.
Especially, the rising again from the dead; the resumption of life by the dead; as, the resurrection of Jesus Christ; the general resurrection of all the dead at the Day of Judgment.
sn.q: Nor after resurrection shall he stay Longer on earth.

sn.def: State of being risen from the dead; future state.
sn.q: In the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marriage.

sn.def: The cause or exemplar of a rising from the dead.
sn.q: I am the resurrection, and the life.

entry.def: One who steals bodies from the grave, as for dissection.
To raise from the dead.
To survey again or anew; to review.
A second or new survey.
Capable of resuscitation; as, resuscitable plants.
One who, or that which resuscitates. Also used adjectively.

entry.ety: L. resuscitatus, p. p. of resuscitare; pref. re- re- + suscitare to raise, rouse. See Suscitate
entry.def: Restored to life.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Resuscitated;p. pr. & vb. n. Resuscitating
entry.def: To revivify; to revive; especially, to recover or restore from apparent death; as, to resuscitate a drowned person; to resuscitate withered plants.
To come to life again; to revive.
entry.q: These projects, however often slain, always resuscitate.

entry.ety: L. resuscitatio
entry.def: The act of resuscitating, or state of being resuscitated.
entry.q: The subject of resuscitation by his sorceries.

entry.def: Tending to resuscitate; reviving; revivifying.

entry.ety: L

sn.def: One who, or that which, resuscitates.

A device which is used to force oxygen or a mixture of oxygen and other gases into the lungs of patients who are suffering from asphyxiation, to revive the patient and induce resumption of respiration.

entry.def: See Aret.

entry.ety: Akin to rot
entry.def: To prepare for use, as flax, by separating the fibers from the woody part by process of soaking, macerating, and other treatment.
A shelf behind the altar, for display of lights, vases of flowers, etc.

entry.ety: F. retaille piece cut off, shred, paring, or OF. retail, from retailler. See Retail v.
entry.def: The sale of commodities in small quantities or parcels; -- opposed to wholesale; sometimes, the sale of commodities at second hand.
Done at retail; engaged in retailing commodities; as a retail trade; a retail grocer.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retailed;p. pr. & vb. n. Retailing
entry.ety: Cf. F. retailler to cut again; pref. re- re + tailler to cut. See Retail n. Tailor, and cf. Detail

sn.def: To sell in small quantities, as by the single yard, pound, gallon, etc.; to sell directly to the consumer; as, to retail cloth or groceries.
To sell at second hand.
To distribute in small portions or at second hand; to tell again or to many (what has been told or done); to report; as, to retail slander.
sn.q: To whom I willretailmy conquest won.
He is wit's peddler, and retails his wares At wakes and wassails.

entry.def: One who retails anything; as, a retailer of merchandise; a retailer of gossip; -- used also of businesses, including large corporations; as, Sears, Roebuck is one the the country's largest retailers .
The act of retailing.

cs.cd: a wall built to keep any movable backing, or a bank of sand or earth, in its place; -- called also retain wall.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retained r�*tānd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Retaining
entry.ety: F. retainir, L. retinere; pref. re- re- + tenere to hold, keep. See Tenable, and cf. Rein of a bridle, Retention Retinue

sn.def: To continue to hold; to keep in possession; not to lose, part with, or dismiss; to restrain from departure, escape, or the like.
sn.q: Thy shape invisibleretain.
Be obedient, and retain Unalterably firm his love entire.
An executor may retain a debt due to him from the testator.

sn.def: To keep in pay; to employ by a preliminary fee paid; to hire; to engage; as, to retain a counselor.
sn.q: A Benedictine convent has now retained the most learned father of their order to write in its defense.

sn.def: To restrain; to prevent.
sn.syn: To keep; hold; restrain. See Keep.

sn.def: To belong; to pertain.
sn.q: A somewhat languid relish, retaining to bitterness.

sn.def: To keep; to continue; to remain.

entry.def: Capable of being retained.
The act of retaining; retention.

sn.def: One who, or that which, retains.
One who is retained or kept in service; an attendant; an adherent; a hanger-on.
Hence, a servant, not a domestic, but occasionally attending and wearing his master's livery.

sd.def: The act of a client by which he engages a lawyer or counselor to manage his cause.
The act of withholding what one has in his hands by virtue of some right.
A fee paid to engage a lawyer or counselor to maintain a cause, or to prevent his being employed by the opposing party in the case; -- called also retaining fee.

sn.def: The act of keeping dependents, or the state of being in dependence.

entry.def: The act of retaining; retention.

sn.def: To take or receive again.
To take from a captor; to recapture; as, to retake a ship or prisoners.

entry.def: One who takes again what has been taken; a recaptor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retaliated; p. pr. & vb. n. Retaliating
entry.ety: L. retaliatus, p. p. of retaliare to retaliate; pref. re- re- + a word akin to talio talion, retaliation. Cf. Talion
entry.def: To return the like for; to repay or requite by an act of the same kind; to return evil for (evil). [Now seldom used except in a bad sense
entry.q: One ambassador sent word to the duke's son that his visit should be retaliated.
It is unlucky to be obliged to retaliate the injuries of authors, whose works are so soon forgotten that we are in danger of appearing the first aggressors.

entry.def: To return like for like; specifically, to return evil for evil; as, to retaliate upon an enemy.
The act of retaliating, or of returning like for like; retribution; now, specifically, the return of evil for evil; e.g., an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth.
entry.q: God . . . takes what is done to others as done to himself, and by promise obloges himself to full retaliation.
entry.syn: Requital; reprisal; retribution; punishment.

entry.def: Same as Retaliatory.
Tending to, or involving, retaliation; retaliative; as retaliatory measures.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retarded; p. pr. & vb. n. Retarding
entry.ety: L. retardare retardatum; pref. re- re- + tardare to make slow, to delay, fr. tardus slow: cf. F. retarder. See Tardy

sn.def: To keep delaying; to continue to hinder; to prevent from progress; to render more slow in progress; to impede; to hinder; as, to retard the march of an army; to retard the motion of a ship; -- opposed to accelerate.
To put off; to postpone; as, to retard the attacks of old age; to retard a rupture between nations.
sn.syn: To impede; hinder; obstruct; detain; delay; procrastinate; postpone; defer.

entry.def: To stay back.

cs.mcol: Retard of the tideorAge of the tide
cs.cd: the interval between the transit of the moon at which a tide originates and the appearance of the tide itself. It is found, in general, that any particular tide is not principally due to the moon's transit immediately proceeding, but to a transit which has occured some time before, and which is said to correspond to it. The retard of the tide is thus distinguished from the lunitidal interval. See under Retardation.

sn.def: Retardation; delay.
A mentally retarded person.
a person who is stupid or inept, especially in social situations.

entry.cs: Retardation of the tide. The lunitidal interval, or the hour angle of the moon at the time of high tide any port; the interval between the transit of the moon and the time of high tide next following. The age of the tide; the retard of the tide. See under Retard n.
entry.ety: L. retardatio: cf. F. retardation

sn.def: The act of retarding; hindrance; the act of delaying; as, the retardation of the motion of a ship; -- opposed to acceleration.
sn.q: The retardations of our fluent motion.

sn.def: That which retards; an obstacle; an obstruction.
sn.q: Hills, sloughs, and other terrestrial retardations.

sn.def: The keeping back of an approaching consonant chord by prolonging one or more tones of a previous chord into the intermediate chord which follows; -- differing from suspension by resolving upwards instead of downwards.
The extent to which anything is retarded; the amount of retarding or delay.

entry.ety: Cf. F. retardatif
entry.def: Tending, or serving, to retard.
having a limited or below normal mental ability; same as mentally retarded; -- used especially in relation to performance in academic tasks.

sn.def: One who, or that which, retards.
Any of various devices, as a helix of flat metal strip, introduced into a boiler tube to increase the heating effect of the fire.
A substance, as potassium bromide, added to a developer to retard its action.

entry.ety: Cf. F. retardement
entry.def: The act of retarding; retardation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retched rĕcht; p. pr. & vb. n. Retching
entry.ety: AS. hræcan to clear the throat, hawk, fr. hraca throat; akin to G. rachen, and perhaps to E. rack neck
entry.def: To make an effort to vomit; to strain, as in vomiting.
entry.q: Beloved Julia, hear me still beseeching!Here he grew inarticulate with retching

entry.ety: See Reck
entry.def: To care for; to heed; to reck.
Careless; reckless.

entry.ety: L., a net
entry.def: A net or network; a plexus; particularly, a network of blood vessels or nerves, or a part resembling a network.

entry.ety: L. rete a net
entry.def: Resembling network; retiform.

entry.ety: L. retegere retectum, to uncover; pref. re- + tegere to cover
entry.def: Act of disclosing or uncovering something concealed.
To tell again.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� pine resin
entry.def: A white crystalline hydrocarbon, polymeric with benzene. It is extracted from pine tar, and is also found in certain fossil resins.

entry.ety: L. retentum, fr. retentus, p. p. See Retain
entry.def: That which is retained.

cs.cd: a cyst produced by obstruction of a duct leading from a secreting organ and the consequent retention of the natural secretions.

entry.ety: L. retentio: cf. F. rétention. See Retain

sn.def: The act of retaining, or the state of being ratined.
The power of retaining; retentiveness.
sn.q: No woman's heart So big, to hold so much; they lack retention.

sn.def: That which contains something, as a tablet; a ���� of preserving impressions.
The act of withholding; retraint; reserve.
Place of custody or confinement.
The right of withholding a debt, or of retaining property until a debt due to the person claiming the right be duly paid; a lien.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétentif
entry.def: Having power to retain; as, a retentive memory.
entry.q: Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron, Can be retentive to the strength of spirit.

entry.def: That which retains or confines; a restraint.
In a retentive manner.
The quality of being retentive.
The power of retaining; retentive force; as, the retentivity of a magnet.

entry.ety: L., a retainer
entry.def: A muscle which serves to retain an organ or part in place, esp. when retracted. See Illust. of Phylactolemata.

entry.ety: L. rete a net + porus pore
entry.def: Any one of several species of bryozoans of the genus Retepora. They form delicate calcareous corals, usually composed of thin fenestrated fronds.

entry.ety: L. retexere, lit., to unweave; pref. re- re + texere to weave.
entry.def: To annual, as orders.
The act of weaving or forming again.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rhéteur. See Rhetor
entry.def: A rhetorician; a careful writer.
entry.q: If a rethor couthe fair endite.

entry.def: Rhetoric.

entry.ety: L., fr. rete a net
entry.def: A gladiator armed with a net for entangling his adversary and a trident for despatching him.

entry.ety: See Retiarius

sn.def: Any spider which spins webs to catch its prey.
A retiarius.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. retiarius

sn.def: Netlike.
sn.q: This work is in retiary, or hanging textures.

sn.def: Constructing or using a web, or net, to catch prey; -- said of certain spiders.
Armed with a net; hence, skillful to entangle.
sn.q: Scholastic retiary versatility of logic.

entry.ety: L. reticentia: cf. F. réticence

sn.def: The quality or state of being reticent, or keeping silence; the state of holding one's tonque; refraining to speak of that which is suggested; uncommunicativeness.
sn.q: Such fine reserve and noble reticence.

sn.def: A figure by which a person really speaks of a thing while he makes a show as if he would say nothingon the subject.

entry.def: Reticence.

entry.ety: L. reticens, p. pr. of reticere to keep silence; re- + tacere to be silent. See Tacit
entry.def: Inclined to keep silent; reserved; uncommunicative.

entry.ety: See Reticule

sn.def: A small net.
A reticule. See Reticule, 2.

entry.ety: Cf. F. réticulaire. See Reticule

sn.def: Having the form of a net, or of network; formed with interstices; retiform; as, reticular cartilage; a reticular leaf.
Of or pertaining to a reticulum.

entry.ety: NL. See Reticular
entry.def: An extensive division of rhizopods in which the pseudopodia are more or less slender and coalesce at certain points, forming irregular meshes. It includes the shelled Foraminifera, together with some groups which lack a true shell.

entries.entry: Re*tic`u*la"ri*an n. Zoöl. One of the Reticularia.

entry.def: In a reticular manner.

cs.cd: ornamental ware made from glass in which one set of white or colored lines seems to meet and interlace with another set in a different plane.
a micrometer for an optical instrument, consisting of a reticule in the focus of an eyepiece.
work constructed with diamond-shaped stones, or square stones placed diagonally.

entry.ety: L. reticulatus. See Reticule

sn.def: Resembling network; having the form or appearance of a net; netted; as, a reticulated structure.
Having veins, fibers, or lines crossing like the threads or fibers of a network; as, a reticulate leaf; a reticulated surface; a reticulated wing of an insect.

entry.def: The quality or state of being reticulated, or netlike; that which is reticulated; network; an organization resembling a net.
entry.q: The particular net you occupy in the great reticulation.

entry.ety: F. réticule, L. reticulum, dim. of rete a net. Cf.Retina Reticle

sn.def: A little bag, originally of network; a woman's workbag, or a little bag to be carried in the hand.
A system of wires or lines in the focus of a telescope or other instrument; a reticle.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Same as Reticularia.

cs.cd: a rhizopod in which the pseudopodia blend together and form irregular meshes.

entry.def: Forming a network; characterized by a reticulated sructure.

entries.entry: ‖Re*tic"u*lum n.;pl.Reticula #. L. dim. of rete a net Anat The second stomach of ruminants, in which folds of the mucous membrane form hexagonal cells; -- also called the honeycomb stomach. The neuroglia.

entry.ety: L. rete a net + -form. cf. F. rétiforme
entry.def: Composed of crossing lines and interstices; reticular; netlike; as, the retiform coat of the eye.

entry.note: ☞ The fibers of the optic nerve and the retinal blood vessels spread out upon the front surface of the retina, while the sensory layer (called Jacob's membrane), containing the rods and cones, is on the back side, next the choroid coat.
entry.ety: NL., from L. rete a net. Cf. Reticule
entry.def: The delicate membrane by which the back part of the globe of the eye is lined, and in which the fibers of the optic nerve terminate. See Eye.

entries.entry:
‖Ret`i*nac"u*lum n.; pl.Retinacula #. L., a holdfast, a band. See Retain
Anat
A connecting band; a frænum; as, the retinacula of the ileocæcal and ileocolic valves.
One of the annular ligaments which hold the tendons close to the bones at the larger joints, as at the wrist and ankle.
Zoöl One of the retractor muscles of the proboscis of certain worms.
Bot A small gland or process to which bodies are attached; as, the glandular retinacula to which the pollinia of orchids are attached, or the hooks which support the seeds in many acanthaceous plants.

cs.cd: the visual purple.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the retina.
A retinoid compound (C20H28O), closely related to vitamin A, which is a component of the visual pigments in the eye. It is also called retinaldehyde and vitamin A aldehyde.

entry.ety: Gr. ���� resin + -lite
entry.def: A translucent variety of serpentine, of a honey yellow or greenish yellow color, having a waxy resinlike luster.

entry.ety: Gr. ���� resin + ����� asphalt
entry.def: Retinite.

entry.ety: L. rete a net + E. nerve
entry.def: Having reticulated veins.

entries.entry:
‖Ret`i*ne"um n.; pl.Retinea #. NL. See Retina
Zoöl That part of the eye of an invertebrate which corresponds in function with the retina of a vertebrate.

entry.ety: Gr. ���� resin
entry.def: Of or pertaining to resin; derived from resin; specifically, designating an acid found in certain fossil resins and hydrocarbons.

entry.ety: Gr.��� resin: cf. F. rétinite
entry.def: An inflammable mineral resin, usually of a yellowish brown color, found in roundish masses, sometimes with coal.

entry.ety: NL., fr. NL. & E. retina + -tis
entry.def: Inflammation of the retina.
A retinoid compound (C20H28O2), closely related to vitamin A. It is also called tretinoin and vitamin A acid.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� resin + -oid
entry.def: Resinlike, or resinform; resembling a resin without being such.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� resin + L. oleum oil

sn.def: A hydrocarbon oil C32H16, obtained by the distillation of resin, -- used as a solvent, as an antiseptic, and in printer's ink.
One of the compounds which function as vitamin A. Called also vitamin A vitamin A1 and vitamin A alcohol. See vitamin A1.

entries.entry: ‖Ret`i*noph"o*ra n.; pl.Retiniphoræ #. NL., fr. NL. & E. retina + Gr. fe`rein to bear Zoöl One of group of two to four united cells which occupy the axial part of the ocelli, or ommatidia, of the eyes of invertebrates, and contain the terminal nerve fibrillæ. See Illust. under Ommatidium.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to retinophoræ.

entry.ety: Retina + -scopy
entry.def: The study of the retina of the eye by means of the ophthalmoscope.

cs.cd: to keep or employ as a retainer; to retain.

entry.ety: OE. retinue, OF. retinue, fr. retenir to retain, engage, hire. See Retain
entry.def: The body of retainers who follow a prince or other distinguished person; a train of attendants; a suite.
entry.q: Others of your insolent retinue.
What followers, what retinue canst thou gain?

entries.entry:
‖Re*tin"u*la n.; pl.Retinulæ #. NL., dim. of NL. & E. retina
Zoöl One of the group of pigmented cells which surround the retinophoræ of invertebrates. See Illust. under Ommatidium.

entry.def: Having, or characterized by, retinul�.

entry.ety: L. rete a net + pes pedis, a foot: cf. F. rétinopède
entry.def: A bird having small polygonal scales covering the tarsi.
Retirement; -- mostly used in a jocose or burlesque way.
entry.q: What one of our great men used to call dignified retiracy.

entry.ety: F.; cf. Sp. retirada retreat. See Retire
entry.def: A kind of retrenchment, as in the body of a bastion, which may be disputed inch by inch after the defenses are dismantled. It usually consists of two faces which make a reëntering angle.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retired; p. pr. & vb. n. Retiring
entry.ety: F. retirer; pref. re- re- + tirer to draw. See Tirade

sn.def: To withdraw; to take away; -- sometimes used reflexively.
sn.q: He . . . retired himself, his wife, and children into a forest.
As when the sun is present all the year, And never doth retire his golden ray.

sn.def: To withdraw from circulation, or from the market; to take up and pay; as, to retire bonds; to retire a note.
To cause to retire; specifically, to designate as no longer qualified for active service; to place on the retired list; as, to retire a military or naval officer.
To go back or return; to draw back or away; to keep aloof; to withdraw or retreat, as from observation; to go into privacy; as, to retire to his home; to retire from the world, or from notice.
sn.q: To Una back he cast him to retire.
The mind contracts herself, and shrinketh in, And to herself she gladly doth retire.

sn.def: To retreat from action or danger; to withdraw for safety or pleasure; as, to retire from battle.
sn.q: Set Uriah in the forefront of the hottest battle, and retire ye from him, that he may be smitten, and die.

sn.def: To withdraw from a public station, or from business; as, having made a large fortune, he retired .
sn.q: And from Britannia's public posts retire.

sn.def: To recede; to fall or bend back; as, the shore of the sea retires in bays and gulfs.
To go to bed; as, he usually retires early.
sn.syn: To withdraw; leave; depart; secede; recede; retreat; retrocede.

sn.def: The act of retiring, or the state of being retired; also, a place to which one retires.
sn.q: The battle and the retire of the English succors.
Eve] discover'd soon the place of her retire.

sn.def: A call sounded on a bugle, announcing to skirmishers that they are to retire, or fall back.

cs.cd: a flank bent inward toward the rear of the work.
a list of officers, who, by reason of advanced age or other disability, are relieved from active service, but still receive a specified amount of pay from the government.

sn.def: Private; secluded; quiet; as, a retired life; a person of retired habits.
sn.q: A retired part of the peninsula.

sn.def: Withdrawn from active duty or business; as, a retired officer; a retired physician.

entry.ety: Cf. F. retirement

sn.def: The act of retiring, or the state of being retired; withdrawal; seclusion; as, the retirement of an officer.
sn.q: O, blest Retirement, friend of life's decline.
Retirement, rural quiet, friendship, books.

sn.def: A place of seclusion or privacy; a place to which one withdraws or retreats; a private abode.
sn.q: This coast full of princely retirements for the sumptousness of their buildings and nobleness of the plantations.
Caprea had been the retirement of Augustus.
sn.syn: Solitude; withdrawment; departure; retreat; seclusion; privacy. See Solitude.

entry.def: One who retires.

cs.cd: a board of officers who consider and report upon the alleged incapacity of an officer for active service.
a pension granted to a public officer on his retirement from office or service.

sn.def: Reserved; shy; not forward or obtrusive; as, retiring modesty; retiring manners.
Of or pertaining to retirement; causing retirement; suited to, or belonging to, retirement.

entry.def: A white crystalline hydrocarbon produced indirectly from retene.

entry.ety: NL., fr. rete a net + tela a web
entry.def: A group of spiders which spin irregular webs; -- called also Retitelariæ.
imp. & p. p. of Retell.
Same as Retortion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retorted; p. pr. & vb. n. Retorting
entry.ety: L. retortus, p. p. of retorquere; pref. re- re- + torquere to turn twist. See Torsion, and cf. Retort n., 2

sn.def: To bend or curve back; as, a retorted line.
sn.q: With retorted head, pruned themselves as they floated.

sn.def: To throw back; to reverberate; to reflect.
sn.q: As when his virtues, shining upon others, Heat them and they retort that heat again To the first giver.

sn.def: To return, as an argument, accusation, censure, or incivility; as, to retort the charge of vanity.
sn.q: And with retorted scorn his back he turned.

entry.def: To return an argument or a charge; to make a severe reply.

cs.cd: a retort having a tubulure for the introduction or removal of the substances which are to be acted upon.

entry.usage: Retort Repartee. A retort is a short and pointed reply, turning back on an assailant the arguments, censure, or derision he had thrown out. A repartee is usually a good-natured return to some witty or sportive remark.
entry.ety: See Retort v. t.

sn.def: The return of, or reply to, an argument, charge, censure, incivility, taunt, or witticism; a quick and witty or severe response.
sn.q: This is called the retort courteous.

sn.ety: F. retortecf. Sp. retorta), fr. L. retortus, p. p. of retorquere. So named from its bent shape. See Retort v. t.
sn.def: A vessel in which substances are subjected to distillation or decomposition by heat. It is made of different forms and materials for different uses, as a bulb of glass with a curved beak to enter a receiver for general chemical operations, or a cylinder or semicylinder of cast iron for the manufacture of gas in gas works.
sn.syn: Repartee; answer.

entry.def: One who retorts.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétorsion. See Retort v. t.

sn.def: Act of retorting or throwing back; reflection or turning back.
sn.q: It was, however, necessary to possess some single term expressive of this intellectual retortion.

sn.def: Retaliation.

entry.def: Containing retort.
To toss back or again.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + touch: cf. F. retoucher

sn.def: To touch again, or rework, in order to improve; to revise; as, to retouch a picture or an essay.
To correct or change, as a negative, by handwork.

entry.def: A partial reworking,as of a painting, a sculptor's clay model, or the like.
One who retouches.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + trace: cf. F. retracer. Cf. Retract

sn.def: To trace back, as a line.
sn.q: Then if the line of Turnus you retrace, He springs from Inachus of Argive race.

sn.def: To go back, in or over (a previous course); to go over again in a reverse direction; as, to retrace one's steps; to retrace one's proceedings.
To trace over again, or renew the outline of, as a drawing; to draw again.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retracted; p. pr. & vb. n. Retracting
entry.ety: F. rétracter, L. retractare retractatum, to handle again, reconsider, retract, fr. retrahere retractum, to draw back. See Retreat

sn.def: To draw back; to draw up or shorten; as, the cat can retract its claws; to retract a muscle.
To withdraw; to recall; to disavow; to recant; to take back; as, to retract an accusation or an assertion.
sn.q: I would as freely have retracted this charge of idolatry as I ever made it.

sn.def: To take back,, as a grant or favor previously bestowed; to revoke.
sn.syn: To recall; withdraw; rescind; revoke; unsay; disavow; recant; abjure; disown.

sn.def: To draw back; to draw up; as, muscles retract after amputation.
To take back what has been said; to withdraw a concession or a declaration.
sn.q: She will, and she will not; she grants, denies, Consents, retracts, advances, and then files.

entry.def: The pricking of a horse's foot in nailing on a shoe.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétractable
entry.def: Capable of being retracted; retractile.

entry.ety: L. retractatus, p. p. of retractare. See Retract
entry.def: To retract; to recant.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétractation, L. retractatio a revision, reconsideration.
entry.def: The act of retracting what has been said; recantation.
Retractable.

entry.ety: Cf. F. -rétractile
entry.def: Capable of retraction; capable of being drawn back or up; as, the claws of a cat are retractile .

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétraction, L. retractio a drawing back, hesitation

sn.def: The act of retracting, or drawing back; the state of being retracted; as, the retraction of a cat's claws.
The act of withdrawing something advanced, stated, claimed, or done; declaration of change of opinion; recantation.
sn.q: Other men's insatiable desire of revenge hath wholly beguiled both church and state of the benefit of all my either retractions or concessions.

sd.def: The act of retracting or shortening; as, the retraction of a severed muscle; the retraction of a sinew.
The state or condition of a part when drawn back, or towards the center of the body.

entry.def: Serving to retract; of the nature of a retraction.
That which retracts, or withdraws.
One who, or that which, retracts.
In breech-loading firearms, a device for withdrawing a cartridge shell from the barrel.
An instrument for holding apart the edges of a wound during amputation.
A bandage to protect the soft parts from injury by the saw during amputation.
A muscle serving to draw in any organ or part. See Illust. under Phylactolæmata.
Retreat.

entry.ety: It. ritratto, fr. ritrarre to draw back, draw, fr. L. retrahere. See Retract
entry.def: A portrait; a likeness.
entry.q: Whose fair retrait I in my shield do bear.

entry.def: To transform anew or back.
To translate anew; especially, to translate back into the original language.

entry.ety: L., (he) has withdrawn. See Retract
entry.def: The withdrawing, or open renunciation, of a suit in court by the plaintiff, by which he forever lost his right of action.
To tread again.

entry.note: ☞ A retreat is properly an orderly march, in which circumstance it differs from a flight.
entry.ety: F. retraite, fr. retraire to withdraw, L. retrahere; pref. re- re- + trahere to draw. See Trace, and cf. Retract Retrace

sn.def: The act of retiring or withdrawing one's self, especially from what is dangerous or disagreeable.
sn.q: In a retreat he o�truns any lackey.

sn.def: The place to which anyone retires; a place or privacy or safety; a refuge; an asylum.
sn.q: He built his son a house of pleasure, and spared no cost to make a delicious retreat.
That pleasing shade they sought, a soft retreat From sudden April showers, a shelter from the heat.

sd.def: The retiring of an army or body of men from the face of an enemy, or from any ground occupied to a greater distance from the enemy, or from an advanced position.
The withdrawing of a ship or fleet from an enemy for the purpose of avoiding an engagement or escaping after defeat.
A signal given in the army or navy, by the beat of a drum or the sounding of trumpet or bugle, at sunset (when the roll is called), or for retiring from action.
A special season of solitude and silence to engage in religious exercises.
A period of several days of withdrawal from society to a religious house for exclusive occupation in the duties of devotion; as, to appoint or observe a retreat .
sd.syn: Retirement; departure; withdrawment; seclusion; solitude; privacy; asylum; shelter; refuge.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retreated; p. pr. & vb. n. Retreating
entry.def: To make a retreat; to retire from any position or place; to withdraw; as, the defeated army retreated from the field.
entry.q: The rapid currents drive Towards the retreating sea their furious tide.

entry.def: Furnishing or serving as a retreat.
entry.q: Ourretreatfulflood.

entry.def: The act of retreating; specifically, the Hegira.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retrenched; p. pr. & vb. n. Retrenching
entry.ety: OF. retrenchier, F. retrancher; pref. re- re- + OF. trenchier, F. trancher, to cut. See Trench

sn.def: To cut off; to pare away.
sn.q: Thy exuberant parts retrench.

sn.def: To lessen; to abridge; to curtail; as, to retrench superfluities or expenses.
sn.q: But this thy glory shall be soon retrenched.

sn.def: To confine; to limit; to restrict.
sn.q: These figures, ought they then to receive a retrenched interpretation?

sn.def: To furnish with a retrenchment; as, to retrench bastions.
sn.syn: To lesen; diminish; curtail; abridge.

entry.def: To cause or suffer retrenchment; specifically, to cut down living expenses; as, it is more reputable to retrench than to live embarrassed.

entry.ety: Cf. F. retrenchment

sn.def: The act or process of retrenching; as, the retrenchment of words in a writing.
sn.q: The retrenchment of my expenses will convince you that � mean to replace your fortune as far as I can.

sn.def: A work constructed within another, to prolong the defense of the position when the enemy has gained possession of the outer work; or to protect the defenders till they can retreat or obtain terms for a capitulation.
sn.syn: Lessening; curtailment; diminution; reduction; abridgment.

entry.def: A secdond trial, experiment, or test; a second judicial trial, as of an accused person.

entry.ety: L. retributus, p. p. ofretribuere to retribute; pref re- + tribuere to bestow, assign, pay. See Tribute
entry.def: To pay back; to give in return, as payment, reward, or punishment; to requite; as, to retribute one for his kindness; to retribute just punishment to a criminal.
One who makes retribution.

entry.ety: L. retributio: cf. F. rétribution

sn.def: The act of retributing; repayment.
sn.q: In good offices and due retributions, we may not be pinching and niggardly.

sn.def: That which is given in repayment or compensation; return suitable to the merits or deserts of, as an action; commonly, condign punishment for evil or wrong.
sn.q: All who have their reward on earth, . . . Naught seeking but the praise of men, here find Fit retribution, empty as their deeds.

sn.def: Specifically, reward and punishment, as distributed at the general judgment.
sn.q: It is a strong argument for a state of retribution hereafter, that in this world virtuous persons are very often unfortunate, and vicious persons prosperous.
sn.syn: Repayment; requital; recompense; payment; retaliation.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. retributorius worthy of retribution
entry.def: Of or pertaining to retribution; of the nature of retribution; involving retribution or repayment; as, retributive justice; retributory comforts.

entry.ety: From Retrieve
entry.def: That may be retrieved or recovered; admitting of retrieval.
The act retrieving.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retrieved; p. pr. & vb. n. Retrieving
entry.ety: OE. retreven, OF. retrover to find again, recover (il retroevee finds again), F. retrouver; pref. re- re- + OF. trover to find, F. trouver. See Trover

sn.def: To find again; to recover; to regain; to restore from loss or injury; as, to retrieve one's character; to retrieve independence.
sn.q: With late repentance now they would retrieve The bodies they forsook, and wish to live.

sn.def: To recall; to bring back.
sn.q: To retrieve them from their cold, trivial conceits.

sn.def: To remedy the evil consequence of, to repair, as a loss or damadge.
sn.q: Accept my sorrow, and retrieve my fall.
There is much to be done . . . and much to be retrieved.
sn.syn: To recover; regain; recruit; repair; restore.

entry.def: To discover and bring in game that has been killed or wounded; as, a dog naturally inclined to retrieve .

sn.def: A seeking again; a discovery.
The recovery of game once sprung; -- an old sporting term.

entry.def: Retrieval.

sn.def: One who retrieves.
A dor, or a breed of dogs, chiefly employed to retrieve, or to find and recover game birds that have been killed or wounded.

entry.def: To trim again.

entry.ety: L. retrimentum
entry.def: Refuse; dregs.

entries.entry: Retro-. L. retro, adv., backward, back. Cf. Re- A prefix or combining form signifying backward back; as, retroact, to act backward; retrospect, a looking back.

entry.ety: Pref. retro- + act
entry.def: To act backward, or in return; to act in opposition; to be retrospective.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétroaction

sn.def: Action returned, or action backward.
Operation on something past or preceding.

cs.cd: one which operates to make criminal or punishable, or in any way expressly to affect, acts done prior to the passing of the law.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétroactif
entry.def: Fitted or designed to retroact; operating by returned action; affecting what is past; retrospective.
In a retroactive manner.

entry.ety: Pref. retro- + cede: cf. F. rétrocéder
entry.def: To cede or grant back; as, to retrocede a territory to a former proprietor.

entry.ety: L. retrocedere; retro backward, back + cedere to go. See Cede
entry.def: To go back.

entry.ety: L. retrocedens, p. pr
entry.def: Disposed or likely to retrocede; -- said of diseases which go from one part of the body to another, as the gout.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétrocession. See Retrocede

sn.def: The act of retroceding.
The state of being retroceded, or granted back.
Metastasis of an eruption or a tumor from the surface to the interior of the body.

entry.ety: Pref. retro- + choir
entry.def: Any extension of a church behind the high altar, as a chapel; also, in an apsidal church, all the space beyond the line of the back or eastern face of the altar.

entry.ety: See Retrocopulation
entry.def: Copulating backward, or from behind.

entry.ety: Pref. retro- + copulation
entry.def: Copulation from behind.

entry.ety: L. retroducere retroductum, to lead or bring back; retro backward + ducere to lead
entry.def: A leading or bringing back.

entry.ety: Pref. retro- + L. flectere flexum, to bend, to turn
entry.def: Reflexed; bent or turned abruptly backward.
The act of reflexing; the state of being retroflexed. Cf. Retroversion.
