entry.ety: Pref. retro- + L. fractus, p. p. of frangere to break
entry.def: Refracted; as, a retrofract stem.

entry.ety: Pref. retro- + generative
entry.def: Begetting young by retrocopulation.

entry.ety: F. rétrogradation or L. retrogradatio. See Retrograde

sn.def: The act of retrograding, or moving backward.
The state of being retrograde; decline.

entry.ety: L. retrogradus, from retrogradi retrogressus, to retrograde; retro back + gradi to step: cf. F. rétrograde. See Grade

sn.def: Apparently moving backward, and contrary to the succession of the signs, that is, from east to west, as a planet.
sn.q: And if he be in the west side in that condition, then is he retrograde.

sn.def: Tending or moving backward; having a backward course; contrary; as, a retrograde motion; -- opposed to progressive.
sn.q: Progressive and notretrograde.
It is most retrograde to our desire.

sn.def: Declining from a better to a worse state; as, a retrograde people; retrograde ideas, morals, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retrograded; p. pr. & vb. n. Retrograding
entry.ety: L. retrogradare retrogradi: cf. F. rétrograder

sn.def: To go in a retrograde direction; to move, or appear to move, backward, as a planet.
Hence, to decline from a better to a worse condition, as in morals or intelligence.

entry.def: By retrograding; so as to retrograde.

entry.ety: Cf. L. retrogressus
entry.def: Retrogression.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétrogression. See Retrograde, and cf. Digression

sn.def: The act of retrograding, or going backward; retrogradation.

Backward development; a passing from a higher to a lower state of organization or structure, as when an animal, approaching maturity, becomes less highly organized than would be expected from its earlier stages or known relationship. Called also retrograde development, and regressive metamorphism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétrogressif

sn.def: Tending to retrograde; going or moving backward; declining from a better to a worse state.
Passing from a higher to a lower condition; declining from a more perfect state of organization; regressive.

entry.def: In a retrogressive manner.
The quality or state of being retromingent.

entry.ety: Pref. retro- + L. mingens, p. pr. of mingere to urinate
entry.def: Organized so as to discharge the urine backward.

def2.def: An animal that discharges its urine backward.

entry.ety: Pref. retro- + L. pellere pulsum, to impel
entry.def: Driving back; repelling.

entry.ety: L. retrorsus retroversus; retro back + vertere versum, to turn. Cf. Retrovert
entry.def: Bent backward or downward.

entry.ety: L. retrospicere; retro back + specere spectum, to look. See Spy and cf. Expect
entry.def: To look backward; hence, to affect or concern what is past.
entry.q: It may be useful to retrospect to an early period.

entry.def: A looking back on things past; view or contemplation of the past.
entry.q: We may introduce a song without retrospect to the old comedy.

entry.def: The act, or the faculty, of looking back on things past.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rétrospectif

sn.def: Looking backward; contemplating things past; -- opposed to prospective; as, a retrospective view.
sn.q: The sage, with retrospective eye.

sn.def: Having reference to what is past; affecting things past; retroactive; as, a retrospective law.
sn.q: Inflicting death by a retrospective enactment.

entry.def: By way of retrospect.
The inoculation of a cow with human vaccine virus.

entry.note: ☞ In retroversion the bending is gradual or curved; in retroflexion it is abrupt or angular.
entry.ety: Cf. F. rétroversion. See Retrovert
entry.def: A turning or bending backward; also, the state of being turned or bent backward; displacement backwards; as, retroversion of the uterus.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retroverted; p. pr. & vb. n. Retroverting
entry.ety: Pref. retro- + L. vertere versum, to turn. Cf. Retrorse
entry.def: To turn back.
In a state of retroversion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Retruded; p. pr. & vb. n. Retruding
entry.ety: L. retrudere; re- + trudere to thrust
entry.def: To thrust back.

entry.ety: L. retrusus concealed, p. p. of retrudere
entry.def: Abstruse.
The act of retruding, or the state of being retruded.
entry.q: In virtue of an endless remotion or retrusion of the constituent cause.

entry.def: To try (esp. judicially) a second time; as, to retry a case; to retry an accused person.
See Aret.
A place or establishment where flax is retted. See Ret.

sn.def: The act or process of preparing flax for use by soaking, maceration, and kindred processes; -- also called rotting. See Ret.
A place where flax is retted; a rettery.

entry.ety: L. retundere retusum; pref. re- re- + tundere to beat
entry.def: To blunt; to turn, as an edge; figuratively, to cause to be obtuse or dull; as, to retund confidence.
To turn again.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Returned; p. pr. & vb. n. Returning
entry.ety: OE. returnen retournen, F. retourner; pref. re- re- + tourner to turn. See Turn

sn.def: To turn back; to go or come again to the same place or condition.
sn.q: Returnto your father's house.
On their embattled ranks the waves return.
If they returned out of bondage, it must be into a state of freedom.
Dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return.

sn.def: To come back, or begin again, after an interval, regular or irregular; to appear again.
sn.q: With the year Seasons return; but not me returns Day or the sweet approach of even or morn.

sn.def: To speak in answer; to reply; to respond.
sn.q: He said, and thus the queen of heaven returned.

sn.def: To revert; to pass back into possession.
sn.q: And Jeroboam said in his heart, Now shall the kingdom return to the house of David.

sn.def: To go back in thought, narration, or argument.
sn.q: But toreturnto my story.

cs.cd: to lead the same suit led by one's partner.

sn.def: To bring, carry, send, or turn, back; as, to return a borrowed book, or a hired horse.
sn.q: Both fled attonce, ne ever back returned eye.

sn.def: To repay; as, to return borrowed money.
To give in requital or recompense; to requite.
sn.q: The Lord shall return thy wickedness upon thine own head.

sn.def: To give back in reply; as, to return an answer; to return thanks.
To retort; to throw back; as, to return the lie.
sn.q: If you are a malicious reader, you return upon me, that I affect to be thought more impartial than I am.

sn.def: To report, or bring back and make known.
sn.q: And all the people answered together, . . . and Moses returned the words of the people unto the Lord.

sn.def: To render, as an account, usually an official account, to a superior; to report officially by a list or statement; as, to return a list of stores, of killed or wounded; to return the result of an election.
Hence, to elect according to the official report of the election officers.
To bring or send back to a tribunal, or to an office, with a certificate of what has been done; as, to return a writ.
To convey into official custody, or to a general depository.
sn.q: Instead of a ship, he should levy money, and return the same to the treasurer for his majesty's use.

sn.def: To bat (the ball) back over the net.
To lead in response to the lead of one's partner; as, to return a trump; to return a diamond for a club.
sn.syn: To restore; requite; repay; recompense; render; remit; report.

cs.cd: a ball held by an elastic string so that it returns to the hand from which it is thrown, -- used as a plaything.
a pipe fitting for connecting the contiguous ends of two nearly parallel pipes lying alongside or one above another.
the day when the defendant is to appear in court, and the sheriff is to return the writ and his proceedings.
in a steam boiler, a flue which conducts flame or gases of combustion in a direction contrary to their previous movement in another flue.
a pipe by which water of condensation from a heater or radiator is conveyed back toward the boiler.

sn.def: The act of returning (intransitive), or coming back to the same place or condition; as, the return of one long absent; the return of health; the return of the seasons, or of an anniversary.
sn.q: At the return of the year the king of Syria will come up against thee.
His personal return was most required and necessary.

sn.def: The act of returning (transitive), or sending back to the same place or condition; restitution; repayment; requital; retribution; as, the return of anything borrowed, as a book or money; a good return in tennis.
sn.q: You made my liberty your late request: Is no return due from a grateful breast?

entry.sn:
That which is returned. Specifically: A payment; a remittance; a requital. I do expect return Of thrice three times the value of this bond.
An answer; as, a return to one's question.
An account, or formal report, of an action performed, of a duty discharged, of facts or statistics, and the like; as, election returns; a return of the amount of goods produced or sold; especially, in the plural, a set of tabulated statistics prepared for general information.
The profit on, or advantage received from, labor, or an investment, undertaking, adventure, etc. The fruit from many days of recreation is very little; but from these few hours we spend in prayer, the return is great.

sn.def: The continuation in a different direction, most often at a right angle, of a building, face of a building, or any member, as a molding or mold; -- applied to the shorter in contradistinction to the longer; thus, a facade of sixty feet east and west has a return of twenty feet north and south.

sd.def: The rendering back or delivery of writ, precept, or execution, to the proper officer or court.
The certificate of an officer stating what he has done in execution of a writ, precept, etc., indorsed on the document.
The sending back of a commission with the certificate of the commissioners.
A day in bank. See Return day, below.

sn.def: An official account, report, or statement, rendered to the commander or other superior officer; as, the return of men fit for duty; the return of the number of the sick; the return of provisions, etc.
The turnings and windings of a trench or mine.
Capable of, or admitting of, being returned.
Legally required to be returned, delivered, given, or rendered; as, a writ or precept returnable at a certain day; a verdict returnable to the court.

entry.def: One who returns.
Admitting no return.

entry.ety: L. retusus, p. p. : cf. F. rétus. See Retund
entry.def: Having the end rounded and slightly indented; as, a retuse leaf.
Rule.
Realm.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + union: cf. F. réunion

sn.def: A second union; union formed anew after separation, secession, or discord; as, a reunion of parts or particles of matter; a reunion of parties or sects.
An assembling of persons who have been separated, as of a family, or the members of a disbanded regiment; an assembly so composed.

entry.def: To unite again; to join after separation or variance.
In a reunited manner.
A second uniting.
To urge again.
To vaccinate a second time or again.
The act of growing well; the state of being revalescent.
entry.q: Would this prove that the patient's revalescence had been independent of the medicines given him?

entry.ety: L. revalescens -entis, p. pr. of revalescere; pref. re- re- + valescere, v. incho. fr. valere to be well
entry.def: Growing well; recovering strength.
A second or new valuation.
To vamp again; hence, to patch up; to reconstruct.
To reave.

entry.ety: See Reeve
entry.def: An officer, steward, or governor.

entry.usage: See Communicate.Reveal Divulge. To reveal is literally to lift the veil, and thus make known what was previously concealed; to divulge is to scatter abroad among the people, or make publicly known. A mystery or hidden doctrine may be revealed; something long confined to the knowledge of a few is at length divulged. “Time, which reveals all things, is itself not to be discovered.” Locke. “A tragic history of facts divulged.” Wordsworth.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Revealed; p. pr. & vb. n. Revealing
entry.ety: F. révéler, L. revelare revelatum, to unveil, reveal; pref. re- re- + velare to veil; fr. velum a veil. See Veil

sn.def: To make known (that which has been concealed or kept secret); to unveil; to disclose; to show.
sn.q: Light was the wound, the prince's care unknown, She might not, would not, yet reveal her own.

sn.def: Specifically, to communicate (that which could not be known or discovered without divine or supernatural instruction or agency).
sn.syn: To communicate; disclose; divulge; unveil; uncover; open; discover; impart; show.

sn.def: A revealing; a disclosure.

The side of an opening for a window, doorway, or the like, between the door frame or window frame and the outer surface of the wall; or, where the opening is not filled with a door, etc., the whole thickness of the wall; the jamb.

entry.def: The quality or state of being revealable; revealableness.
Capable of being revealed.
One who, or that which, reveals.
Act of revealing.
To vegetate anew.

entry.ety: F. réveil, fr. réveiller to awake; pref. re- re- + pref. es-L. ex) + veiller to awake, watch, L. vigilare to watch. The English form was prob. taken by mistake from the French imper. réveillez,2d pers. pl. See Vigil
entry.def: The beat of drum, or bugle blast, about break of day, to give notice that it is time for the soldiers to rise, and for the sentinels to forbear challenging.
entry.q: Sound areveille.
For at dawning to assail ye Here no bugles sound reveille.

entry.def: See Reveal.

entry.cs: Master of the revels Revel master . Same as Lord of misrule, under Lord.
entry.ety: OF. revel rebellion, disorder, feast, sport. See Revel v. i.
entry.def: A feast with loose and noisy jollity; riotous festivity or merrymaking; a carousal.
entry.q: This day in mirth and revel to dispend.
Some men ruin . . . their bodies by incessant revels.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reveled or Revelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Reveling or Revelling
entry.ety: OF. reveler to revolt, rebel, make merry, fr. L. rebellare. See Rebel

sn.def: To feast in a riotous manner; to carouse; to act the bacchanalian; to make merry.
To move playfully; to indulge without restraint.
sn.q: Where joy mostrevels.

entry.ety: L. revellere; re- + vellere to pluck, pull
entry.def: To draw back; to retract.

entry.ety: L. revelatus, p. p. of revelare to reveal
entry.def: To reveal.

entry.ety: F. révélation, L. revelatio. See Reveal

sn.def: The act of revealing, disclosing, or discovering to others what was before unknown to them.
That which is revealed.

sd.def: The act of revealing divine truth.
That which is revealed by God to man; esp., the Bible.
sd.q: By revelation he made known unto me the mystery, as I wrote afore in few words.

sn.def: Specifically, the last book of the sacred canon, containing the prophecies of St. John; the Apocalypse or Book of Revelation or The Revelation of Saint John.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who makes a revelation; a revealer.

entry.ety: Written also reveller
entry.def: One who revels.
entry.q: Moonshinerevelers.

entry.ety: L. revellens, p. pr. of revellere. See Revel v. t.
entry.def: Causing revulsion; revulsive.
The act of reveling.

entry.ety: OF. reveleus
entry.def: Fond of festivity; given to merrymaking or reveling.
entry.q: Companionable and revelous was she.

entry.ety: See Rout

sn.def: Tumultuous festivity; revelry.
A rabble; a riotous assembly; a mob.

entry.ety: See Revel v. i. & n.
entry.def: The act of engaging in a revel; noisy festivity; reveling.
entry.q: And pomp and feast and revelry.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Revendicated; p. pr. & vb. n. Revendicating
entry.ety: Cf. F. revendiquer. See Revenge
entry.def: To reclaim; to demand the restoration of.

entry.ety: F. revendication
entry.def: The act of revendicating.

entry.ety: OF. revengier, F. revancher; pref. re- re- + OF. vengier to avenge, revenge, F. venger, L. vindicare. See Vindicate Vengerance, and cf. Revindicate

sn.def: To inflict harm in return for, as an injury, insult, etc.; to exact satisfaction for, under a sense of injury; to avenge; -- followed either by the wrong received, or by the person or thing wronged, as the object, or by the reciprocal pronoun as direct object, and a preposition before the wrong done or the wrongdoer.
sn.q: To revenge the death of our fathers.
The gods are just, and will revenge our cause.
Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come,Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius.

sn.def: To inflict injury for, in a spiteful, wrong, or malignant spirit; to wreak vengeance for maliciously.
sn.syn: To avenge; vindicate. See Avenge.

entries.entry: Re*venge" v. i. To take vengeance; -- with upon. Obs A bird that willrevengeupon you all.

sn.def: The act of revenging; vengeance; retaliation; a returning of evil for evil.
sn.q: Certainly, in taking revenge, a man is even with his enemy; but in passing it over he is superior.

sn.def: The disposition to revenge; a malignant wishing of evil to one who has done us an injury.
sn.q: Revenge now goes To lay a complot to betray thy foes.
The indulgence of revenge tends to make men more savage and cruel.

entry.def: Capable of being revenged; as, revengeable wrong.
Vengeance; revenge.
Full of, or prone to, revenge; vindictive; malicious; revenging; wreaking revenge.
entry.q: If thy revengeful heart can not forgive.
May my hands . . . Never brandish more revengeful steel.
entry.syn: Vindictive; vengeful; resentful; malicious.

entry.def: Unrevenged.
Revenge.
entry.q: He 'll breed revengement and a scourge for me.

entry.def: One who revenges.
Executing revenge; revengeful.

cs.cd: an armed government vessel employed to enforce revenue laws, prevent smuggling, etc.

entry.ety: F. revenu, OF. revenue, fr. revenir to return, L. revenire; pref. re- re- + venire to come. See Come

sn.def: That which returns, or comes back, from an investment; the annual rents, profits, interest, or issues of any species of property, real or personal; income.
sn.q: Do not anticipate your revenues and live upon air till you know what you are worth.

sn.def: Hence, return; reward; as, a revenue of praise.
The annual yield of taxes, excise, customs, duties, rents, etc., which a nation, state, or municipality collects and receives into the treasury for public use.

entry.def: To echo.

entry.ety: L. reverberans, p. pr. : cf. F. réverbérant. See Reverberate
entry.def: Having the quality of reverberation; reverberating.

entry.ety: L. reverberatus, p. p. of reverberare to strike back, repel; pref. re- re- + verberare to lash, whip, beat, fr. verber a lash, whip, rod

sn.def: Reverberant.
sn.q: Thereverberatehills.

sn.def: Driven back, as sound; reflected.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reverberated; p. pr. & vb. n. Reverberating

sn.def: To return or send back; to repel or drive back; to echo, as sound; to reflect, as light, as light or heat.
sn.q: Who, like an arch, reverberates The voice again.

sn.def: To send or force back; to repel from side to side; as, flame is reverberated in a furnace.
Hence, to fuse by reverberated heat.
sn.q: Reverberatedinto glass.

sn.def: To resound; to echo.
To be driven back; to be reflected or repelled, as rays of light; to be echoed, as sound.

entry.ety: CF. F. réverbération
entry.def: The act of reverberating; especially, the act of reflecting light or heat, or reëchoing sound; as, the reverberation of rays from a mirror; the reverberation of rays from a mirror; the reverberation of voices; the reverberation of heat or flame in a furnace.
Of the nature of reverberation; tending to reverberate; reflective.
entry.q: This reverberative influence is that which we have intended above, as the influence of the mass upon its centers.

entry.def: One who, or that which, produces reverberation.

entry.cs: Reverberatory furnace. See the Note under Furnace.
entry.def: Producing reverberation; acting by reverberation; reverberative.
A reverberatory furnace.
To cover again with verdure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Revered; p. pr. & vb. n. Revering
entry.ety: L. revereri; pref. re- re- + vereri to fear, perh. akin to E. wary: cf. F. révérer
entry.def: To regard with reverence, or profound respect and affection, mingled with awe or fear; to venerate; to reverence; to honor in estimation.
entry.q: Marcus Aurelius, whom he rather revered as his father than treated as his partner in the empire.
entry.syn: To venerate; adore; reverence.

entry.note: ☞ Formerly, as in Chaucer, reverence denoted “respect” “honor”, without awe or fear.

cs.cd: an apologetical phrase for an unseemly expression made in the presence of a priest or clergyman.
a contracted form of Save your reverence.
cs.q: Such a one as a man may not speak of, without he say. “Sir reverence.”
cs.cd: to show reverence or honor; to perform an act of reverence.
cs.q: Now lies he there, And none so poor to do him reverence.

entry.usage: Awe Reverence Dread Veneration. Reverence is a strong sentiment of respect and esteem, sometimes mingled slightly with fear; as, reverence for the divine law. Awe is a mixed feeling of sublimity and dread in view of something great or terrible, sublime or sacred; as, awe at the divine presence. It does not necessarily imply love. Dread is an anxious fear in view of an impending evil; as, dread of punishment. Veneration is reverence in its strongest manifestations. It is the highest emotion we can exercise toward human beings. Exalted and noble objects produce reverence; terrific and threatening objects awaken dread; a sense of the divine presence fills us with awe; a union of wisdom and virtue in one who is advanced in years inspires us with veneration.
entry.ety: F. révérence, L. reverentia. See Reverent

sn.def: Profound respect and esteem mingled with fear and affection, as for a holy being or place; the disposition to revere; veneration.
sn.q: If thou be poor, farewell thy reverence.
Reverence, which is the synthesis of love and fear.
When discords, and quarrels, and factions, are carried openly and audaciously, it is a sign the reverence of government islost.

sn.def: The act of revering; a token of respect or veneration; an obeisance.
sn.q: Make twenty reverences upon receiving . . . about twopence.
And each of them doeth all his diligence To do unto the feast reverence.

sn.def: That which deserves or exacts manifestations of reverence; reverend character; dignity; state.
sn.q: I am forced to lay my reverence by.

sn.def: A person entitled to be revered; -- a title applied to priests or other ministers with the pronouns his or your; sometimes poetically to a father.
sn.syn: Awe; honor; veneration; adoration; dread.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reverenced; p. pr. & vb. n. Reverencing
entry.def: To regard or treat with reverence; to regard with respect and affection mingled with fear; to venerate.
entry.q: Let . . . the wife see that she reverence her husband.
Those that I reverence those I fear, the wise.

entry.def: One who regards with reverence.
entry.q: Reverencersof crowned heads.

entry.note: ☞ This word is commonly given as a title of respect to ecclesiastics. A clergyman is styled the reverend; a dean, the very reverend; a bishop, the right reverend; an archbishop, the most reverend.
entry.ety: F. révérend, L. reverendus, fr. revereri. See Revere
entry.def: Worthy of reverence; entitled to respect mingled with fear and affection; venerable.
entry.q: A reverend sire among them came.
They must give good example and reverend deportment in the face of their children.

entry.def: Reverently.

entry.ety: L. reverens -entis, p. pr. of revereri. See Revere

sn.def: Disposed to revere; impressed with reverence; submissive; humble; respectful; as, reverent disciples.
sn.q: They . . . prostrate fell before himreverent.

sn.def: Expressing reverence, veneration, devotion, or submission; as, reverent words; reverent behavior.

entry.ety: Cf. F. révérenciel. See Reverence
entry.def: Proceeding from, or expressing, reverence; having a reverent quality; reverent; as, reverential fear or awe.
entry.q: Areverentialesteem of things sacred.

entry.def: In a reverential manner.
In a reverent manner; in respectful regard.
One who reveres.

entries.entry:
Rev"er*ie Rev"er*y, n.; pl.Reveries #. F. réverie, fr. rêver to dream, rave, be light-headed. Cf. Rave
A loose or irregular train of thought occurring in musing or mediation; deep musing; daydream. Rapt in namelessreveries. When ideas float in our mind without any reflection or regard of the understanding, it is that which the French call revery, our language has scarce a name for it.
An extravagant conceit of the fancy; a vision. R There are infinite reveries and numberless extravagancies pass through both [wise and foolish minds].

entry.ety: F. See Reverse n.
entry.def: A part turned or folded back so as to show the inside, or a piece put on in imitation of such a part, as the lapel of a coat.

entry.ety: See Reverse
entry.def: Intended to reverse; implying reversal.

entry.ety: From Reverse

sn.def: The act of reversing; the causing to move or face in an opposite direction, or to stand or lie in an inverted position; as, the reversal of a rotating wheel; the reversal of objects by a convex lens.

A change or overthrowing; as, the reversal of a judgment, which amounts to an official declaration that it is false; the reversal of an attainder, or of an outlawry, by which the sentence is rendered void.

cs.cd: the bearing of a back station as observed from the station next in advance.
a curve like the letter S, formed of two curves bending in opposite directions.
a fire in the rear.

an operation the steps of which are taken in a contrary order to that in which the same or similar steps are taken in another operation considered as direct; an operation in which that is sought which in another operation is given, and that given which in the other is sought; as, finding the length of a pendulum from its time of vibration is the reverse operation to finding the time of vibration from the length.

entry.ety: OE. revers, OF. revers, L. reversus, p. p. of revertere. See Revert

sn.def: Turned backward; having a contrary or opposite direction; hence; opposite or contrary in kind; as, the reverse order or method.
sn.q: A vicereverseunto this.

sn.def: Turned upside down; greatly disturbed.
sn.q: He found the sea diverse With many a windy storm reverse.

sn.def: Reversed; as, a reverse shell.

entry.ety: Cf. F. revers. See Reverse a.

sn.def: That which appears or is presented when anything, as a lance, a line, a course of conduct, etc., is reverted or turned contrary to its natural direction.
sn.q: He did so with the reverse of the lance.

sn.def: That which is directly opposite or contrary to something else; a contrary; an opposite.
sn.q: And then mistook reverse of wrong for right.
To make everything the reverse of what they have seen, is quite as easy as to destroy.

sn.def: The act of reversing; complete change; reversal; hence, total change in circumstances or character; especially, a change from better to worse; misfortune; a check or defeat; as, the enemy met with a reverse .
sn.q: The strange reverse of fate you see; I pitied you, now you may pity me.
By a reverse of fortune, Stephen becomes rich.

sn.def: The back side; as, the reverse of a drum or trench; the reverse of a medal or coin, that is, the side opposite to the obverse . See Obverse.
A thrust in fencing made with a backward turn of the hand; a backhanded stroke.
A turn or fold made in bandaging, by which the direction of the bandage is changed.

cs.cd: a position of a soldier in which the piece passes between the right elbow and the body at an angle of 45°, and is held as in the illustration.
cs.mcol: To reverse an engineorTo reverse a machine
cs.cd: to cause it to perform its revolutions or action in the opposite direction.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reversed r�*vẽrst";p. pr. & vb. n. Reversing
entry.ety: See Reverse a., and cf. Revert

sn.def: To turn back; to cause to face in a contrary direction; to cause to depart.
sn.q: And that old dame said many an idle verse, Out of her daughter's heart fond fancies to reverse.

sn.def: To cause to return; to recall.
sn.q: And to his fresh remembrance did reverse The ugly view of his deformed crimes.

sn.def: To change totally; to alter to the opposite.
sn.q: Reverse the doom of death.
She reversed the conduct of the celebrated vicar of Bray.

sn.def: To turn upside down; to invert.
sn.q: A pyramid reversed may stand upon his point if balanced by admirable skill.

sn.def: Hence, to overthrow; to subvert.
sn.q: These can divide, and these reverse, the state.
Custom . . . reverses even the distinctions of good and evil.

sn.def: To overthrow by a contrary decision; to make void; to under or annual for error; as, to reverse a judgment, sentence, or decree.
sn.syn: To overturn; overset; invert; overthrow; subvert; repeal; annul; revoke; undo.

sn.def: To return; to revert.
To become or be reversed.

cs.cd: a picture corresponding with the original in light and shade, but reversed as to right and left.

sn.def: Turned side for side, or end for end; changed to the contrary;
sinistrorse or sinistral; as, a reversed, or sinistral, spiral or shell.
Annulled and the contrary substituted; as, a reversed judgment or decree.

entry.def: In a reversed way.
Irreversible.
In a reverse manner; on the other hand; on the opposite.
One who reverses.
The quality of being reversible.

entry.cs: Reversible lock a lock that may be applied to a door opening in either direction, or hinged to either jamb. Reversible process. See under Process.
entry.ety: Cf. F. réversible revertible, reversionary

sn.def: Capable of being reversed; as, a chair or seat having a reversible back; a reversible judgment or sentence.
Hence, having a pattern or finished surface on both sides, so that either may be used; -- said of fabrics.

entry.def: In a reversible manner.

cs.cd: a steam engine having a reversing gear by means of which it can be made to run in either direction at will.
gear for reversing the direction of rotation at will.

entry.def: Serving to effect reversal, as of motion; capable of being reversed.

cs.cd: the act of reverting a series. See To revert a series, under Revert v. t.

entry.ety: F. réversion, L. reversio a turning back. See Revert

sn.def: The act of returning, or coming back; return.
sn.q: After his reversion home, [he] was spoiled, also, of all that he brought with him.

sn.def: That which reverts or returns; residue.
sn.q: The small reversion of this great navy which came home might be looked upon by religious eyes as relics.

sn.def: The returning of an estate to the grantor or his heirs, by operation of law, after the grant has terminated; hence, the residue of an estate left in the proprietor or owner thereof, to take effect in possession, by operation of law, after the termination of a limited or less estate carved out of it and conveyed by him.
Hence, a right to future possession or enjoyment; succession.
sn.q: For even reversions are all begged before.

sn.def: A payment which is not to be received, or a benefit which does not begin, until the happening of some event, as the death of a living person.
A return towards some ancestral type or character; atavism.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a reversion; involving a reversion; to be enjoyed in succession, or after the termination of a particular estate; as, a reversionary interest or right.
That which is to be received in reversion.
One who has a reversion, or who is entitled to lands or tenements, after a particular estate granted is terminated.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A certain game at cards.

cs.cd: to treat a series, as y = a + bx + cx2 + etc., where one variable y is expressed in powers of a second variable x, so as to find therefrom the second variable x, expressed in a series arranged in powers of y.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reverted; p. pr. & vb. n. Reverting
entry.ety: L. revertere reversum; pref. re- re- + vertere to turn: cf. OF. revertir. See Verse, and cf. Reverse

sn.def: To turn back, or to the contrary; to reverse.
sn.q: Till happy chance revert the cruel scence.
The tumbling stream . . . Reverted, plays in undulating flow.

sn.def: To throw back; to reflect; to reverberate.
To change back. See Revert v. i.
To return; to come back.
sn.q: So that my arrows Would have reverted to my bow again.

sn.def: To return to the proprietor after the termination of a particular estate granted by him.
To return, wholly or in part, towards some preëxistent form; to take on the traits or characters of an ancestral type.
To change back, as from a soluble to an insoluble state or the reverse; thus, phosphoric acid in certain fertilizers reverts .

entry.def: One who, or that which, reverts.
entry.q: An active promoter in making the East Saxons converts, or rather reverts, to the faith.

entry.def: Turned back; reversed. Specifically: Her Bent or curved twice, in opposite directions, or in the form of an S.
A remedy which restores the natural order of the inverted irritative motions in the animal system.

sn.def: One who, or that which, reverts.
Reversion.

entry.def: Capable of, or admitting of, reverting or being reverted; as, a revertible estate.
Reverting, or tending to revert; returning.
entry.q: The tide revertive, unattracted, leaves A yellow waste of idle sands behind.

entry.def: Same as Reverie.

entry.ety: OF reverstir, F. revêtir, L. revestire; pref. re- re- + vestire to clothe, fr. vestis a garment. See Vestry, and cf. Revet

sn.def: To clothe again; to cover, as with a robe; to robe.
sn.q: Her, nathless, . . . the enchanter Did thus revest and decked with due habiliments.

sn.def: To vest again with possession or office; as, to revest a magistrate with authority.

entry.def: To take effect or vest again, as a title; to revert to former owner; as, the title or right revests in A after alienation.

entry.ety: LL. revestiarium: cf. F. revestiaire. See Revest
entry.def: The apartment, in a church or temple, where the vestments, etc., are kept; -- now contracted into vestry.
Same as Revestiary.
Vesture.
entry.q: Richrevesture of cloth of gold.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Revetted;p. pr. & vb. n. Revetting
entry.ety: See Revetment
entry.def: To face, as an embankment, with masonry, wood, or other material.

entry.ety: F. revêtement the lining of a ditch, fr. revêtir to clothe, L. revestire. See Revest v. t.
entry.def: A facing of wood, stone, or any other material, to sustain an embankment when it receives a slope steeper than the natural slope; also, a retaining wall.
To vibrate back or in return.

entry.ety: L. revictus, p. p. of revincere to conquer
entry.def: To reconquer.

entry.ety: From L. revivere revictum, to live again; pref. re- re- + vivere to live
entry.def: Return to life.
To victual again.

sn.def: To vie with, or rival, in return.
To meet a wager on, as on the taking of a trick, with a higher wager.
To exceed an adversary's wager in card playing.
To make a retort; to bandy words.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Review�d; p. pr. & vb. n. Reveiwing
entry.ety: Pref. re- + view. Cf. Review n.

sn.def: To view or see again; to look back on.
sn.q: I shallreviewSicilia.

entry.sn:
To go over and examine critically or deliberately. Specifically: To reconsider; to revise, as a manuscript before printing it, or a book for a new edition.
To go over with critical examination, in order to discover exellences or defects; hence, to write a critical notice of; as, to review a new novel.
To make a formal or official examination of the state of, as troops, and the like; as, to review a regiment.
Law To reëxamine judically; as, a higher court may review the proceedings and judgments of a lower one.

sn.def: To retrace; to go over again.
sn.q: Shall I the long, laborious scene review?

entry.def: To look back; to make a review.

cs.cd: a bill, in the nature of proceedings in error, filed to procure an examination and alteration or reversal of a final decree which has been duly signed and enrolled.
a commission formerly granted by the crown to revise the sentence of the court of delegates.

entry.ety: F. revue, fr. revu, p. p. of revoir to see again, L. revidere; pref. re- re- + videre to see. See View and cf. Revise

sn.def: A second or repeated view; a reëxamination; a retrospective survey; a looking over again; as, a review of one's studies; a review of life.
An examination with a view to amendment or improvement; revision; as, an author's review of his works.
A critical examination of a publication, with remarks; a criticism; a critique.
A periodical containing critical essays upon matters of interest, as new productions in literature, art, etc.
An inspection, as of troops under arms or of a naval force, by a high officer, for the purpose of ascertaining the state of discipline, equipments, etc.
The judicial examination of the proceedings of a lower court by a higher.
A lesson studied or recited for a second time.
sn.syn: Reëxamination; resurvey; retrospect; survey; reconsideration; revisal; revise; revision.

entry.def: Capable of being reviewed.
A review.
One who reviews or reëxamines; an inspector; one who examines publications critically, and publishes his opinion upon their merits; a professional critic of books.

entry.ety: LL. revigoratus, p. p. of revigorare; L. re- + vigor vigor
entry.def: Having new vigor or strength; invigorated anew.
To give new vigor to.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Reviled; p. pr. & vb. n. Reviling
entry.ety: Pref. re- + OF. aviler to make vile, depreciate, F. avilir; à (L. ad.) + vil vile. See Vile
entry.def: To address or abuse with opprobrious and contemptuous language; to reproach.
entry.q: And did not she herselfrevileme there?
Who, when he was reviled reviled not again.
entry.syn: To reproach; vilify; upbraid; calumniate.

entry.def: Reproach; reviling.
entry.q: The gracious Judge, without revile, replied.

entry.def: The act of reviling; also, contemptuous language; reproach; abuse.
One who reviles.
Reproach; abuse; vilification.
entry.q: Neither be ye afraid of their revilings.

entry.def: Uttering reproaches; containing reproaches.

entry.ety: See Revict
entry.def: To overcome; to refute, as error.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + vindicate. Cf. Revindicate Revenge
entry.def: To vindicate again; to reclaim; to demand and take back.

entry.ety: L. revirescens, p. pr. of revirescere to grow green again
entry.def: A growing green or fresh again; renewal of youth or vigor.
That may be revised.

entry.ety: From Revise
entry.def: The act of revising, or reviewing and reëxamining for correction and improvement; revision; as, the revisal of a manuscript; the revisal of a proof sheet; the revisal of a treaty.

cs.col: The Revised Version of the Bible
cs.cd: a version prepared in accordance with a resolution passed, in 1870, by both houses of the Convocation of the Province of Canterbury, England. Both English and American revisers were employed on the work. It was first published in a complete form in 1885, and is a revised form of the Authorized Version. See Authorized Version, under Authorized.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Revised; p. pr. & vb. n. Revising
entry.ety: F. reviser, fr. L. revidere revisum, to see again; pref. re- re- + videre visum, to see. See Review View

sn.def: To look at again for the detection of errors; to reëxamine; to review; to look over with care for correction; as, to revise a writing; to revise a translation.
To compare (a proof) with a previous proof of the same matter, and mark again such errors as have not been corrected in the type.
To review, alter, and amend; as, to revise statutes; to revise an agreement; to revise a dictionary.
A review; a revision.
A second proof sheet; a proof sheet taken after the first or a subsequent correction.

entry.def: One who revises.

entry.ety: F. révision, L. revisio

sn.def: The act of revising; reëxamination for correction; review; as, the revision of a book or writing, or of a proof sheet; a revision of statutes.
That which is made by revising.
sn.syn: Reëxamination; revisal; revise; review.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to revision; revisory.

sn.def: To visit again.
To revise.

entry.def: The act of revisiting.
Having the power or purpose to revise; revising.
To restore vitality to; to bring back to life.
That may be revived.

entries.entry:
Re*viv"al n. From Revive
The act of reviving, or the state of being revived. Specifically: Renewed attention to something, as to letters or literature. Renewed performance of, or interest in, something, as the drama and literature. Renewed interest in religion, after indifference and decline; a period of religious awakening; special religious interest. Reanimation from a state of langour or depression; -- applied to the health, spirits, and the like. Renewed pursuit, or cultivation, or flourishing state of something, as of commerce, arts, agriculture. Renewed prevalence of something, as a practice or a fashion. Law Restoration of force, validity, or effect; renewal; as, the revival of a debt barred by limitation; the revival of a revoked will, etc.
Revivification, as of a metal. See Revivification, 2.

entry.def: The spirit of religious revivals; the methods of revivalists.

A clergyman or layman who promotes revivals of religion; an advocate for religious revivals; sometimes, specifically, a clergyman, without a particular charge, who goes about to promote revivals. Also used adjectively.
Pertaining to revivals.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Revived; p. pr. & vb. n. Reviving
entry.ety: F. revivere, L. revivere; pref. re- re- + vivere to live. See Vivid

sn.def: To return to life; to recover life or strength; to live anew; to become reanimated or reinvigorated.
sn.q: The Lord heard the voice of Elijah; and the soul of the child came into again, and he revived.

sn.def: Hence, to recover from a state of oblivion, obscurity, neglect, or depression; as, classical learning revived in the fifteenth century.
To recover its natural or metallic state, as a metal.

entry.ety: Cf. F. reviver. See Revive v. i.

sn.def: To restore, or bring again to life; to reanimate.
sn.q: Those bodies, by reason of whose mortality we died, shall be revived.

sn.def: To raise from coma, languor, depression, or discouragement; to bring into action after a suspension.
sn.q: Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts.
Your coming, friends, revives me.

sn.def: Hence, to recover from a state of neglect or disuse; as, to revive letters or learning.
To renew in the mind or memory; to bring to recollection; to recall attention to; to reawaken.
sn.q: Revivethe libels born to die.
The mind has a power in many cases to revive perceptions which it has once had.

sn.def: To restore or reduce to its natural or metallic state; as, to revive a metal after calcination.

entry.def: Revival.
One who, or that which, revives.

entry.ety: Pref. re- + vivificate: cf. L. revivificare revivificatum. Cf. Revivify
entry.def: To revive; to recall or restore to life.

entry.ety: Cf. F. révivification

sn.def: Renewal of life; restoration of life; the act of recalling, or the state of being recalled, to life.
The reduction of a metal from a state of combination to its metallic state.

entry.ety: Cf. F. révivifier, L. revivificare. See Vivify
entry.def: To cause to revive.
entry.q: Some association may revivify it enough to make it flash, after a long oblivion, into consciousness.

entry.def: Returning or restoring to life or vigor; reanimating.
The act of reviving, or the state of being revived; renewal of life.
entry.q: In this age we have a sort of reviviscence, not, I fear, of the power, but of a taste for the power, of the early times.

entry.ety: L. reviviscens, p. pr. ofreviviscere to revive; pref. re- re- + viviscere, v. incho. fr. vivere to live
entry.def: Able or disposed to revive; reviving.
Revival of a suit which is abated by the death or marriage of any of the parties, -- done by a bill of revivor.
The quality of being revocable; as, the revocability of a law.

entry.ety: L. revocabilis: cf. F. révocable. See Revoke
entry.def: Capable of being revoked; as, a revocable edict or grant; a revocable covenant.

entry.ety: L. revocatus, p. p. of revocare. See Revoke
entry.def: To recall; to call back.

entry.ety: L. revocatio: cf. F. révocation

sn.def: The act of calling back, or the state of being recalled; recall.
sn.q: One that saw the people bent for the revocation of Calvin, gave him notice of their affection.

sn.def: The act by which one, having the right, annuls an act done, a power or authority given, or a license, gift, or benefit conferred; repeal; reversal; as, the revocation of an edict, a power, a will, or a license.

entry.ety: L. revocatorius: cf. F. révocatoire
entry.def: Of or pertaining to revocation; tending to, or involving, a revocation; revoking; recalling.
To refurnish with a voice; to refit, as an organ pipe, so as to restore its tone.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Revoked;p. pr. & vb. n. Revoking
entry.ety: F. révoquer, L. revocare; pref. re- re- + vocare to call, fr. vox vocis, voice. See Voice, and cf. Revocate

sn.def: To call or bring back; to recall.
sn.q: The faint sprite he did revoke again, To her frail mansion of morality.

sn.def: Hence, to annul, by recalling or taking back; to repeal; to rescind; to cancel; to reverse, as anything granted by a special act; as, , to revoke a will, a license, a grant, a permission, a law, or the like.
To hold back; to repress; to restrain.
sn.q: She] still strove their sudden rages to revoke.

sn.def: To draw back; to withdraw.
To call back to mind; to recollect.
sn.q: A man, by revoking and recollecting within himself former passages, will be still apt to inculcate these sad memoris to his conscience.
sn.syn: To abolish; recall; repeal; rescind; countermand; annul; abrogate; cancel; reverse. See Abolish.

entry.def: To fail to follow suit when holding a card of the suit led, in violation of the rule of the game; to renege.
The act of revoking.
entry.q: She [Sarah Battle] never made a revoke.

entry.def: Revocation.
One who revokes.
By way of revocation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Revolted; p. pr. & vb. n. Revolting
entry.ety: Cf. F. révoller, It. rivoltare. See Revolt n.

sn.def: To turn away; to abandon or reject something; specifically, to turn away, or shrink, with abhorrence.
sn.q: But this got by casting pearl to hogs, That bawl for freedom in their senseless mood, And still revolt when trith would set them free.
His clear intelligence revolted from the dominant sophisms of that time.

sn.def: Hence, to be faithless; to desert one party or leader for another; especially, to renounce allegiance or subjection; to rise against a government; to rebel.
sn.q: Our discontented counties do revolt.
Plant those that have revolted in the van.

sn.def: To be disgusted, shocked, or grossly offended; hence, to feel nausea; -- with at; as, the stomach revolts at such food; his nature revolts at cruelty.
To cause to turn back; to roll or drive back; to put to flight.
To do violence to; to cause to turn away or shrink with abhorrence; to shock; as, to revolt the feelings.
sn.q: This abominable medley is made rather to revolt young and ingenuous minds.
To derive delight from what inflicts pain on any sentient creatuure revolted his conscience and offended his reason.

entry.ety: F. révolte, It. rivolta, fr. rivolto, p. p. fr. L. revolvere revolutum. See Revolve

sn.def: The act of revolting; an uprising against legitimate authority; especially, a renunciation of allegiance and subjection to a government; rebellion; as, the revolt of a province of the Roman empire.
sn.q: Who first seduced them to that foul revolt?

sn.def: A revolter.
sn.q: Ingraterevolts.
sn.syn: Insurrection; sedition; rebellion; mutiny. See Insurrection.

entry.def: One who revolts.
Causing abhorrence mixed with disgust; exciting extreme repugnance; loathsome; as, revolting cruelty.

entry.ety: L. revolubilis that may be rolled back. See Revolve
entry.def: Capable of revolving; rotatory; revolving.
entry.q: Us, then, to whom the thrice three year Hath filled his revoluble orb since our arrival here, I blame not.

entry.note: ☞ A revolute leaf is coiled downwards, with the lower surface inside the coil. A leaf with revolute margins has the edges rolled under, as in the Andromeda polifilia.
entry.ety: L. revolutus, p. p. of revolvere. See Revolve
entry.def: Rolled backward or downward.

entry.note: ☞ The term is sometimes applied in astronomy to the motion of a single body, as a planet, about its own axis, but this motion is usually called rotation.

☞ When used without qualifying terms, the word is often applied specifically, by way of eminence, to: (a) The English Revolution in 1689, when William of Orange and Mary became the reigning sovereigns, in place of James II. (b) The American Revolution, beginning in 1775, by which the English colonies, since known as the United States, secured their independence. (c) The revolution in France in 1789, commonly called the French Revolution, the subsequent revolutions in that country being designated by their dates, as the Revolution of 1830, of 1848, etc.
entry.ety: F. révolution, L. revolutio. See Revolve

sn.def: The act of revolving, or turning round on an axis or a center; the motion of a body round a fixed point or line; rotation; as, the revolution of a wheel, of a top, of the earth on its axis, etc.
Return to a point before occupied, or to a point relatively the same; a rolling back; return; as, revolution in an ellipse or spiral.
sn.q: That fear Comes thundering back, with dreadful revolution, On my defenseless head.

sn.def: The space measured by the regular return of a revolving body; the period made by the regular recurrence of a measure of time, or by a succession of similar events.
sn.q: The shortrevolutionof a day.

sn.def: The motion of any body, as a planet or satellite, in a curved line or orbit, until it returns to the same point again, or to a point relatively the same; -- designated as the annual anomalistic nodical sidereal, or tropical revolution, according as the point of return or completion has a fixed relation to the year, the anomaly, the nodes, the stars, or the tropics; as, the revolution of the earth about the sun; the revolution of the moon about the earth.

The motion of a point, line, or surface about a point or line as its center or axis, in such a manner that a moving point generates a curve, a moving line a surface (called a surface of revolution), and a moving surface a solid (called a solid of revolution); as, the revolution of a right-angled triangle about one of its sides generates a cone; the revolution of a semicircle about the diameter generates a sphere.
A total or radical change; as, a revolution in one's circumstances or way of living.
sn.q: The ability . . . of the great philosopher speedily produced a complete revolution throughout the department.

sn.def: A fundamental change in political organization, or in a government or constitution; the overthrow or renunciation of one government, and the substitution of another, by the governed.
sn.q: The violence of revolutions is generally proportioned to the degree of the maladministration which has produced them.

entry.ety: Cf. F. révolutionnaire
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a revolution in government; tending to, or promoting, revolution; as, revolutionary war; revolutionary measures; revolutionary agitators.
A revolutionist.
entry.q: Dumfries was a Tory town, and could not tolerate a revolutionary.

entry.def: One who is engaged in effecting a revolution; a revolutionist.
The state of being in revolution; revolutionary doctrines or principles.
One engaged in effecting a change of government; a favorer of revolution.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Revolutioniezed; p. pr. & vb. n. Revolutionizing
entry.def: To change completely, as by a revolution; as, to revolutionize a government.
entry.q: The gospel . . . has revolutionized his soul.

entry.def: Inclined to revolve things in the mind; meditative.
That may be revolved.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Revolved; p. pr. & vb. n. Revolving
entry.ety: L. revolvere revolutum; pref. re- re- + volvere to roll, turn round. See Voluble, and cf. Revolt revolution

sn.def: To turn or roll round on, or as on, an axis, like a wheel; to rotate, -- which is the more specific word in this sense.
sn.q: If the earth revolve thus, each house near the equator must move a thousand miles an hour.

sn.def: To move in a curved path round a center; as, the planets revolve round the sun.
To pass in cycles; as, the centuries revolve .
To return; to pass.
To cause to turn, as on an axis.
sn.q: Then in the east her turn she shines,Revolved on heaven's great axile.

sn.def: Hence, to turn over and over in the mind; to reflect repeatedly upon; to consider all aspects of.
sn.q: This having heard, straight I again revolved The law and prophets.

entry.def: Act of revolving.
The act or state of revolving; revolution.
entry.q: Its own revolvency upholds the world.

entry.def: One who, or that which, revolves; specifically, a firearm ( commonly a pistol) with several chambers or barrels so arranged as to revolve on an axis, and be discharged in succession by the same lock; a repeater.

entry.cs: Revolving firearm. See Revolver. Revolving light a light or lamp in a lighthouse so arranged as to appear and disappear at fixed intervals, either by being turned about an axis so as to show light only at intervals, or by having its light occasionally intercepted by a revolving screen.
entry.def: Making a revolution or revolutions; rotating; -- used also figuratively of time, seasons, etc., depending on the revolution of the earth.
entry.q: But grief returns with the revolving year.
Revolving seasons, fruitless as they pass.

entry.ety: L. revulsus, p. p. of revellere
entry.def: To pull back with force.

entry.ety: F. révulsion, L. revulsio, fr. revellere revulsum, to pluck or pull away; pref. re- re- + vellere to pull. Cf. Convulse

sn.def: A strong pulling or drawing back; withdrawal.
sn.q: Revulsionsand pullbacks.

sn.def: A sudden reaction; a sudden and complete change; -- applied to the feelings.
sn.q: A sudden and violent revulsion of feeling, both in the Parliament and the country, followed.

sn.def: The act of turning or diverting any disease from one part of the body to another. It resembles derivation, but is usually applied to a more active form of counter irritation.

entry.ety: Cf. F. révulsif
entry.def: Causing, or tending to, revulsion.
That which causes revulsion; specifically Med, a revulsive remedy or agent.

entry.ety: See Row a series
entry.def: A row.
entry.q: Arewof sundry colored stones.

entry.def: To wake again.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rewarded; p. pr. & vb. n. Rewarding
entry.ety: OF. rewarder, another form of regarder, of German origin. The original sense is, to look at, regard, hence, to regard as worthy, give a reward to. See Ward Regard
entry.def: To give in return, whether good or evil; -- commonly in a good sense; to requite; to recompense; to repay; to compensate.
entry.q: After the deed that is done, one doom shall reward, Mercy or no mercy as truth will accord.
Thou hast rewarded me good, whereas I have rewarded thee evil.
I will render vengeance to mine enemies, and will reward them that hate me.
God rewards those that have made use of the single talent.

entry.ety: See Reward v., and cf. Regard n.

sn.def: Regard; respect; consideration.
sn.q: Take reward of thine own value.

sn.def: That which is given in return for good or evil done or received; esp., that which is offered or given in return for some service or attainment, as for excellence in studies, for the return of something lost, etc.; recompense; requital.
sn.q: Thou returnest From flight, seditious angel, to receive Thy merited reward.
Rewards and punishments do always presuppose something willingly done well or ill.

sn.def: Hence, the fruit of one's labor or works.
sn.q: The dead know not anything, neither have they any more a reward.

sn.def: Compensation or remuneration for services; a sum of money paid or taken for doing, or forbearing to do, some act.
sn.syn: Recompense; compensation; remuneration; pay; requital; retribution; punishment.

entry.def: Worthy of reward.
One who rewards.
Yielding reward.
Having, or affording, no reward.
To rue.

entries.entry:
Rew"el bone`. Perh. from F. rouelle, dim. of roue a wheel, L. rota
An obsolete phrase of disputed meaning, -- perhaps, smooth or polished bone. His saddle was of rewel boon.

entry.ety: See Rouet
entry.def: A gunlock.
Rueful.
To win again, or win back.
entry.q: The Palatinate was not worth the rewinning.

entry.def: Rule.
Realm.

sn.def: To repeat in the same words; to reëcho.
To alter the wording of; to restate in other words; as, to reword an idea or a passage.

entry.def: To write again.
Ruth.

entries.entry:
‖Rex
To play rex to play the king; to domineer. Obs
n.; pl.Reges #. L A king.

entry.def: Rain or rein.
An appelation applied after the manner of a proper name to the fox. Same as Renard.
To raise.

entry.ety: Cf. G. reisen to travel
entry.def: To go on a military expedition.

entry.ety: F., lit., level of the street. See Raze v. t., and Causey
entry.def: The ground story of a building, either on a level with the street or raised slightly above it; -- said esp. of buildings on the continent of Europe.
entry.q: Tier above tier of neat apartments rise over the little shops which form the rez-de-chaussée.

entry.ety: From NL. rhabarbarum, an old name of rhubarb. See Rhubarb
entry.def: Impregnated or tinctured with rhubarb.
Chrysophanic acid.

entry.ety: Gr. "ra`bdos a rod

sn.def: A minute smooth rodlike or fusiform structure found in the tissues of many Turbellaria.
One of the hard parts forming the ovipositor of insects.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ra`bdos a rod + koi^los hollow
entry.def: A suborder of Turbellaria including those that have a simple cylindrical, or saclike, stomach, without an intestine.
Of or pertaining to the Rhabdocœla.
See Sagittal.

entry.ety: Gr. "ra`bdos a rod + -lith
entry.def: A minute calcareous rodlike structure found both at the surface and the bottom of the ocean; -- supposed by some to be a calcareous alga.
Same as Rabdology.

entry.ety: Gr. "ra`bdwma a bundle of rods, fr. "ra`bdos a rod
entry.def: One of numerous minute rodlike structures formed of two or more cells situated behind the retinulæ in the compound eyes of insects, etc. See Illust. under Ommatidium.
Same as Rabdomancy.

entry.ety: Rhabdom + -mere
entry.def: One of the several parts composing a rhabdom.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ra`bdos a rod + fe`rein to bear
entry.def: An extinct division of Hydrozoa which includes the graptolities.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ra`bdos a rod + ���� the side
entry.def: A genus of marine Bryozoa in which the tubular cells have a centralchitinous axis and the tentacles are borne on a bilobed lophophore. It is the type of the order Pterobranchia, or Podostomata

entry.ety: Gr. "ra`bdos a rod + E. sphere
entry.def: A minute sphere composed of rhabdoliths.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Rachialgia.
Of or pertaining to the rhachis; as, the rhachidian teeth of a mollusk.

entry.ety: NL. See Rhachis, and Glossa
entry.def: A division of marine gastropods having a retractile proboscis and three longitudinal rows of teeth on the radula. It includes many of the large ornamental shells, as the miters murices olives purpuras volutes, and whelks. See Illust. in the Appendix.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ra`chis the spine
entry.def: A branch of inflorescence; the zigzag axis on which the florets are arranged in the spikelets of grasses.

entry.ety: Gr. "ra`chis -ios, the spine + ���, ���, a tooth
entry.def: Having gular teeth formed by a peculiar modification of the inferior spines of some of the vertebræ, as certain South African snakes (Dasypeltis) which swallow birds' eggs and use these gular teeth to crush them.

entries.entry:
‖Rha"chis n.; pl. E. Rhachises #, L. Rhachides #. See Rachis
rechis
Anat The spine.
Bot
The continued stem or midrib of a pinnately compound leaf, as in a rose leaf or a fern.
The principal axis in a raceme, spike, panicle, or corymb.
Zoöl
The shaft of a feather. The rhachis of the after-shaft, or plumule, is called the hyporhachis.
The central cord in the stem of a crinoid.
The median part of the radula of a mollusk.
A central cord of the ovary of nematodes.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: See Rachitis.
Of or pertaining to Rhadamanthus; rigorously just; as, a Rhadamanthine judgment.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. ���
entry.def: One of the three judges of the infernal regions; figuratively, a strictly just judge.
Rhetain.

entry.ety: L. Rhaeticus Rhetian
entry.def: Pertining to, or of the same horizon as, certain Mesozoic strata of the Rhetian Alps. These strata are regarded as closing the Triassic period. See the Chart of Geology.

entry.ety: So called from L. Rhaetia Raetia, the Rhetian Alps, where it is found
entry.def: A variety of the mineral cyanite.
See Ramadan.

Of or pertaining to a natural order of shrubs and trees (Rhamnaceæ, or Rhamneæ) of which the buckthorn (Rhamnus) is the type. It includes also the New Jersey tea, the supple-jack, and one of the plants called lotus (Zizyphus).

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. "ra`mnos a kind of prickly shrub; cf. L. rhamnos
entry.def: A genus of shrubs and small trees; buckthorn. The California Rhamnus Purshianus and the European Rhamnus catharticus are used in medicine. The latter is used for hedges.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ra`mfos a beak + ���� snout
entry.def: A genus of pterodactyls in which the elongated tail supported a leathery expansion at the tip.

entries.entry: ‖Rham`pho*the"ca n.; pl.Rhamphothecæ #. NL., fr. Gr "ra`mnos a beak + �� a case Zoöl The horny covering of the bill of birds.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ��� seam, fr. ��� to sew.
entry.def: The continuation of the seed stalk along the side of an anatropous ovule or seed, forming a ridge or seam.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ���, ���, a needle, F. raphides
entry.def: Minute transparent, often needle-shaped, crystals found in the tissues of plants.

entry.ety: L. rhaponticum rhubarb. See Rhubarb
entry.def: Chrysophanic acid.

entry.ety: Gr. "rapsw,do`s. See Rhapsody
entry.def: A rhapsodist.
A rhapsodist.

entry.ety: Gr. "rapsw,diko`s: cf. F. rhapsodique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to rhapsody; consisting of rhapsody; hence, confused; unconnected.

entry.ety: From Rhapsody

sn.def: Anciently, one who recited or composed a rhapsody; especially, one whose profession was to recite the verses of Hormer and other epic poets.
Hence, one who recites or sings poems for a livelihood; one who makes and repeats verses extempore.
sn.q: The same populace sit for hours listening to rhapsodists who recite Ariosto.

sn.def: One who writes or speaks disconnectedly and with great excitement or affectation of feeling.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rhapsodized; p. pr. & vb. n. Rhapsodizing
entry.def: To utter as a rhapsody, or in the manner of a rhapsody
To utter rhapsodies.

entry.ety: Rhapsody + -mancy
entry.def: Divination by means of verses.

entries.entry:
Rhap"so*dy n.; pl.Rhapsodies #. F. rhapsodie, L. rhapsodia, Gr. "rapsw,di`a, fr. "rapsw,do`s a rhapsodist; "ra`ptein to sew, stitch together, unite + 'w,dh` a song. See Ode
A recitation or song of a rhapsodist; a portion of an epic poem adapted for recitation, or usually recited, at one time; hence, a division of the Iliad or the Odyssey; -- called also a book.
A disconnected series of sentences or statements composed under excitement, and without dependence or natural connection; rambling composition. Arhapsodyof words. Shak. Arhapsodyof tales.
Mus A composition irregular in form, like an improvisation; as, Liszt's “Hungarian Rhapsodies .”

cs.cd: the root of Krameria Ixina, a native of New Granada.

entry.ety: Sp. ratania rataña, Peruv. rataña
entry.def: The powerfully astringent root of a half-shrubby Peruvian plant (Krameria triandra). It is used in medicine and to color port wine.
The ramie or grass-cloth plant. See Grass-cloth plant, under Grass.

entry.note: ☞ The common rhea, or nandou (Rhea Americana), ranges from Brazil to Patagonia. Darwin's rhea (Pterocnemia Darwinii), of Patagonia, is smaller, and has the legs feathered below the knee.
entry.ety: L., a proper name
entry.def: Any one of three species of large South American ostrichlike birds of the genera Rhea and Pterocnemia. Called also the American ostrich.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A suborder of struthious birds including the rheas.

entry.ety: D. reebok roebuck
entry.def: The peele.

entry.ety: NL. Rheum rhubarb, Gr. ��� See Rhubarb
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (commonly called chrysophanic acid) found in rhubarb (Rheum).
Chrysophanic acid.

entry.ety: G. rheinbeere
entry.def: One of the berries or drupes of the European buckthorn; also, the buckthorn itself.

entry.ety: Gr. ���� of or for a verb, fr. ���, ���, a sentence. See Rhetoric
entry.def: Having a verb for its base; derived from a verb; as, rhematic adjectives.
The doctrine of propositions or sentences.

cs.cd: the English version of the New Testament used by Roman Catholics. See Douay Bible.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Rheimis, or Reima, in France.

entry.ety: L. Rhenus the Rhine.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the river Rhine; as, Rhenish wine.

entry.ety: Gr. "rei^n to flow + ��� chord
entry.def: A metallic wire used for regulating the resistance of a circuit, or varying the strength of an electric current, by inserting a greater or less length of it in the circuit.

entry.ety: Gr. "rei^n to flow + kratei^n to rule
entry.def: A kind of motor speed controller permitting of very gradual variation in speed and of reverse. It is especially suitable for use with motor driven machine tools.

entry.ety: Gr. "rei^n to flow + -meter

sn.def: An instrument for measuring currents, especially the force or intensity of electrical currents; a galvanometer.
An instrument for measuring the velocity of the blood current in the arteries.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to a rheometer or rheometry.

sn.def: The measurement of the force or intensity of currents.
The calculus; fluxions.

entry.ety: Gr. "rei^n to flow + E. motor
entry.def: Any apparatus by which an electrical current is originated.

entry.ety: Gr. "rei^n to flow + ��� to carry
entry.def: A connecting wire of an electric or voltaic apparatus, traversed by a current.
One of the poles of a voltaic battery; an electrode.

entry.ety: Gr. "rei^n to flow + -scope
entry.def: An instrument for detecting the presence or movement of currents, as of electricity.

entry.ety: Gr. "rei^n + stato`s standing still
entry.def: A contrivance for adjusting or regulating the strength of electrical currents, operating usually by the intercalation of resistance which can be varied at will.

entry.ety: Gr. "rei^n to flow + te`mnein to cut
entry.def: An instrument which periodically or otherwise interrupts an electric current.

entry.ety: Gr. "rei^n to flow + ��� to turn
entry.def: An instrument for reversing the direction of an electric current.

entry.ety: L. Rhesus, a proper name, Gr. ���
entry.def: A monkey; the bhunder.

entry.ety: L. Rhaetius Raetius: cf. F. rhétien
entry.def: Pertaining to the ancient Rhæti, or Rhætians, or to Rhætia, their country; as, the Rhetian Alps, now the country of Tyrol and the Grisons.
Same as Rhætic.
Same as Rhætizite.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. ���
entry.def: A rhetorician.

entry.ety: F. rhétorique, L. rhetorica, Gr. ���� (sc. ���), fr. ��� rhetorical, oratorical, fr. ��� orator, rhetorician; perhaps akin to E. word; cf. ��� to say

sn.def: The art of composition; especially, elegant composition in prose.
Oratory; the art of speaking with propriety, elegance, and force.
Hence, artificial eloquence; fine language or declamation without conviction or earnest feeling.
Fig. : The power of persuasion or attraction; that which allures or charms.
sn.q: Sweet, silent rhetoric of persuading eyes.

entry.ety: L. rhetoricus, Gr. ����. See Rhetoric
entry.def: Of or pertaining to rhetoric; according to, or exhibiting, rhetoric; oratorical; as, the rhetorical art; a rhetorical treatise; a rhetorical flourish.
entry.q: They permit him to leave their poetical taste ungratified, provided that he gratifies their rhetorical sense.

entry.ety: L. rhetoricari. See Rhetoric
entry.def: To play the orator.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rhétorication
entry.def: Rhetorical amplification.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rhétoricien

sn.def: One well versed in the rules and principles of rhetoric.
sn.q: The understanding is that by which a man becomes a mere logician and a mere rhetorician.

sn.def: A teacher of rhetoric.
sn.q: The ancient sophists and rhetoricians, which ever had young auditors, lived till they were an hundred years old.

sn.def: An orator; specifically, an artificial orator without genuine eloquence; a declaimer.

entry.def: Suitable to a master of rhetoric.
entry.q: Withrhetoricianpride.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rhetorized -rīzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Rhetorizing -rī`zĭng
entry.def: To play the orator.
To represent by a figure of rhetoric, or by personification.

entry.ety: NL., from L. Rha the river Volga, on the banks of which it grows. See Rhubarb
entry.def: A genus of plants. See Rhubarb.

entry.cs: Salt rheum. Med See Salt rheum, in the Vocabulary.
entry.ety: OF. reume rheume, F. rhume a cold,, L. rheuma rheum, from Gr. ���, fr. "rei^n to flow, akin to E. stream. See Stream n., and cf. Hemorrhoids
entry.def: A serous or mucous discharge, especially one from the eves or nose.
entry.q: I have a rheum in mine eyes too.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� subject to a discharge or flux: cf. L. rheumaticus, F. rhumatique. See Rheum Rheumatism

sn.def: Derived from, or having the character of, rheum; rheumic.
Of or pertaining to rheumatism; as, rheumatic pains or affections; affected with rheumatism; as, a rheumatic old man; causing rheumatism; as, a rheumatic day.
sn.q: That rheumatic diseases do abound.

entry.def: One affected with rheumatism.

entry.cs: Inflammatory rheumatism Med acute rheumatism attended with fever, and attacking usually the larger joints, which become swollen, hot, and very painful. Rheumatism root. Bot See Twinleaf.
entry.ety: L. rheumatismus rheum, Gr. ����, fr.��� to have or suffer from a flux, fr. ��� rheum: cf. F. rheumatisme. See 2d Rheum
entry.def: A general disease characterized by painful, often multiple, local inflammations, usually affecting the joints and muscles, but also extending sometimes to the deeper organs, as the heart.
Of or pertaining to rheumatism.

entry.ety: Rheumatism + -oid
entry.def: Of or resembling rheum or rheumatism.

entry.cs: Rheumic diathesis. See Dartrous diathesis, under Dartrous.
entry.def: Pertaining to, or characterized by, rheum.

entry.ety: NL. See Rheum
entry.def: The class of skin disease developed by the dartrous diathesis. See under Dartrous.
Of or pertaining to rheum; abounding in, or causing, rheum; affected with rheum.
entry.q: His head and rheumy eyes distill in showers.
And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air To add unto his sickness.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� cold + L. oleum oil
entry.def: A mixture of volatile hydrocarbons intermediate between gsolene and cymogene. It is obtained in the purification of crude petroleum, and is used as a refregerant.
See Rhyme.

entry.ety: Gr���, ���, the nose
entry.def: Og or pertaining to the nose or olfactory organs.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ���, ���, nose + ��� star
entry.def: The borele.

entry.ety: AS. ryne. See Run
entry.def: A water course; a ditch.
Of or pertaining to the rhinencephalon.

entries.entry: ‖Rhi`nen*ceph"a*lon ☞ The term is sometimes used for one of the olfactory lobes, the plural being used for the two taken together. rī`nĕn*sĕf"ȧ*lŏn n.; pl.Rhinencephala rī`nĕn*sĕf"ȧ*lȧ. NL., fr. Gr. "ri`s "rino`s, the nose + 'egke`falos the brain Anat The division of the brain in front of the prosencephalon, consisting of the two olfactory lobes from which the olfactory nerves arise.

entry.ety: Cf. G. rheinkiesel Rhine quartz
entry.def: A colorless stone of high luster, made of paste. It is much used as an inexpensive ornament.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ri`s "rino`s, the nose + -itis
entry.def: Inflammation of the nose; esp., inflammation of the mucous membrane of the nostrils.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: Gold and silver, or money.
entry.q: As long as the rhino lasted.

entries.entry: Rhi"no-. A combining form from Greek ��, ���, the nose, as in rhinolith, rhinology.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the rhinoceros; resembling the rhinoceros, or his horn.

entry.note: ☞ The Indian, or white, and the Javan rhinoceroses (Rhinoceros Indicus and Rhinoceros Sondaicus) have incisor and canine teeth, but only one horn, and the very thick skin forms shieldlike folds. The two or three African species belong to Atelodus, and have two horns, but lack the dermal folds, and the incisor and canine teeth. The two Malay, or East Indian, two-horned species belong to Ceratohinus, in which incisor and canine teeth are present. See Borele, and Keitloa.
entry.cs: Rhinoceros auk Zoöl an auk of the North Pacific (Cerorhina monocrata) which has a deciduous horn on top of the bill. Rhinoceros beetle Zoöl a very large beetle of the genus Dynastes, having a horn on the head. Rhinoceros bird. Zoöl A large hornbill (Buceros rhinoceros), native of the East Indies. It has a large hollow hornlike process on the bill. Called also rhinoceros hornbill . See Hornbill. An African beefeater (Buphaga Africana). It alights on the back of the rhinoceros in search of parasitic insects.
entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. "rinoke`rws "rinoke`rwtos; "ri`s "rino`s, the nose + ke`ras a horn: cf. F. rhinocéros. See Horn
entry.def: Any pachyderm belonging to the genera Rhinoceros Atelodus, and several allied genera of the family Rhinocerotidæ, of which several living, and many extinct, species are known. They are large and powerful, and usually have either one or two stout conical median horns on the snout.
A rhinoceros.
Of or pertaining to the rhinoceros.

entry.ety: Rhino- + -lite -lith
entry.def: A concretion formed within the cavities of the nose.
Of or pertaining to rhinology.
One skilled in rhinology.

entry.ety: Rhino- + -logy
entry.def: The science which treats of the nose, and its diseases.

entry.ety: Rhino- + Gr. ��� crest
entry.def: Any species of the genus Rhinilophus, or family Rhinolophidæ, having a horseshoe-shaped nasal crest; a horseshoe bat.
Like or pertaining to the rhinolophids, or horseshoe bats.

entry.ety: Rhino- + Gr. fe`rein to bear
entry.def: One of the two tentacle-like organs on the back of the head or neck of a nudibranch or tectibranch mollusk. They are usually retractile, and often transversely furrowed or plicate, and are regarded as olfactory organs. Called also dorsal tentacles. See Illust. under Pygobranchia, and Opisthobranchia.

entry.ety: Rhino- + -plastic: cf. F. rhinoplastique
entry.def: Of or pertaining to rhinoplasty; as, a rhinoplastic operation.

entry.ety: Rhino- + -plasty: cf. F. rhinoplastie
entry.def: Plastic surgery of the nose to correct deformity or to replace lost tissue. Tissue may be transplanted from the patient's cheek, forehead, arm, etc., or even from another person.

entry.ety: Rhino- + Gr. pw^ma a lid.
entry.def: Any old-world bat of the genus Rhinopoma. The rhinopomes have a long tail extending beyond the web, and inhabit caves and tombs.

entry.ety: Rhino- + scleroma
entry.def: A rare disease of the skin, characterized by the development of very hard, more or less flattened, prominences, appearing first upon the nose and subsequently upon the neighboring parts, esp. the lips, palate, and throat.

entry.ety: Rhino- + -scope
entry.def: A small mirror for use in rhinoscopy.
Of or pertaining to rhinoscopy.

entry.ety: Rhino- + -scopy
entry.def: The examination or study of the soft palate, posterior nares, etc., by means of a laryngoscopic mirror introduced into the pharynx.

entries.entry: ‖Rhi`no*the"ca n.; pl.Rhinothecæ #. NL., from gr. ���, ���, the nose + ��� case Zoöl The sheath of the upper mandible of a bird.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ��� a fan + ���� a tongue
entry.def: A division of gastropod mollusks having a large number of long, divergent, hooklike, lingual teeth in each transverse row. It includes the scutibranchs. See Illustration in Appendix.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� a fan + ��� wing
entry.def: One of the Rhipiptera, a group of insects having wings which fold like a fan; a strepsipter.
Same as Rhipipter.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� root + ��� flower
entry.def: Producing flowers from a rootstock, or apparently from a root.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� root
entry.def: A rootlike filament or hair growing from the stems of mosses or on lichens; a rhizoid.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� root + ��� fruit
entry.def: Having perennial rootstocks or bulbs, but annual flowering stems; -- said of all perennial herbs.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ��� root + ��� head
entry.def: A division of Pectostraca including saclike parasites of Crustacea. They adhere by rootlike extensions of the head. See Illusration in Appendix.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� root + ���, ���, a tooth
entry.def: A reptile whose teeth are rooted in sockets, as the crocodile.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� root + -gen: cf. F. rhizogène
entry.def: Prodicing roots.
One of a proposed class of flowering plants growning on the roots of other plants and destitute of green foliage.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� root + -oid
entry.def: A rootlike appendage.

entries.entry: ‖Rhi*zo"ma n.; pl.Rhizomata #. NL Bot SAme as Rhizome.

entry.def: Having the nature or habit of a rhizome or rootstock.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� the mass of roots (of a tree), a stem, race, fr. ��� to make to root, pass., to take root, fr. ��� a root: cf. F. rhizome
entry.def: A rootstock. See Rootstock.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A division of marsupials. The wombat is the type.

entry.ety: Gr. ���; ��� a root + ��� to eat
entry.def: Feeding on roots; root-eating.

entry.ety: NL. See Rhizophorous
entry.def: A genus of trees including the mangrove. See Mangrove.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� a root + fe`rein to bear
entry.def: Bearing roots.

entry.note: ☞ The rhizopods belonging to the Radiolaria and Foraminifera have been of great geological importance, especially in the Cretaceous and Tertiary periods. Chalk is mostly made from the shells of Foraminifera. The nummulites are the principal ingredient of a limestone which is of great extent in Europe and Asia, and is the material of which some of the pyramids of Egypt are made. The shells are abundant in deepsea mud, and are mostly minute, seldom larger than a small grain of sand, except in the case of the nummulities, which are sometimes an inch in diameter.
entry.def: One of the Rhizopoda.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ��� a root + -poda
entry.def: An extensive class of Protozoa, including those which have pseudopodia, by means of which they move about and take their food. The principal groups are Lobosa (or Amœbea), Helizoa, Radiolaria, and Foraminifera (or Reticularia). See Protozoa.
Of or pertaining to the rhizopods.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ��� a root + ���, ����, a mouth
entry.def: A suborder of Medusæ which includes very large species without marginal tentacles, but having large mouth lobes closely united at the edges. See Illust. in Appendix.
One of the Rhizostomata.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ��� a root + ��� arrangement
entry.def: The arrangement of the roots of plants.
See 1st Rob.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, rhodium and ammonia; -- said of certain complex compounds.
A salt of rhodanic acid; a sulphocyanate.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� the rose
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (commonly called sulphocyanic acid) which frms a red color with ferric salts.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� the rose + ��� resin
entry.def: Same as Convolvuln.
