entry.ety: L. Rhodius: cf. F. rhodien
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Rhodes, an island of the Mediterranean.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Rhodes.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to rhodium; containing rhodium.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ro`don the rose. So called from the rose-red color of certain of its solutions. See Rhododendron
entry.def: A rare element of the light platinum group. It is found in platinum ores, and obtained free as a white inert metal which it is very difficult to fuse. Symbol Rh. Atomic weight 104.1. Specific gravity 12.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� to be rose-red
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, a colorless crystalline substance (called rhodizonic acid, and carboxylic acid) obtained from potassium carboxide and from certain quinones. It forms brilliant red, yellow, and purple salts.

entry.ety: Gr. "ro`don the rose + ��� a coloring
entry.def: Manganese carbonate, a rose-red mineral sometimes occuring crystallized, but generally massive with rhombohedral cleavage like calcite; -- called also dialogite.

entry.ety: Gr. "ro`don rose + ��� lily
entry.def: A rose encrinite.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. "rodo`dendron, literally, rose tree; "ro`don rose + de`ndron tree. See Rose
entry.def: A genus of shrubs or small trees, often having handsome evergreen leaves, and remarkable for the beauty of their flowers; rosebay.
See Rodomontade.
See Rodomontador.

entry.ety: Gr. "ro`don the rose.
entry.def: Manganese spar, or silicate of manganese, a mineral occuring crystallised and in rose-red masses. It is often used as an ornamental stone.

entry.ety: Gr. "ro`don the rose + ��� to show
entry.def: The red pigment contained in the inner segments of the cones of the retina in animals. See Chromophane.

entry.ety: Gr. "ro`don rose + "w`ps eye
entry.def: The visual purple. See under Visual.

entry.note: ☞ As the name of a subclass, Rhodosperms, or Rhodospermeæ, is synonymous with Florideæwhich see
entry.ety: Gr. "ro`don the rose + spe`rma a seed
entry.def: Any seaweed with red spores.

cs.cd: a rhomb or oblique parallelopiped of crown or St. Gobain glass so cut that a ray of light entering one of its faces at right angles shall emerge at right angles at the opposite face, after undergoing within the rhomb, at other faces, two reflections. It is used to produce a ray circularly polarized from a plane-polarized ray, or the reverse.

entry.ety: L. rhombus, Gr. "ro`mbos rhomb, a spinning top, magic wheel, fr. "re`mbein to turn or whirl round, perhaps akin to E. wrench: cf. F. rhombe. Cf. Rhombus Rhumb

sn.def: An equilateral parallelogram, or quadrilateral figure whose sides are equal and the opposite sides parallel. The angles may be unequal, two being obtuse and two acute, as in the cut, or the angles may be equal, in which case it is usually called a square.
A rhombohedron.
Shaped like a rhomb.
Same as Orthorhombic.

entry.ety: Rhomb + ganoid
entry.def: A ganoid fish having rhombic enameled scales; one of the Rhomboganoidei.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: Same as Ginglymodi.

entry.ety: Rhomb + root of Gr. gi`gnesqai to be born
entry.def: A dicyemid which produces infusorialike embryos; -- opposed to nematogene. See Dicyemata.

cs.cd: See Hematite.
a division of the hexagonal system embracing the rhombohedron, scalenohedron, etc.

entry.def: Related to the rhombohedron; presenting the form of a rhombohedron, or a form derivable from a rhombohedron; relating to a system of forms including the rhombohedron and scalenohedron.
Rhombohedral.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. ��� rhomb + ��� seat, base
entry.def: A solid contained by six rhomboids; a parallelopiped.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� rhomboidal; ��� rhomb + e'i^dos shape: cf. F. rhomboïde
entry.def: An oblique-angled parallelogram like a rhomb, but having only the opposite sides equal, the length and with being different.
Same as Rhomboidal.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rhomboïdal
entry.def: Having, or approaching, the shape of a rhomboid.
A rhomboid.
Between rhomboid and ovate, or oval, in shape.

entries.entry: Rhomb" spar`. Min A variety of dolomite.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: Same as Rhomb, 1.
Rhonchial.

entry.cs: Rhonchial fremitus. L. fremitus a dull roaring or murmuring Med A vibration of the chest wall that may be felt by the hand laid upon its surface. It is caused in the production of rhonchi in the bronchial tubes.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a rhonchus; produced by rhonchi.

entry.ety: L. rhonchus a snoring + sonans, p. pr. of sonare to sound
entry.def: Making a snorting noise; snorting.

entries.entry: ‖Rhon"chus n.; pl.Rhonchi #. L., a snoring, a croaking Med An adventitious whistling or snoring sound heard on auscultation of the chest when the air channels are partially obstructed. By some writers the term rhonchus is used as equivalent to râle in its widest sense. See Râle.

entry.ety: Gr. ���� club-shaped; fr. ��� a club: cf. F. rhopalique
entry.def: Applied to a line or verse in which each successive word has one more syllable than the preceding.

entries.entry: ‖Rho*pa"li*um n.; pl.Rhopalia #. NL Zoöl One of the marginal sensory bodies of medusæ belonging to the Discophora.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. ��� a club + ��� ahorn
entry.def: A division of Lepidoptera including all the butterflies. They differ from other Lepidoptera in having club-shaped antennæ.

entry.ety: Gr. "rwtaki`zein to use the letter rρ) overmuch: cf. F. rhotacisme
entry.def: An oversounding, or a misuse, of the letter r; specifically Phylol, the tendency, exhibited in the Indo-European languages, to change s to r, as wese to were.

entry.cs: Monk's rhubarb. Bot See under Monk. Turkey rhubarb Med the roots of Rheum Emodi.
entry.ety: F. rhubarbe, OF. rubarbe rheubarbe reubarbare reobarbe, LL. rheubarbarum for rheum barbarum, Gr. ��� (and ��) rhubarb, from the river Rhathe Volga) on whose banks it grew. Originally, therefore, it was the barbarian plant from the Rha. Cf. Barbarous Rhaponticine

sn.def: The name of several large perennial herbs of the genus Rheum and order Polygonaceæ.
The large and fleshy leafstalks of Rheum Rhaponticum and other species of the same genus. They are pleasantly acid, and are used in cookery. Called also pieplant.
The root of several species of Rheum, used much as a cathartic medicine.

entry.def: Like rhubarb.

cs.cd: to sail continuously on one course, following a rhumb line.

entry.ety: F. rumb, Sp. rumbo, or Pg. rumbo rumo, probably fr. Gr. ��� a magic wheel, a whirling motion, hence applied to a point of the compass. See Rhomb
entry.def: A line which crosses successive meridians at a constant angle; -- called also rhumb line, and loxodromic curve. See Loxodromic.

entry.ety: L., sumac, fr. Gr. ���
entry.def: A genus of shrubs and small treets. See Sumac.

entry.ety: See Rusma
entry.def: A mixtire of caustic lime and orpiment, or tersulphide of arsenic, -- used in the depilation of hides.

entry.cs: Female rhyme. See under Female. Male rhyme. See under Male. Rhyme or reason sound or sense. Rhyme royal Pros a stanza of seven decasyllabic verses, of which the first and third, the second, fourth, and fifth, and the sixth and seventh rhyme.
entry.ety: OE. ryme rime, AS. rīm number; akin to OHG. rīm number, succession, series, G. reim rhyme. The modern sense is due to the influence of F. rime, which is of German origin, and originally the same word

sn.def: An expression of thought in numbers, measure, or verse; a composition in verse; a rhymed tale; poetry; harmony of language.
sn.q: Railingrhymes.
A ryme I learned long ago.
He knew Himself to sing, and build the lofty rime.

sn.def: Correspondence of sound in the terminating words or syllables of two or more verses, one succeeding another immediately or at no great distance. The words or syllables so used must not begin with the same consonant, or if one begins with a vowel the other must begin with a consonant. The vowel sounds and accents must be the same, as also the sounds of the final consonants if there be any.
sn.q: For rhyme with reason may dispense, And sound has right to govern sense.

sn.def: Verses, usually two, having this correspondence with each other; a couplet; a poem containing rhymes.
A word answering in sound to another word.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rhymed;p. pr. & vb. n. Rhyming
entry.ety: OE. rimen rymen, AS. rīman to count: cf. F. rimer to rhyme. See Rhyme n.

sn.def: To make rhymes, or verses.
sn.q: Thou shalt no longerryme.
There marched the bard and blockhead, side by side, Who rhymed for hire, and patronized for pride.

sn.def: To accord in rhyme or sound.
sn.q: And, if they rhymed and rattled, all was well.

sn.def: To put into rhyme.
To influence by rhyme.
sn.q: Hearken to a verser, who may chanceRhyme thee to good.

entry.def: Destitute of rhyme.
One who makes rhymes; a versifier; -- generally in contempt; a poor poet; a poetaster.
entry.q: This would make them soon perceive what despicaple creatures our common rhymers and playwriters be.

entry.def: The art or habit of making rhymes; rhyming; -- in contempt.
A rhymer; a maker of poor poetry.
Pertaining to rhyme.
A rhymer; a rhymester.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ry`gchos snout + ��� a leech
entry.def: A suborder of leeches including those that have a protractile proboscis, without jaws. Clepsine is the type.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ry`gchos snout + kefalh` head
entry.def: An order of reptiles having biconcave vertebræ, immovable quadrate bones, and many other peculiar osteological characters. Hatteria is the only living genus, but numerous fossil genera are known, some of which are among the earliest of reptiles. See Hatteria. Called also Rhynchocephalia.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ry`gchos snout + koi`los hollow
entry.def: Same as Nemertina.

entry.ety: Gr. "ry`gchos snout, beak + -lie: cf. F. rhyncholithe
entry.def: A fossil cephalopod beak.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ry`gchos snout
entry.def: A genus of brachiopods of which some species are still living, while many are found fossil.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ry`gchos snout + fe`rein to carry
entry.def: A group of Coleoptera having a snoutlike head; the snout beetles, curculios, or weevils.
One of the Rhynchophora.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ry`gchos snout
entry.def: Same as Hemiptera.

entry.ety: Gr. "rei^n to flow + -lite
entry.def: A quartzose trachyte, an igneous rock often showing a fluidal structure.

entry.ety: Gr. ���� painting foul or mean objects; "ryparo`s filthy, dirty + gra`fein to write, paint
entry.def: In ancient art, the painting of genre or still-life pictures.

entry.ety: Gr. ��� flow + -meter
entry.def: An instrument, acting on the principle of Pitot's tube, for measuring the velocity of a fluid current, the speed of a ship, etc.

entry.ety: F. rhythme rythme, L. rhythmus, fr. Gr. ��� measured motion, measure, proportion, fr. "rei^n to flow. See Stream

sn.def: In the widest sense, a dividing into short portions by a regular succession of motions, impulses, sounds, accents, etc., producing an agreeable effect, as in music poetry, the dance, or the like.
Movement in musical time, with periodical recurrence of accent; the measured beat or pulse which marks the character and expression of the music; symmetry of movement and accent.
A division of lines into short portions by a regular succession of arses and theses, or percussions and remissions of voice on words or syllables.
The harmonious flow of vocal sounds.

entry.def: One who writes in rhythm, esp. in poetic rhythm or meter.
entry.q: One now scarce counted a rhythmer, formerly admitted for a poet.

entry.cs: Rhythmical accent. Mus See Accent n., 6 .
entry.ety: Gr. ����: cf. L. rhythmicus, F. rhythmique
entry.def: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, rhythm
entry.q: Day and night I worked my rhythmic thought.

entry.def: In a rhythmical manner.
The department of musical science which treats of the length of sounds.
Writing rhythm; verse making.
entry.q: Therhythmingmonk.

entry.def: Being without rhythm.

entry.ety: Rhythm + -meter
entry.def: An instrument for marking time in musical movements. See Metronome.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: Rhythm.
See Rytina.
A Spanish coin. See Real.
Royal.

entry.ety: From Royal
entry.def: A gold coin formerly current in England, of the value of ten shillings sterling in the reign of Henry VI., and of fifteen shillings in the reign of Elizabeth.

entry.ety: F. riant, p. pr. of rire to laugh, L. ridere
entry.def: Laughing; laughable; exciting gayety; gay; merry; delightful to the view, as a landscape.
entry.q: In such cases the sublimity must be drawn from the other sources, with a strict caution, howewer, against anything light and riant.

entry.note: ☞ In man there are twelve ribs on each side, of which the upper seven are directly connected with the sternum by cartilages, and are called sternal, or true ribs. The remaining five pairs are called asternal, or false ribs, and of these each of the three upper pairs is attached to the cartilage of the rib above, while the two lower pairs are free at the ventral ends, and are called floating ribs. See Thorax.
entry.cs: Chuck rib a cut of beef immediately in front of the middle rib. See Chuck. Fore ribs a cut of beef immediately in front of the sirloin. Middle rib a cut of beef between the chuck rib and the fore ribs. Rib grass. Bot Same as Ribwort.
entry.ety: AS. rib ribb; akin to D. rib, G. rippe, OHG. rippa rippi, Dan. ribbe, Icel. rif, Russ. rebro

sn.def: One of the curved bones attached to the vertebral column and supporting the lateral walls of the thorax.

entry.sn:
That which resembles a rib in form or use. Specifically: Shipbuilding One of the timbers, or bars of iron or steel, that branch outward and upward from the keel, to support the skin or planking, and give shape and strength to the vessel.
Mach. & Structures A ridge, fin, or wing, as on a plate, cylinder, beam, etc., to strengthen or stiffen it.
One of the rods on which the cover of an umbrella is extended.
A prominent line or ridge, as in cloth.
A longitudinal strip of metal uniting the barrels of a double-barreled gun.

sn.def: The chief nerve, or one of the chief nerves, of a leaf.

sd.def: Any longitudinal ridge in a plant.

In Gothic vaulting, one of the primary members of the vault. These are strong arches, meeting and crossing one another, dividing the whole space into triangles, which are then filled by vaulted construction of lighter material. Hence, an imitation of one of these in wood, plaster, or the like.
A projecting mold, or group of moldings, forming with others a pattern, as on a ceiling, ornamental door, or the like.
Solid coal on the side of a gallery; solid ore in a vein.
An elongated pillar of ore or coal left as a support.

sn.def: A wife; -- in allusion to Eve, as made out of Adam's rib.
sn.q: How many have we known whose heads have been broken with their own rib.

cs.cd: to leave strips of undisturbed ground between the furrows in plowing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ribbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Ribbing

sn.def: To furnish with ribs; to form with rising lines and channels; as, to rib cloth.
To inclose, as with ribs, and protect; to shut in.
sn.q: It [lead] were too gross To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.

entry.ety: OE. ribald ribaud, F. ribaud, OF. ribald ribault, LL. ribaldus, of German origin; cf. OHG hrīpa prostitute. For the ending -ald cf. E. Herald
entry.def: A low, vulgar, brutal, foul-mouthed wretch; a lewd fellow.
entry.q: Ribald was almost a class name in the feudal system . . . He was his patron's parasite, bulldog, and tool . . . It is not to be wondered at that the word rapidly became a synonym for everything ruffianly and brutal.

entry.def: Low; base; mean; filthy; obscene.
entry.q: The busy day, Waked by the lark, hath roused the ribald crows.

entry.def: Like a ribald.
Of a ribald quality.

entry.ety: OE. ribaldrie ribaudrie, OF. ribalderie ribauderie
entry.def: The talk of a ribald; low, vulgar language; indecency; obscenity; lewdness; -- now chiefly applied to indecent language, but formerly, as by Chaucer, also to indecent acts or conduct.
entry.q: The ribaldry of his conversation moved �stonishment even in that age.

entry.def: See Ribbon.

cs.cd: a variety of jasper having stripes of different colors, as red and green.

entry.def: See Ribbon.
See Rib-band.
Ribboned.
A ribald.

entry.ety: F

sn.def: An engine of war used in the Middle Ages, consisting of a protected elevated staging on wheels, and armed in front with pikes. It was (after the 14th century) furnished with small cannon.
A huge bow fixed on the wall of a fortified town for casting javelins.

entry.def: Filthy; obscene; ribald.
Ribaldry.
Ribaldry.
A ribald.
A ribbon.

cs.cd: oblique longitudinal sections of the hull of a vessel.

entry.ety: Rib + band
Written also riband, and ribbon
entry.def: A long, narrow strip of timber bent and bolted longitudinally to the ribs of a vessel, to hold them in position, and give rigidity to the framework.

sn.def: Furnished or formed with ribs; as, a ribbed cylinder; ribbed cloth.
Intercalated with slate; -- said of a seam of coal.

entry.def: An assemblage or arrangement of ribs, as the timberwork for the support of an arch or coved ceiling, the veins in the leaves of some plants, ridges in the fabric of cloth, or the like.

entry.note: ☞ The blue ribbon, and The red ribbon, are phrases often used to designate the British orders of the Garter and of the Bath, respectively, the badges of which are suspended by ribbons of these colors. See Blue ribbon, under Blue.
entry.cs: Ribbon fish. Zoöl Any elongated, compressed, ribbon-shaped marine fish of the family Trachypteridæ, especially the species of the genus Trachypterus, and the oarfish (Regelecus Banksii) of the North Atlantic, which is sometimes over twenty feet long. The hairtail, or bladefish. A small compressed marine fish of the genus Cepola, having a long, slender, tapering tail. The European species (Cepola rubescens) is light red throughout. Called also band fish. Ribbon grass Bot a variety of reed canary grass having the leaves stripped with green and white; -- called also Lady's garters. See Reed grass, under Reed. Ribbon seal Zoöl a North Pacific seal (Histriophoca fasciata). The adult male is dark brown, conspicuously banded and striped with yellowish white. Ribbon snake Zoöl a common North American snake (Eutainia saurita). It is conspicuously striped with bright yellow and dark brown. Ribbon Society a society in Ireland, founded in the early part of the 19th century in antagonism to the Orangemen. It afterwards became an organization of tennant farmers banded together to prevent eviction by landlords. It took its name from the green ribbon worn by members as a badge. Ribborn worm. Zoöl A tapeworm. A nemertean.
entry.ety: OE. riban, OF. riban, F. ruban, probably of German origin; cf. D. ringband collar, necklace, E. ring circle, and band

sn.def: A fillet or narrow woven fabric, commonly of silk, used for trimming some part of a woman's attire, for badges, and other decorative purposes.
A narrow strip or shred; as, a steel or magnesium ribbon; sails torn to ribbons.
Same as Rib-band.
Driving reins.
A bearing similar to the bend, but only one eighth as wide.
A silver.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ribboned; p. pr. & vb. n. Ribboning
entry.def: To adorn with, or as with, ribbons; to mark with stripes resembling ribbons.
The principles and practices of the Ribbonmen. See Ribbon Society, under Ribbon.

entries.entry: Rib"bon*man n.; pl.-men. A member of the Ribbon Society. See Ribbon Society, under Ribbon.

entry.def: A malvaceous tree (Hoheria populnea) of New Zealand, the bark of which is used for cordage.

entry.ety: NL.; cf. Dan. ribs, and Ar. rībās a plant with an acid juice
entry.def: A genus of shrubs including gooseberries and currants of many kinds.

entry.ety: See Rebec

sn.def: A sort of stringed instrument; a rebec.
An old woman; -- in contempt.
A bawd; a prostitute.

entry.ety: See Ribibe
entry.def: A small threestringed viol; a rebec.
entry.q: All can be play on gittern or ribible.

entry.def: Having no ribs.
To beat soundly.
A species of plantain (Plantago lanceolata) with long, narrow, ribbed leaves; -- called also rib grass ripple grass ribwort plantain.

entries.entry:
-ric. AS rīce kingdom, dominion. See Rich
A suffix signifying dominion jurisdiction; as, bishopric, the district over which a bishop exercises authority.

entry.cs: Ant rice. Bot See under Ant. French rice. Bot See Amelcorn. Indian rice., a tall reedlike water grass (Zizania aquatica), bearing panicles of a long, slender grain, much used for food by North American Indians. It is common in shallow water in the Northern States. Called also water oat Canadian wild rice, etc. Mountain rice any species of an American genus (Oryzopsis) of grasses, somewhat resembling rice. Rice bunting. Zoöl Same as Ricebird. Rice hen Zoöl the Florida gallinule. Rice mouse Zoöl a large dark-colored field mouse (Calomys palistris) of the Southern United States. Rice paper a kind of thin, delicate paper, brought from China, -- used for painting upon, and for the manufacture of fancy articles. It is made by cutting the pith of a large herb (Fatsia papyrifera, related to the ginseng) into one roll or sheet, which is flattened out under pressure. Called also pith paper. Rice troupial Zoöl the bobolink. Rice water a drink for invalids made by boiling a small quantity of rice in water. Rice-water discharge Med a liquid, resembling rice water in appearance, which is vomited, and discharged from the bowels, in cholera. Rice weevil Zoöl a small beetle (Calandra oryzæorSitophilus oryzæ) which destroys rice, wheat, and Indian corn by eating out the interior; -- called also black weevil.
entry.ety: F. rizcf. Pr. ris, It. riso), L. oryza, Gr. ���, ���, probably from the Persian; cf. OPers. brīzi, akin to Skr. vrīhi; or perh. akin to E. rye. Cf. Rye
entry.def: A well-known cereal grass (Oryza sativa) and its seed. This plant is extensively cultivated in warm climates, and the grain forms a large portion of the food of the inhabitants. In America it grows chiefly on low, moist land, which can be overflowed.
The Java sparrow.
The bobolink.
Any one of numerous species of small white polished marine shells of the genus Olivella.

entry.note: ☞ Rich is sometimes used in the formation of self-explaining compounds; as, rich-fleeced, rich-jeweled, rich-laden, rich-stained.
entry.ety: OE. riche, AS. rīce rich, powerful; akin to OS. rīki, D. rijk, G. reich, OHG. rīhhi, Icel. rīkr, Sw. rik, Dan. rig, Goth. reiks; from a word meaning, ruler, king, probably borrowed from Celtic, and akin to L. rex regis, king, regere to guide, rule. √283. See Right, and cf. Derrick Enrich Rajah Riches Royal

sn.def: Having an abundance of material possessions; possessed of a large amount of property; well supplied with land, goods, or money; wealthy; opulent; affluent; -- opposed to poor.
sn.q: Richmerchants.
The richperson] hath many friends.
As a thief, bent to unhoard the cash Of some rich burgher.

sn.def: Hence, in general, well supplied; abounding; abundant; copious; bountiful; as, a rich treasury; a rich entertainment; a rich crop.
sn.q: If life be short, it shall be glorious; Each minute shall be rich in some great action.
The gorgeous East with richest hand Showers on her kings barbaric pearl and gold.

sn.def: Yielding large returns; productive or fertile; fruitful; as, rich soil or land; a rich mine.
Composed of valuable or costly materials or ingredients; procured at great outlay; highly valued; precious; sumptuous; costly; as, a rich dress; rich silk or fur; rich presents.
sn.q: Like to rich and various gems.

sn.def: Abounding in agreeable or nutritive qualities; -- especially applied to articles of food or drink which are high-seasoned or abound in oleaginous ingredients, or are sweet, luscious, and high-flavored; as, a rich dish; rich cream or soup; rich pastry; rich wine or fruit.
sn.q: Sauces and rich spices are fetched from India.

sn.def: Not faint or delicate; vivid; as, a rich color.
Full of sweet and harmonius sounds; as, a rich voice; rich music.
Abounding in beauty; gorgeous; as, a rich landscape; rich scenery.
Abounding in humor; exciting amusement; entertaining; as, the scene was a rich one; a rich incident or character.
sn.syn: Wealthy; affluent; opulent; ample; copious; abundant; plentiful; fruitful; costly; sumptuous; precious; generous; luscious.

entry.def: To enrich.

entry.note: ☞ Richesse, the older form of this word, was in the singular number. The form riches, however, is plural in appearance, and has now come to be used as a plural.
entry.ety: OE. richesse, F. richesse, from riche rich, of German origin. See Rich,a.

sn.def: That which makes one rich; an abundance of land, goods, money, or other property; wealth; opulence; affluence.
sn.q: Riches do not consist in having more gold and silver, but in having more in proportion, than our neighbors.

sn.def: That which appears rich, sumptuous, precious, or the like.
sn.q: The riche of heaven's pavement, trodden gold.
Against the richesses of this world shall they have misease of poverty.
In one hour so great riches is come to nought.
And for that riches where is my deserving?
sn.syn: Wealth; opulence; affluence; wealthiness; richness; plenty; abundance.

entry.ety: F. See Riches
entry.def: Wealth; riches. See the Note under Riches.
entry.q: Some man desireth for to have richesse.
The richesse of all heavenly grace.

entry.def: In a rich manner.
The quality or state of being rich (in any sense of the adjective).
An herb (Pilea pumila) of the Nettle family, having a smooth, juicy, pellucid stem; -- called also clearweed.

entry.ety: Ricinoleic + elaidic
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, an isomeric modification of ricinoleic acid obtained as a white crystalline solid.
The glycerin salt of ricinelaidic acid, obtained as a white crystalline waxy substance by treating castor oil with nitrous acid.

entry.ety: L. ricinus castor-oil plant
entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, castor oil; formerly, designating an acid now called ricinoleicacid.

entry.ety: L. ricinus castor-oil plant
entry.def: A bitter white crystalline alkaloid (C8H8N2O2) extracted from the seeds of the castor-oil plant (Ricinus communalis). Called also ricidine. Ingestion may cause vomiting and various other toxic reactions, including liver and kidney damage, convulsions, hypotension, and death.
A salt of ricinoleic acid; -- formerly called palmate.

Pertaining to, or designating, a fatty acid analogous to oleic acid, obtained from castor oil as an oily substance, C18H34O3 with a harsh taste. Formerly written ricinolic and formerly referred to as palmic.

An organic acid (C18H34O3) obtained from the castor-oil plant (Ricinus communis, or Palma Christi) and other species of the family Euphorbiaceae; chemicaly it is d-12-hydroxyoleic acid (CH3(CH2)5.CH(OH).CH2.CH=CH.(CH2)7COOH). Formerly called palmic acid.

entry.ety: L. ricinus castor-oil plant + oleum oil
entry.def: The glycerin salt of ricinoleic acid, occuring as a characteristic constituent of castor oil; -- formerly called palmin.
Ricinoleic.

entry.ety: L., the castor-oil plant
entry.def: A genus of plants of the Spurge family, containing but one species (Ricinus communis), the castor-oil plant. The fruit is three-celled, and contains three large seeds from which castor oil is expressed. See Palma Christi.

entry.ety: OE. reek rek, AS. hreác a heap; akin to hryce rick, Icel. hraukr
entry.def: A stack or pile, as of grain, straw, or hay, in the open air, usually protected from wet with thatching.
entry.q: Golden clusters of beehive ricks, rising at intervals beyond the hedgerows.

entry.def: To heap up in ricks, as hay, etc.
A stout pole for use in making a rick, or for a spar to a boat.
Rickety.

entry.ety: Of uncertain origin; but cf. AS. wrigian to bend, D. wrikken to shake, E. wriggle
entry.def: A disease which affects children, and which is characterized by a bulky head, crooked spine and limbs, depressed ribs, enlarged and spongy articular epiphyses, tumid abdomen, and short stature, together with clear and often premature mental faculties. The essential cause of the disease appears to be the nondeposition of earthy salts in the osteoid tissues. Children afflicted with this malady stand and walk unsteadily. Called also rachitis.

sn.def: Affected with rickets.
Feeble in the joints; imperfect; weak; shaky.

entry.def: A kind of openwork edging made of serpentine braid.
A flooring or framework on which a rick is made.

cs.cd: the firing of guns or howitzers, usually with small charges, at an elevation of only a few degrees, so as to cause the balls or shells to bound or skip along the ground.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A rebound or skipping, as of a ball along the ground when a gun is fired at a low angle of elevation, or of a fiat stone thrown along the surface of water.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ricochetted; p. pr. & vb. n. Ricochetting
entry.def: To operate upon by ricochet firing. See Ricochet n.
To skip with a rebound or rebounds, as a flat stone on the surface of water, or a cannon ball on the ground. See Ricochet n.
Of or pertaining to the rictus; as, rictal bristles.

entry.ety: L. ringi rictus, to open wide the mouth, to gape
entry.def: A gaping.

entry.ety: L., the aperture of the mouth
entry.def: The gape of the mouth, as of birds; -- often resricted to the corners of the mouth.
imp. & p. p. of Ride v. i.
entry.q: He rid to the end of the village, where he alighted.

cs.cd: to be free or delivered from.
to get deliverance from; to free one's self from.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. RidorRidded; p. pr. & vb. n. Ridding
entry.ety: OE. ridden redden, AS. hreddan to deliver, liberate; akin to D. & LG. redden, G. retten, Dan. redde, Sw. rädda, and perhaps to Skr. �rath to loosen

sn.def: To save; to rescue; to deliver; -- with out of.
sn.q: Deliver the poor and needy; rid them out of the hand of the wicked.

sn.def: To free; to clear; to disencumber; -- followed by of.
sn.q: Ridall the sea of pirates.
In never ridded myself of an overmastering and brooding sense of some great calamity traveling toward me.

sn.def: To drive away; to remove by effort or violence; to make away with; to destroy.
sn.q: I will red evil beasts out of the land.
Death's men, you have rid this sweet young prince!

sn.def: To get over; to dispose of; to dispatch; to finish.
sn.q: Willingnessridsway.
Mirth will make us rid ground faster than if thieves were at our tails.

entry.def: Suitable for riding; as, a ridable horse; a ridable road.

sn.def: The act of ridding or freeing; deliverance; a cleaning up or out.
sn.q: Thou shalt not make clean riddance of the corners of thy field.

sn.def: The state of being rid or free; freedom; escape.
sn.q: Riddancefrom all adversity.

entry.def: p. p. of Ride.
One who, or that which, rids.

entry.ety: OE. ridil, AS. hridder; akin to G. reiter, L. cribrum, and to Gr. ��� to distinguish, separate, and G. rein clean. See Crisis Certain

sn.def: A sieve with coarse meshes, usually of wire, for separating coarser materials from finer, as chaff from grain, cinders from ashes, or gravel from sand.
A board having a row of pins, set zigzag, between which wire is drawn to straighten it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Riddled; p. pr. & vb. n. Riddling

sn.def: To separate, as grain from the chaff, with a riddle; to pass through a riddle; as, riddle wheat; to riddle coal or gravel.
To perforate so as to make like a riddle; to make many holes in; as, a house riddled with shot.

entry.ety: For riddelss being misunderstood as the plural ending; OE. ridels redels. AS. r�dels; akin to D. raadsel, G. räthsel; fr. AS. r�dan to counsel or advise, also, to guess. √116. Cf. Read
entry.def: Something proposed to be solved by guessing or conjecture; a puzzling question; an ambiguous proposition; an enigma; hence, anything ambiguous or puzzling.
entry.q: To wring from me, and tell to them, my secret, That solved the riddle which I had proposed.
'T was a strange riddle of a lady.

entry.def: To explain; to solve; to unriddle.
entry.q: Riddle me this, and guess him if you can.

entry.def: To speak ambiguously or enigmatically.
entry.q: Lysanderriddelsvery prettily.

entry.def: One who riddles (grain, sand, etc.).
One who speaks in, or propounds, riddles.
Speaking in a riddle or riddles; containing a riddle.
entry.q: Riddlingtriplets.

entry.cs: To ride easy Naut to lie at anchor without violent pitching or straining at the cables. To ride hard Naut to pitch violently. To ride out. To go upon a military expedition. Obs Chaucer. To ride in the open air. Colloq To ride to hounds to ride behind, and near to, the hounds in hunting.
entry.usage: Ride Drive. Ride originally meant (and is so used throughout the English Bible) to be carried on horseback or in a vehicle of any kind. At present in England, drive is the word applied in most cases to progress in a carriage; as, a drive around the park, etc.; while ride is appropriated to progress on a horse. Johnson seems to sanction this distinction by giving “to travel on horseback” as the leading sense of ride; though he adds “to travel in a vehicle” as a secondary sense. This latter use of the word still occurs to some extent; as, the queen rides to Parliament in her coach of state; to ride in an omnibus.
entry.vmorph: imp. Rode rōd Ridrĭd], archaic); p. p. Ridden Rid archaic); p. pr. & vb. n. Riding
entry.ety: AS. rīdan; akin to LG. riden, D. rijden, G. reiten, OHG. rītan, Icel. rīða, Sw. rida, Dan. ride; cf. L. raeda a carriage, which is from a Celtic word. Cf. Road

sn.def: To be carried on the back of an animal, as a horse.
sn.q: To-morrow, when ye riden by the way.
Let your master ride on before, and do you gallop after him.

sn.def: To be borne in a carriage; as, to ride in a coach, in a car, and the like. See Synonym, below.
sn.q: The richest inhabitants exhibited their wealth, not by riding in gilden carriages, but by walking the streets with trains of servants.

sn.def: To be borne or in a fluid; to float; to lie.
sn.q: Men once walked where ships at anchor ride.

sn.def: To be supported in motion; to rest.
sn.q: Strong as the exletree On which heaven rides.
On whose foolish honesty My practices ride easy!

sn.def: To manage a horse, as an equestrian.
sn.q: He rode, he fenced, he moved with graceful ease.

sn.def: To support a rider, as a horse; to move under the saddle; as, a horse rides easy or hard, slow or fast.
sn.syn: Drive.
sn.q: “Will you ride over or drive?” said Lord Willowby to his quest, after breakfast that morning.

entry.cs: To ride a hobby to have some favorite occupation or subject of talk. To ride and tie to take turn with another in labor and rest; -- from the expedient adopted by two persons with one horse, one of whom rides the animal a certain distance, and then ties him for the use of the other, who is coming up on foot. Fielding. To ride down. To ride over; to trample down in riding; to overthrow by riding against; as, to ride down an enemy . Naut To bear down, as on a halyard when hoisting a sail. To ride out Naut to keep safe afloat during (a storm) while riding at anchor or when hove to on the open sea; as, to ride out the gale.

sn.def: To sit on, so as to be carried; as, to ride a horse; to ride a bicycle.
sn.q: They] rend up both rocks and hills, and ride the air In whirlwind.

sn.def: To manage insolently at will; to domineer over.
sn.q: The nobility could no longer endure to be ridden by bakers, cobblers, and brewers.

sn.def: To convey, as by riding; to make or do by riding.
sn.q: Tue only men that safe can ride Mine errands on the Scottish side.

sn.def: To overlap (each other); -- said of bones or fractured fragments.
The act of riding; an excursion on horseback or in a vehicle.
A saddle horse.
A road or avenue cut in a wood, or through grounds, to be used as a place for riding; a riding.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: A small mound of earth; ground slightly elevated; a small ridge.
imp. pl. & p. p. of Ride.

entry.ety: L. ridens, p. pr. of ridere to laugh
entry.def: Laughing.

cs.cd: a bony deposit in the muscles of the upper and inner part of the thigh, due to the pressure and irritation caused by the saddle in riding.

sn.def: One who, or that which, rides.
Formerly, an agent who went out with samples of goods to obtain orders; a commercial traveler.
One who breaks or manages a horse.

An addition or amendment to a manuscript or other document, which is attached on a separate piece of paper; in legislative practice, an additional clause annexed to a bill while in course of passage; something extra or burdensome that is imposed.
sn.q: After the third reading, a foolish man stood up to propose a rider.
This [question] was a rider which Mab found difficult to answer.

sn.def: A problem of more than usual difficulty added to another on an examination paper.
A Dutch gold coin having the figure of a man on horseback stamped upon it.
sn.q: His moldy money ! half a dozen riders.

sn.def: Rock material in a vein of ore, dividing it.
An interior rib occasionally fixed in a ship's hold, reaching from the keelson to the beams of the lower deck, to strengthen her frame.
The second tier of casks in a vessel's hold.
A small forked weight which straddles the beam of a balance, along which it can be moved in the manner of the weight on a steelyard.
A robber.

entry.def: Having no rider; as, a riderless horse.
to be executed by electrocution in the electric chair.

entry.ety: OE. rigge the back, AS. hrycg; akin to D. rug, G. rÜcken, OHG. rucki hrukki, Icel. hryggr, Sw. rugg, Dan. ryg. √16

sn.def: The back, or top of the back; a crest.
A range of hills or mountains, or the upper part of such a range; any extended elevation between valleys.
sn.q: The frozenridgesof the Alps.
Part rise crystal wall, or ridge direct.

sn.def: A raised line or strip, as of ground thrown up by a plow or left between furrows or ditches, or as on the surface of metal, cloth, or bone, etc.
The intersection of two surface forming a salient angle, especially the angle at the top between the opposite slopes or sides of a roof or a vault.
The highest portion of the glacis proceeding from the salient angle of the covered way.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ridged; p. pr. & vb. n. Ridging

sn.def: To form a ridge of; to furnish with a ridge or ridges; to make into a ridge or ridges.
sn.q: Bristles ranged like those that ridge the back Of chafed wild boars.

sn.def: To form into ridges with the plow, as land.
To wrinkle.
sn.q: With a foreheadridged.

entry.def: The part of a harness which passes over the saddle, and supports the shafts of a cart; -- called also ridgerope, and ridger.
The backbone.
entry.q: Blood . . . lying cluttered about the ridgebone.

entry.def: Same as Ridgelling.
A little ridge.

entry.ety: Prov. E. riggilt riggot, ananimal half castrated, a sheep having only one testicle; cf. Prov. G. rigel rig, a barrow hog, rigler a cock half castrated
entry.def: A half-castrated male animal.
See Ridgepole.
The timber forming the ridge of a roof, into which the rafters are secured.
See Life line, under Life.
So as to form ridges.
Having a ridge or ridges; rising in a ridge.
entry.q: Lifted on aridgywave.

entry.def: Ridicule.

entry.usage: Ridicule Derision mockery ribbing: All four words imply disapprobation; but ridicule and mockery may signify either good-natured opposition without manifest malice, or more maliciously, an attempt to humiliate. Derision is commonly bitter and scornful, and sometimes malignant. ribbing is almost always good-natured and fun-loving.
entry.ety: F. ridicule, L. ridiculum a jest, fr. ridiculus. See Ridiculous

sn.def: An object of sport or laughter; a laughingstock; a laughing matter.
sn.q: Marlborough] was so miserably ignorant, that his deficiencies made him the ridicule of his contemporaries.
To the people . . . but a trifle, to the king but a ridicule.

sn.def: Remarks concerning a subject or a person designed to excite laughter with a degree of contempt; wit of that species which provokes contemptuous laughter; disparagement by making a person an object of laughter; banter; -- a term lighter than derision.
sn.q: We have in great measure restricted the meaning of ridicule, which would properly extend over whole region of the ridiculous, -- the laughable, -- and we have narrowed it so that in common usage it mostly corresponds to “derision”, which does indeed involve personal and offensive feelings.
Safe from the bar, the pulpit, and the throne, Yet touched and shamed by ridicule alone.

sn.def: Quality of being ridiculous; ridiculousness.
sn.q: To see the ridicule of this practice.
sn.syn: Derision; banter; raillery; burlesque; mockery; irony; satire; sarcasm; gibe; jeer; sneer; ribbing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ridiculed;p. pr. & vb. n. Ridiculing
entry.def: To laugh at mockingly or disparagingly; to awaken ridicule toward or respecting.
entry.q: I 've known the young, who ridiculed his rage.
entry.syn: To deride; banter; rally; burlesque; mock; satirize; lampoon. See Deride.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Ridiculous.
entry.q: This action . . . became so ridicule.

entry.def: One who ridicules.
To make ridiculous; to ridicule.
The quality or state of being ridiculous; ridiculousness; also, something ridiculous.

entry.ety: L. ridiculosus ridiculus, fr. ridere to laigh. Cf. Risible

sn.def: Fitted to excite ridicule; absurd and laughable; unworthy of serious consideration; as, a ridiculous dress or behavior.
sn.q: Agricola, discerning that those little targets and unwieldy glaives ill pointed would soon become ridiculous against the thrust and close, commanded three Batavian cohorts . . . to draw up and come to handy strokes.

sn.def: Involving or expressing ridicule.
sn.q: It] provokes me to ridiculous smiling.
sn.syn: Ludicrous; laughable; risible; droll; comical; absurd; preposterous. See Ludicrous.

entry.ety: For thriding, Icel. þriðjungr the third part, fr. þriði third, akin to E. third. See Third
entry.def: One of the three jurisdictions into which the county of York, in England, is divided; -- formerly under the government of a reeve. They are called the North, the East, and the West Riding.

entry.cs: Riding clerk. A clerk who traveled for a commercial house. Obs. Eng One of the “six clerks” formerly attached to the English Court of Chancery. Riding hood. A hood formerly worn by women when riding. A kind of cloak with a hood. Riding master an instructor in horsemanship. Riding rhyme Pros the meter of five accents, with couplet rhyme; -- probably so called from the mounted pilgrims described in the Canterbury Tales. Dr. Guest. Riding school a school or place where the art of riding is taught.

sn.def: Employed to travel; traveling; as, a riding clerk.
sn.q: Oneridingapparitor.

sn.def: Used for riding on; as, a riding horse.
Used for riding, or when riding; devoted to riding; as, a riding whip; a riding habit; a riding day.
The act or state of one who rides.
A festival procession.
sn.q: When there any riding was in Cheap.

sn.def: Same as Ride n., 3.
A district in charge of an excise officer.

entry.ety: It., fr. LL. reductus a retreat. See Redoubt

sn.def: A favorite Italian public entertainment, consisting of music and dancing, -- held generally on fast eves.
sn.q: There are to be ridottos at guinea tickets.

sn.def: An arrangement or abridgment of a piece from the full score.

entry.def: To hold ridottos.

entry.cs: Rie grass. Bot A kind of wild barley (Hordeum pratense . Dr. Prior. Ray grass. Dr. Prior.
entry.def: See Rye.

entry.ety: See Reave
entry.def: Robbery.

entry.ety: D. riet reed + bok buck
entry.def: The reedbuck, a South African antelope (Cervicapra arundinacea); -- so called from its frequenting dry places covered with high grass or reeds. Its color is yellowish brown. Called also inghalla, and rietbok.

entries.entry: ‖Ri*fa`ci*men"to n.; pl. Rifacimenti # . It A remaking or recasting; an adaptation, esp. of a literary work or musical composition.

entry.ety: AS. rīf abundant, or Icel. rīfr munificent; akin to OD. riff rijve, abundant

sn.def: Prevailing; prevalent; abounding.
sn.q: Before the plague of London, inflammations of the lungs were rife and mortal.
Even now the tumult of loud mirth Was rife, and perfect in may listening ear.

sn.def: Having power; active; nimble.
sn.q: What! I am rife a little yet.

entry.ety: CF. G. riffeln riefeln, to groove. Cf. Rifle a gun

sn.def: A trough or sluice having cleats, grooves, or steps across the bottom for holding quicksilver and catching particles of gold when auriferous earth is washed; also, one of the cleats, grooves, or steps in such a trough. Also called ripple.
A ripple in a stream or current of water; also, a place where the water ripples, as on a shallow rapid.
sn.q: The bass have left the cool depth beside the rock and are on the riffle or just below it.

entry.ety: See Riffle
entry.def: A curved file used in carving wool and marble.

entry.ety: OE. rif and raf every particle, OF. rif et raf. CF. Raff and 1st Rifle
entry.def: Sweepings; refuse; the lowest order of society.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rifled; p. pr. & vb. n. Rifling
entry.ety: F. rifler to rifle, sweep away; of uncertain origin. CF. Raff

sn.def: To seize and bear away by force; to snatch away; to carry off.
sn.q: Till time shall rifle every youthful grace.

sn.def: To strip; to rob; to pillage.
sn.q: Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye: If not, we'll make you sit and rifle you.

To raffle.
To commit robbery.

cs.cd: a trench for sheltering sharpshooters.

entry.ety: Akin to Dan. rifle, or riffel, the rifle of a gun, a chamfer (cf. riffel riffelbösse, a rifle gun, rifle to rifle a gun, G. riefeln riefen, to chamfer, groove), and E. rive. See Rive, and cf. Riffle Rivel

sn.def: A gun, the inside of whose barrel is grooved with spiral channels, thus giving the ball a rotary motion and insuring greater accuracy of fire. As a military firearm it has superseded the musket.
A body of soldiers armed with rifles.
A strip of wood covered with emery or a similar material, used for sharpening scythes.
To grove; to channel; especially, to groove internally with spiral channels; as, to rifle a gun barrel or a cannon.
To whet with a rifle. See Rifle n., 3.

entry.note: ☞ The largest and best known species is Ptiloris paradisea of Australia. Its general color is rich velvety brown, glossed with lilac; the under parts are varied with rich olive green, and the head, throat, and two middle tail feathers are brilliant metallic green.
entry.def: Any one of several species of beautiful birds of Australia and New Guinea, of the genera Ptiloris and Craspidophora, allied to the paradise birds.

entries.entry: Ri"fle*man n.; pl.Rifleman. Mil A soldier armed with a rifle.

entry.def: One who rifles; a robber.

cs.cd: rifling for cannon, in which one side of the groove is made deeper than the other, to facilitate loading with shot having projections which enter by the deeper part of the grooves.

entry.def: The act or process of making the grooves in a rifled cannon or gun barrel.
The system of grooves in a rifled gun barrel or cannon.
p. p. of Rive.

entry.ety: Dan. rift, fr. rieve to rend. See Rive

sn.def: An opening made by riving or splitting; a cleft; a fissure.
A shallow place in a stream; a ford.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rifted; p. pr. & vb. n. Rifting
entry.def: To cleave; to rive; to split; as, to rift an oak or a rock; to rift the clouds.
entry.q: To dwell these rifted rocks between.

sn.def: To burst open; to split.
sn.q: Timber . . . not apt to rif with ordnance.

sn.def: To belch.

entry.def: A rafter.

entry.ety: See Ridge
entry.def: A ridge.

cs.cd: to adapt apparatus so as to get a purchase for moving a weight, as with a lever, tackle, capstan, etc.
to fit the shrouds, stays, braces, etc., to their respective masts and yards.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rigged; p. pr. & vb. n. Rigging
entry.ety: Norweg. rigga to bind, particularly, to wrap round, rig; cf. AS. wrīhan to cover

sn.def: To furnish with apparatus or gear; to fit with tackling.
To dress; to equip; to clothe, especially in an odd or fanciful manner; -- commonly followed by out.
sn.q: Jack was rigged out in his gold and silver lace.

sn.def: The peculiar fitting in shape, number, and arrangement of sails and masts, by which different types of vessels are distinguished; as, schooner rig, ship rig, etc. See Illustration in Appendix.
Dress; esp., odd or fanciful clothing.

cs.cd: to play a trick; to engage in a frolic; to do something strange and unbecoming.

entry.ety: Cf. Wriggle

sn.def: A romp; a wanton; one given to unbecoming conduct.
A sportive or unbecoming trick; a frolic.
A blast of wind.
sn.q: That uncertain season before the rigs of Michaelmas were yet well composed.
He little dreamt when he set out Of running such a rig.

entry.def: To play the wanton; to act in an unbecoming manner; to play tricks.
entry.q: Riggingand rifling all ways.

cs.cd: to raise or lower market prices, as by some fraud or trick.

entry.def: To make free with; hence, to steal; to pilfer.

entry.ety: F. rigadon rigaudon
entry.def: A gay, lively dance for one couple, -- said to have been borrowed from Provence in France.
entry.q: Whose dancing dogs in rigadoons excel.

entry.ety: So called from Riga, a city in Russia
entry.def: A species of pine (Pinus sylvestris), and its wood, which affords a valuable timber; -- called also Scotch pine, and red dealoryellow deal. It grows in all parts of Europe, in the Caucasus, and in Siberia.

entry.ety: L. rigatio, fr. rigare to water
entry.def: See Irrigation.

entry.ety: Ar. rijl, properly, foot
entry.def: A fixed star of the first magnitude in the left foot of the constellation Orion.

entry.ety: L. rigescens, p. pr. fr. rigescere to grow stiff
entry.def: Growing stiff or numb.

sn.def: One who rigs or dresses; one whose occupation is to fit the rigging of a ship.
A cylindrical pulley or drum in machinery.
A long slender, and pointed sable brush for making fine lines, etc.; -- said to be so called from its use by marine painters for drawing the lines of the rigging.

cs.cd: all those ropes used in bracing the yards, making and shortening sail, etc., such as braces, sheets, halyards, clew lines, and the like.
the shrouds and stays.

entry.def: Dress; tackle; especially Naut, the ropes, chains, etc., that support the masts and spars of a vessel, and serve as purchases for adjusting the sails, etc. See Illustr. of Ship and Sails.
Like a rig or wanton.
entry.q: Riggishand unmaidenly.

entry.def: See Wriggle.
The European lance fish.

entry.note: ☞ In designating the banks of a river, right and left are used always with reference to the position of one who is facing in the direction of the current's flow.
entry.cs:
At right angles so as to form a right angle or right angles, as when one line crosses another perpendicularly. Right and left in both or all directions. Colloq Right and left coupling Pipe fitting a coupling the opposite ends of which are tapped for a right-handed screw and a left-handed screw, respectivelly. Right angle. The angle formed by one line meeting another perpendicularly, as the angles ABD DBC. Spherics A spherical angle included between the axes of two great circles whose planes are perpendicular to each other. Right ascension. See under Ascension. Right Center Politics those members belonging to the Center in a legislative assembly who have sympathies with the Right on political questions. See Center n., 5.
Right cone Right cylinder Right prism Right pyramid
Geom a cone, cylinder, prism, or pyramid, the axis of which is perpendicular to the base. Right line. See under Line. Right sailing Naut sailing on one of the four cardinal points, so as to alter a ship's latitude or its longitude, but not both. Ham. Nav. Encyc. Right sphere Astron. & Geol a sphere in such a position that the equator cuts the horizon at right angles; in spherical projections, that position of the sphere in which the primitive plane coincides with the plane of the equator.
entry.note: ☞ Right is used elliptically for it is right what you say is right true.
entry.ety: OE. right riht, AS. riht; akin to D. regt, OS. & OHG. reht, G. recht, Dan. ret, Sw. rätt, Icel. rëttr, Goth. raíhts, L. rectus, p. p. of regere to guide, rule; cf. Skr. ṛju straight, right. √115. Cf. Adroit,Alert Correct Dress Regular Rector Recto Rectum Regent Region Realm Rich Royal Rule

sn.def: Straight; direct; not crooked; as, a right line.
sn.q: Rightas any line.

sn.def: Upright; erect from a base; having an upright axis; not oblique; as, right ascension; a right pyramid or cone.
Conformed to the constitution of man and the will of God, or to justice and equity; not deviating from the true and just; according with truth and duty; just; true.
sn.q: That which is conformable to the Supreme Rule is absolutely right, and is called right simply without relation to a special end.

sn.def: Fit; suitable; proper; correct; becoming; as, the right man in the right place; the right way from London to Oxford.
Characterized by reality or genuineness; real; actual; not spurious.
sn.q: Hisrightwife.
In this battle, . . . the Britons never more plainly manifested themselves to be right barbarians.

sn.def: According with truth; passing a true judgment; conforming to fact or intent; not mistaken or wrong; not erroneous; correct; as, this is the right faith.
sn.q: You are right, Justice, and you weigh this well.
If there be no prospect beyond the grave, the inference is . . . right, “Let us eat and drink, for to-morrow we die.”

sn.def: Most favorable or convenient; fortunate.
sn.q: The lady has been disappointed on the right side.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to that side of the body in man on which the muscular action is usually stronger than on the other side; -- opposed to left when used in reference to a part of the body; as, the right side, hand, arm. Also applied to the corresponding side of the lower animals.
sn.q: Became the sovereign's favorite, his right hand.

sn.def: Well placed, disposed, or adjusted; orderly; well regulated; correctly done.
Designed to be placed or worn outward; as, the right side of a piece of cloth.
sn.q: “Right,” cries his lordship.
sn.syn: Straight; direct; perpendicular; upright; lawful; rightful; true; correct; just; equitable; proper; suitable; becoming.

entry.note: ☞ In this sense now chiefly prefixed to titles; as, right honorable; right reverend.

cs.cd: a title given in England to peers and peeresses, to the eldest sons and all daughters of such peers as have rank above viscounts, and to all privy councilors; also, to certain civic officers, as the lord mayor of London, of York, and of Dublin.

entry.note: ☞ Right is used in composition with other adverbs, as upright, downright, forthright, etc.
entry.cs:
Right along without cessation; continuously; as, to work right along for several hours. Colloq. U.S
Right awayorRight off
at once; straightway; without delay. Colloq. U.S “We will . . . shut ourselves up in the office and do the work right off.” D. Webster.

sn.def: In a right manner.
In a right or straight line; directly; hence; straightway; immediately; next; as, he stood right before me; it went right to the mark; he came right out; he followed right after the guide.
sn.q: Unto Dian's temple goeth she right.
Let thine eyes look right on.
Right across its track there lay, Down in the water, a long reef of gold.

sn.def: Exactly; just.
sn.q: Came he right now to sing a raven's note?

sn.def: According to the law or will of God; conforming to the standard of truth and justice; righteously; as, to live right; to judge right.
According to any rule of art; correctly.
sn.q: You with strict discipline instructed right.

sn.def: According to fact or truth; actually; truly; really; correctly; exactly; as, to tell a story right .
sn.q: Rightat mine own cost.
Right as it were a steed of Lumbardye.
His wounds so smarted that he slept right naught.

entry.sn: In a great degree; very; wholly; unqualifiedly; extremely; highly; as, right humble; right noble; right valiant. He was notrightfat.Chaucer. For which I should be right sorry. I] return those duties back as are right fit.

entry.cs:
At all right at all points; in all respects. Obs Chaucer. Bill of rights a list of rights; a paper containing a declaration of rights, or the declaration itself. See under Bill.
By right By rightsorBy good rights
rightly; properly; correctly. He should himself use it by right. Chaucer. I should have been a woman by right. Shak. Divine rightorDivine right of kings a name given to the patriarchal theory of government, especially to the doctrine that no misconduct and no dispossession can forfeit the right of a monarch or his heirs to the throne, and to the obedience of the people. To rights. In a direct line; straight. R Woodward. At once; directly. Obs. or Colloq Swift.
To set to rights To put to rights
to put in good order; to adjust; to regulate, as what is out of order. Writ of right Law a writ which lay to recover lands in fee simple, unjustly withheld from the true owner. Blackstone.
entry.ety: AS. right. See Right a.
entry.sn:
That which is right or correct. Specifically: The straight course; adherence to duty; obedience to lawful authority, divine or human; freedom from guilt, -- the opposite of moral wrong.
A true statement; freedom from error of falsehood; adherence to truth or fact. Seldom your opinions err; Your eyes are always in the right.
A just judgment or action; that which is true or proper; justice; uprightness; integrity. Long love to her has borne the faithful knight, And well deserved, had fortune done him right.

sn.def: That to which one has a just claim.

sd.def: That which one has a natural claim to exact.
sd.q: There are no rights whatever, without corresponding duties.

sd.def: That which one has a legal or social claim to do or to exact; legal power; authority; as, a sheriff has a right to arrest a criminal.
That which justly belongs to one; that which one has a claim to possess or own; the interest or share which anyone has in a piece of property; title; claim; interest; ownership.
sd.q: Born free, he sought his right.
Hast thou not right to all created things?
Men have no right to what is not reasonable.

sd.def: Privilege or immunity granted by authority.

sn.def: The right side; the side opposite to the left.
sn.q: Led her to the Souldan's right.

sn.def: In some legislative bodies of Europe (as in France), those members collectively who are conservatives or monarchists. See Center, 5.
The outward or most finished surface, as of a piece of cloth, a carpet, etc.

cs.cd: to restore her to an upright position after careening.
to place it in line with the keel.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Righted; p. pr. & vb. n. Righting
entry.ety: AS. rihtan. See Right a.

sn.def: To bring or restore to the proper or natural position; to set upright; to make right or straight (that which has been wrong or crooked); to correct.
To do justice to; to relieve from wrong; to restore rights to; to assert or regain the rights of; as, to right the oppressed; to right one's self; also, to vindicate.
sn.q: So just is God, to right the innocent.
All experience hath shown that mankind are more disposed to suffer while evils are sufferable, than to right themselves by abolishing the forms to which they are accustomed.

sn.def: To recover the proper or natural condition or position; to become upright.
Hence, to regain an upright position, as a ship or boat, after careening.

cs.cd: to cause to turn toward the opposite point or quarter; -- hence, of troops, to cause to turn and retreat.

entry.ety: Right, adv. + about, adv
entry.def: A turning directly about by the right, so as to face in the opposite direction; also, the quarter directly opposite; as, to turn to the right-about .
Containing a right angle or right angles; as, a right-angled triangle.
To do justice to.
entry.q: Relieve [marginal reading, righten] the opressed.

entry.ety: OE. rightways rightwise, AS. rightwīs; riht right + wīs wise, having wisdom, prudent. See Right a. Wise a.
entry.def: Doing, or according with, that which is right; yielding to all their due; just; equitable; especially, free from wrong, guilt, or sin; holy; as, a righteous man or act; a righteous retribution.
entry.q: Fearless in his righteous cause.
entry.syn: Upright; just; godly; holy; uncorrupt; virtuous; honest; equitable; rightful.

entry.def: Made righteous.

entry.ety: AS. rightwīslīce
entry.def: In a righteous manner; as, to judge righteously .

entry.note: ☞ Righteousness, as used in Scripture and theology, in which it chiefly occurs, is nearly equivalent to holiness, comprehending holy principles and affections of heart, and conformity of life to the divine law.
entry.ety: AS. rihtwīsnes

sn.def: The quality or state of being righteous; holiness; purity; uprightness; rectitude.
A righteous act, or righteous quality.
sn.q: All our righteousnesses are as filthy rags.

sn.def: The act or conduct of one who is righteous.
sn.q: Blessed are they that keep judgment, and he that doeth righteousness at all times.

sn.def: The state of being right with God; justification; the work of Christ, which is the ground of justification.
sn.q: There are two kinds of Christian righteousness: the one without us, which we have by imputation; the other in us, which consisteth of faith, hope, and charity, and other Christian virtues.
Only for the righteousness of Christ imputed to us, and received by faith alone.
sn.syn: Uprightness; holiness; godliness; equity; justice; rightfulness; integrity; honesty; faithfulness.

entry.def: One who sets right; one who does justice or redresses wrong.

sn.def: Righteous; upright; just; good; -- said of persons.
Consonant to justice; just; as, a rightful cause.
Having the right or just claim according to established laws; being or holding by right; as, the rightful heir to a throne or an estate; a rightful king.
Belonging, held, or possessed by right, or by just claim; as, a rightful inheritance; rightful authority.
sn.syn: Just; lawful; true; honest; equitable; proper.

entry.def: According to right or justice.

sn.def: The quality or state of being rightful; accordance with right and justice.
Moral rectitude; righteousness.
sn.q: We fail of perfect rightfulness.

cs.cd: a rope which is laid up and twisted with the sun, that is, in the same direction as plain-laid rope. See Illust. of Cordage.

sn.def: Situated or being on the right; nearer the right hand than the left; as, the right-hand side, room, or road.
Chiefly relied on; almost indispensable.
sn.q: Mr. Alexander Truncheon, who is their right-hand man in the troop.

cs.cd: a screw, the threads of which, like those of a common wood screw, wind spirally in such a direction that the screw advances away from the observer when turned with a right-handed movement in a fixed nut.

sn.def: Using the right hand habitually, or more easily than the left.
Having the same direction or course as the movement of the hands of a watch seen in front; -- said of the motion of a revolving object looked at from a given direction.
Having the whorls rising from left to right; dextral; -- said of spiral shells. See Illust. of Scalaria.

entry.def: The state or quality of being right-handed; hence, skill; dexterity.
Having a right heart or disposition.
Destitute of right.
Formed by right lines; rectilineal; as, a right-lined angle.

entry.ety: AS. richtlice

sn.def: Straightly; directly; in front.
According to justice; according to the divine will or moral rectitude; uprightly; as, duty rightly performed.
Properly; fitly; suitably; appropriately.
sn.q: Eve rightly called, Mother of all mankind.

sn.def: According to truth or fact; correctly; not erroneously; exactly.
sn.q: I can notrightlysay.
Thou didst not rightly see.

entry.def: Having a right or honest mind.

entry.ety: AS. rihtnes
entry.def: Straightness; as, the rightness of a line.

sn.def: The quality or state of being right; right relation.
sn.q: The craving for rightness with God.

entry.def: Straight; direct.
Toward the right.
entry.q: Rightward and leftward rise the rocks.

entries.entry:
Right" whale`
Pygmy right whale Zoöl a small New Zealand whale Neobalæna marginata which is only about sixteen feet long. It produces short, but very elastic and tough, whalebone. . Zoöl The bowhead, Arctic, or Greenland whale (Balæna mysticetus), from whose mouth the best whalebone is obtained. Any other whale that produces valuable whalebone, as the Atlantic, or Biscay, right whale (Balæna cisarctica), and the Pacific right whale (Balæna Sieboldii); a bone whale.

entry.def: Righteous.
To make righteous.
Righteously.
Righteousness.
entry.q: In doom and eke in rightwisnesse.

entry.ety: L. rigidus, fr. rigere to be stiff or numb: cf. F. rigide. Cf. Rigor.

sn.def: Firm; stiff; unyielding; not pliant; not flexible.
sn.q: Upright beams innumerable Of rigid spears.

sn.def: Hence, not lax or indulgent; severe; inflexible; strict; as, a rigid father or master; rigid discipline; rigid criticism; a rigid sentence.
sn.q: The more rigid order of principles in religion and government.
sn.syn: Stiff; unpliant; inflexible; unyielding; strict; exact; severe; austere; stern; rigorous; unmitigated.

entry.ety: L. rigiditas: cf. F. rigidité. See Rigid

sn.def: The quality or state of being rigid; want of pliability; the quality of resisting change of form; the amount of resistance with which a body opposes change of form; -- opposed to flexibility ductility malleability, and softness.
Stiffness of appearance or manner; want of ease or elegance.
Severity; rigor.
sn.syn: Stiffness; rigidness; inflexibility.

entry.def: In a rigid manner; stiffly.
The quality or state of being rigid.

entry.ety: Dim. from rigid
entry.def: Somewhat rigid or stiff; as, a rigidulous bristle.
See Reglet.

entry.ety: For ragman roll. See Ragman's roll
entry.def: A succession of confused or nonsensical statements; foolish talk; nonsense.
entry.q: Often one's dear friend talks something which one scruples to call rigmarole.

entry.def: Consisting of rigmarole; frivolous; nonsensical; foolish.

entry.ety: OE. also ringol. Cf. Ring
entry.def: A circle; hence, a diadem.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. Rigolette, name of a girl in Eugene Sue's novel “Mystères de Paris.”
entry.def: A woman's light scarflike head covering, usually knit or crocheted of wool.

entry.ety: Corrupted fr. regal
entry.def: A musical instrument formerly in use, consisting of several sticks bound together, but separated by beads, and played with a stick with a ball at its end.

cs.cd: a form of rigor mortis induced by heat, as when the muscle of a mammal is heated to about 50° C.

death stiffening; the rigidity of the muscles that occurs at death and lasts till decomposition sets in. It is due to the formation of myosin by the coagulation of the contents of the individual muscle fibers.

entry.ety: L. See Rigor., below

sn.def: Rigidity; stiffness.
A sense of chilliness, with contraction of the skin; a convulsive shuddering or tremor, as in the chill preceding a fever.

entry.ety: OE. rigour, OF. rigour, F. rigueur, from L. rigor, fr. rigere to be stiff. See Rigid

sn.def: The becoming stiff or rigid; the state of being rigid; rigidity; stiffness; hardness.
sn.q: The rest his look Bound with Gorgonian rigor not to move.

sn.def: See 1st Rigor, 2.
Severity of climate or season; inclemency; as, the rigor of the storm; the rigors of winter.
Stiffness of opinion or temper; rugged sternness; hardness; relentless severity; hard-heartedness; cruelty.
sn.q: All his rigor is turned to grief and pity.
If I shall be condemn'd Upon surmises, . . . I tell you 'T is rigor and not law.

sn.def: Exactness without allowance, deviation, or indulgence; strictness; as, the rigor of criticism; to execute a law with rigor; to enforce moral duties with rigor ; -- opposed to lenity.
Severity of life; austerity; voluntary submission to pain, abstinence, or mortification.
sn.q: The prince lived in this convent with all the rigor and austerity of a capuchin.

sn.def: Violence; force; fury.
sn.q: Whose raging rigor neither steel nor brass could stay.
sn.syn: Stiffness; rigidness; inflexibility; severity; austerity; sternness; harshness; strictness; exactness.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rigorisme

sn.def: Rigidity in principle or practice; strictness; -- opposed to laxity.
Severity, as of style, or the like.
Strictness in ethical principles; -- usually applied to ascetic ethics, and opposed to ethical latitudinarianism.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rigoriste
entry.def: One who is rigorous; -- sometimes applied to an extreme Jansenist.

entry.ety: F. rigoureux, LL. rigorosus. See Rigor

sn.def: Manifesting, exercising, or favoring rigor; allowing no abatement or mitigation; scrupulously accurate; exact; strict; severe; relentless; as, a rigorous officer of justice; a rigorous execution of law; a rigorous definition or demonstration.
sn.q: He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian Rock With rigorous hands.
We do not connect the scattered phenomena into their rigorous unity.

sn.def: Severe; intense; inclement; as, a rigorous winter.
Violent.
sn.q: Rigorousuproar.

sn.def: Adhering scrupulously and exactly to accepted principles; hence, logically valid; as, a rigorous proof.
sn.syn: Rigid; inflexible; unyielding; stiff; severe; austere; stern; harsh; strict; exact.

entry.ety: Dan. Cf. Reichstag
entry.def: See Legislature Denmark.

entry.ety: Dan. See Rix-dollar
entry.def: A Danish coin worth about fifty-four cents. It was the former unit of value in Denmark.

entries.entry: ‖Rig`-Ve"da. See Veda.

entry.ety: Sw. See Rix-dollar
entry.def: A Swedish coin worth about twenty-seven cents. It was formerly the unit of value in Sweden.

entry.note: ☞ In both senses provincial in England and colloquial in the United States.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Riled rīld; p. pr. & vb. n. Riling
entry.ety: See Roil

sn.def: To render turbid or muddy; to stir up; to roil.
To stir up in feelings; to make angry; to vex.

entry.ety: It. See Relief
entry.def: Same as Relief n., 5.

entry.ety: Cf. LG. rille a small channel or brook, a furrow, a chamfer, OE. rigol a small brook, F. rigole a trench or furrow for water, W. rhill a row, rhigol a little ditch. √11

sn.def: A very small brook; a streamlet.
See Rille.

entry.def: To run a small stream.

entry.ety: G. rille a furrow
entry.def: One of certain narrow, crooked valleys seen, by aid of the telescope, on the surface of the moon.
A little rill.
Roily.

entry.cs: Arch rim Phonetics the line between the gums and the palate. Rim-fire cartridge. Mil See under Cartridge. Rim lock. See under Lock.
entry.ety: As. rima reoma, edge; cf. W. rhim rhimp, a rim, edge, boundary, termination, Armor, rim. Cf. Rind

sn.def: The border, edge, or margin of a thing, usually of something circular or curving; as, the rim of a kettle or basin.
The lower part of the abdomen.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rimmed; p. pr. & vb. n. Rimming
entry.def: To furnish with a rim; to border.

entries.entry: ‖Ri"ma n.; pl.Rimæ #. L Anat A narrow and elongated aperture; a cleft; a fissure.
‖Ri"mau da"han. From the native Oriental name Zoöl The clouded tiger cat (Felis marmorata) of Southern Asia and the East Indies.

entry.def: A short cylinder connecting a trunnion with the body of a cannon. See Illust. of Cannon.

entry.ety: L. rima
entry.def: A rent or long aperture; a chink; a fissure; a crack.

entry.ety: AS. hrīm; akin to D. rijm, Icel. hrīm, Dan. rim, Sw. rim; cf. D. rijp, G. reif, OHG. rīfo hrīfo
entry.def: White frost; hoarfrost; congealed dew or vapor.
entry.q: The trees were now covered with rime.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rimed; p. pr. & vb. n. Riming
entry.def: To freeze or congeal into hoarfrost.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: A step or round of a ladder; a rung.

entry.note: ☞ This spelling, which is etymologically preferable, is coming into use again.
entry.def: Rhyme. See Rhyme.
To rhyme. See Rhyme.
A rhymer; a versifier.
A tool for shaping the rimes of a ladder.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. rimoier. See Ryime
entry.def: To compose in rhyme; to versify.
entry.q: Laysrimeyed in their first Breton tongue.

entry.def: Having the percussion fulminate in a rim surrounding the base, distinguished from center-fire; -- said of cartridges; also, using rim-fire cartridges; as, a rim-fire gun. Such cartridges are now little used.
An implement for cutting, trimming, or ornamenting the rim of anything, as the edges of pies, etc.; also, a reamer.

entry.ety: L. rimosus, fr. rima a chink: cf. F. rimeux

sn.def: Full of rimes, fissures, or chinks.
Having long and nearly parallel clefts or chinks, like those in the bark of trees.

entry.def: In a rimose manner.
State of being rimose.
Rimose.

entry.ety: AS. hrimpele, or rimpel. See Rumple
entry.def: A fold or wrinkle. See Rumple.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rimpled; p. pr. & vb. n. Rimpling
entry.def: To rumple; to wrinkle.
Abounding with rime; frosty.

entries.entry:
‖Rin*con" n.; pl. Rincones # . Sp. rincón
An interior corner; a nook; hence, an angular recess or hollow bend in a mountain, river, cliff, or the like. Western & Southern U. S

entry.ety: AS. rind bark, crust of bread; akin to OHG. rinta, G. rinde, and probably to E. rand rim; cf. Skr. ram to end, rest
entry.def: The external covering or coat, as of flesh, fruit, trees, etc.; skin; hide; bark; peel; shell.
entry.q: Thou canst not touch the freedom of my mind With all thy charms, although this corporal rind Thou hast immanacled.
Sweetest nut hath sourest rind.

entry.def: To remove the rind of; to bark.

entry.ety: G., fr. rind, pl. rinder, cattle + pest pest, plague
entry.def: A highly contagious distemper or murrain, affecting neat cattle, and less commonly sheep and goats; -- called also cattle plague Russian cattle plague, and steppe murrain.

entry.ety: AS. rynele. √11. See Run
entry.def: A small water course or gutter.
Destitute of a rind.
Having a rind or skin.
See Rind.
Having a rind

entry.ety: It., fr. rinforzare to reënforce, strengthen
entry.def: Increasing; strengthening; -- a direction indicating a sudden increase of force (abbreviated rf. rfz.) Cf. Forzando, and Sforzando.

entry.cs:
To ring a peal to ring a set of changes on a chime of bells. To ring the changes upon. See under Change.
To ring inorTo ring out
to usher, attend on, or celebrate, by the ringing of bells; as, to ring out the old year and ring in the new. Tennyson.To ring the bells backward to sound the chimes, reversing the common order; -- formerly done as a signal of alarm or danger. Sir W. Scott.
entry.vmorph: imp. Rang răng or Rung rŭng; p. p. Rung; p. pr. & vb. n. Ringing
entry.ety: AS. hringan; akin to Icel. hringja, Sw. ringa, Dan. ringe, OD. ringhen ringkelen. √19

sn.def: To cause to sound, especially by striking, as a metallic body; as, to ring a bell.
To make (a sound), as by ringing a bell; to sound.
sn.q: The shard-borne beetle, with his drowsy hums, Hath rung night's yawning peal.

sn.def: To repeat often, loudly, or earnestly.
To sound, as a bell or other sonorous body, particularly a metallic one.
sn.q: Now ringen trompes loud and clarion.
Why ring not out the bells?

sn.def: To practice making music with bells.
To sound loud; to resound; to be filled with a ringing or reverberating sound.
sn.q: With sweeter notes each rising temple rung.
The hall with harp and carol rang.
My ears still ring with noise.

sn.def: To continue to sound or vibrate; to resound.
sn.q: The assertion is still ringing in our ears.

sn.def: To be filled with report or talk; as, the whole town rings with his fame.
A sound; especially, the sound of vibrating metals; as, the ring of a bell.
Any loud sound; the sound of numerous voices; a sound continued, repeated, or reverberated.
sn.q: The ring of acclamations fresh in his ears.

sn.def: A chime, or set of bells harmonically tuned.
sn.q: As great and tunable a ring of bells as any in the world.

entry.cs:
Ring armor armor composed of rings of metal. See Ring mail, below, and Chain mail, under Chain. Ring blackbird Zoöl the ring ousel. Ring canal Zoöl the circular water tube which surrounds the esophagus of echinoderms.
Ring dotterelorRinged dotterel . Zoöl See Dotterel, and Illust. of Pressiroster. Ring dropper a sharper who pretends to have found a ring (dropped by himself), and tries to induce another to buy it as valuable, it being worthless. Ring fence. See under Fence. Ring finger the third finger of the left hand, or the next the little finger, on which the ring is placed in marriage. Ring formula Chem a graphic formula in the shape of a closed ring, as in the case of benzene, pyridine, etc. See Illust. under Benzene. Ring mail a kind of mail made of small steel rings sewed upon a garment of leather or of cloth. Ring micrometer. Astron See Circular micrometer, under Micrometer. Saturn's rings. See Saturn. Ring ousel. Zoöl See Ousel. Ring parrot Zoöl any one of several species of Old World parrakeets having a red ring around the neck, especially Palæornis torquatus, common in India, and Palæornis Alexandri of Java. Ring plover. Zoöl The ringed dotterel. Any one of several small American plovers having a dark ring around the neck, as the semipalmated plover (Ægialitis semipalmata). Ring snake Zoöl a small harmless American snake (Diadophis punctatus) having a white ring around the neck. The back is ash-colored, or sage green, the belly of an orange red. Ring stopper. Naut See under Stopper. Ring thrush Zoöl the ring ousel. The prize ring the ring in which prize fighters contend; prize fighters, collectively. The ring. The body of sporting men who bet on horse races. Eng The prize ring.
entry.ety: AS. hring hrinc; akin to Fries. hring, D. & G. ring, OHG. ring hring, Icel. hringr, DAn. & SW. ring; cf. Russ. krug'. Cf. Harangue Rank a row,Rink
entry.def: A circle, or a circular line, or anything in the form of a circular line or hoop.

sn.def: Specifically, a circular ornament of gold or other precious material worn on the finger, or attached to the ear, the nose, or some other part of the person; as, a wedding ring .
sn.q: Upon his thumb he had of gold a ring.
The dearest ring in Venice will I give you.

sn.def: A circular area in which races are or run or other sports are performed; an arena.
sn.q: Place me, O, place me in the dusty ring, Where youthful charioteers contend for glory.

sn.def: An inclosed space in which pugilists fight; hence, figuratively, prize fighting.
sn.q: The road was an institution, theringwas an institution.

sn.def: A circular group of persons.
sn.q: And hears the Muses in a ring Aye round about Jove's alter sing.

sd.def: The plane figure included between the circumferences of two concentric circles.
The solid generated by the revolution of a circle, or other figure, about an exterior straight line (as an axis) lying in the same plane as the circle or other figure.

sn.def: An instrument, formerly used for taking the sun's altitude, consisting of a brass ring suspended by a swivel, with a hole at one side through which a solar ray entering indicated the altitude on the graduated inner surface opposite.
An elastic band partly or wholly encircling the spore cases of ferns. See Illust. of Sporangium.
A clique; an exclusive combination of persons for a selfish purpose, as to control the market, distribute offices, obtain contracts, etc.
sn.q: The ruling ring at Constantinople.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ringed; p. pr. & vb. n. Ringing

sn.def: To surround with a ring, or as with a ring; to encircle.
sn.q: Ringthese fingers.

sn.def: To make a ring around by cutting away the bark; to girdle; as, to ring branches or roots.
To fit with a ring or with rings, as the fingers, or a swine's snout.

entry.def: To rise in the air spirally.
