sn.def: A complete set of plays in a game or contest covering a standard number of individual plays or parts; as, a round of golf; a round of tennis.
One set of games in a tournament.
The time during which prize fighters or boxers are in actual contest without an intermission, as prescribed by their rules; a bout.
A circular dance.
sn.q: Come, knit hands, and beat the ground, In a light fantastic round.

sn.def: That which goes round a whole circle or company; as, a round of applause.
Rotation, as in office; succession.
The step of a ladder; a rundle or rung; also, a crosspiece which joins and braces the legs of a chair.
sn.q: All the rounds like Jacob's ladder rise.

sd.def: A walk performed by a guard or an officer round the rampart of a garrison, or among sentinels, to see that the sentinels are faithful and all things safe; also, the guard or officer, with his attendants, who performs this duty; -- usually in the plural.
A general discharge of firearms by a body of troops in which each soldier fires once.
One piece of ammunition for a firearm, used by discharging one piece at a time; as, each soldier carried a hundred rounds of ammunition.

sn.def: A short vocal piece, resembling a catch in which three or four voices follow each other round in a species of canon in the unison.
A brewer's vessel in which the fermentation is concluded, the yeast escaping through the bunghole.
A vessel filled, as for drinking; as, to drink a round od ale together.
An assembly; a group; a circle; as, a round of politicians.
See Roundtop.
Same as Round of beef, below.

entry.cs: All round over the whole place; in every direction. All-round of general capacity; as, an all-round man. Colloq To bring one round. To cause one to change his opinions or line of conduct. To restore one to health. Colloq

sn.def: On all sides; around.
sn.q: Round he throws his baleful eyes.

sn.def: Circularly; in a circular form or manner; by revolving or reversing one's position; as, to turn one's head round; a wheel turns round.
In circumference; as, a ball is ten inches round .
From one side or party to another; as to come or turn round, -- that is, to change sides or opinions.
By or in a circuit; by a course longer than the direct course; back to the starting point.
Through a circle, as of friends or houses.
sn.q: The invitations were sent round accordingly.

sn.def: Roundly; fully; vigorously.

entry.cs: Round about an emphatic form for round or about. “Moses . . . set them [The eldersround about the tabernacle.” Num. xi. 24. To come round to gain the consent of, or circumvent, (a person) by flattery or deception. Colloq
entry.def: On every side of, so as to encompass or encircle; around; about; as, the people atood round him; to go round the city; to wind a cable round a windlass.
entry.q: The serpent Error twines round human hearts.

entry.cs:
To round in Naut To haul up; usually, to haul the slack of (a rope) through its leading block, or to haul up (a tackle which hangs loose) by its fall. Totten. To collect together (cattle) by riding around them, as on cattle ranches
. Western U.S
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rounded; p. pr. & vb. n. Rounding

sn.def: To make circular, spherical, or cylindrical; to give a round or convex figure to; as, to round a silver coin; to round the edges of anything.
sn.q: Worms with many feet, which round themselves into balls, are bred chiefly under logs of timber.
The figures on our modern medals are raised and rounded to a very great perfection.

sn.def: To surround; to encircle; to encompass.
sn.q: The inclusive verge Of golden metal that must round my brow.

sn.def: To bring to fullness or completeness; to complete; hence, to bring to a fit conclusion.
sn.q: We are such stuff As dreams are made on, and our little life Is rounded with a sleep.

sn.def: To go round wholly or in part; to go about (a corner or point); as, to round a corner; to round Cape Horn.
To make full, smooth, and flowing; as, to round periods in writing.

cs.cd: to turn the head of a ship toward the wind.

sn.def: To grow round or full; hence, to attain to fullness, completeness, or perfection.
sn.q: The queen your mother rounds apace.
So rounds he to a separate mind, From whence clear memory may begin.

sn.def: To go round, as a guard.
sn.q: They . . . nightly rounding walk.

sn.def: To go or turn round; to wheel about.
Circuitous; going round; indirect; as, roundabout speech.
sn.q: We have taken a terrible roundabout road.

sn.def: Encircling; enveloping; comprehensive.
sn.q: Large, sound,roundaboutsense.

sn.def: A large horizontal wheel or frame, commonly with wooden horses, etc., on which children ride; a merry-go-round; a carousel.
A dance performed in a circle.
A short, close jacket worn by boys, sailors, etc.
A state or scene of constant change, or of recurring labor and vicissitude.
a traffic circle.

entry.def: The quality of being roundabout; circuitousness.
Applied to the method delivering the ball in bowling, by swinging the arm horizontally.
Having a round back or shoulders; round-shouldered.
Modified by contraction of the lip opening; labialized; labial. See Guide to Pronunciation, § 11.

entry.ety: OF. rondel a roundelay, F. rondel rondeau, a dim. fr. rond; for sense 2, cf. F. rondelle a round, a round shield. See Round a., and cf. Rondel Rondelay

sn.def: A rondelay.
sn.q: Sung all theroundellustily.
Come, now a roundel and a fairy song.

sn.def: Anything having a round form; a round figure; a circle.
sn.q: The Spaniards, casting themselves into roundels, . . . made a flying march to Calais.

sd.def: A small circular shield, sometimes not more than a foot in diameter, used by soldiers in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries.
A circular spot; a sharge in the form of a small circle.
A bastion of a circular form.

entry.ety: OF. rondelet, dim. of rondel. See Roundel Roundeau, and cf. Roundlet Rundlet

sn.def: See Rondeau, and Rondel.

sd.def: A tune in which a simple strain is often repeated; a simple rural strain which is short and lively.
A dance in a circle.

sn.def: Anything having a round form; a roundel.
One who rounds; one who comes about frequently or regularly.
A tool for making an edge or surface round.
An English game somewhat resembling baseball; also, another English game resembling the game of fives, but played with a football.
sn.q: Now we play rounders, and then we played prisoner's base.

entry.def: Any ordinary market fish, exclusive of flounders, sole, halibut, and other flatfishes.
A lake whitefish (Coregonus quadrilateralis), less compressed than the common species. It is very abundant in British America and Alaska.
A nickname for a Puritan. See Roundheads the, in the Dictionary of Noted Names in Fiction.
Having a round head or top.

sn.def: A constable's prison; a lockup, watch-house, or station house.

sd.def: A cabin or apartament on the after part of the quarter-deck, having the poop for its roof; -- sometimes called the coach.
A privy near the bow of the vessel.

sn.def: A house for locomotive engines, built circularly around a turntable.

entry.def: Round or nearly round; becoming round; roundish.

sn.def: Small rope, or strands of rope, or spun yarn, wound round a rope to keep it from chafing; -- called also service.
Modifying a speech sound by contraction of the lip opening; labializing; labialization. See Guide to Pronunciation, § 11.

entry.def: Somewhat round; as, a roundish seed; a roundish figure.
A little circle.

sn.def: In a round form or manner.
Openly; boldly; peremptorily; plumply.
sn.q: He affirms everything roundly.

sn.def: Briskly; with speed.
sn.q: Two of the outlaws walked roundly forward.

sn.def: Completely; vigorously; in earnest.
Without regard to detail; in gross; comprehensively; generally; as, to give numbers roundly .
sn.q: In speaking roundly of this period.

sn.def: The quality or state of being round in shape; as, the roundness of the globe, of the orb of the sun, of a ball, of a bowl, a column, etc.
Fullness; smoothness of flow; as, the roundness of a period; the roundness of a note; roundness of tone.
Openess; plainess; boldness; positiveness; as, the roundness of an assertion.
sn.syn: Circularity; sphericity; globosity; globularity; globularness; orbicularness; cylindricity; fullness; plumpness; rotundity.

entry.def: To form into round ridges by plowing.

sn.def: Any series or sequence of actions.
A document circulated from one person to another in a group, often with comments added by each recipient.
A petition or similar document, in which the signatures are arranged in circular form in order to conceal the order of signing.

A tournament in which each contestant plays against every other contestant at least once; a failure to win any contest does not result in elimination from the tournament. Contrasted with elimination tournament

entry.def: Having the shoulders stooping or projecting; round-backed.

entries.entry: Rounds"man n.; pl.Roundsmen. A patrolman; also, a policeman who acts as an inspector over the rounds of the patrolmen.

entry.def: A top; a platform at a masthead; -- so called because formerly round in shape.

sn.def: The act of collecting or gathering together scattered cattle by riding around them and driving them in.
A rounding up, or upward curvature or convexity, as in the deck of a vessel.
A gathering in of scattered persons or things; as, a round-up of criminals.

entry.def: to collect or gather together scattered animals, persons, or things.
entry.q: Round upthe usual suspects.

entry.ety: Cf. Rondure
entry.def: Roundness; a round or circle.
A nematoid worm.
Round.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. hr�pan to cry out, G. rufen, Goth. hr�pian. Cf. Roop
entry.def: To cry or shout; hence, to sell by auction.

sn.def: An outcry; hence, a sale of gods by auction.
sn.q: To roup, that is, the sale of his crops, was over.

sn.def: A disease in poultry. See Pip.

entry.def: Rising; -- applied to a bird in the attitude of rising; also, sometmes, to a bird in profile with wings addorsed.

entry.ety: Perhaps the same word as rouse to start up, “buckle to.”
entry.def: To pull or haul strongly and all together, as upon a rope, without the assistance of mechanical appliances.

entry.ety: Cf. D. roes drunkeness, icel. rūss, Sw. rus, G. rauchen, and also E. rouse, v.t., rush, v.i. Cf. Row a disturbance

sn.def: A bumper in honor of a toast or health.
A carousal; a festival; a drinking frolic.
sn.q: Fill the cup, and fill the can, Have a rouse before the morn.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Roused rouzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Rousing
entry.ety: Probably of Scan. origin; cf. Sw. rusa to rush, Dan. ruse, AS. hreósan to fall, rush. Cf. Rush v.

sn.def: To cause to start from a covert or lurking place; as, to rouse a deer or other animal of the chase.
sn.q: Like wild boars late roused out of the brakes.
Rouse the fleet hart, and cheer the opening hound.

sn.def: To wake from sleep or repose; as, to rouse one early or suddenly.
To excite to lively thought or action from a state of idleness, languor, stupidity, or indifference; as, to rouse the faculties, passions, or emotions.
sn.q: To rouse up a people, the most phlegmatic of any in Christendom.

sn.def: To put in motion; to stir up; to agitate.
sn.q: Blustering winds, which all night long Had roused the sea.

sn.def: To raise; to make erect.
To get or start up; to rise.
sn.q: Night's black agents to their preys do rouse.

sn.def: To awake from sleep or repose.
sn.q: Morpheus rouses from his bed.

sn.def: To be exited to thought or action from a state of indolence or inattention.
One who, or that which, rouses.
Something very exciting or great.
A stirrer in a copper for boiling wort.
Having power to awaken or excite; exciting.
sn.q: I begin to feel Some rousing motions in me.

sn.def: Very great; violent; astounding; as, a rousing fire; a rousing lie.

entry.def: In a rousing manner.

entry.ety: [F.; -- so called in allusion to the color. See Russet

sn.def: A fruit bat, especially the large species (Pieropus vulgaris) inhabiting the islands of the Indian ocean. It measures about a yard across the expanded wings.
Any small shark of the genus Scyllium; -- called also dogfish. See Dogfish.

entry.def: To rouse; to disturb; as, to roust one out.

entry.ety: Cf. Icel. röst an estuary
entry.def: A strong tide or current, especially in a narrow channel.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: A laborer, especially a deck hand, on a river steamboat, who moves the cargo, loads and unloads wood, and the like; in an opprobrious sense, a shiftless vagrant who lives by chance jobs.

entry.ety: AS. hrūtan
entry.def: To roar; to bellow; to snort; to snore loudly.
A bellowing; a shouting; noise; clamor; uproar; disturbance; tumult.
entry.q: This new book the whole world makes such a rout about.
“My child, it is not well,” I said, “Among the graves to shout; To laugh and play among the dead, And make this noisy rout.”

entry.cs: To rout out To turn up to view, as if by rooting; to discover; to find. To turn out by force or compulsion; as, to rout people out of bed. Colloq
entry.ety: A variant of root
entry.def: To scoop out with a gouge or other tool; to furrow.
To search or root in the ground, as a swine.

cs.cd: to defeat and throw into confusion; to overthrow and put to flight.

entry.ety: OF. route, LL. rupta, properly, a breaking, fr. L. ruptus, p. p. of rumpere to break. See Rupture reave, and cf. Rote repetition of forms, Route. In some senses this word has been confused with rout a bellowing, an uproar

sn.def: A troop; a throng; a company; an assembly; especially, a traveling company or throng.
sn.q: Arouteof ratones [rats].
A great solemnroute.
And ever he rode the hinderest of the route.
A rout of people there assembled were.

sn.def: A disorderly and tumultuous crowd; a mob; hence, the rabble; the herd of common people.
sn.q: the endless routs of wretched thralls.
The ringleader and head of all this rout.
Nor do I name of men the common rout.

sn.def: The state of being disorganized and thrown into confusion; -- said especially of an army defeated, broken in pieces, and put to flight in disorder or panic; also, the act of defeating and breaking up an army; as, the rout of the enemy was complete.
sn.q: thy army . . . Dispersed in rout, betook them all to fly.
To these giad conquest, murderous rout to those.

sn.def: A disturbance of the peace by persons assembled together with intent to do a thing which, if executed, would make them rioters, and actually making a motion toward the executing thereof.
A fashionable assembly, or large evening party.
sn.q: Atroutsand dances.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Routed; p. pr. & vb. n. Routing
entry.def: To break the ranks of, as troops, and put them to flight in disorder; to put to rout.
entry.q: That party . . . that charged the Scots, so totally routed and defeated their whole army, that they fied.
entry.syn: To defeat; discomfit; overpower; overthrow.

entry.def: To assemble in a crowd, whether orderly or disorderly; to collect in company.
entry.q: In all that land no Christian[s] durste route.

entries.entry: Rout" cake`. A kind of rich sweet cake made for routs, or evening parties. Twenty-four little rout cakes that were lying neglected in a plate.

entry.ety: OE. & F. route, OF. rote, fr. L. ruptasc. via), fr. ruptus, p. p. of rumpere to break; hence, literally, a broken or beaten way or path. See Rout, and cf. Rut a track
entry.def: The course or way which is traveled or passed, or is to be passed; a passing; a course; a road or path; a march.
entry.q: Wide through the furzy field their route they take.

sd.def: A plane made like a spokeshave, for working the inside edges of circular sashes.
A plane with a hooked tool protruding far below the sole, for smoothing the bottom of a cavity.

sn.def: A machine with a rapidly revolving vertical spindle and cutter for scooping out the surface of wood or metal, as between and around the engraved parts of an electrotype.

entry.def: Ruth; sorrow.
Involving, or pertaining to, routine; ordinary; customary.

entry.ety: F., fr. route a path, way, road. See Route Roterepetition

sn.def: A round of business, amusement, or pleasure, daily or frequently pursued; especially, a course of business or offical duties regularly or frequently returning.
Any regular course of action or procedure rigidly adhered to by the mere force of habit.

entry.def: the practice of doing things with undiscriminating, mechanical regularity.
One who habituated to a routine.
Uproarious; riotous.
With that violation of law called a rout. See 5th Rout, 4.

entry.ety: F. beurre roux brown butter
entry.def: A thickening, made of flour, for soups and gravies.

entry.ety: perhaps fr. or akin to reeve

sn.def: To draw through an eye or aperture.
To draw out into flakes; to card, as wool.
To twist slightly; to bring together, as slivers of wool or cotton, and twist slightly before spinning.
A copper washer upon which the end of a nail is clinched in boat building.
A roll or sliver of wool or cotton drawn out and slighty twisted, preparatory to further process; a roving.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Roved; p. pr. & vb. n. Roving
entry.ety: Cf. D. rooven to rob; akin to E. reave. See Reave Rob

sn.def: To practice robbery on the seas; to wander about on the seas in piracy.
Hence, to wander; to ramble; to rauge; to go, move, or pass without certain direction in any manner, by sailing, walking, riding, flying, or otherwise.
sn.q: For who has power to walk has power to rove.

sn.def: To shoot at rovers; hence, to shoot at an angle of elevation, not at point-blank (rovers usually being beyond the point-blank range).
sn.q: Fair Venus' son, that with thy cruel dart At that good knight so cunningly didst rove.
sn.syn: To wander; roam; range; ramble stroll.

sn.def: To wander over or through.
sn.q: Roving the field, I chanced A goodly tree far distant to behold.

sn.def: To plow into ridges by turning the earth of two furrows together.

cs.cd: any one of numerous species of beetles of the family Staphylinidæ, having short elytra beneath which the wings are folded transversely. They are rapid runners, and seldom fly.

entry.def: The act of wandering; a ramble.
entry.q: In thy nocturnal rove one moment halt.

cs.cd: at casual marks; hence, at random; as, shooting at rovers . See def. 5 above.
cs.q: Bound down on every side with many bands because it shall not run at rovers.

entry.ety: D. roover a robber. See Rove v. i.

sn.def: One who practices robbery on the seas; a pirate.
sn.q: Yet Pompey the Great deserveth honor more justly for scouring the seas, and taking from the rovers 846 sail of ships.

sn.def: One who wanders about by sea or land; a wanderer; a rambler.
Hence, a fickle, inconstant person.
A ball which has passed through all the hoops and would go out if it hit the stake but is continued in play; also, the player of such a ball.

sd.def: Casual marks at uncertain distances.
A sort of arrow.
sd.q: All sorts, flights, rovers, and butt shafts.

cs.cd: a machine for drawing and twisting roves and twisting roves and winding them on bobbin for the spinning machine.

sn.def: The operatin of forming the rove, or slightly twisted sliver or roll of wool or cotton, by means of a machine for the purpose, called a roving frame, or roving machine.
A roll or sliver of wool or cotton drawn out and slightly twisted; a rove. See 2d Rove, 2.

entry.def: The act of one who roves or wanders.
In a wandering manner.
The state of roving.

entry.ety: See Rough
entry.def: Rough; stern; angry.
entry.q: Lock he never sorow.

entry.ety: Abbrev. fr. rouse, n
entry.def: A noisy, turbulent quarrel or disturbance; a brawl.

cs.cd: the practice of cultivating crops in drills.
the points on a line, infinite in number, as the points in which a pencil of rays is intersected by a line.

entry.ety: OE. rowe rawe rewe, AS. rāw r�w; probably akin to D. rij, G. reihe; cf. Skr. r�khā a line, stroke
entry.def: A series of persons or things arranged in a continued line; a line; a rank; a file; as, a row of trees; a row of houses or columns.
entry.q: And there were windows in three rows.
The bright seraphim in burning row.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Rowing
entry.ety: AS. r�wan; akin to D. roeijen, MHG. rüejen, Dan. roe, Sw. ro, Icel. r�a, L. remus oar, Gr. �, Skr. aritra. √8. Cf. Rudder

sn.def: To propel with oars, as a boat or vessel, along the surface of water; as, to row a boat.
To transport in a boat propelled with oars; as, to row the captain ashore in his barge.
To use the oar; as, to row well.
To be moved by oars; as, the boat rows easily.

entry.def: The act of rowing; excursion in a rowboat.
That may be rowed, or rowed upon.
entry.q: That long barren fen, oncerowable.

cs.cd: a barry of the rowan tree.

entry.def: Rowan tree.

entries.entry:
Row"an tree`. Cf. Sw. rönn, Dan. rönne, Icel. reynir, and L. ornus
Bot A european tree (Pyrus aucuparia) related to the apple, but with pinnate leaves and flat corymbs of small white flowers followed by little bright red berries. Called also roan tree, and mountain ash. The name is also applied to two American trees of similar habit (Pyrus Americana, and Pyrus sambucifolia).

entry.def: A boat designed to be propelled by oars instead of sails.

entries.entry: Row"dy n.; pl.Rowdies #. From Rout, or Row a brawl One who engages in rows, or noisy quarrels; a ruffianly fellow.

entry.def: Hubbub; uproar.
Uproarious.
Resembling a rowdy in temper or conduct; characteristic of a rowdy.
the conduct of a rowdy.
Formed into a row, or rows; having a row, or rows; as, a twelve-rowed ear of corn.

entry.ety: OF. roele rouele, properly, a little wheel, F. rouelle collop, slice, LL. rotella a little wheel, dim. of L. rota a wheel. See Roll, and cf. Rota

sn.def: The little wheel of a spur, with sharp points.
sn.q: With sounding whip, and rowels dyed in blood.

sn.def: A little flat ring or wheel on horses' bits.
sn.q: The iron rowels into frothy foam he bit.

sn.def: A roll of hair, silk, etc., passed through the flesh of horses, answering to a seton in human surgery.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Roweled or Rowelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Roweling or Rowelling
entry.def: To insert a rowel, or roll of hair or silk, into (as the flesh of a horse).

entries.entry: Row"el bone`. See rewel bone. Obs

Row"en n. Cf. E. rough, OE. row rowe Called also rowet rowett rowings roughings
A stubble field left unplowed till late in the autumn, that it may be cropped by cattle. Turn your cows, that give milk, into your rowens till snow comes.
The second growth of grass in a season; aftermath. Prov. Eng. & Local, U.S

entry.def: One who rows with an oar.
See Rowen.

entry.ety: For oarlock; AS. ☞rloc, where the second part is skin to G. loch a hole, E. lock a fastening. See Oar, and Lock

sn.def: A contrivance or arrangement serving as a fulcrum for an oar in rowing. It consists sometimes of a notch in the gunwale of a boat, sometimes of a pair of pins between which the oar rests on the edge of the gunwale, sometimes of a single pin passing through the oar, or of a metal fork or stirrup pivoted in the gunwale and suporting the oar; same as oarlock.
One of the rings of masonry included in an arch having more than one ring.

entry.def: see Roun.
An opening in the side of small vessels of war, near the surface of the water, to facilitate rowing in calm weather.

entry.ety: From the third duke of RoxburghScotland), a noted book collector who had his books so bound
entry.def: A style of bookbinding in which the back is plain leather, the sides paper or cloth, the top gilt-edged, but the front and bottom left uncut.

entry.ety: F. roi
entry.def: A king.
Royal.

entry.cs:
Battle royal. See under Battle. Royal bay Bot the classic laurel (Laurus nobilis
Royal eagle. Zoöl See Golden eagle, under Golden. Royal fern Bot the handsome fern Osmunda regalis. See Osmund. Royal mast Naut the mast next above the topgallant mast and usually the highest on a square-rigged vessel. The royal yard and royal sail are attached to the royal mast. Royal metal an old name for gold. Royal palm Bot a magnificent West Indian palm tree (Oreodoxa regia), lately discovered also in Florida. Royal pheasant. See Curassow. Royal purple an intense violet color, verging toward blue. Royal tern Zoöl a large, crested American tern (Sterna maxima). Royal tiger. Zoöl See Tiger. Royal touch the touching of a diseased person by the hand of a king, with the view of restoring to health; -- formerly extensively practiced, particularly for the scrofula, or king's evil.
entry.ety: OE. roial riall real, OF. roial. reial, F. royal, fr. L. regalis, fr. rex regis, king. See Rich, and cf. regal real a coin, Rial

sn.def: Kingly; pertaining to the crown or the sovereign; suitable for a king or queen; regal; as, royal power or prerogative; royal domains; the royal family; royal state.
Noble; generous; magnificent; princely.
sn.q: How doth that royal merchant, good Antonio?

sn.def: Under the patronage of royality; holding a charter granted by the sovereign; as, the Royal Academy of Arts; the Royal Society.
sn.syn: Kingly; regal; monarchical; imperial; kinglike; princely; august; majestic; superb; splendid; illustrious; noble; magnanimous.

sn.def: Printing and writing papers of particular sizes. See under paper n.
A small sail immediately above the topgallant sail.
One of the upper or distal branches of an antler, as the third and fourth tynes of the antlers of a stag.
A small mortar.
One of the soldiers of the first regiment of foot of the British army, formerly called the Royals, and supposed to be the oldest regular corps in Europe; -- now called the Royal Scots.
An old English coin. See Rial.
A royal spade.

entry.def: A petty or powerless king.
entry.q: there were at this time two other royalets, as only kings by his leave.

entry.ety: Cf. F. royalisme
entry.def: the principles or conduct of royalists.

entry.ety: Cf. F. royaliste
entry.def: An adherent of a king (as of Charles I. in England, or of the Bourbons in france); one attached to monarchical government.
entry.q: Where Ca'ndish fought, the Royalists prevailed.

entry.def: The act of making loyal to a king.
to make royal.
In a royal or kingly manner; like a king; as becomes a king.
entry.q: His body shall be royally interred.

entries.entry: Royal spade. Auction Bridge A spade when spades are trumps under the condition that every trick over six taken by the successful bidder has a score value of 9; -- usually in pl.

Roy"al*ty n.; pl.Royalties #. OF. roialté royaulté, F. royauté. See Royal, and cf. Regality
The state of being royal; the condition or quality of a royal person; kingship; kingly office; sovereignty.
Royalty by birth was the sweetest way of majesty.
The person of a king or sovereign; majesty; as, in the presence of royalty . For thus his royalty doth speak.
An emblem of royalty; -- usually in the plural, meaning regalia. Obs Wherefore do I assume These royalties, and not refuse to reign?
Kingliness; spirit of regal authority. In his royalty of nature Reigns that which would be fear'd.
Domain; province; sphere.
That which is due to a sovereign, as a seigniorage on gold and silver coined at the mint, metals taken from mines, etc.; the tax exacted in lieu of such share; imperiality.
A share of the product or profit (as of a mine, forest, etc.), reserved by the owner for permitting another to use the property.
Hence Com, a duty paid by a manufacturer to the owner of a patent or a copyright at a certain rate for each article manufactured; or, a percentage paid to the owner of an article by one who hires the use of it.

entry.ety: F. rogner, OF. rooignier, to clip, pare, scare, fr. L. rotundus round See Rotund
entry.def: To bite; to gnaw.

entry.ety: F. rogneux, from rogne scab, mange, itch
entry.def: Mangy; scabby; hence, mean; paltry; troublesome.
entry.q: Theroynishclown.

entry.def: same as Roister Roisterer.

entries.entry: Roys"ton crow`. So called from Royston, a town in England Zoöl See Hooded crow, under Hooded.

entry.ety: F. roitelet, dim. of roi king
entry.def: A little king.

entry.ety: Prob. for riotish, from riot, like Scot. roytous for riotous
entry.def: Wild; irregular.

entry.cs: To rub down. To clean by rubbing; to comb or curry; as, to down a horse. To reduce or remove by rubbing; as, to rub down the rough points. To rub off to clean anything by rubbing; to separate by friction; as, to rub off rust. To rub out to remove or separate by friction; to erase; to obliterate; as, to rub out a mark or letter; to rub out a stain. To rub up. To burnish; to polish; to clean. To excite; to awaken; to rouse to action; as, to rub up the memory.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rubbed; p. pr. & vb. n. Rubbing
entry.ety: Probably of Celtic origin; cf. W. rhwbiaw, gael. rub

sn.def: To subject (a body) to the action of something moving over its surface with pressure and friction, especially to the action of something moving back and forth; as, to rub the flesh with the hand; to rub wood with sandpaper.
sn.q: It shall be expedient, after that body is cleaned, to rub the body with a coarse linen cloth.

sn.def: To move over the surface of (a body) with pressure and friction; to graze; to chafe; as, the boat rubs the ground.
To cause (a body) to move with pressure and friction along a surface; as, to rub the hand over the body.
sn.q: Two bones rubbed hard against one another.

sn.def: To spread a substance thinly over; to smear.
sn.q: The smoothed plank, . . . New rubbed with balm.

sn.def: To scour; to burnish; to polish; to brighten; to cleanse; -- often with up or over; as, to rub up silver.
sn.q: The whole business of our redemption is to rub over the defaced copy of the creation.

sn.def: To hinder; to cross; to thwart.
sn.q: 'T is the duke's pleasure, Whose disposition, all the world well knows, Will not be rubbed nor stopped.

cs.cd: to go on with difficulty; as, they manage, with strict economy, to rub along .

sn.def: To move along the surface of a body with pressure; to grate; as, a wheel rubs against the gatepost.
To fret; to chafe; as, to rub upon a sore.
To move or pass with difficulty; as, to rub through woods, as huntsmen; to rub through the world.

cs.cd: an iron guard on a wagon body, against which a wheel rubs when cramped too much.
anything happening to a ball in motion, such as its being deflected or stopped by any agency outside the match, or by the fore caddie.

entry.ety: Cf. W. rhwb. See Rub, v,t,

sn.def: The act of rubbing; friction.
That which rubs; that which tends to hinder or obstruct motion or progress; hindrance; obstruction, an impediment; especially, a difficulty or obstruction hard to overcome; a pinch.
sn.q: Every rub is smoothed on our way.
To sleep, perchance to dream; ay, there's the rub.
Upon this rub, the English ambassadors thought fit to demur.
One knows not, certainly, what other rubs might have been ordained for us by a wise Providence.

sn.def: Inequality of surface, as of the ground in the game of bowls; unevenness.
Something grating to the feelings; sarcasm; joke; as, a hard rub .
Imperfection; failing; fault.
A chance.
sn.q: Flight shall leave no Greek a rub.

sn.def: A stone, commonly flat, used to sharpen cutting tools; a whetstone; -- called also rubstone.

entry.def: The sound of a drum when continuously beaten; hence, a clamorous, repeated sound; a clatter.
entry.q: The rubadub of the abolition presses.

entries.entry: ‖Ru*bai*yat" n. pl.; sing.Rubai . Ar. rubā'iyāh quatrian, pl. of rubā'iy having four radicals, fr. rubā' four Quatrians; as, the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam . Sometimes in pl. construed as sing., a poem in such stanzas.

entry.cs: ‖Temple rubato. It Mus Borrowed time; -- a term applied to a style of performance in which some tones are held longer than their legitimate time, while others are proportionally curtailed.
entry.ety: It
entry.def: Robbed; borrowed.
Rubbish.

cs.cd: an elastic durable variety of vulcanized caoutchouc of a red color. It contains antimony sulphide as an important constituent.
a kind of vulcanized caoutchouc which nearly resembles horn in texture, rigidity, etc.
caoutchouc. See Caoutchouc.
cloth covered with caoutchouc for excluding water or moisture.
a shield of thin sheet rubber clasped around a tooth to exclude saliva from the tooth.

entry.sn:
One who, or that which, rubs. Specifically: An instrument or thing used in rubbing, polishing, or cleaning.
A coarse file, or the rough part of a file.
A whetstone; a rubstone.
An eraser, usually made of caoutchouc or a synthetic rubber[4].
The cushion of an electrical machine.
One who performs massage, especially in a Turkish bath.
Something that chafes or annoys; hence, something that grates on the feelings; a sarcasm; a rub.

sn.def: In some games, as bridge or whist, the odd game, as the third or the fifth, which decides the winner when there is a tie between the players; as, to play the rubber ; also, a contest determined by the winning of two out of three games; as, to play a rubber of whist.
sn.q: Arubberof cribbage.

sn.def: India rubber; caoutchouc; gum elastic; -- also called natural rubber.
Any substance, whether natural or synthetic, resembling India rubber with respect to its elasticity[1].
A low-cut overshoe made of natural or synthetic rubber[4], serving to keep the feet and shoes dry when walking in the rain or on a wet surface; -- usually used in the plural.
A condom.

entry.def: A closed loop of rubber usually having a thin rectangular cross-section; also called elastic band; -- it varies in length from the circumference of a finger to several inches, and is usually used to hold several objects together temporarily, by the tension exerted when the band is stretched and fitted around the objects to be held; as, to hold a pack of cards together with a rubber band .
To coat or impregnate with rubber or a rubber solution or preparation, as silk.
Rubbish.
a. & n. from Rub v.

entry.cs: Rubbish pulley. See Gin block, under Gin.
entry.ety: OE. robows robeux, rubble, originally an Old French plural from an assumed dim. of robe, probably in the sense of trash; cf. It. robaccia trash, roba stuff, goods, wares, robe. Thus, etymologically rubbish is the pl. of rubble. See Robe, and cf. Rubble
entry.def: Waste or rejected matter; anything worthless; valueless stuff; trash; especially, fragments of building materials or fallen buildings; ruins; débris.
entry.q: What rubbish and what offal!
he saw the town's one half in rubbish lie.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to rubbish; of the quality of rubbish; trashy.

cs.cd: rubble masonry in which courses are formed by leveling off the work at certain heights.

entry.ety: From an assumed Old French dim. of robe See Rubbish

sn.def: Water-worn or rough broken stones; broken bricks, etc., used in coarse masonry, or to fill up between the facing courses of walls.
sn.q: Inside [the wall] there was rubble or mortar.

sn.def: Rough stone as it comes from the quarry; also, a quarryman's term for the upper fragmentary and decomposed portion of a mass of stone; brash.
A mass or stratum of fragments or rock lying under the alluvium, and derived from the neighboring rock.
The whole of the bran of wheat before it is sorted into pollard, bran, etc.

entry.def: See Rubble, 1 and 2.
Masonry constructed of unsquared stones that are irregular in size and shape.
Relating to, or containing, rubble.

entry.ety: L. rubedo redness, fr. rubere to be red
entry.def: Reddish.

entry.ety: L. rubefaciens, p. pr. of rubefacere to make red; rubere to be red + facere to make
entry.def: Making red.

def2.def: An external application which produces redness of the skin.

entry.def: The act or process of making red.
A little ruby.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. rubellus reddish
entry.def: An acute but mild viral infection characterized by a dusky red cutaneous eruption resembling that of measles, but attended by only mild respiratory problems or fever; -- called also German measles. The infective virus is called Rubella virus, or Rubivirus. If contracted by a woman during the first several months of pregnancy, rubella may cause serious abnormalities in the fetus.
The virus that causes rubella.

entry.ety: L. rubellus reddish
entry.def: A red color used in enameling.

entry.ety: L. rubellus reddish, dim. of ruber red
entry.def: A variety of tourmaline varying in color from a pale rose to a deep ruby, and containing lithium.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. ruber red
entry.def: the measles.
Rubella.

entry.ety: L. ruber red + erythrin
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid extracted from madder root. It is a yellow crystalline substance from which alizarin is obtained.
The quality or state of being rubescent; a reddening; a flush.

entry.ety: L. rubescens -entis, p. pr. of rubescere to grow red, v. incho from rubere to be red: cf. F. rubescent. See Ruby
entry.def: Growing or becoming red; tending to redness.

entry.ety: L. rubia madder, fr. rubeus red
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a very large natural order of plants (Rubiaceæ) named after the madder (Rubia tinctoria), and including about three hundred and seventy genera and over four thousand species. Among them are the coffee tree, the trees yielding peruvian bark and quinine, the madder, the quaker ladies, and the trees bearing the edible fruits called genipap and Sierre Leone peach, besides many plants noted for the beauty or the fragrance of their blossoms.

entry.ety: L. rubia madder, fr. rubeus red
entry.def: A substance found in madder root, and probably identical with ruberythrinic acid.

entry.ety: L. rubia madder, fr. rubeus red
entry.def: One of several color-producing glycosides found in madder root.
pertaining to, or derived from, rubian; specifically, designating an acid called also ruberythrinic acid.
A ribble.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: Colored a prevailing red, bay, or black, with flecks of white or gray especially on the flanks; -- said of horses.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rubacelle rubicelle, fr. L. rubeus red, reddish
entry.def: A variety of ruby of a yellowish red color, from Brazil.

entry.note: ☞ By leading an army across this river, contrary to the prohibition of the civil government at Rome, Cæsar precipitated the civil war which resulted in the death of Pompey and the overthrow of the senate; hence, the phrase to pass or cross the Rubicon signifies to take the decisive step by which one is committed to a hazardous enterprise from which there is no retreat.
entry.def: A small river which separated Italy from Cisalpine Gaul, the province alloted to Julius Cæsar.

entry.ety: L. rubicundus, fr. rubere to be red, akin to ruber red. See Red
entry.def: Inclining to redness; ruddy; red.
entry.q: Hisrubicundface.

entry.ety: LL. rubicunditas
entry.def: The quality or state of being rubicund; ruddiness.
entry.q: To parade your rubicundity and gray hairs.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to rubidium; containing rubidium.
A nitrogenous base homologous with pyridine, obtained from coal tar as an oily liquid, C11H17N; also, any one of the group od metameric compounds of which rubidine is the type.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. rubidus red, fr. rubere to be red. So called from two dark red spectroscopic lines by means of which it was discovered in the lepidolite from Rozena, Moravia. See Rubicund
entry.def: A rare metallic element of the alkali metal series, atomic number 37. It occurs quite widely, but in small quantities, and always combined. It is isolated as a soft yellowish white metal, analogous to potassium in most of its properties. Symbol Rb. Atomic weight, 85.48.

entry.ety: L. ruber red + facere to make
entry.def: Making red; as, rubific rays.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rubification
entry.def: The act of making red.

entry.ety: L. ruber red + -form
entry.def: Having the nature or quality of red; as, the rubiform rays of the sun.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rubéfier. See Rubific
entry.def: To redden.
entry.q: Watersrubifying.

entry.ety: L. rubiginosus, fr. rubigo robigo, rust: cf. F. rubigineux
entry.def: Having the appearance or color of iron rust; rusty-looking.

entry.ety: L. rubigo robigo, rust of metals, rust, blight
entry.def: same as Rust n., 2.

entry.ety: Cf. LL. rubinus, It. rubino. See Ruby
entry.def: A ruby.

entry.ety: L. rubeus, fr. rubere to be red. See Rouge
entry.def: Red; ruddy.

entry.ety: Rubian + Gr. � resin
entry.def: One of the red dye products extracted from madder root, and probably identical with ruberythrinic acid.

entry.ety: Russ. ruble
entry.def:
The unit of monetary value in Russia.
It is divided into 100 copecks, and in the gold coin of the realm (as in the five and ten ruble pieces) is worth about 77 cents. The silver ruble is a coin worth about 60 cents.

entries.entry:
Ru"bric n. OE. rubriche, OF. rubriche, F. rubriquecf. it. rubrica), fr. L. rubrica red earth for coloring, red chalk, the title of a law (because written in red), fr. ruber red. See red
That part of any work in the early manuscripts and typography which was colored red, to distinguish it from other portions. Hence, specifically: A titlepage, or part of it, especially that giving the date and place of printing; also, the initial letters, etc., when printed in red. Law books The title of a statute; -- so called as being anciently written in red letters. Bell. Liturgies The directions and rules for the conduct of service, formerly written or printed in red; hence, also, an ecclesiastical or episcopal injunction; -- usually in the plural. All the clergy in England solemnly pledge themselves to observe the rubrics. Hence, that which is established or settled, as by authority; a thing definitely settled or fixed. Nay, as a duty, it had no place or rubric in human conceptions before Christianity.

entry.def: To adorn ith red; to redden; to rubricate.

sn.def: Colored in, or marked with, red; placed in rubrics.
sn.q: What though my name stood rubric on the walls Or plaistered posts, with claps, in capitals?

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the rubric or rubrics.
sn.q: Rubricaleccentricities.

entry.ety: L. rubricatus p. p. of rubricare to color red. See Rubric n.
entry.def: Marked with red.
To mark or distinguished with red; to arrange as in a rubric; to establish in a settled and unchangeable form.
entry.q: A system . . . according to which the thoughts of men were to be classed and rubricated forever after.

entry.def: One skilled in, or tenaciously adhering to, the rubric or rubrics.
Redness.
A stone for scouring or rubbing; a whetstone; a rub.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: A genus of rosaceous plants, including the raspberry and blackberry.

entries.entry:
Ru"by ☞ Besides the true or Oriental ruby above defined, there are the balas ruby, or ruby spinel, a red variety of spinel, and the rock ruby, a red variety of garnet.
Ruby of arsenic Ruby of sulphur
Chem a glassy substance of a red color and a variable composition, but always consisting chiefly of the disulphide of arsenic; -- called also ruby sulphur. Ruby of zinc Min zinc sulphide; the mineral zinc blende or sphalerite. Ruby silver Min red silver. See under Red.
n.; pl.Rubies #. F. rubiscf. Pr. robi), LL. rubinus robinus, fr. L. rubeus red, reddish, akin to ruber. See Rouge red
Min A precious stone of a carmine red color, sometimes verging to violet, or intermediate between carmine and hyacinth red. It is a red crystallized variety of corundum.
Of rubies, sapphires, and pearles white.
The color of a ruby; carmine red; a red tint. The natural ruby of your cheeks.
That which has the color of the ruby, as red wine. Hence, a red blain or carbuncle.
Print See Agate n., 2. Eng
Zoöl Any species of South American humming birds of the genus Clytolæma. The males have a ruby-colored throat or breast.

entry.def: Ruby-colored; red; as, ruby lips.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rubied; p. pr. & vb. n. Rubying
entry.def: To make red; to redden.

A European gold wasp (Chrysis ignita) which has the under side of the abdomen bright red, and the other parts deep bluish green with a metallic luster. The larva is parasitic in the nests of other wasps and of bees.
Having the tail, or lower part of the body, bright red.

Any one of numerous species of humming birds belonging to Trochilus Calypte Stellula, and allies, in which the male has on the throat a brilliant patch of red feathers having metallic reflections; esp., the common humming bird of the Eastern United States (Trochilus colubris).
red sandalwood. See under Sandalwood.

entry.ety: NL. Rucervus, the genus, fr. NL. Rusa a certain genus of deer (Malay r�sa deer) + Cervus
entry.def: Of, like, or pertaining to, a deer of the genus Rucervus, which includes the swamp deer of India.

entry.ety: F. ruche ruche, beehive, OF. rusche a beehive, which was formerly made of the bark of trees; cf. W. rhisg rhisgl, bark, gael. rusg bark, rind

sn.def: A plaited, quilled, or goffered strip of lace, net, ribbon, or other material, -- used in place of collars or cuffs, and as a trimming for women's dresses and bonnets.
A pile of arched tiles, used to catch and retain oyster spawn.

entry.def: A ruche, or ruches collectively.
A roc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rucked; p. pr. & vb. n. Rucking
entry.ety: Icel hrukkast to wrinkle, hrukka wrinkle, fold
entry.def: To draw into wrinkles or unsightly folds; to crease; as, to ruck up a carpet.

entry.ety: Icel. hrukka. Cf. Ruck v. t.
entry.def: A wrinkle or crease in a piece of cloth, or in needlework.

entry.ety: Cf. Dan. ruge to brood, to hatch
entry.def: To cower; to huddle together; to squat; to sit, as a hen on eggs.
entry.q: The sheep that rouketh in the fold.

entry.ety: Cf. Ruck

sn.def: A heap; a rick.
The common sort, whether persons or things; as, the ruck in a horse race.
sn.q: The ruck in society as a whole.

entry.ety: L. ructatio, fr. ructare to belch: cf. F. ructation
entry.def: The act of belching wind.
An uproar; a quarrel; a noisy outbreak.

entry.ety: AS. rudu, akin to reád red. √113. See Red, and cf. Ruddy

sn.def: Redness; blush.
Ruddle; red ocher.
The rudd.

entry.def: To make red.

entry.ety: NL. So named after Olaf Rudebeck, a Swedish botanist
entry.def: A genus of composite plants, the coneflowers, consisting of perennial herbs with showy pedunculate heads, having a hemispherical involucre, sterile ray flowers, and a conical chaffy receptacle. There are about thirty species, exclusively North American. Rudbeckia hirta, the black-eyed Susan, is a common weed in meadows.

entry.ety: See Rud n.
entry.def: A fresh-water European fish of the Carp family (Leuciscus erythrophthalmus). It is about the size and shape of the roach, but it has the dorsal fin farther back, a stouter body, and red irises. Called also redeye roud finscale, and shallow. A blue variety is called azurine, or blue roach.
A riddle or sieve.

entry.cs: Balance rudder Naut a rudder pivoted near the middle instead of at the edge, -- common on sharpies. Drop rudder Naut a rudder extending below the keel so as to be more effective in steering. Rudder chain Naut one of the loose chains or ropes which fasten the rudder to the quarters to prevent its loss in case it gets unshipped, and for operating it in case the tiller or the wheel is broken. Rudder coat Naut a covering of tarred canvas used to prevent water from entering the rudderhole. Rudder fish. Zoöl The pilot fish. The amber fish (Seriola zonata), which is bluish having six broad black bands. A plain greenish black American fish (Leirus perciformis); -- called also black rudder fish logfish, and barrel fish. The name is also applied to other fishes which follow vessels. Rudder pendants Naut ropes connected with the rudder chains.
entry.ety: OE. rother, AS. rōðer a paddle; akin to D. roer rudder, oar, G. ruder, OHG. roadar, Sw. roder ror, Dan. roer ror. √ 8. See Row to propel with an oar, and cf. Rother.

sn.def: The mechanical appliance by means of which a vessel is guided or steered when in motion. It is a broad and flat blade made of wood or iron, with a long shank, and is fastened in an upright position, usually by one edge, to the sternpost of the vessel in such a way that it can be turned from side to side in the water by means of a tiller, wheel, or other attachment.
Fig.: That which resembles a rudder as a guide or governor; that which guides or governs the course.
sn.q: For rhyme the rudder is of verses.

sn.def: In an aircraft, a surface the function of which is to exert a turning moment about an axis of the craft.

entry.def: The upper end of the rudderpost, to which the tiller is attached.
The hole in the deck through which the rudderpost passes.
Without a rudder.
The shank of a rudder, having the blade at one end and the attachments for operating it at the other.
The main part or blade of the rudder, which is connected by hinges, or the like, with the sternpost of a vessel.
Made ruddy or red.
In a ruddy manner.
The quality or state of being ruddy; as, the ruddiness of the cheeks or the sky.
To raddle or twist.
A riddle or sieve.

entry.ety: See Rud; cf. Reddle
entry.def: A species of red earth colored by iron sesquioxide; red ocher.
To mark with ruddle; to raddle; to rouge.
entry.q: Theirruddledcheeks.
A fair sheep newly ruddled.

entry.ety: AS. ruddic; cf. W. rhuddog the redbreast. √113. See Rud n.

sn.def: The European robin.
sn.q: The tameruddockand the coward kite.

sn.def: A piece of gold money; -- probably because the gold of coins was often reddened by copper alloy. Called also red ruddock, and golden ruddock.
sn.q: Great pieces of gold . . . red ruddocks.

cs.cd: an American duck (Erismatura rubida) having a broad bill and a wedge-shaped tail composed of stiff, sharp feathers. The adult male is rich brownish red on the back, sides, and neck, black on the top of the head, nape, wings, and tail, and white on the cheeks. The female and young male are dull brown mixed with blackish on the back; grayish below. Called also dunbird dundiver ruddy diver stifftail spinetail hardhead sleepy duck fool duck spoonbill, etc.
the sanderling.

entry.ety: AS. rudig. See Rud n.

sn.def: Of a red color; red, or reddish; as, a ruddy sky; a ruddy flame.
sn.q: They were more ruddy in body than rubies.

sn.def: Of a lively flesh color, or the color of the human skin in high health; as, ruddy cheeks or lips.

entry.def: To make ruddy.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. rudis

sn.def: Characterized by roughness; umpolished; raw; lacking delicacy or refinement; coarse.
sn.q: Such gardening tools as art, yet rude, . . . had formed.

entry.sn:
Hence, specifically: Unformed by taste or skill; not nicely finished; not smoothed or polished; -- said especially of material things; as, rude workmanship.
Rudewas the cloth.
Rude and unpolished stones. The heaven-born child All meanly wrapt in the rude manger lies.
Of untaught manners; unpolished; of low rank; uncivil; clownish; ignorant; raw; unskillful; -- said of persons, or of conduct, skill, and the like. Mine ancestors wererude.
Chaucer. He was but rude in the profession of arms. the rude forefathers of the hamlet sleep.
Violent; tumultuous; boisterous; inclement; harsh; severe; -- said of the weather, of storms, and the like; as, the rude winter. Clouds] pushed with winds, rude in their shock. The rude agitation [of water] breaks it into foam.
Barbarous; fierce; bloody; impetuous; -- said of war, conflict, and the like; as, the rude shock of armies.
Not finished or complete; inelegant; lacking chasteness or elegance; not in good taste; unsatisfactory in mode of treatment; -- said of literature, language, style, and the like. TherudeIrish books.
Rude am I in my speech. Unblemished by my rude translation. Impertinent; rough; uneven; shapeless; unfashioned; rugged; artless; unpolished; uncouth; inelegant; rustic; coarse; vulgar; clownish; raw; unskillful; untaught; illiterate; ignorant; uncivil; impolite; saucy; impudent; insolent; surly; currish; churlish; brutal; uncivilized; barbarous; savage; violent; fierce; tumultuous; turbulent; impetuous; boisterous; harsh; inclement; severe. See Impertiment.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. rudens a rope
entry.def: Cabling. See Cabling.

entry.ety: L. ruderarius, fr. rudus ruderis, stones crushed and mixed with lime, old rubbish
entry.def: Of or pertaining to rubbish..

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: An uncivil, turbulent fellow.
A German wine made near Rüdesheim, on the Rhine.

entry.ety: L. rudimentum, fr. rudis unwrought, ignorant, rude: cf. F. rudiment. See Rude

sn.def: That which is unformed or undeveloped; the principle which lies at the bottom of any development; an unfinished beginning.
sn.q: but I will bring thee where thou soon shalt quit Those rudiments, and see before thine eyes The monarchies of the earth.
the single leaf is the rudiment of beauty in landscape.

sn.def: Hence, an element or first principle of any art or science; a beginning of any knowledge; a first step.
sn.q: This boy is forest-born, And hath been tutored in the rudiments of many desperate studies.
There he shall first lay down the rudiments Of his great warfare.

sn.def: An imperfect organ or part, or one which is never developed.

entry.def: To furnish with first principles or rules; to insrtuct in the rudiments.
Rudimentary.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rudimentaire

sn.def: Of or pertaining to rudiments; consisting in first principles; elementary; initial; as, rudimental essays.
Very imperfectly developed; in an early stage of development; embryonic.

entry.def: Somewhat rude.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. rudis rough
entry.def: An extinct order or suborder of bivalve mollusks characteristic of the Cretaceous period; -- called also Rudista. See Illust. under Hippurite.

entry.ety: L. ruditas ignorance, fr. rudis rude, illiterate
entry.def: Rudeness; ignorance.

entry.ety: See Rood Mass Day
entry.def: Either of the feasts of the Holy Cross, occuring on May 3 and September 14, annually.
Pertaining to, or designating, a set of astronomical tables computed by Kepler, and founded on the observations of Tycho Brahe; -- so named from Rudolph II., emperor of Germany.

entry.cs: Goat's rue. See under Goat. Rue anemone a pretty springtime flower (Thalictrum anemonides) common in the United States. Wall rue a little fern (Asplenium Ruta-muraria) common on walls in Europe.
entry.ety: F. rue, L. ruta, akin to Gr. �; cf. AS. r�de

sn.def: A perennial suffrutescent plant (Ruta graveolens), having a strong, heavy odor and a bitter taste; herb of grace. It is used in medicine.
sn.q: Then purged with euphrasy and rue The visual nerve, for he had much to see.
They [the exorcists] are to try the devil by holy water, incense, sulphur, rue, which from thence, as we suppose, came to be called herb of grace.

sn.def: Fig.: Bitterness; disappointment; grief; regret.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rued; p. pr. & vb. n. Ruing
entry.ety: OE. rewen reouwen, to grive, make sorry, AS. hreówan; akin to OS. hrewan, D. rouwen, OHG. hriuwan, G. reun, Icel. hruggr grieved, hrugð sorrow. √ 18. Cf. Ruth

sn.def: To lament; to regret extremely; to grieve for or over.
sn.q: I wept to see, and rued it from my heart.
Thy will Chose freely what it now so justly rues.

sn.def: To cause to grieve; to afflict.
sn.q: God wot, itruethme.

sn.def: To repent of, and withdraw from, as a bargain; to get released from.
To have compassion.
sn.q: God so wisly [i. e., truly] on my soul rue.
Which stirred men's hearts to rue upon them.

sn.def: To feel sorrow and regret; to repent.
sn.q: Work by counsel and thou shalt not rue.
Old year, we'll dearly rue for you.

entry.ety: AS. hreów. See Rue v. t.
entry.def: Sorrow; repetance.

sn.def: Causing one to rue or lament; woeful; mournful; sorrowful.
Expressing sorrow.
sn.q: Ruefulfaces.
Two rueful figures, with long black cloaks.

entries.entry: Ru"ell bone`. See rewel bone. Obs

entry.ety: F. ruelle a narrow street, a lan�, ruelle, fr. rue a street
entry.def: A private circle or assembly at a private house; a circle.

entry.ety: L. rufescens, p. pr. of rufescere to become reddish, fr. rufus red: cf. F. rufescent
entry.def: Reddish; tinged with red.

entry.ety: F. ronfle; cf. It. ronfa, Pg. rufa rifa
entry.def: A game similar to whist, and the predecessor of it.
The act of trumping, especially when one has no card of the suit led.
To trump.

entry.ety: Of uncertain origin: cf. Icel. rūfinn rough, uncombed, Pr. ruf rude, rough, Sp. rufo frizzed, crisp, curled, G. raufen to pluck, fight, rupfen to pluck, pull, E. rough. √18. Cf. Ruffle to wrinkle

sn.def: A muslin or linen collar plaited, crimped, or fluted, worn formerly by both sexes, now only by women and children.
sn.q: Here to-morrow with his best ruff on.

His gravity is much lessened since the late proclamation came out against ruffs; . . . they were come to that height of excess herein, that twenty shillings were used to be paid for starching of a ruff.

sn.def: Something formed with plaits or flutings, like the collar of this name.
sn.q: I reared this flower; . . . Soft on the paper ruff its leaves I spread.

sn.def: An exhibition of pride or haughtiness.
sn.q: How many princes . . . in the ruff of all their glory, have been taken down from the head of a conquering army to the wheel of the victor's chariot!

sn.def: Wanton or tumultuous procedure or conduct.
sn.q: To ruffle it out in a riotous ruff.

sn.def: A low, vibrating beat of a drum, not so loud as a roll; a ruffle.
A collar on a shaft ot other piece to prevent endwise motion. See Illust. of Collar.
A set of lengthened or otherwise modified feathers round, or on, the neck of a bird.

sd.def: A limicoline bird of Europe and Asia (Pavoncella pugnax, syn. Philomachus pugnax) allied to the sandpipers. The males during the breeding season have a large ruff of erectile feathers, variable in their colors, on the neck, and yellowish naked tubercles on the face. They are polygamous, and are noted for their pugnacity in the breeding season. The female is called reeve, or rheeve.
A variety of the domestic pigeon, having a ruff of its neck.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ruffed; p. pr. & vb. n. Ruffing

sn.def: To ruffle; to disorder.
To beat with the ruff or ruffle, as a drum.
To hit, as the prey, without fixing it.
To play a trump card at bridge; as, he ruffed his partner's ace.

entry.ety: OE. ruffe
entry.def: A small freshwater European perch (Acerina vulgaris); -- called also pope blacktail, and stone perch, or striped perch.

cs.cd: a North American grouse (Bonasa umbellus) common in the wooded districts of the Northern United States. The male has a ruff of brown or black feathers on each side of the neck, and is noted for the loud drumming sound he makes during the breeding season. Called also tippet grouse partridge birch partridge pheasant drummer, and white-flesher.
a species of lemur (lemur varius) having a conspicuous ruff on the sides of the head. Its color is varied with black and white. Called also ruffed maucaco.

entry.def: Furnished with a ruff.

entry.ety: F. rufien, OF. ruffien ruffian, pimp, libertine, rake; cf. Pr. & Sp. rufian, It. ruffiano; all perhaps of German or Dutch origin; cf. G. raufen to pluck, scuffle, fight, OD. roffen to pander. Cf. Ruffle to grow turbulent

sn.def: A pimp; a pander; also, a paramour.
sn.q: He [her husband] is no sooner abroad than she is instantly at home, reveling with her ruffians.

sn.def: A boisterous, cruel, brutal fellow; a desperate fellow ready for murderous or cruel deeds; a cutthroat.
sn.q: Wilt thou on thy deathbed play the ruffian?

sn.def: A tough, lawless or bullying person.

entry.def: Brutal; cruel; savagely boisterous; murderous; as, ruffian rage.
To play the ruffian; to rage; to raise tumult.
Ruffians, collectively; a body of ruffians.
entry.q: The vilestruffianage.

entry.def: Having the qualities or manners of a ruffian; ruffianly.
Ruffianly.
Like a ruffian; bold in crimes; characteristic of a ruffian; violent; brutal.
Ruffianly.

entry.ety: See Ruffian
entry.def: Disordered.
entry.q: His ruffin rainment all was stained with blood.

cs.cd: to exite the resentment of; to irritate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ruffled; p. pr. & vb. n. Ruffling
entry.ety: From Ruff a plaited collar, a drum beat, a tumult: cf. OD. ruyffelen to wrinkle

sn.def: To make into a ruff; to draw or contract into puckers, plaits, or folds; to wrinkle.
To furnish with ruffles; as, to ruffle a shirt.
To oughen or disturb the surface of; to make uneven by agitation or commotion.
sn.q: The fantastic revelries . . . that so often ruffled the placid bosom of the Nile.
She smoothed the ruffled seas.

sn.def: To erect in a ruff, as feathers.
sn.q: the swanruffles her pure cold plume.

sn.def: To beat with the ruff or ruffle, as a drum.
To discompose; to agitate; to disturb.
sn.q: These ruffle the tranquillity of the mind.
But, ever after, the small violence done Rankled in him and ruffled all his heart.

sn.def: To throw into disorder or confusion.
sn.q: Where best He might the ruffled foe infest.

sn.def: To throw together in a disorderly manner.
sn.q: I ruffled up falen leaves in heap.

entry.ety: Perhaps of different origin from ruffle to wrinkle; cf. OD. roffeln roffen, to pander, LG. raffein, Dan. ruffer a pimp. Cf. Rufflan

sn.def: To grow rough, boisterous, or turbulent.
sn.q: The night comes on, and the bleak winds Do sorely ruffle.

sn.def: To become disordered; to play loosely; to flutter.
sn.q: On his right shoulder his thick mane reclined,Ruffles at speed, and dances in the wind.

sn.def: To be rough; to jar; to be in contention; hence, to put on airs; to swagger.
sn.q: They would ruffle with jurors.
Gallants who ruffled in silk and embroidery.

cs.cd: the top turned down, and scalloped or plaited.

entry.ety: See Ruffle v. t. & i.

sn.def: That which is ruffled; specifically, a strip of lace, cambric, or other fine cloth, plaited or gathered on one edge or in the middle, and used as a trimming; a frill.
A state of being ruffled or disturbed; disturbance; agitation; commotion; as, to put the mind in a ruffle .
A low, vibrating beat of a drum, not so loud as a roll; -- called also ruff.
The connected series of large egg capsules, or oöthecæ, of any one of several species of American marine gastropods of the genus Fulgur. See Oötheca.

entry.def: Having no ruffle.
The act of ruffling.

sn.def: One who ruffles; a swaggerer; a bully; a ruffian.
sn.q: Assaults, if not murders, done at his own doors by that crew of rufflers.

sn.def: That which ruffles; specifically, a sewing machine attachment for making ruffles.

entry.ety: Rufiopin + gallic
entry.def: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid which is obtained from gallic acid as a brown or red crystalline substance, and is related to rufiopin and anthracene.

entry.ety: L. rufus reddish + opianic
entry.def: A yellowish red crystalline substance related to anthracene, and obtained from opianic acid.

entry.ety: L. rufus reddish + -ol
entry.def: A phenol derivative of anthracene obtained as a white crystalline substance, which on oxidation produces a red dyestuff related to anthraquinone.

entry.ety: L. rufus
entry.def: Reddish; of a yellowish red or brownish red color; tawny.
Eructation; belching.

entry.ety: Cf. Ruff a plaited collar
entry.def: A kind of hood for a hawk.

cs.cd: a gown made of rug, of or coarse, shaggy cloth.

entry.ety: Cf. Sw. rugg entanglend hair, ruggig rugged, shaggy, probably akin to E. rough. See Rough a.

sn.def: A kind of coarse, heavy frieze, formerly used for garments.
sn.q: They spin the choicest rug in Ireland. A friend of mine . . . repaired to Paris Garden clad in one of these Waterford rugs. The mastiffs, . . . deeming he had been a bear, would fain have baited him.

sn.def: A piece of thick, nappy fabric, commonly made of wool, -- used for various purposes, as for covering and ornamenting part of a bare floor, for hanging in a doorway as a potière, for protecting a portion of carpet, for a wrap to protect the legs from cold, etc.
A rough, woolly, or shaggy dog.

entry.def: To pull roughly or hastily; to plunder; to spoil; to tear.

entries.entry: ‖Ru"ga n.; pl.Rugæ #. L Nat. Hist A wrinkle; a fold; as, the rugæ of the stomach.

entry.ety: L. rugatus, p. p. of rugare to wrinkle, fr. ruga a wrinkle
entry.def: Having alternate ridges and depressions; wrinkled.

entry.ety: See Rug n.

sn.def: Full of asperities on the surface; broken into sharp or irregular points, or otherwise uneven; not smooth; rough; as, a rugged mountain; a rugged road.
sn.q: The rugged bark of some broad elm.

sn.def: Not neat or regular; uneven.
sn.q: His well-proportioned beard made rough and rugged.

sn.def: Rough with bristles or hair; shaggy.
sn.q: TheruggedRussian bear.

sn.def: Harsh; hard; crabbed; austere; -- said of temper, character, and the like, or of persons.
sn.q: Neither melt nor endear him, but leave him as hard, rugged, and unconcerned as ever.

sn.def: Stormy; turbulent; tempestuous; rude.
Rough to the ear; harsh; grating; -- said of sound, style, and the like.
sn.q: Through the harsh cadence of a rugged line.

sn.def: Sour; surly; frowning; wrinkled; -- said of looks, etc.
sn.q: Sleek o'er yourruggedlooks.

sn.def: Violent; rude; boisterrous; -- said of conduct, manners, etc.
Vigorous; robust; hardy; -- said of health, physique, etc.
sn.syn: Rough; uneven; wrinkled; cragged; coarse; rude; harsh; hard; crabbed; severe; austere; surly; sour; frowning; violent; boisterous; tumultuous; turbulent; stormy; tempestuous; inclement.

entry.def: A coarse kind of woolen cloth, used for wrapping, blanketing, etc.
Wearing a coarse gown or shaggy garment made of rug.
Rugged; rough.
entry.q: Withruggy, ashy hairs.

entry.def: Having shaggy hair; shock-headed.
entry.q: Those rough rug-headed kerns.

entry.def: A nappy cloth.

entry.ety: F
entry.def: An instrument for scraping the periosteum from bones; a raspatory.

entry.ety: F. ruginer to scrape
entry.def: To scrape or rasp, as a bone; to scale.

entry.ety: NL. See Rugose
entry.def: An extinct tribe of fossil corals, including numerous species, many of them of large size. They are characteristic of the Paleozoic formations. The radiating septs, when present, are usually in multiples of four. See Cyathophylloid.

entry.ety: L. rugosus, r. ruga a wrinkle
entry.def: Wrinkled; full of wrinkles;
having the veinlets sunken and the spaces between them elevated, as the leaves of the sage and horehound.

entry.ety: L. rugositas: cf. F. rugosité
entry.def: The quality or state of being rugose.

entry.ety: Cf. F. rugueux
entry.def: Wrinkled; rugose.
Somewhat rugose.

entries.entry: Ruhm"korff's coil`. So called from its inventor, Ruhmkorff, a german physicist Elec See Induction coil, under Induction.

entry.ety: OE. ruine, F. ruine, fr. L. ruina, fr. ruere, rutum, to fall with violence, to rush or tumble down

sn.def: The act of falling or tumbling down; fall.
sn.q: Hisruinstartled the other steeds.

sn.def: Such a change of anything as destroys it, or entirely defeats its object, or unfits it for use; destruction; overthrow; as, the ruin of a ship or an army; the ruin of a constitution or a government; the ruin of health or hopes.
sn.q: Ruinseize thee, ruthless king!

sn.def: That which is fallen down and become worthless from injury or decay; as, his mind is a ruin ; especially, in the plural, the remains of a destroyed, dilapidated, or desolate house, fortress, city, or the like.
sn.q: The Veian and the Gabian towers shall fall, And one promiscuous ruin cover all; Nor, after length of years, a stone betray The place where once the very ruins lay.
The labor of a day will not build up a virtuous habit on the ruins of an old and vicious character.

sn.def: The state of being dcayed, or of having become ruined or worthless; as, to be in ruins; to go to ruin .
That which promotes injury, decay, or destruction.
sn.q: The errors of young men are the ruin of business.
sn.syn: Destruction; downfall; perdition; fall; overthrow; subversion; defeat; bane; pest; mischief.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ruined;p. pr. & vb. n. Ruining
entry.ety: Cf. F. ruiner, LL. ruinare. See Ruin n.
entry.def: To bring to ruin; to cause to fall to pieces and decay; to make to perish; to bring to destruction; to bring to poverty or bankruptcy; to impair seriously; to damage essentially; to overthrow.
entry.q: this mortal house I'll ruin.
By thee raised, I ruin all my foes.
The eyes of other people are the eyes that ruin us.
By the fireside there are old men seated, Seeling ruined cities in the ashes.

entry.def: To fall to ruins; to go to ruin; to become decayed or dilapidated; to perish.
entry.q: Though he his house of polished marble build, Yet shall it ruin like the moth's frail cell.
If we are idle, and disturb the industrious in their business, we shall ruin the faster.

entry.def: Capable of being ruined.

entry.ety: LL. ruinatus, p. p. of ruinare to ruin. See Ruin

sn.def: To demolish; to subvert; to destroy; to reduce to poverty; to ruin.
sn.q: I will not ruinate my f�ther's house.
Ruinating thereby the health of their bodies.

sn.def: To cause to fall; to cast down.
sn.q: On the other side they saw that perilous rock Threatening itself on them to ruinate.

entry.def: To fall; to tumble.

entry.ety: L. ruinatus, p. p
entry.def: Involved in ruin; ruined.
entry.q: My brother Edward lives in pomp and state, I in a mansion here all ruinate.

entry.ety: LL. ruinatio
entry.def: The act of ruining, or the state of being ruined.
One who, or that which, ruins.

entry.ety: Ruin + -form: cf. F. ruiniforme
entry.def: Having the appearance of ruins, or of the ruins of houses; -- said of certain minerals.

entry.ety: L. ruinosus: cf. F. ruineux. See Ruin

sn.def: Causing, or tending to cause, ruin; destructive; baneful; pernicious; as, a ruinous project.
sn.q: After a night of storm so ruinous.

sn.def: Characterized by ruin; ruined; dilapidated; as, an edifice, bridge, or wall in a ruinous state.
Composed of, or consisting in, ruins.
sn.q: Behold, Damascus . . . shall be a ruinous heap.
sn.syn: Dilapidated; decayed; demolished; pernicious; destructive; baneful; wasteful; mischievous.

entry.ety: Srr Roc

sn.def: The roc.
A large bird, supposed by some to be the same as the extinct Epiornis of Madagascar.

entry.def: That may be ruled; subject to rule; accordant or conformable to rule.

cs.cd: as a general thing; in the main; usually; as, he behaves well, as a rule .
See under Board Caliber, etc.
a knuckle joint having shoulders that abut when the connected pieces come in line with each other, and thus permit folding in one direction only.

any of the various regulations imposed upon travelers by land or water for their mutual convenience or safety. In the United States it is a rule of the road that land travelers passing in opposite directions shall turn out each to his own right, and generally that overtaking persons or vehicles shall turn out to the left; in England the rule for vehicles (but not for pedestrians) is the opposite of this.
that rule which directs, when three terms are given, how to find a fourth, which shall have the same ratio to the third term as the second has to the first; proportion. See Proportion, 5 .
any rude process or operation, like that of using the thumb as a rule in measuring; hence, judgment and practical experience as distinguished from scientific knowledge.

entry.ety: OE. reule riule, OF. riule reule, F. régle, fr. L. regula a ruler, rule, model, fr. regere rectum, to lead straight, to direct. See Right a., and cf. Regular

sn.def: That which is prescribed or laid down as a guide for conduct or action; a governing direction for a specific purpose; an authoritative enactment; a regulation; a prescription; a precept; as, the rules of various societies; the rules governing a school; a rule of etiquette or propriety; the rules of cricket.
sn.q: We profess to have embraced a religion which contains the most exact rules for the government of our lives.

entry.sn:
Hence: Uniform or established course of things. 'T is against the rule of nature.
Systematic method or practice; as, my ule is to rise at six o'clock.
Ordibary course of procedure; usual way; comon state or condition of things; as, it is a rule to which there are many exeptions.
Conduct in general; behavior. Obs This uncivil rule; she shall know of it.

sn.def: The act of ruling; administration of law; government; empire; authority; control.
sn.q: Obey them that have the rule over you.
His stern rule the groaning land obeyed.

sn.def: An order regulating the practice of the courts, or an order made between parties to an action or a suit.
A determinate method prescribed for performing any operation and producing a certain result; as, a rule for extracting the cube root.

A general principle concerning the formation or use of words, or a concise statement thereof; thus, it is a rule in England, that s or es , added to a noun in the singular number, forms the plural of that noun; but “man” forms its plural “men”, and is an exception to the rule.

sd.def: A straight strip of wood, metal, or the like, which serves as a guide in drawing a straight line; a ruler.

A measuring instrument consisting of a graduated bar of wood, ivory, metal, or the like, which is usually marked so as to show inches and fractions of an inch, and jointed so that it may be folded compactly.
sd.q: A judicious artist will use his eye, but he will trust only to his rule.

sd.def: A thin plate of metal (usually brass) of the same height as the type, and used for printing lines, as between columns on the same page, or in tabular work.
A composing rule. See under Conposing.

entry.syn: regulation; law; precept; maxim; guide; canon; order; method; direction; control; government; sway; empire.

cs.cd: any surface that may be described by a straight line moving according to a given law; -- called also a scroll.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ruled; p. pr. & vb. n. Ruling
entry.ety: Cf. OF. riuler ruiler, L. regulare. See Rule n., and cf. Regulate

sn.def: To control the will and actions of; to exercise authority or dominion over; to govern; to manage.
sn.q: A bishop then must be blameless; . . . one that ruleth well his own house, having his children in subjection.

sn.def: To control or direct by influence, counsel, or persuasion; to guide; -- used chiefly in the passive.
sn.q: I think she will be ruled In all respects by me.

sn.def: To establish or settle by, or as by, a rule; to fix by universal or general consent, or by common practice.
sn.q: That's are ruled case with the schoolmen.

sn.def: To require or command by rule; to give as a direction or order of court.

To mark with lines made with a pen, pencil, etc., guided by a rule or ruler; to print or mark with lines by means of a rule or other contrivance effecting a similar result; as, to rule a sheet of paper of a blank book.
To have power or command; to exercise supreme authority; -- often followed by over.
sn.q: By me princes rule, and nobles.
We subdue and rule over all other creatures.

sn.def: To lay down and settle a rule or order of court; to decide an incidental point; to enter a rule.
To keep within a (certain) range for a time; to be in general, or as a rule; as, prices ruled lower yesterday than the day before.

entry.def: Destitute of rule; lawless.
A stickler for rules; a slave of rules

entry.cs: Parallel ruler. See under Parallel.

sn.def: One who rules; one who exercises sway or authority; a governor.
sn.q: And he made him ruler over all the land.
A prince and ruler of the land.

sn.def:
A straight or curved strip of wood, metal, etc., with a smooth edge, used for guiding a pen or pencil in drawing lines. Cf. Rule n., 7
.
Predominant; chief; reigning; controlling; as, a ruling passion; a ruling sovereign.
Used in marking or engraving lines; as, a ruling machine or pen.
sn.syn: Predominant; chief; controlling; directing; guiding; governing; prevailing; prevalent.

sn.def: The act of one who rules; ruled lines.
A decision or rule of a judge or a court, especially an oral decision, as in excluding evidence.

entry.def: In a ruling manner; so as to rule.

entry.ety: Cf. D. rolletje a little roll
entry.def: Chopped meat stuffed into small bags of tripe. They are cut in slices and fried.

entry.ety: From Rule
entry.def: Orderly; easily restrained; -- opposed to unruly.

cs.cd: a grog blossom.
a drink composed of rum, water, sugar, and lime juice or lemon juice, with some flavoring extract.

entry.ety: probably shortened from Prov. E. rumbullion a great tumult, formerly applied in the island of Barbadoes to an intoxicating liquor
entry.def: A kind of intoxicating liquor distilled from cane juice, or from the scummings of the boiled juice, or from treacle or molasses, or from the lees of former distillations. Also, sometimes used colloquially as a generic or a collective name for intoxicating liquor.

entry.ety: Formerly rome, a slang word for good; possibly of Gypsy origin; cf. Gypsy rom a husband, a gypsy
entry.def: Old-fashioned; queer; odd; as, a rum idea; a rum fellow.
A queer or odd person or thing; a country parson.

entry.ety: OE. romblen, akin to D. rommelen, G. rumpeln, Dan. rumle; cf. Icel. rymja to roar

sn.def: To make a low, heavy, continued sound; as, the thunder rumbles at a distance.
sn.q: In the mean while the skies 'gan rumble sore.
The people cried and rombled up and down.

sn.def: To murmur; to ripple.
sn.q: To rumble gently down with murmur soft.

sn.def: A noisy report; rumor.
sn.q: Delighting ever in rumble that is new.

sn.def: A low, heavy, continuous sound like that made by heavy wagons or the reverberation of thunder; a confused noise; as, the rumble of a railroad train.
sn.q: Clamor and rumble, and ringing and clatter.
Merged in the rumble of awakening day.

sn.def: A seat for servants, behind the body of a carriage.
sn.q: Kit, well wrapped, . . . was in the rumble behind.

sn.def: A rotating cask or box in which small articles are smoothed or polished by friction against each other.

entry.def: To cause to pass through a rumble, or shaking machine. See Rumble n., 4.
One who, or that which, rumbles.
a. & n. from Rumble v. i.
In a rumbling manner.
Grog.
Same as Rombowline.

entry.ety: L. rumen - inis, the throat

sn.def: The first stomach of ruminants; the paunch; the fardingbag. See Illust. below.
The cud of a ruminant.

entry.def: A yellow crystalline substance found in the root of yellow dock (Rumex crispus) and identical with chrysophanic acid.

entry.ety: L. ruminalis
entry.def: Ruminant; ruminating.

entry.ety: L. ruminans -antis, p. pr.: cf. F. ruminant. See Ruminate
entry.def: Chewing the cud; characterized by chewing again what has been swallowed; of or pertaining to the Ruminantia.
A ruminant animal; one of the Ruminantia.

entry.note: ☞ The vegetable food, after the first mastication, enters the first stomach (r). It afterwards passes into the second (n), where it is moistened, and formed into pellets which the animal has the power of bringing back to the mouth to be chewed again, after which it is swallowed into the third stomach (m), whence it passes to the fourth (s), where it is finally digested.
entry.ety: NL
entry.def: A division of Artiodactyla having four stomachs. This division includes the camels, deer, antelopes, goats, sheep, neat cattle, and allies.
In a ruminant manner; by ruminating, or chewing the cud.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ruminated; p. pr. & vb. n. Ruminating
entry.ety: L. ruminatus, p. p. of ruminari ruminare, fr. rumen -inis, throat, akin to ructare to belch, erugere to belch out, Gr. �, AS. roccettan

sn.def: To chew the cud; to chew again what has been slightly chewed and swallowed.
sn.q: Cattle free toruminate.

sn.def: To think again and again; to muse; to meditate; to ponder; to reflect.
sn.q: Apart from the hope of the gospel, who is there that ruminates on the felicity of heaven?

sn.def: To chew over again.
To meditate or ponder over; to muse on.
sn.q: Mad with desire, she ruminates her sin.
