What I know Is ruminated, plotted, and set down.

entry.def: Having a hard albumen penetrated by irregular channels filled with softer matter, as the nutmeg and the seeds of the North American papaw.

entry.ety: L. ruminatio: cf. F. rumination

sn.def: The act or process of ruminating, or chewing the cud; the habit of chewing the cud.
sn.q: Rumination is given to animals to enable them at once to lay up a great store of food, and afterward to chew it.

sn.def: The state of being disposed to ruminate or ponder; deliberate meditation or reflection.
sn.q: Retiring full of rumination sad.

sn.def: The regurgitation of food from the stomach after it has been swallowed, -- occasionally observed as a morbid phenomenon in man.

entry.def: Inclined to, or engaged in, rumination or meditation.

entry.ety: L
entry.def: One who ruminates or muses; a meditator.

entry.ety: Cf. Rummer, and see -kin
entry.def: A popular or jocular name for a drinking vessel.

cs.cd: a clearance sale of unclaimed goods in a public store, or of odds and ends which have accumulated in a shop.

entry.ety: For roomage, fr. room; hence originally, a making room, a packing away closely. See Room

sn.def: A place or room for the stowage of cargo in a ship; also, the act of stowing cargo; the pulling and moving about of packages incident to close stowage; -- formerly written romage.
A searching carefully by looking into every corner, and by turning things over.
sn.q: He has made such a general rummage and reform in the office of matrimony.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rummaged; p. pr. & vb. n. Rummaging

sn.def: To make room in, as a ship, for the cargo; to move about, as packages, ballast, so as to permit close stowage; to stow closely; to pack; -- formerly written roomage, and romage.
sn.q: They might bring away a great deal more than they do, if they would take pain in the romaging.

sn.def: To search or examine thoroughly by looking into every corner, and turning over or removing goods or other things; to examine, as a book, carefully, turning over leaf after leaf.
sn.q: He . . . searcheth his pockets, and taketh his keys, and so rummageth all his closets and trunks.
What schoolboy of us has not rummaged his Greek dictionary in vain for a satisfactory account!

entry.def: To search a place narrowly.
entry.q: I have often rummaged for old books in Little Britain and Duck Lane.
His house] was haunted with a jolly ghost, that . . . . . . rummaged like a rat.

sn.def: One who rummages.
A person on shipboard whose business was to take charge of stowing the cargo; -- formerly written roomager, and romager.
sn.q: The master must provide a perfect mariner, called a romager, to range and bestow all merchandise.

entry.ety: D. roemer romer, akin to G. römer, Sw. remmare; perhaps properly, Roman
entry.def: A large and tall glass, or drinking cup.
Of or pertaining to rum; characteristic of rum; as a rummy flavor.

entries.entry: Rum"my n.; pl.Rummies. One who drinks rum; an habitually intemperate person. Low

entry.ety: See Rum a.
entry.def: Strange; odd.
A sort of Spanish wine.

entry.ety: F. rumeur, L. rumor; cf. rumificare rumitare to rumor, Skr. ru to cry

sn.def: A flying or popular report; the common talk; hence, public fame; notoriety.
sn.q: This rumor of him went forth throughout all Judea, and throughout all the region round about.
Great is the rumor of this dreadful knight.

sn.def: A current story passing from one person to another, without any known authority for its truth; -- in this sense often personified.
sn.q: Rumor next, and Chance, And Tumult, and Confusion, all embroiled.

sn.def: A prolonged, indistinct noise.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rumored; p. pr. & vb. n. Rumoring
entry.def: To report by rumor; to tell.
entry.q: 'T was rumored My father 'scaped from out the citadel.

entry.def: A teller of news; especially, one who spreads false reports.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. rumoreux, It. rumoroso romoroso

sn.def: Of or pertaining to a rumor; of the nature of rumors.
Famous; notorious.
Murmuring.

cs.cd: the remnant of the Long Parliament after the expulsion by Cromwell in 1648 of those who opposed his purposes. It was dissolved by Cromwell in 1653, but twice revived for brief sessions, ending finally in 1659.
cs.q: The Rump abolished the House of Lords, the army abolished the Rump, and by this army of saints Cromwell governed.
cs.cd: a beefsteak from the rump.

entry.ety: OE. rumpe; akin to D. romp trunk, body, LG. rump, G. rumpf, Dan. rumpe rump, Icel. rumpr, Sw. rumpa rump, tail

sn.def: The end of the backbone of an animal, with the parts adjacent; the buttock or buttocks.
Among butchers, the piece of beef between the sirloin and the aitchbone piece. See Illust. of Beef.
The hind or tail end; a fag-end; a remnant.

entry.def: A member or a supporter of the Rump Parliament.
A Shakespearean word of uncertain meaning. Perhaps “fattened in the rump, pampered.”
entry.q: Therump-fedronyon.

entry.ety: Cf. rimple, and D. rimpelen to wrinkle, rompelig rough, uneven, G. rümpfen to wrinkle, MHG. rümphen, OHG. rimpfan, Gr. "ra`mfos the crooked beak of birds of prey, � to roam
entry.def: To make uneven; to form into irregular inequalities; to wrinkle; to crumple; as, to rumple an apron or a cravat.
entry.q: They would not give a dog's ear of their most rumpled and ragged Scotch paper for twenty of your fairest assignats.

entry.def: A fold or plait; a wrinkle.
Wrinkled; crumpled.
Destitute of a rump.
Rumpled.
A disturbance; noise and confusion; a quarrel.
One who sells rum; one who deals in intoxicating liquors; especially, one who sells spirituous beverages at retail.

entry.cs:
As things run according to the usual order, conditions, quality, etc.; on the average; without selection or specification. To let run Naut to allow to pass or move freely; to slacken or loosen. To run after to pursue or follow; to search for; to endeavor to find or obtain; as, to run after similes. Locke. To run away to flee; to escape; to elope; to run without control or guidance. To run away with. To convey away hurriedly; to accompany in escape or elopement. To drag rapidly and with violence; as, a horse runs away with a carriage. To run down. To cease to work or operate on account of the exhaustion of the motive power; -- said of clocks, watches, etc.
To decline in condition; as, to run down in health. To run down a coast to sail along it. To run for an office to stand as a candidate for an office.
To run inorTo run into . To enter; to step in. To come in collision with. To run into To meet, by chance; as, I ran into my brother at the grocery store. To run in trust to run in debt; to get credit. Obs To run in with. To close; to comply; to agree with. R T. Baker. Naut To make toward; to near; to sail close to; as, to run in with the land.
To run mad To run mad afterorTo run mad on . See under Mad. To run on. To be continued; as, their accounts had run on for a year or two without a settlement. To talk incessantly. To continue a course. To press with jokes or ridicule; to abuse with sarcasm; to bear hard on. Print To be continued in the same lines, without making a break or beginning a new paragraph.To run out. To come to an end; to expire; as, the lease runs out at Michaelmas. To extend; to spread. “Insectile animals . . . run all out into legs.” Hammond. To expatiate; as, to run out into beautiful digressions. To be wasted or exhausted; to become poor; to become extinct; as, an estate managed without economy will soon run out. And had her stock been less, no doubt She must have long ago run out. Dryden. To run over. To overflow; as, a cup runs over, or the liquor runs over . To go over, examine, or rehearse cursorily. To ride or drive over; as, to run over a child. To run riot to go to excess. To run through. To go through hastily; as to run through a book. To spend wastefully; as, to run through an estate. To run to seed to expend or exhaust vitality in producing seed, as a plant; figuratively and colloquially, to cease growing; to lose vital force, as the body or mind. To run up to rise; to swell; to grow; to increase; as, accounts of goods credited run up very fast. But these, having been untrimmed for many years, had run up into great bushes, or rather dwarf trees. Sir W. Scott. To run with. To be drenched with, so that streams flow; as, the streets ran with blood. To flow while charged with some foreign substance. “Its rivers ran with gold.” J. H. Newman.
entry.vmorph: imp. Ran or Run; p. p. Run; p. pr. & vb. n. Running
entry.ety: OE. rinnen rennenimp. ran, p. p. runnen ronnen). AS. rinnan to flow (imp. ran, p. p. gerunnen), and iernan irnan, to run (imp. orn arn earn, p. p. urnen); akin to D. runnen rennen, OS. & OHG. rinnan, G. rinnen rennen, Icel. renna rinna, Sw. rinna, ränna, Dan. rinde rende, Goth. rinnan, and perh. to L. oriri to rise, Gr. � to stir up, rouse, Skr. � (cf. Origin), or perh. to L. rivus brook (cf. Rival). √11. Cf. Ember a. Rennet
entry.sn: To move, proceed, advance, pass, go, come, etc., swiftly, smoothly, or with quick action; -- said of things animate or inanimate. Hence, to flow, glide, or roll onward, as a stream, a snake, a wagon, etc.; to move by quicker action than in walking, as a person, a horse, a dog. Specifically:

Of voluntary or personal action: To go swiftly; to pass at a swift pace; to hasten. “Ha, ha, the fox!” and after him they ran.
To flee, as from fear or danger. As from a bear a man would run for life.
To steal off; to depart secretly.
To contend in a race; hence, to enter into a contest; to become a candidate; as, to run for Congress. Know ye not that they which run in a race run all, but one receiveth the prize? So run, that ye may obtain.
To pass from one state or condition to another; to come into a certain condition; -- often with in or into; as, to run into evil practices; to run in debt. Have I not cause to rave and beat my breast, to rend my heart with grief and run distracted?
To exert continuous activity; to proceed; as, to run through life; to run in a circle.
To pass or go quickly in thought or conversation; as, to run from one subject to another. Virgil, in his first Georgic, has run into a set of precepts foreign to his subject.
To discuss; to continue to think or speak about something; -- with on.
To make numerous drafts or demands for payment, as upon a bank; -- with on.
To creep, as serpents.

Of involuntary motion: To flow, as a liquid; to ascend or descend; to course; as, rivers run to the sea; sap runs up in the spring; her blood ran cold.
To proceed along a surface; to extend; to spread. The fire ran along upon the ground.
To become fluid; to melt; to fuse. As wax dissolves, as ice begins to run. Sussex iron ores run freely in the fire.
To turn, as a wheel; to revolve on an axis or pivot; as, a wheel runs swiftly round.
To travel; to make progress; to be moved by mechanical means; to go; as, the steamboat runs regularly to Albany; the train runs to Chicago.
To extend; to reach; as, the road runs from Philadelphia to New York; the memory of man runneth not to the contrary. She saw with joy the line immortal run, Each sire impressed, and glaring in his son.
To go back and forth from place to place; to ply; as, the stage runs between the hotel and the station.
To make progress; to proceed; to pass. As fast as our time runs, we should be very glad in most part of our lives that it ran much faster.
To continue in operation; to be kept in action or motion; as, this engine runs night and day; the mill runs six days in the week. When we desire anything, our minds run wholly on the good circumstances of it; when it is obtained, our minds run wholly on the bad ones.
To have a course or direction; as, a line runs east and west. Where the generally allowed practice runs counter to it. Little is the wisdom, where the flight So runs against all reason.
To be in form thus, as a combination of words. The king's ordinary style runneth, “Our sovereign lord the king.”
To be popularly known; to be generally received. Men gave them their own names, by which they run a great while in Rome. Neither was he ignorant what report ran of himself.
To have growth or development; as, boys and girls run up rapidly. If the richness of the ground cause turnips to run to leaves.
To tend, as to an effect or consequence; to incline. A man's nature runs either to herbs or weeds. Temperate climates run into moderate governments.
To spread and blend together; to unite; as, colors run in washing. In the middle of a rainbow the colors are . . . distinguished, but near the borders they run into one another.
To have a legal course; to be attached; to continue in force, effect, or operation; to follow; to go in company; as, certain covenants run with the land. Customs run only upon our goods imported or exported, and that but once for all; whereas interest runs as well upon our ships as goods, and must be yearly paid.
To continue without falling due; to hold good; as, a note has thirty days to run .
To discharge pus or other matter; as, an ulcer runs .
To be played on the stage a number of successive days or nights; as, the piece ran for six months.
Naut To sail before the wind, in distinction from reaching or sailing closehauled; -- said of vessels.

sn.def: Specifically, of a horse: To move rapidly in a gait in which each leg acts in turn as a propeller and a supporter, and in which for an instant all the limbs are gathered in the air under the body.
To move rapidly by springing steps so that there is an instant in each step when neither foot touches the ground; -- so distinguished from walking in athletic competition.

entry.cs:
To run a blockade to get to, or away from, a blockaded port in safety. To run down. Hunting To chase till the object pursued is captured or exhausted; as, to run down a stag . Naut To run against and sink, as a vessel. To crush; to overthrow; to overbear. “Religion is run down by the license of these times.” Berkeley. To disparage; to traduce. F. W. Newman. To run hard. To press in competition; as, to run one hard in a race. To urge or press importunately. To banter severely. To run into the ground to carry to an absurd extreme; to overdo. Slang, U.S
To run off to cause to flow away, as a charge of molten metal from a furnace. To run on Print to carry on or continue, as the type for a new sentence, without making a break or commencing a new paragraph. To run out. To thrust or push out; to extend. To waste; to exhaust; as, to run out an estate. Baseball To put out while running between two bases. Also called to run out.
To run the chancesorTo run one's chances
to encounter all the risks of a certain course. To run through to transfix; to pierce, as with a sword. “[He] was run through the body by the man who had asked his advice.” Addison. To run up. To thrust up, as anything long and slender. To increase; to enlarge by additions, as an account.
To erect hastily, as a building.

sn.def: To cause to run (in the various senses of Run v. i.); as, to run a horse; to run a stage; to run a machine; to run a rope through a block.
To pursue in thought; to carry in contemplation.
sn.q: To run the world back to its first original.
I would gladly understand the formation of a soul, and run it up to its “punctum saliens.”

sn.def: To cause to enter; to thrust; as, to run a sword into or through the body; to run a nail into the foot.
sn.q: You run your head into the lion's mouth.
Having run his fingers through his hair.

sn.def: To drive or force; to cause, or permit, to be driven.
sn.q: They ran the ship aground.
A talkative person runs himself upon great inconveniences by blabbing out his own or other's secrets.
Others, accustomed to retired speculations, run natural philosophy into metaphysical notions.

sn.def: To fuse; to shape; to mold; to cast; as, to run bullets, and the like.
sn.q: The purest gold must be run and washed.

sn.def: To cause to be drawn; to mark out; to indicate; to determine; as, to run a line.
To cause to pass, or evade, offical restrictions; to smuggle; -- said of contraband or dutiable goods.
sn.q: Heavy impositions . . . are a strong temptation of running goods.

sn.def: To go through or accomplish by running; as, to run a race; to run a certain career.
To cause to stand as a candidate for office; to support for office; as, to run some one for Congress.

entry.sn: To encounter or incur, as a danger or risk; as, to run the risk of losing one's life. See To run the chances, below. Herunnethtwo dangers. If we don't succeed, we run the risk of failure. Dan Quail.

sn.def: To put at hazard; to venture; to risk.
sn.q: He would himself be in the Highlands to receive them, and run his fortune with them.

sn.def: To discharge; to emit; to give forth copiously; to be bathed with; as, the pipe or faucet runs hot water.
sn.q: At the base of Pompey's statua, Which all the while ran blood, great Cæsar fell.

sn.def: To be charged with, or to contain much of, while flowing; as, the rivers ran blood.
To conduct; to manage; to carry on; as, to run a factory or a hotel.
To tease with sarcasms and ridicule.
To sew, as a seam, by passing the needle through material in a continuous line, generally taking a series of stitches on the needle at the same time.
To migrate or move in schools; -- said of fish; esp., to ascend a river in order to spawn.
To strike (the ball) in such a way as to cause it to run along the ground, as when approaching a hole.

entry.cs:
At the long runnow, commonlyIn the long run
in or during the whole process or course of things taken together; in the final result; in the end; finally. Man] starts the inferior of the brute animals, but he surpasses them in the long run. J. H. Newman. Home run. A running or returning toward home, or to the point from which the start was made. Cf. Home stretch. Baseball See under Home.
The runorThe common runorThe run of the mill etc. ordinary persons; the generality or average of people or things; also, that which ordinarily occurs; ordinary current, course, or kind. I saw nothing else that is superior to the common run of parks. Walpole. Burns never dreamed of looking down on others as beneath him, merely because he was conscious of his own vast superiority to the common run of men. Prof. Wilson. His whole appearance was something out of the common run. W. Irving. To let go by the run Naut to loosen and let run freely, as lines; to let fall without restraint, as a sail.

sn.def: The act of running; as, a long run; a good run; a quick run; to go on the run .
A small stream; a brook; a creek.
That which runs or flows in the course of a certain operation, or during a certain time; as, a run of must in wine making; the first run of sap in a maple orchard.
A course; a series; that which continues in a certain course or series; as, a run of good or bad luck.
sn.q: They who made their arrangements in the first run of misadventure . . . put a seal on their calamities.

sn.def: State of being current; currency; popularity.
sn.q: It is impossible for detached papers to have a general run, or long continuance, if not diversified with humor.

sn.def: Continued repetition on the stage; -- said of a play; as, to have a run of a hundred successive nights.
sn.q: A canting, mawkish play . . . had an immense run.

sn.def: A continuing urgent demand; especially, a pressure on a bank or treasury for payment of its notes.
A range or extent of ground for feeding stock; as, a sheep run .

sd.def: The aftermost part of a vessel's hull where it narrows toward the stern, under the quarter.
The distance sailed by a ship; as, a good run; a run of fifty miles.
A voyage; as, a run to China.

sn.def: A pleasure excursion; a trip.
sn.q: I think of giving her a run in London.

sn.def: The horizontal distance to which a drift may be carried, either by license of the proprietor of a mine or by the nature of the formation; also, the direction which a vein of ore or other substance takes.
A roulade, or series of running tones.
The greatest degree of swiftness in marching. It is executed upon the same principles as the double-quick, but with greater speed.
The act of migrating, or ascending a river to spawn; -- said of fish; also, an assemblage or school of fishes which migrate, or ascend a river for the purpose of spawning.

In baseball, a complete circuit of the bases made by a player, which enables him to score one point; also, the point thus scored; in cricket, a passing from one wicket to the other, by which one point is scored; as, a player made three runs; the side went out with two hundred runs; the Yankees scored three runs in the seventh inning.
sn.q: The “runs” are made from wicket to wicket, the batsmen interchanging ends at each run.

sn.def: A pair or set of millstones.
A number of cards of the same suit in sequence; as, a run of four in hearts.

sd.def: The movement communicated to a golf ball by running.
The distance a ball travels after touching the ground from a stroke.

cs.cd: malleable iron castings. See under Malleable.

sn.def: Melted, or made from molten material; cast in a mold; as, run butter; run iron or lead.
Smuggled; as, run goods.

entry.ety: F. renégat, Prov. renegat. LL. renegatus; confused with E. run and gate a way. See Renegade
entry.def: A fugitive; a vagabond; an apostate; a renegade. See Renegade.
entry.q: Wretched runagates from the jail.
Who has not been a runagate from duty?

entry.def: A whitlow running around the finger nail, but not affecting the bone.
a delaying or evasive, and sometimes deceptive, answer to an inquiry or request.

sn.def: One who, or that which, flees from danger, duty, restraint, etc.; a fugitive.
sn.q: Thou runaway, thou coward, art thou fled?

sn.def: The act of running away, esp. of a horse or teams; as, there was a runaway yesterday.
Running away; fleeing from danger, duty, restraint, etc.; as, runaway soldiers; a runaway horse.
Accomplished by running away or elopement, or during flight; as, a runaway marriage.

entry.ety: L. runcatio, fr. runcare to weed out
entry.def: A weeding.
The wild radish.

entry.ety: L. runcinatus, p. p. of runcinare to plane off, fr. runcina a plane
entry.def: Pinnately cut with the lobes pointing downwards, as the leaf of the dandelion.

entry.ety: Cf. Rindle
entry.def: A moat with water in it; also, a small stream; a runlet.

entry.ety: Cf. Rundle
entry.def: A circle.

entry.ety: E. round. Cf. Rondle

sn.def: A round; a step of a ladder; a rung.
A ball.
Something which rotates about an axis, as a wheel, or the drum of a capstan.
sn.q: An axis or cylinder having arundleabout it.

sn.def: One of the pins or trundles of a lantern wheel.

entry.ety: Dim. of OF. rondele a little tun, fr. rond round. See Round, and cf. Roundlet Runlet
entry.def: A small barrel of no certain dimensions. It may contain from 3 to 20 gallons, but it usually holds about 141/2 gallons.

entry.note: ☞ The Norsemen had a peculiar alphabet, consisting of sixteen letters, or characters, called runes, the origin of which is lost in the remotest antiquity. The signification of the word runemystery) seems to allude to the fact that originally only a few were acquainted with the use of these marks, and that they were mostly applied to secret tricks, witchcrafts and enchantments. But the runes were also used in communication by writing.

cs.cd: a stone bearing a runic inscription.

entry.ety: AS. rūn a rune, a secret, a mystery; akin to Icel. rūn, OHG. & Goth. rūna a secret, secret colloquy, G. & Dan. rune rune, and probably to Gr. 'ereyna^n to search for. Cf. Roun to whisper

sn.def: A letter, or character, belonging to the written language of the ancient Norsemen, or Scandinavians; in a wider sense, applied to the letters of the ancient nations of Northern Europe in general.
Old Norse poetry expressed in runes.
sn.q: Runes were upon his tongue, As on the warrior's sword.

entry.def: A bard, or learned man, among the ancient Goths.
imp. & p. p. of Ring.

entry.ety: OE. ronge, AS. hrung, a staff, rod, pole; akin to G. runge a short, thick piece of iron or wood, OD. ronghe a prop, support, Icel. röng a rib in a ship, Goth. Hrugga a staff

sn.def: A floor timber in a ship.
One of the rounds of a ladder.
One of the stakes of a cart; a spar; a heavy staff.
One of the radial handles projecting from the rim of a steering wheel; also, one of the pins or trundles of a lantern wheel.

entry.def: The upper end of a floor timber in a ship.

entry.cs: Runic staff. See Clog almanac, under Clog. Runic wand a willow wand bearing runes, formerly thought to have been used by the heathen tribes of Northern Europe in magical ceremonies.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a rune, to runes, or to the Norsemen; as, runic verses; runic letters; runic names; runic rhyme.
An argument or quarrel.

entry.ety: Run + -let
entry.def: A little run or stream; a streamlet; a brook.
entry.q: To trace out to its marshy source every runlet that has cast in its tiny pitcherful with the rest.

entry.def: Same as Rundlet.
entry.q: A stoup of sack, or arunletof canary.

entry.ety: From Run. Cf. Rindle
entry.def: A rivulet or small brook.
entry.q: Bubbling runnels joined the sound.
By the very sides of the way . . . there are slow runnels, in which one can see the minnows swimming.

entry.ety: From Run

sn.def: One who, or that which, runs; a racer.
A detective.
A messenger.
A smuggler.
One employed to solicit patronage, as for a steamboat, hotel, shop, etc.
A slender trailing branch which takes root at the joints or end and there forms new plants, as in the strawberry and the common cinquefoil.
The rotating stone of a set of millstones.
A rope rove through a block and used to increase the mechanical power of a tackle.
One of the pieces on which a sled or sleigh slides; also the part or blade of a skate which slides on the ice.

sd.def: A horizontal channel in a mold, through which the metal flows to the cavity formed by the pattern; also, the waste metal left in such a channel.
A trough or channel for leading molten metal from a furnace to a ladle, mold, or pig bed.

sn.def: The movable piece to which the ribs of an umbrella are attached.
A food fish (Elagatis pinnulatus) of Florida and the West Indies; -- called also skipjack shoemaker, and yellowtail. The name alludes to its rapid successive leaps from the water.
Any cursorial bird.

sd.def: A movable slab or rubber used in grinding or polishing a surface of stone.
A tool on which lenses are fastened in a group, for polishing or grinding.

entry.def: See Rennet.

cs.cd: a block in an arrangement of pulleys which rises or sinks with the weight which is raised or lowered.
a narrow platform extending along the side of a locomotive.
Same as Reefing bowsprit.
the consecutive days occupied on a voyage under a charter party, including Sundays and not limited to the working days.
a constant fire of musketry or cannon.
the wheels and axles of a vehicle, and their attachments, in distinction from the body; all the working parts of a locomotive or other machine, in distinction from the framework.
a style of rapid writing in which the letters are usually slanted and the words formed without lifting the pen; -- distinguished from round hand.
that part of a rope that is hauled upon, -- in distinction from the standing part.
that part of a ship's rigging or ropes which passes through blocks, etc.; -- in distinction from standing rigging.
the title of a book or chapter continued from page to page on the upper margin.

sn.def: Moving or advancing by running.

sd.def: Having a running gait; not a trotter or pacer.
trained and kept for running races; as, a running horse.

sn.def: Successive; one following the other without break or intervention; -- said of periods of time; as, to be away two days running; to sow land two years running .
Flowing; easy; cursive; as, a running hand.
Continuous; keeping along step by step; as, he stated the facts with a running explanation.
sn.q: Arunningconquest.
What are art and science if not a running commentary on Nature?

sn.def: Extending by a slender climbing or trailing stem; as, a running vine.
Discharging pus; as, a running sore.

cs.cd: in the long run.

entry.def: The act of one who, or of that which runs; as, the running was slow.

sn.def: That which runs or flows; the quantity of a liquid which flows in a certain time or during a certain operation; as, the first running of a still.
The discharge from an ulcer or other sore.

entries.entry: Run"ning load. Aëronautics The air pressure supported by each longitudinal foot segment of a wing. Commonly, the whole weight of aëroplane and load divided by the span, or length from tip to tip.

entry.def: In a running manner.
See Ronion.
Ordinary; common; unexceptional.

entry.ety: Rune + -logy
entry.def: The science of runes.
A felon or whitlow.

entry.ety: Scot. runt an old cow, an old, withered woman, a hardened stem or stalk, the trunk of a tree; cf. D. rund a bullock, an ox or cow, G. rind. Cf. Rother a.

sn.def: Any animal which is unusually small, as compared with others of its kind; -- applied particularly to domestic animals.
A variety of domestic pigeon, related to the barb and carrier.
A dwarf; also, a mean, despicable, boorish person; -- used opprobriously.
sn.q: Before I buy a bargain of such runts, I'll buy a college for bears, and live among 'em.

sn.def: The dead stump of a tree; also, the stem of a plant.
sn.q: Neither young poles nor old runts are durable.

entry.def: Like a runt; diminutive; mean.

sn.def: The channel of a stream.
The beaten path made by deer or other animals in passing to and from their feeding grounds.

entry.note: ☞ The valuation of the rupee of sixteen annas, the standard coin of India, by the United States Treasury department, varies from time to time with the price of silver. In 1889 it was rated at about thirty-two cents.
entry.ety: Hind. rūpiyah, fr. Skr. rūpya silver, coined silver or gold, handsome
entry.def: A silver coin, and money of account, in the East Indies.

entry.ety: From L. rupes a rock
entry.def: Rocky.
entry.q: Thisrupellarynidary.

entries.entry: Ru"pert's drop` Ru"pert's drop`. A kind of glass drop with a long tail, made by dropping melted glass into water. It is remarkable for bursting into fragments when the surface is scratched or the tail broken; -- so called from Prince Rupert, nephew of Charles I., by whom they were first brought to England. Called also Rupert's ball, and glass tear.

entry.ety: NL., fr. G. � filth, dirt
entry.def: An eruption upon the skin, consisting of vesicles with inflamed base and filled with serous, purulent, or bloody fluid, which dries up, forming a blackish crust.
Of or pertaining to rupia.

entry.note: ☞ The species are remarkable for having an elevated fan-shaped crest of feathers on the head, and for the beautiful color of their plumage, which is mostly some delicate shade of yellow or orange.
entry.ety: NL., fr. L. rupes, gen. rupis, a rock + colere to inhabit
entry.def: A genus of beautiful South American passerine birds, including the cock of the rock.
Rock-inhabiting.

entry.ety: L. ruptio, fr. rumpere ruptum, to break
entry.def: A breaking or bursting open; breach; rupture.
entry.q: Byruptionor apertion.

entry.ety: Cf. Roturier
entry.def: One not of noble blood; a plebeian; a roturier.
entry.q: The exclusion of the French ruptuaries“roturiers,” for history must find a word for this class when it speaks of other nations) from the order of nobility.

entry.cs: Modulus of rupture. Engin.) See under Modulus.
entry.ety: L. ruptura, fr. rumpere ruptum to break: cf. F. rupture. See Reave, and cf. Rout a defeat

sn.def: The act of breaking apart, or separating; the state of being broken asunder; as, the rupture of the skin; the rupture of a vessel or fiber; the rupture of a lutestring.
sn.q: Hatch from the egg, that soon, Bursting with kindly rupture, forth disclosed Their callow young.

sn.def: Breach of peace or concord between individuals; open hostility or war between nations; interruption of friendly relations; as, the parties came to a rupture .
sn.q: He knew that policy would disincline Napoleon from a rupture with his family.

sn.def: Hernia. See Hernia.
A bursting open, as of a steam boiler, in a less sudden manner than by explosion. See Explosion.
sn.syn: Fracture; breach; break; burst; disruption; dissolution. See Fracture.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ruptured; p. pr. & vb. n. Rupturing

sn.def: To part by violence; to break; to burst; as, to rupture a blood vessel.
To produce a hernia in.

entry.def: To suffer a breach or disruption.
Having a rupture, or hernia.
Same as Burstwort.
A West Indian plant (Alternanthera polygonoides) somewhat resembling burstwort.

entry.cs: Rural dean. Eccl See under Dean. Rural deanery Eccl the state, office, or residence, of a rural dean.
entry.usage: Rural Rustic. Rural refers to the country itself; as, rural scenes, prospects, delights, etc. Rustic refers to the character, condition, taste, etc., of the original inhabitants of the country, who were generally uncultivated and rude; as, rustic manners; a rustic dress; a rustic bridge; rustic architecture, etc.We turn To where the silver Thames first rural grows. Thomson. Lay bashfulness, that rustic virtue, by; To manly confidence thy throughts apply. Dryden.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. ruralis, fr. rus ruris, the country. Cf. Room space, Rustic

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the country, as distinguished from a city or town; living in the country; suitable for, or resembling, the country; rustic; as, rural scenes; a rural prospect.
sn.q: Here is a rural fellow; . . . He brings you figs.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to agriculture; as, rural economy.
sn.syn: Rustic.

entry.ety: NL
entry.def: The gossamer-winged butterflies; a family of small butterflies, including the hairstreaks, violets, and theclas.

sn.def: The quality or state of being rural; ruralness.
A rural idiom or expression.

entry.def: One who leads a rural life.

entries.entry:
Ru*ral"i*ty n.; pl. -ties #. Cf. LL. ruralitas
The quality or state of being rural.
A rural place. Leafyruralities.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ruralized; p. pr. & vb. n. Ruralizing
entry.def: To render rural; to give a rural appearance to.
To become rural; to go into the country; to rusticate.
In a rural manner; as in the country.
The quality or state of being rural.

entry.ety: L. ruricola; rus ruris, the country + colere to inhabit
entry.def: An inhabitant of the country.

entry.ety: L. rus ruris the country + decanus the chief of ten. See Dean
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a rural dean; as, a ruridecanal district; the ruridecanal intellect.

entry.ety: L. rurigena; rus ruris, the country + genere gignere, to bring forth, pass., to be born
entry.def: Born in the country.

cs.cd: a stratagem of war.

entry.ety: F., fr. OF. reüser rehuser, to turn aside, to shuffle, retreat, fr. L. recusare to refuse; pref. re- again + causa cause. See Cause, and cf. Recusant
entry.def: An artifice; trick; stratagem; wile; fraud; deceit.

entry.note: ☞ Some species are used in bottoming chairs and plaiting mats, and the pith is used in some places for wicks to lamps and rushlights.
entry.cs: Bog rush. See under Bog. Club rush any rush of the genus Scirpus. Flowering rush. See under Flowering. Nut rush Any plant of the genus Scleria, rushlike plants with hard nutlike fruits. A name for several species of Cyperus having tuberous roots. Rush broom an Australian leguminous plant (Viminaria denudata), having long, slender branches. Also, the Spanish broom. See under Spanish. Rush candle See under Candle. Rush grass any grass of the genus Vilfa, grasses with wiry stems and one-flowered spikelets. Rush toad Zoöl the natterjack. Scouring rush. Bot Same as Dutch rush, under Dutch. Spike rush, any rushlike plant of the genus Eleocharis, in which the flowers grow in dense spikes. Sweet rush a sweet-scented grass of Arabia, etc. (Andropogon schœnanthus), used in Oriental medical practice. Wood rush any plant of the genus Luzula, which differs in some technical characters from Juncus.
entry.ety: OE. rusche rische resche, AS. risce, akin to LG. rusk risch, D. & G. rusch; all probably fr. L. ruscum butcher's broom; akin to Goth. raus reed, G. rohr

sn.def: A name given to many aquatic or marsh-growing endogenous plants with soft, slender stems, as the species of Juncus and Scirpus.
The merest trifle; a straw.
sn.q: John Bull's friendship is not worth a rush.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rushed rŭsht; p. pr. & vb. n. Rushing
entry.ety: OE. ruschen; cf. AS. hryscan to make a noise, D. ruischen to rustle, G. rauschen, MHG. rūschen to rush, to rustle, LG. rusken, OSw. ruska, Icel. & Sw. ruska to shake, Dan. ruske to shake, and E. rouse

sn.def: To move forward with impetuosity, violence, and tumultuous rapidity or haste; as, armies rush to battle; waters rush down a precipice.
sn.q: Like to an entered tide, they all rush by.

sn.def: To enter into something with undue haste and eagerness, or without due deliberation and preparation; as, to rush business or speculation.
sn.q: They . . . never think it to be a part of religion to rush into the office of princes and ministers.

sn.def: To push or urge forward with impetuosity or violence; to hurry forward.
To recite (a lesson) or pass (an examination) without an error.

cs.cd: a combined rush by main strength.
the line composed of rushers.

sn.def: A moving forward with rapidity and force or eagerness; a violent motion or course; as, a rush of troops; a rush of winds; a rush of water.
sn.q: A gentleman of his train spurred up his horse, and, with a violent rush, severed him from the duke.

sn.def: Great activity with pressure; as, a rush of business.
A perfect recitation.

sd.def: A rusher; as, the center rush, whose place is in the center of the rush line; the end rush .
The act of running with the ball.

entry.def: A kind of rural festival at the dedication of a church, when the parishioners brought rushes to strew the church.
A bullying and violent person; a braggart; a swashbuckler.
entry.q: That flock of stout, bragging rushbucklers.

entry.def: Abounding or covered with rushes.
One who rushes.
One who strewed rushes on the floor at dances.

entry.ety: From Rushy
entry.def: The quality or state of abounding with rushes.
In a rushing manner.
A rush candle, or its light; hence, a small, feeble light.
Resembling a rush; weak.

sn.def: Abounding with rushes.
Made of rushes.
sn.q: My rushy couch and frugal fare.

cs.cd: an antler with the brow tyne simple, and the beam forked at the tip.

entry.ety: NL. rusa, the name of the genus, Malay rūsa deer
entry.def: Of, like, or pertaining to, a deer of the genus Rusa, which includes the sambur deer (Rusa Aristotelis) of India.

entry.ety: Sp. rosca de mar sea rusks, a kind of biscuit, rosca properly meaning, a screw, spiral

sn.def: A kind of light, soft bread made with yeast and eggs, often toasted or crisped in an oven; or, a kind of sweetened biscuit.
A kind of light, hard cake or bread, as for stores.
Bread or cake which has been made brown and crisp, and afterwards grated, or pulverized in a mortar.

entry.ety: Corrupt. from Turk. khyryzma a paste used as a depilatory, fr. Gr. � an unguent; cf. F. rusma
entry.def: A depilatory made of orpiment and quicklime, and used by the Turks. See Rhusma.

sn.def: A Russian, or the Russians.
The language of the Russians.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the Russians.

entry.ety: F. rousset, dim. of roux red, L. russusfor rudtus rudhtus), akin to E. red. See Red, and cf. Roussette

sn.def: Of a reddish brown color, or (by some called) a red gray; of the color composed of blue, red, and yellow in equal strength, but unequal proportions, namely, two parts of red to one each of blue and yellow; also, of a yellowish brown color.
sn.q: The morn, in russet mantle clad.
Our summer such a russet livery wears.

sn.def: Coarse; homespun; rustic.
A russet color; a pigment of a russet color.
Cloth or clothing of a russet color.
A country dress; -- so called because often of a russet color.
An apple, or a pear, of a russet color; as, the English russet, and the Roxbury russet .

entry.def: See Russet n., 2 and 4.
Of a russet color; russet.

cs.cd: a kind of sheet iron made in Russia, having a lustrous blue-black surface.

a soft kind of leather, made originally in Russia but now elsewhere, having a peculiar odor from being impregnated with an oil obtained from birch bark. It is much used in bookbinding, on account of its not being subject to mold, and being proof against insects.
matting manufactured in Russia from the inner bark of the linden (Tilia Europæa).

entry.def: A country of Europe and Asia.

entry.cs: Russian bath. See under Bath.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Russia, its inhabitants, or language.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Russia; the language of Russia.

entries.entry: Rus"sian Church Rus"sian Or"tho*dox Church . The established church of the Russian empire up to the revolution of 1917, at which time the ruling Communist party tried to suppress all religious worship. The czar was the nominal head of the church, but he never claimed the right of deciding questions of theology and dogma. It still forms a portion, by far the largest, of the Orthodox (Eastern) Church and is governed by the Patriarch and the Holy Synod. In 1988 the church, with official approval, celebrated the 1000 year anniversary of the baptism of Russia. After breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991 the Russian Church began to regain some its old influence in Russian life, and the government turned over some of the confiscated churches back to church control. The Russian Church was recognized anew as the official church of Russia, with special priveleges, by an act of the Russian Duma in 1997. The Metropolitan of Moscow, as Patriarch of the church, is regarded as the first among equals in order of deference among bishops of the church.

entry.def: To make Russian, or more or less like the Russians; as, to Russianize the Poles.

An act of bravado played by loading one bullet into one chamber of a revolver in which the cylinder has five or six positions, spinning the cylinder (thus moving the bullet randomly to one of the six positions of the cylinder), pointing the gun to one's head, and pulling the trigger. If the bullet is in firing position, the "player" is usually killed. Such a "game" may be played on a dare, or, in some places, as part of a gamble.
Any dangerous act resembling Russian roulette in the acceptance of a high risk of serious negative consequences, usually unnecessarily.
entry.q: The congress is playingRussian roulettewith the economy by enacting such large tax reductions without spending cuts.

entry.ety: Russia + L. -ficarein comp.) to make. See -fy
entry.def: The act or process of Russifying, or the state of being Russified.

entry.ety: Cf. F. russifier. See -fy
entry.def: To Russianize; as, to Russify conquered tribes.

entry.ety: Russia + Gr. filei^n to love: cf. F. russophile
entry.def: One who, not being a Russian, favors Russian policy and aggrandizement.

entry.ety: Russia + Gr. fobei^n to fear
entry.def: One who dreads Russia or Russian influence.
entry.mark: Words sometimes found in the newspapers

entry.def: Morbid dread of Russia or of Russian influence.

entry.note: ☞ Rust is also applied to many other minute fungi which infest vegetation, such as the species of Ustilago Uredo, and Lecythea.
☞ Rust is used in the formation of compounds of obvious meaning; as, rust-colored, rust-consumed, rust-eaten, and the like.

cs.cd: a joint made between surfaces of iron by filling the space between them with a wet mixture of cast-iron borings, sal ammoniac, and sulphur, which by oxidation becomes hard, and impervious to steam, water, etc.
a minute mite (Phytopius oleivorus) which, by puncturing the rind, causes the rust-colored patches on oranges.

entry.ety: AS. rust; akin to D. roest, G. & Sw. rost, Icel. ryð; -- named from its color, and akin to E. red. √113. See Red

sn.def: The reddish yellow coating formed on iron when exposed to moist air, consisting of ferric oxide or hydroxide; hence, by extension, any metallic film of corrosion.

A minute mold or fungus forming reddish or rusty spots on the leaves and stems of cereal and other grasses (Trichobasis Rubigo-vera), now usually believed to be a form or condition of the corn mildew (Puccinia graminis). As rust, it has solitary reddish spores; as corn mildew, the spores are double and blackish.

entry.sn:
That which resembles rust in appearance or effects. Specifically:aA composition used in making a rust joint. See Rust joint, below.
Foul matter arising from degeneration; as, rust on salted meat.
Corrosive or injurious accretion or influence. Sacred truths cleared from all rust and dross of human mixtures.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rusted; p. pr. & vb. n. Rusting
entry.ety: AS. rustian

sn.def: To contract rust; to be or become oxidized.
sn.q: If gold ruste, what shall iron do?
Our armors now may rust.

sn.def: To be affected with the parasitic fungus called rust; also, to acquire a rusty appearance, as plants.
To degenerate in idleness; to become dull or impaired by inaction.
sn.q: Must I rust in Egypt? never more Appear in arms, and be the chief of Greece?

sn.def: To cause to contract rust; to corrode with rust; to affect with rust of any kind.
sn.q: Keep up your bright swords, for the dew will rust them.

sn.def: To impair by time and inactivity.

entry.def: Full of rust; resembling rust; causing rust; rusty.
entry.q: Rustfulsloth.

entry.cs: Rustic moth Zoöl any moth belonging to Agrotis and allied genera. Their larvæ are called cutworms. See Cutworm. Rustic work. Arch Cut stone facing which has the joints worked with grooves or channels, the face of each block projecting beyond the joint, so that the joints are very conspicuous. Arch. & Woodwork Summer houses, or furniture for summer houses, etc., made of rough limbs of trees fancifully arranged.
entry.ety: L. rusticus, fr. rus ruris, the country: cf. F. rustique. See Rural

sn.def: Of or pertaining to the country; rural; as, the rustic gods of antiquity.
sn.q: Rusticlays.
And many a holy text around she strews, That teach the rustic moralist to die.
She had a rustic, woodland air.

sn.def: Rude; awkward; rough; unpolished; as, rustic manners.
sn.q: Arusticmuse.

sn.def: Coarse; plain; simple; as, a rustic entertainment; rustic dress.
Simple; artless; unadorned; unaffected.
sn.syn: Rural; rude; unpolished; inelegant; untaught; awkward; rough; coarse; plain; unadorned; simple; artless; honest. See Rural.

sn.def: An inhabitant of the country, especially one who is rude, coarse, or dull; a clown.
sn.q: Hence to your fields, you rustics! hence, away.

sn.def: A rural person having a natural simplicity of character or manners; an artless, unaffected person.

entry.def: Rustic.
entry.q: Rusticalsociety.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rusticated; p. pr. & vb. n. Rusticating
entry.ety: L. rusticaticus, p. p. of rusticari to rusticate. See Rustic
entry.def: To go into or reside in the country; to ruralize.
To require or compel to reside in the country; to banish or send away temporarily; to impose rustication on.
entry.q: The town is again beginning to be full, and the rusticated beauty sees an end of her banishment.

entry.def: Resembling rustic work. See Rustic work, under Rustic.

entry.ety: L. rusticatio

sn.def: The act of rusticating, or the state of being rusticated; specifically, the punishment of a student for some offense, by compelling him to leave the institution for a time.
Rustic work.

entry.ety: L. rusticitas: cf. F. rusticité
entry.def: The quality or state of being rustic; rustic manners; rudeness; simplicity; artlessness.
entry.q: The sweetness and rusticity of a pastoral can not be so well expressed in any other tongue as in the Greek, when rightly mixed and qualified with the Doric dialect.
The Saxons were refined from their rusticity.

entry.def: In a rustic manner; rustically.
In a rusty state.
The quality or state of being rusty.

cs.cd: To gather or find by searching; as, to rustle up some food for supper.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rustled; p. pr. & vb. n. Rustling
entry.ety: AS. hristlan to rustle; or cf. Sw. rusta to stir, make a riot, or E. rush, v

sn.def: To make a quick succession of small sounds, like the rubbing or moving of silk cloth or dry leaves.
sn.q: He is coming; I hear his straw rustle.
Prouder than rustling in unpaid-for silk.

sn.def: To stir about energetically; to strive to succeed; to bustle about.
To steal; -- used of livestock and esp. of cattle.

entry.def: To cause to rustle; as, the wind rustles the leaves.
A quick succession or confusion of small sounds, like those made by shaking leaves or straw, by rubbing silk, or the like; a rustling.
entry.q: When the noise of a torrent, the rustle of a wood, the song of birds, or the play of lambs, had power to fill the attention, and suspend all perception of the course of time.

sn.def: One who, or that which, rustles.
A bovine animal that can care for itself in any circumstances; also, an alert, energetic, driving person.

entry.def: Free from rust.

entry.ety: AS. rustig

sn.def: Covered or affected with rust; as, a rusty knife or sword; rusty wheat.
Impaired by inaction, disuse, or neglect.
sn.q: Hector,] in this dull and long-continued truce, Is rusty grown.

sn.def: Discolored and rancid; reasty; as, rusty bacon.
Surly; morose; crusty; sullen.
sn.q: Rustywords.

sn.def: Rust-colored; dark.
sn.q: Rustyblood.

sn.def: Discolored; stained; not cleanly kept; filthy.
sn.q: The rusty little schooners that bring firewood from the British provinces.

sn.def: Resembling, or covered with a substance resembling, rust; affected with rust; rubiginous.

entry.ety: F. rut, OF. ruit, L. rugitus a roaring, fr. rugire to roar; -- so called from the noise made by deer in rutting time.]

sn.def: Sexual desire or œstrus of deer, cattle, and various other mammals; heat; also, the period during which the œstrus exists.
Roaring, as of waves breaking upon the shore; rote. See Rote.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Rutted; p. pr. & vb. n. Rutting
entry.def: To have a strong sexual impulse at the reproductive period; -- said of deer, cattle, etc.
To cover in copulation.

entry.ety: variant of route
entry.def: A track worn by a wheel or by habitual passage of anything; a groove in which anything runs. Also used figuratively.
To make a rut or ruts in; -- chiefly used as a past participle or a participial adj.; as, a rutted road.
A kind of turnip commonly with a large and long or ovoid yellowish root; a Swedish turnip. See Turnip.

entry.ety: L. rutaceous, from ruta rue. See Rue the plant
entry.def: Of or pertaining to plants of a natural order (Rutaceæ) of which the rue is the type, and which includes also the orange, lemon, dittany, and buchu.
A salt of rutic acid.

entry.ety: From Rue v.: cf. Icel. hryggð hrygð

sn.def: Sorrow for the misery of another; pity; tenderness.
sn.q: They weep forruth.
Haveruthof the poor.
To stir up gentle ruth, Both for her noble blood, and for her tender youth.

sn.def: That which causes pity or compassion; misery; distress; a pitiful sight.
sn.q: It had been hard this ruth for to see.
With wretched miseries and woeful ruth.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or containing, ruthenium; specifically, designating those compounds in which it has a higher valence as contrasted with ruthenious compounds.
Pertaining to, or containing, ruthenium; specifically, designating those compounds in which it has a lower valence as contrasted with ruthenic compounds.

entry.ety: NL. So named from the Ruthenians, a Little Russian people, as coming from Russia, the metal having been found in the Ural mountains
entry.def: A rare element of the light platinum group, found associated with platinum ores, and isolated as a hard, brittle steel-gray metal which is very infusible. Symbol Ru. Atomic weight 103.5. Specific gravity 12.26. See Platinum metals, under Platinum.

entries.entry:
Ruth"ful
Ruth"ful*ly adv.
a. Full of ruth; as: Pitiful; tender. Full of sorrow; woeful. Causing sorrow.

entry.def: Having no ruth; cruel; pitiless.
entry.q: Their rage the hostile bands restrain, All but the ruthless monarch of the main.

entry.ety: Cf. Rutaceous
entry.def: Pertaining to, or obtained from, rue (Ruta); as, rutic acid, now commonly called capric acid .

entry.ety: L. rutilans, p. pr. of rutilare to have a reddish glow, fr. rutilus red: cf. F. rutilant
entry.def: Having a reddish glow; shining.
entry.q: Parchments . . . colored with this rutilant mixture.

entry.ety: L. rutilare rutilatum
entry.def: To shine; to emit rays of light.

entry.ety: L. rutilus red, inclining to golden yellow
entry.def: A mineral usually of a reddish brown color, and brilliant metallic adamantine luster, occurring in tetragonal crystals. In composition it is titanium dioxide, like octahedrite and brookite.
Any species of lamellicorn beetles belonging to Rutila and allied genera, as the spotted grapevine beetle (Pelidnota punctata).

A glucoside resembling, but distinct from, quercitrin. Rutin is found in the leaves of the rue (Ruta graveolens) and other plants, and obtained as a bitter yellow crystalline substance which yields quercitin on decomposition.

entry.note: It is prepared from rutin by hydrolysis with rhamnodiastase. 6-O-α-L-rhamnosyl-D-glucose; C12H22O10.
entry.def: A disaccharide present in glycosides.

entry.ety: D. ruiter a rider. Cf. Ruttier
entry.def: A horseman or trooper.
entry.q: Such a regiment of rutters Never defied men braver.

entry.ety: From Rut
entry.def: That which ruts.
An old crafty fox or beguiler -- a word of contempt.

entry.ety: F. routier, fr. route a road. See Route
entry.def: A chart of a course, esp. at sea.
Inclined to rut; lustful; libidinous; salacious.
A rattling sound in the throat arising from difficulty of breathing; a rattle.
Ruttish; rutting; lustful.
Full of ruts; rutted; as, a rutty road.

entry.ety: See Root
entry.def: Rooty.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H18, of the acetylene series. It is produced artificially.
Royal.
See Rial, an old English coin.

sn.def: A clause added to a document; a rider. See Rider.
A gold coin of Zealand [Netherlands] equal to 14 florins, about $5.60 (ca. 1910).

cs.cd: See under Grass. See also Ray grass, and Darnel.
any plant of the genus Elymus, tall grasses with much the appearance of rye.

entry.ety: OE. rie reie, AS. ryge; akin to Icel. rugr, Sw. råg, Dan. rug, D. rogge, OHG. rocco roggo, G. rocken roggen, Lith. rugei, Russ. roje, and perh. to Gr. 'o`ryza rice. Cf. Rice

sn.def: A grain yielded by a hardy cereal grass (Secale cereale), closely allied to wheat; also, the plant itself. Rye constitutes a large portion of the breadstuff used by man.
A disease in a hawk.

entry.ety: Etymol. uncertain
entry.def: A piece of iron crossing the hole in the upper millstone by which the stone is supported on the spindle.

entry.ety: Ar. & Hind. ra'iyat, the same word as ra'iyah, a subject, tenant, peasant. See Rayah
entry.def: A peasant or cultivator of the soil.
entry.q: The Indian ryot and the Egyptian fellah work for less pay than any other laborers in the world.

entry.ety: Gr. "ry`pos filth + fagei^n to eat
entry.def: Eating, or subsisting on, filth.
A branch.
Rush, a plant.
See Rhysimeter.

entry.ety: Cf. AS. rið brook
entry.def: A ford.

entry.note: ☞ It is now extinct, but was formerly abundant at Bering's Island, near Bering's Straits. It was twenty-five feet or more in length, with a thick, blackish, naked skin. The last were killed in 1768 for their oil and flesh.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "ryti`s a wrinkle
entry.def: A genus of large edentulous sirenians, allied to the dugong and manatee, including but one species (Rytina Stelleri); -- called also Steller's sea cow stellerine and steller.
